question_text: Which of the following timelines would be included in the perinatal period as per WHO?
options: 37th week of gestation to 28 days after birth
20th week of gestation to 7 days after birth
28th week of gestation to 28 days after birth
22nd week of gestation to 7 days after birth
explanation: The WHO states that the perinatal period commences at 22 completed weeks and ends at seven completed days after birth - 154 days. It corresponds to when the fetus weighs 500g or more. This definition is not to be confused with the period used for the calculation of the perinata mortality rate (PMR). To calculate the PMR, a fetal weight above 1000 g is considered, which is achieved at 28 weeks of gestation. Therefore, for all statistical purposes, internationa comparisons, and calculation of perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is considered. Perinatal period: from the 22nd week. Perinatal mortality rate calculation: from the 28th week. The neonatal period is defined as the first 28 days after birth. Infancy is defined as the first year of life. The image below shows various time periods. Only the time period for perinatal mortality and the perinatal period are different as shown in the image. For others, corresponding mortality rates are calculated using the same time periods shown.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You would classify a baby as post-term if it is born after
explanation: Post-term infants are those born after 42 completed weeks of gestation, as calculated from the mother’s last menstrual period, regardless of weight at birth.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You would classify a baby as a very low birth weight baby if the weight of the baby is found to be less than kg.
explanation: A very low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1.5 Kg. They are often premature (<37 weeks of gestation). A low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <2.5 Kg. An extremely low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1 kg.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Reena, a 34-year-old lady with gestation diabetes mellitus delivers an LGA baby at 37 weeks. What would the birth weight of this child be?
explanation: Infants with birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for their gestational age are called large for gestational age (LGA) babies. Maternal diabetes and obesity are predisposing factors for LGA babies. They have a higher incidence of: Birth injuries: Brachial plexus injury Phrenic nerve injury Cephalohematomas Hypoglycemia Polycythemia Congenital heart disease
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As the intern assisting in the labor room, you are tasked with administering Vitamin K to the term newborns with no complications. Which of the following dose and route would you use for administration?
explanation: All newborn infants are to be administered vitamin K at a dose of 0.5–1 mg intramuscularly, to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN). However, for newborns with vitamin K deficiency, the dose of vitamin K administered is 1–5 mg intravenously.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A term neonate born by normal vaginal delivery is diagnosed with hypothermia. Which of the following is not a physiological response for heat regulation in this baby?
options: Breakdown of brown fat with noradrenaline secretion
explanation: Neonates do not generate heat by shivering. Heat production in neonates happens by increasing the metabolic rate and oxygen consumption by releasing norepinephrine, which results in non-shivering thermogenesis through beta-oxidation of brown fat. This sympathetic surge also causes cutaneous vasoconstriction. Increased physical activity - crying, increased body movements, and muscular activity also contribute to thermogenesis. Preterm and small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants have scanty brown fat stores.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are conducting the routine newborn assessment of a 2.3 kg baby born 10 minutes back. You would classify the neonate as having cold stress if you notice the body temperature to be:
explanation: A temperature of 36.0 to 36.4°C categorizes a neonate as having cold stress. An infant’s normal body temperature is 36.5 to 37.5 °C. It is measured in the apex of the baby's axilla by holding the thermometer for at least 3 minutes. Hypothermia is an axillary temperature of <36.5 °C. Cold stress: 36.0 to 36.4 °C Moderate hypothermia: 32 to 35.9 °C Severe hypothermia: <32 °C Hyperthermia is an axillary temperature of >37.5 °C.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below. Which of the following statements about this method is false?
options: Safety and thermal protection is equivalent to incubators
Reduces severe morbidity in the newborns
Should be performed only by the mother
explanation: Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver. KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components— Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest. Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding. Early discharge and ambulatory care. Support for mother and family for child care. Evidence shows that- It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality) Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding Humanization of neonatal care Promoted bonding between mother and child E igibility criteria for KMC: It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby. Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC. Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea. The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day. KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation. Note: Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are the intern posted in the labor room and are tasked with calculating the gestational maturity of the infants delivered. As per the expanded New Ballard scoring, what will be the lowest and highest scores you can obtain?
explanation: The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age. An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age. question_text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
explanation: Scarf sign is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score. Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below), In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline. In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline. question_text: A 1.8 Kg neonate is born to a 24-year-old primigravida with no antenatal checkups. While calculating the physical maturity of the neonate by the new Ballard scoring, which of the following criteria would you not take into account?
explanation: Palmar surface is not a component of the physical criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score. Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score): Skin Lanugo Eye/ear Plantar crease (Not palmar surface) Breast Genitals
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: While examining a healthy term neonate, you notice that the baby passes greenish-black colored stools. This color is due to -
explanation: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin. Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the oxidation of bilirubin). Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next few weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system. Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools. Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: When does the parachute reflex disappear?
options: At birth and reappears at 9 months
explanation: The parachute reflex has its onset at 7–8 months of age. It is fully developed by 10-11 months of age and remains throughout life. It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall. This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-day old infant is being examined. While checking the reflexes, a brisk Moro's reflex is noted. Which of the following conditions is a likely cause for this?
explanation: A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia. In hypoglycemic babies, there is an activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex. The Moro reflex is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It is elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fa backward onto the examiner’s hand. An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities is shown below The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants. Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS Stage III HIE Kernicterus Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease Fractured clavicle Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy) Hemiparesis Brisk Moro reflex: Neonatal hypoglycemia Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants Stage I HIE Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following: Hydranencephaly Severe micrencephaly Moro reflex in different stages of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE): Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete Stage III HIE (severe): Absent Option A: In kernicterus, there is a deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem. Hence, the Moro reflex is absent Option C: In stage III HIE, the muscles are flaccid and the infant is comatose. Thus, the Moro reflex is absent. Option D: Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, the reflex is absent on the side of injury as the nerve supplying the muscles involved (efferent of the reflex) is affected.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On turning the baby's head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does this reflex normally disappear?
explanation: Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally. The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm). An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A first-time mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature. On microscopic examination, these papular lesions on an erythematous base will reveal
explanation: The given clinical complex describes a case of erythema neonatorum. Wright stained smear of the contents of the pustule will show an abundance of eosinophils. They are papular lesions on an erythematous base, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. They are seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for up to a week, after which they resolve spontaneously. Neutrophils are seen in pustular melanosis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 5-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. A lesion that was present since birth is noticed as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Dermal melanocytosis
explanation: The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis. Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms. These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size. Disorders of Newborn
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A male infant born at 34 weeks of gestation by emergency LSCS was found to have the following finding on histopathological examination of his umbilical cord. Anomalies of which of the following systems are most likely to be found in this infant?
explanation: The image shows the presence of a single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased risk for an occult renal anomaly. The histopathological image of the cross-section of the umbilical cord shows 2 vessels as marked, a thin-walled umbilical vein and a thicker-walled umbilical artery. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Trisomy 18 is a common association.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: On a particularly busy day in the labor room, you are requested by the PG to take anthropometric measurements and calculate the ponderal index of a baby while she attends to another baby. You find the ponderal index to be 1.45. Which of the following organs is unlikely to be affected in this neonate?
explanation: A ponderal index of <2 suggests asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction. Asymmetric IUGR is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, where there is no sparing of head growth. Ponderal index = Birth weight (gm)/Length (cm)3 x 100. It is a weight-height-related parameter used as an indicator of fetal growth status. SymmetricIUGR Asymmetric IUGR Insult on fetal growth occurs early Insult occurs inlate gestation Head circumference, length, and weight areequallyaffecte d Relativesparingofbrain growt h A ponderal indexgreater than or equal to2 A ponderal indexless than 2 Caused by genetic, chromoso mal disorders, or TORCH inf ections Caused by placental insufficie ncy, pregnancy-induced hype rtension, or maternal medica l diseases
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The ponderal index of a term baby delivered by elective cesarean section is 1.75. Which of the following is unlikely to be associated?
explanation: A ponderal index of 1.75 suggests intrauterine growth restriction. Gestational diabetes usually presents with fetal macrosomia. Maternal factors associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR): Hypertension/renal disease Diabetes with placental vasculopathy Hypoxemia Malnutrition Chronic illness Sickle cell anemia Drugs (narcotics, alcohol, cigarettes, cocaine) Maternal infection and parasite infestations
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5kg male baby by normal delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against a diagnosis of prematurity?
explanation: Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity). No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn. Note: Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back. Scor e Ear 0 Pinna flat and stays folded; n o recoil 1 Slightly curved pinna; soft; sl ow recoil 2 Well-curved pinna; soft but r eady recoil 3 Formed & firm, instant recoil 4 Thick cartilage, ear stiff
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A lady with wrong dates and a corrected gestational age of 43 weeks presents with labor pains. The CTG suggests placental insufficiency, and she is taken up for emergency LSCS. Which of the following physical signs is unlikely to be seen in this neonate?
explanation: The physical sign of an infant born post-term (43 weeks) in association with presumed placental insufficiency is abundant hair (not scanty hair). Infants born post-term in association with presumed placental insufficiency may have various physical signs, together termed as postmaturity syndrome (or dysmaturity syndrome). These include: Desquamation, pale skin, and long nails. Loose skin around the thighs and buttocks. Meconium-stained nails, skin, vernix, and umbilical cord. Presence of placental membranes.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 34-year-old lady with an obstetric score of G3P2L2 delivers a baby boy at 43 weeks + 2 days period of gestation. Which of the following are unlikely to be associated in the given scenario?
explanation: Anemia is not a complication of post-maturity. Polycythemia may be seen in neonates born after 42 weeks of gestation. Complications of post-maturity include: Perinatal depression Meconium aspiration Persistent pulmonary hypertension Hypoglycemia Hypocalcemia Polycythemia
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Immediately following vaginal delivery, a baby is noted to have a diffuse ecchymotic swelling on the scalp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is caput succedaneum. Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines. Option A: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp. Option C: Subgaleal hemorrhages occur with the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the dural sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. Blood accumulates between the epicranial aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum and resolves over 2-3 weeks. Often associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. Option D: Epidural hemorrhages, usually traumatic in origin, are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or occur as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of marking B?
options: Swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp
Appears only several hours after birth
explanation: The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp. Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp. Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs). Other markings- A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first week of life. C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures. D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A baby in the postnatal ward is noted to have paralysis of the left hand along with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis. What is the most likely cause?
options: Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome
explanation: Left-hand paralysis with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis in a newborn suggests a diagnosis of Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome. There is an injury to the 7th-8th cervical nerves and the 1st thoracic nerve. This produces a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected, and the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1 thoracic root are also injured. Option A: Erb–Duchenne paralysis affects the 5th and 6th cervical nerves. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. Moro's reflex is absent on the affected side. Option B: Phrenic nerve palsy (3, 4, and 5 cervical nerves) results in diaphragmatic paralysis. It is characterized by cyanosis and irregular and labored breathing. Option C: Horner's syndrome is characterized by miosis, ptosis, enophthalmos, anhydrosis, and loss of ciliospinal reflex.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Following a delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia, the baby is noted to have a deformity in the right upper limb. On inspection, the orthopedics JR notes an adducted, internally rotated arm and a pronated forearm. Which nerve roots are affected here?
explanation: The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Erb–Duchenne paralysis. The injury is limited to the 5th and 6th cervical nerve roots. The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. There is an asymmetric Moro's Reflex Note: In shoulder dystocia, the most common nerve injury is to the C5-6 nerve root. The most common bone to fracture is the clavicle.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A term infant develops jaundice at day 2 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk by day 4. It completely disappeared by day 7 following phototherapy. Which of the following statements is false regarding the cause of this pattern of jaundice?
options: Due to a rise in unconjugated bilirubin
Due to limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver
Due to Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells
Due to increased breakdown of fetal red blood cells
explanation: The above pattern of jaundice is suggestive of physiological jaundice/icterus neonatorum. It is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks on the 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth. Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells leads to pathological jaundice. Note: Depth of jaundice (degree of yellowness) should be carefully noted (light staining as lemon-yellow; deep staining as orange-yellow), as it is an important indicator of the level of jaundice. Earlier, the involvement of soles and palms indicated severe jaundice but deep yellow staining (even in absence of yellow soles or palms) may be associated with severe jaundice.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A male infant with a birth weight of 3.2 Kg is admitted to the phototherapy unit with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dl at 36 hours of life. Which of the following statements does not describe pathological jaundice?
options: Jaundice appears within first 24 hours after birth
Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks
Jaundice associated with rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dl/24 hour
Jaundice seen in the mid-abdomen and soles
explanation: Jaundice associated with a rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dL/24 hours suggests physiological jaundice. Features suggestive of pathological jaundice: Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infan Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in he mid-abdominal region ( 15 mg/dL) and soles ( 20 mg/dL) Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The peripheral smear of a newborn baby girl sent on day 2 of life shows mild hemolysis. What is the most common cause of this finding in a newborn?
explanation: ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease of newborns and affects the firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical. This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh incompatibility does. It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of different blood type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs. Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunization (natural antibodies), they are usually IgM, which do not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A antigen may be present, and these do cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic disease in the first-born infant (A-O is more common than B-O).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3.3 Kg term neonate is admitted on day 3 of life with yellowish discoloration of the skin and is going to undergo phototherapy. What is the most effective wavelength of light used for treatment?
explanation: The most effective range of wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia is 460–490 nm (blue-green light). Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms: Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state. Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation. Photo-oxidation: minor method
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother noticed yellowish discoloration of her term newborn within the first 6 hours of life. On examination, jaundice extended up to the lower abdomen and thighs. Which of the following drugs can be administered along with phototherapy?
explanation: Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for pathological jaundice in neonates. It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy. Tolazoline is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that produces systemic and pulmonary vasodilatation, which is used to correct pulmonary artery vasospasm when it causes severe right-left shunting soon after birth. Tromethamine is an organic buffer used in the management of metabolic acidosis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
While on rounds in the postnatal ward, the senior PG shows you a baby with dark,
grayish-brown skin discoloration. It is a term, AGA baby on day 7 of life. She tells you that it is a case of bronze baby syndrome. This syndrome is caused by:
explanation: The bronze baby syndrome is a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration in infants undergoing phototherapy; it mainly occurs in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia as an adverse effect of phototherapy. Despite the bronze baby syndrome, phototherapy can continue if needed. Other complications of Phototherapy: Loose stools Erythematous macular rash The purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia Overheating Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea) Hypothermia from exposure Gray baby syndrome is an adverse effect of chloramphenicol. Redman syndrome is an adverse effect of vancomycin.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3.2 Kg term neonate born to a primigravida with gestational diabetes presented to the OPD with complaints of lethargy, hypotonia, and difficulty in feeding. Periodic monitoring of blood glucose is being done. What blood glucose levels indicate a need for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia?
explanation: The cut-off for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia to start IV glucose is a blood glucose level of <40 mg/dL. Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when the blood glucose is <45 mg/dL. Clinically in neonates, hypoglycemia can be asymptomatic or symptomatic. The neonate presents with tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, tachypnea, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia, and rarely cardiac arrest. Management in symptomatic neonates: Blood glucose <40mg/dL: IV glucose infusion Blood glucose <25mg/dL: Bolus IV dextrose 1-2 mL/kg followed by infusion at the rate of 5-8mL/kg/min. Management in asymptomatic neonates: Breastfeeding within 30 minutes Start IV glucose therapy if blood glucose <35 mg/dL Recheck blood glucose before the next feeding Continue skin-to-skin care Evaluation for other underlying illnesses The desired target glucose value is >50mg/dL and blood glucose should be rechecked until three normal values.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do?
explanation: In an infant of a diabetic mother with normal blood glucose levels, the next investigation to consider is serum calcium due to the high risk of developing hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia in these infants is attributed to the delayed response of the parathyroid hormone system. Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium concentration of less than 8 mg/dL for a term baby (ionized calcium below 4mg/dL) and less than 7 mg/dL for a preterm baby. Asymptomatic neonates can be managed conservatively with early nutrition. Symptomatic neonates should receive iv or oral calcium replacement. Maternal hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperglycemia, and the fetal pancreatic response leads to fetal hyperinsulinemia, which causes neonatal hypoglycemia. Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose <40 mg/dL (plasma glucose <45 mg/dL). The infant tends to be jittery, tremulous, hyperexcitable, hypotonic, lethargic, and poor sucking during the 1st three days after birth. These symptoms can also be related to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia which occur in the 1st 24 to 72 hours of life. Respiratory distress syndrome, macrosomia, hyperbilirubinemia, polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis, visceromegaly, heart failure, and persistent pulmonary hypertension are other features seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Congenital anomalies are seen in infants of mothers with pregestational diabetes. Neural tube defects (Encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels (TGA), ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. Caudal regression syndrome is rare, but a specific anomaly seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady?
1, 2, 3
explanation: Infants born to diabetic mothers may present with macrosomia (large for gestational age), hypocalcemia, and/ or neural tube defects. Other common features include: Hypoglycemia Respiratory distress syndrome Cardiomegaly Heart failure Lumbosacral agenesis Cardiac malformations Ventricular or atrial septal defec Transposition of the great vessels (most specific) Truncus arteriosus Double-outlet right ventricle Tricuspid atresia Coarctation of the aorta Additional anomalies include neural tube defects, hydronephrosis, renal agenesis and dysplasia, duodenal or anorectal atresia, situs inversus, double ureter, and holoprosencephaly. Diseases in Neonates requiring Special Care
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A preterm neonate delivered one hour back in a PHC is rushed to the district hospital. There is an evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region. The defects seen in the ventral body wall include: Gastroschisis- The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid. Omphalocele- The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion. Congenital umbilical hernia- This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines. Ectopia Vesicae/ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the lower abdominal wall does not form properly and the bladder is open and exposed.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: While performing the head-to-toe examination in a term 2.6kg neonate, a large, wide anterior fontanelle is noted. Which of the following congenital anomalies is least likely?
explanation: In craniosynostosis, infants have small fontanelles. Craniosynostosis is the premature fusion of cranial sutures An infant has 2 fontanelles at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle and the triangular posterior fontanelle. Closure of the anterior fontanelle occurs at 18 months Closure of the posterior fontanelle occurs by the 6th - 8th week after birth; its persistence suggests underlying hydrocephalus or congenital hypothyroidism. The presence of a third fontanelle may suggest trisomy 21 or prematurity. The persistence of excessively large anterior fontanelles and small fontanelles has been associated with several disorders: Large fontanelles Small fontanelles Achondroplasia Microcephaly Cleidocranial dysostosis Craniosynostosis Congenital rubella syndrome Congenital hyperthyroidis m Hydrocephaly Wormian bones Osteogenesis imperfecta Prematurity Russell–Silver syndrome Trisomies 13, 18, and 21 Vitamin D deficiency, rickets
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An anxious new mother brings her 18-day-old baby, to the casualty with complaints of poor feeding and yellowish discoloration of the skin. In the casualty, the baby had an episode of seizure. His total bilirubin is 32 mg/dl and he is diagnosed to have kernicterus. Which of the following will not be seen as a late feature of the disease?
explanation: Hypotonia is seen in the early phase of kernicterus. Kernicterus or bilirubin encephalopathy is a neurological syndrome resulting from the deposition of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei. It can result in permanent brain damage. Early Phase (Acut e) Late Phase Poor suck Movement disorders- choreo athetosis, ballismus, tremor Stupor Sensorineural hearing loss Hypotonia Defectiveupward gaze Seizures
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the most common cause of seizures in a term neonate?
explanation: Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is the most common cause of neonatal seizures in term babies. Seizures due to HIE typically appear within the first 12-24 hours of birth. Subtle seizures are the most common type of seizures in neonates with HIE. Neonatal seizures: Most common type - Subtle seizures Least common type - Myoclonic seizures Most common metabolic cause - Hypoglycemi Investigation of choice for the diagnosis of seizures - Electroencephalogram (EEG) Neuroimaging modality of choice for etiological evaluation - MRI Drug of choice - Phenobarbitone
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The video clip of a 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs suggests a neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. Other options: Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. Option C: Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. They too cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedalling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies. Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. They can be provoked by stimulation. Clinically apparent seizures in a neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures. In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before starting anti-epileptic drug treatment. Causes of neonatal seizure according to the age of presentation: 1 to 4 days 4 to 14 days 2 to 8 weeks Hypoxic ischemic encephalop athyMaternal use of narcotics or barbituratesDrug toxicity: lidocaine, penicillinIntravent ricular hemorrhageHypocalce mia, sepsis, hypoglycemia, hy pomagnesemia, hypo or hyp ernatremiaGalactosemia, ure cycle disorders Meningitis (bacterial)Enceph alitis (enteroviral, herpes sim plex)Hypocalcemia, hypoglyc emiaGalactosemia, fructosem ia,Hyperinsulinism, hyperam monemia syndrome Herpes simplex or enterovira l encephalitis, bacterial meni ngitisSubdural hematoma, ch ild abuseAminoaciduria, urea cycle defectsMalformations of cortical developmentTuber ous sclerosisSturge-Weber sy ndrome
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A term neonate born to a lady with chorioamnionitis is diagnosed with neonatal sepsis. Which of the following statements are false?
explanation: Late-onset sepsis usually presents after 72 hours of age (not 48 hours). Neutropenia appears to be a better predictor of neonatal sepsis (not neutrophilia). Neonatal sepsis is a clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of infection, with or without accompanying bacteremia in the first month of life. Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella spp. are the predominant organisms involved. Organisms such as Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas, and coagulase-negative staphylococci are also important pathogens in hospital-acquired infections. Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis Presentation Within thefirst 72 hours of lif e After 72 hours of life Source of infectio n Maternal genital tract Nosocomial or community-ac quired Manifestation Respiratory distress and pne umonia Septicemia, pneumonia, or m eningitis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Blood cultures drawn from a late preterm baby on day 8 of life show the growth of streptococcus species within 18 hours. An umbilical line tip culture also shows the same bacteria. Which among the following is the most common manifestation of the described type of neonatal sepsis?
explanation: Bacterial growth in the umbilical tip and blood cultures on day 8 suggests a hospital-acquired infection after 72 hours. This is late-onset neonatal sepsis. The most common manifestation of late-onset neonatal sepsis is meningitis. Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis Presentation Presents withinfirst 72 hours of life Presentsafter 72 hours of life Source of infectio n Maternal genital tract Nosocomial or community-ac quired Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis Manifestation Respiratory distress and pne umonia Septicemia, pneumonia, orm eningitis NOTE: Traditionally, neonatal sepsis had been classified as EOS (<7 days) and LOS (>7days), but recently, experts have come to believe that Early-onset neonatal sepsis manifests within the first 72 hours of life and Late-onset neonatal sepsis after 72 hours of life.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A focus of Klebsiella is detected in one of the ventilators during a routine quality and maintenance check in the NICU. Sepsis protocol is enacted and a sepsis screen is ordered for all the neonates at risk. Which of the following investigations is not sent as part of a neonatal sepsis screen?
explanation: Absolute eosinophil count is not a component of neonatal sepsis screen. The various components of the septic screen include: Total leukocyte count (TLC) Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) Immature: Total neutrophil ratio (IT), Micro-erythrocyte sedimentation rate C-reactive protein. Blood culture: Gold standard for diagnosis. All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a septic screen to corroborate the diagnosis. Note: Most common fungus causing neonatal sepsis: Candida species.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following findings in a healthy term child would warrant further evaluation?
explanation: Buphthalmos is not a normal finding in a newborn; it is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and should, therefore, be investigated. The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (“ox eye”). Recommended screening for eye diseases at birth: Buphthalmos Cataract Ophthalmia Neonatorum Developmental anomalies - Microphthalmos, Anophthalmos Nystagmus Squint Retinopathy of prematurity
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A neonate undergoing routine ophthalmological examination was found to have the finding shown below. Which among the following can be ruled out as the cause of this finding?
explanation: The image shows leukokoria or white pupillary reflex. It is not seen in congenital glaucoma. Leukokoria is seen in: Congenital cataract Chorioretinitis Retinoblastom Retinopathy of prematurity Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivers a 1.5 kg baby girl at 27 weeks of gestation. When is an ophthalmological examination recommended for the initial screening of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in this baby?
options: At age equivalent to 32 weeks of gestation
explanation: The first Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) screening in this baby should be conducted 2 weeks postnatal. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a vaso-proliferative disorder of the developing retinal blood vessels of the preterm infant, which may lead to poor visual acuity or blindness. Criteria for screening: Birth weight <2000g OR Gestational age <34 weeks OR Gestational age between 34-36 weeks with the following risk factors - prolonged oxygen therapy (respiratory distress syndrome, apnea, cardiorespiratory support), neonatal sepsis, blood/exchange transfusion. According to IAP guidelines, ROP screening should be conducted according to the table given below: Period of gestation (POG) / bi rth weight Screening <28 weeksOR <1200g 2-3 weeksof postnatal ag e >28 weeks OR >1200g 4 weeks of postnatal age According to Nelson's 22nd edition, ROP screening should be conducted according to the table given below: Annual follow-up is carried out unless indicated otherwise in cases where cryotherapy/laser treatment or cycloplegic refraction has been done. POG Screening <28 week s 31 weeks of POG 28-32 we eks 4 weeks of postnatal ag e
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant born 48 hours back by vaginal delivery with birth asphyxia develops seizures. What stage of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the child likely to be in?
explanation: Seizures are common in stage 2 of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). HIE is an important cause of permanent damage to CNS tissues, resulting in the following: Neonatal Death Cerebral Palsy Developmental Delay Stag es Seizures Stag e 1 Nil Stag e 2 Common Stag e 3 Decerebrati on
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 27-year-old primigravida delivers a 3kg term baby after a cesarean section done in view of prolonged labor. The child cries 5 mins after birth and has a seizure 8 hours later. What is the imaging of choice for evaluation?
explanation: The clinical vignette of prolonged labor, delayed cry after birth (birth asphyxia), and seizure suggest hypoxic-ischemic injury. The preferred imaging modality in term neonates with HIE is diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). This is because of its increased sensitivity and specificity early in the process and its ability to outline the topography of the lesion. Computed Tomography (CT) is helpful in identifying focal hemorrhagic lesions, diffuse cortical injury, and damage to the basal ganglia, but limited ability during the first few days of life. Ultrasonography (USG) - Neurosonogram is the initial preferred modality for preterm infants. Amplitude–integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) may help to determine which infants are at increased risk for long-term brain injury.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-day old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is hyper-alert with mydriasis. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes and clonus. On investigations, normal EEG is obtained. What stage of HIE is she in?
explanation: Hyperactive tendon reflexes may be seen in stages 1 and 2; however, the infant is hyperalert with mydriasis and normal EEG findings in stage 1. Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE): Signs Stage 1 Stage 2 Stage 3 Level of consciousn ess Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate Tendon reflex/clonu s Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent Myoclonus Present Present Absent Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex Seizures None Common Decerebration EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to se izure activity Burst suppression to isoele ctric Duration <24 hour if progresses; oth erwise, may remain norma l 24 hour to 14 days Days to weeks Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 1.4 Kg neonate is born at 29 weeks of gestation. The sonologist performing neurosonogram is most likely to find an intracranial hemorrhage in the:
explanation: Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymal or germinal matrix. In preterm infants, the germinal matrix (situated ventrolateral to lateral ventricles) is extensive and highly vascular which makes them prone to bleeding. Germinal matrix normally involutes during the third trimester. Major neuropathologic lesions associated with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants are intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL). Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is characterized by focal necrotic lesions in the periventricular white matter.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-week old infant with a birth weight of 1.8 Kg is being treated in the NICU for necrotizing enterocolitis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?
options: Proximal part of the ileum is involved most frequently
It is associated with intestinal ischemi
It is more common in preterm infants
explanation: The distal ileum and the proximal colon are involved most frequently in necrotizing enterocolitis. Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturity characterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterm infants, and prematurity is the biggest risk factor. The triad of intestinal ischemia (injury), enteral nutrition (metabolic substrate), and bacterial translocation have classically been linked to necrotizing enterocolitis. Pathologic findings include necrotic segment(s) of intestine, gas accumulation in the submucosa of the bowel wall (pneumatosis intestinalis), and progression of the necrosis to perforation, peritonitis, sepsis, and death. Breast milk protects against necrotizing enterocolitis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 12-day old preterm neonate was diagnosed to have necrotizing enterocolitis. She had been switched over from breastmilk to formula feed 5 days after birth as the mother died of COVID-associated complications. Which of the following features will not be seen in the baby?
explanation: Necrotizing enterocolitis can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis (not alkalosis). Other Signs and Symptoms G strointestinal Systemic Abdominal distention Lethargy Abdominal tenderness Apnea/respiratory distress Vomiting Temperature instability Occult/gross blood in stools, Acidosis- metabolic and/or re spiratory Change in stool pattern/diarr hea Hyponatremia Abdominal mass Glucose instability Poor perfusion/shock DIC

question_text:
A 1.9 Kg neonate delivered at 32 weeks has abdominal distention and hematochezia on the 11th day of life. The abdomen x-ray is as shown below. What is the stage of disease according to Modified Bell's Staging Criteria?

Stage IB
explanation: The above X-ray image shows gas accumulation in the submucosa of the bowel wall- pneumatosis intestinalis, a pathognomonic finding of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), seen in stage IIA, according to the Modified Bell Staging Criteria. Modified Bell's Staging Criteria: Stage I - Suspected NEC Stage II - Proven NEC Stage III - Advanced NEC Stage Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs Treatment IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal dist ention, emesis, guai ac-positive stool Temperature instabi lity, apnea, bradycar dia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus NPO, Antibiotic for 3 days IB IA + Bright red bloo d from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA Same as IA IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sound s Same as IA Pneumatosis intesti nalis,ileus NPO, Antibiotics for 7-10 days IIB Moderately ill IIA + definite abdom inal tenderness IA+ Metabolic acido sis and thrombocyto penia IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days IIIA Severely ill, bowel in tact IIB + peritonitis wit h marked tendernes s, and abdominal dis tension IIB+ hypotension, br adycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia IIB + definite ascitis NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days, fluid resusci tation +/- inotropes, ventilator, paracente sis IIIB Severely ill, bowelpe rforated Same as III A Same as IIIA IIB +pneumoperiton eum Same as III A, surge ry Apgar score and Neonatal Resuscitation
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: While assessing the Apgar score of the newborns, you would assess and score all of the following except:
explanation: Respiratory effort, not rate is a component of Apgar score. The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 parameters explained below. It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. Color (A, appearance) Heart rate (P, pulse) Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace) Muscle tone (A, activity) Respiratory effort (R) Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and shows minimal response to stimulation with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is
explanation: The Apgar score in this baby is 4. It is calculated as: Appearance: blue - score 0 Pulse: <100 beats/min - score 1 Grimace: with minimal response to stimulation - score 1 Activity: some flexion of the extremities - score 1 Respiratory effort: irregular - score 1 The total score is 4. Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts. Causes for low Apgar score are: Fetal distress Prematurity Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate Acute cerebral trauma Precipitous delivery Airway obstruction (choanal atresia) Congenital pneumonia or sepsis Haemorrhage- hypovolemia False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels. A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Where would you attach the oxygen inlet in the instrument given below?
explanation: The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask. It is used in neonatal resuscitation; it inflates automatically, without a compressed gas source. Marking 1 is the pressure release valve. Marking 2 is the 360-degree swivel. Marking 3 is the oxygen inlet. Marking 4 is the air inlet. The parts of the self-inflating bag and mask are labeled in the image below: Absolute contraindication for using the bag and mask ventilation is congenital diaphragmatic hernia
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 35-week neonate with grade 2 meconium-stained amniotic fluid is delivered by emergency LSCS. There is no spontaneous cry and the baby is unresponsive to tactile stimulation also. As the intern assisting in resuscitation, what is the order of suctioning that you will follow?
explanation: During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 French suction catheter is used, with the suction pressure kept between 80-100 mmHg. Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended. The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically. It may produce a vagal response - apnea and/or bradycardia due to stimulation of the nerve in the posterior pharynx.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the ideal ratio of compression to ventilation that you would use in the resuscitation of a newborn?
explanation: The ratio of compressions to ventilation in the resuscitation of the newborn is 3:1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths in one minute). A 3:1 compression-to-ventilation ratio is used for neonatal resuscitation where compromise of gas exchange is nearly always the primary cause of the cardiovascular collapse. Chest compressions are indicated if the heart rate is below 60/min even after 30 seconds of positive pressure ventilation. Once the HR is 60/min or more, chest compressions should be discontinued.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A neonate with suspected birth asphyxia is intubated in the labor room after bag and mask ventilation did not yield successful results. All of the following parameters would indicate successful ventilation except
explanation: End-tidal CO2 should be present (EtCO2 should not be zero). This is an important sign of successful ventilation. Successful ventilation is signified by the following: Adequate chest rise Symmetric breath sounds Improved pink color Heart rate > 100 beats/min Spontaneous respirations Presence of end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2 should not be zero) Improved tone
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A panicked primigravida, at 38 weeks of gestation, rushes to the ER at 3 am as she had not appreciated any fetal movements since 10 pm. She is taken up for an emergency c-section in view of fetal distress. Following delivery, the infant was cyanotic and apneic. What is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation?
explanation: Room air is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation in term infants. Resuscitation with room air in term infants is as effective as using 100% oxygen. By using room air, we may reduce the risk of hyperoxia which is associated with decreased cerebral blood flow and generation of oxygen free radicals. If the neonate does not achieve normal oxygen saturation levels within 90 seconds, increased concentrations of oxygen are administered until normal saturation levels are achieved. If pulmonary hypertension is suspected (meconium aspiration, diaphragmatic hernia), one may consider 100% oxygen as the initial gas for resuscitation. Resuscitation of most preterm infants can be initiated with a slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21–30%).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During neonatal resuscitation, when would you consider administering IV adrenaline?
options: Heart rate < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.
Severe respiratory depression, and failure to respond to positive-pressure ventilation with ba and mask ventilation.
explanation: If the heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, consider administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation. Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access in the delivery room.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 34-year-old lady is taken up for an emergency C-section due to meconium-stained amniotic fluid. The neonate does not cry after tactile stimulation and the heart rate is 60 beats/min. In order to determine the course of resuscitation, you assess if the baby is vigorous. For this, you would consider all of the following parameters except:
explanation: Color is not a parameter considered to determine if the child is vigorous. Vigorous babies have (HRT): Heart rate of >100, Respiratory effort: good Tone: good If the infant is vigorous with good respiratory effort and a heart rate >100 beats/min; the mouth and nose may be suctioned with a bulb or suction catheter if needed. A newborn is defined as non-vigorous if any of the above three signs are absent. Resuscitation of non-vigorous newborns with meconium-stained amniotic fluid includes positive-pressure ventilation and in severe cases, endotracheal intubation and chest compressions. Note: Even for non-vigorous infants, endotracheal intubation to aspirate meconium is not recommended anymore.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A term primiparous lady with moderate mitral stenosis received 2 doses of meperidine, 2 hours before delivery. She delivers a female baby vaginally, but the baby is apneic at birth. What is the most important immediate management of the newborn in this case?
options: Administer naloxone in the endotracheal tube
explanation: The most important immediate management is to maintain adequate ventilation via bag and mask, because the baby is apneic. Meperidine is a narcotic and the administration of narcotics such as opioids or barbiturates, to the mother shortly before delivery (within 4 hours prior) result in narcosis and respiratory depression in the newborn. In these babies, naloxone hydrochloride is given while adequate ventilation (bag and mask) is maintained. Breathing in the depressed infant should be maintained until a response to naloxone is noted. Naloxone hydrochloride, 0.1 mg/kg, can be given intravenously or intramuscularly.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Antenatal imaging in an infant delivered late preterm, showed severe congenital diaphragmatic hernia with tracheal occlusion. An airway is secured before the placenta is removed from the circulation. What is this procedure called?
explanation: Ex-utero intrapartum treatment procedure (EXIT) is a procedure by which the airway is secured before the infant is separated from the placenta. It allows time to secure the airway in an infant known to have airway obstruction due to various causes, including laryngeal atresia or stenosis, teratomas, hygromas, and oral tumors before the infant is separated from the placenta. Uteroplacental gas exchange is maintained throughout the procedure. Option A: BiPAP machines provide positive airway pressure during exhalation and additional positive pressure during inspiration. It allows for adjusting of inspiratory and expiratory pressures. The additional pressures augment tidal volume and improve alveolar ventilation. Children with neuromuscular weakness and intrathoracic airway obstruction benefit from this. Option C: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a form of cardiopulmonary bypass that augments systemic perfusion and provides gas exchange. This may be helpful to prevent and treat hypoxia and respiratory acidosis and decrease the work of breathing in ARDS, central apnea, refractory shock, severe sepsis, pulmonary hypertension, etc. Option D: CPAP is provided via a high-flow nasal cannula, with a gas flow of 4-16 L/min. It is used in diseases with mildly decreased lung compliance, and low functional residual capacity.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A newborn baby has respiratory distress in the delivery room. Attempts to pass a nasogastric tube through both the nares are unsuccessful. Genital and ear abnormalities are also noted on the preliminary examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
Potter sequence
explanation: Inability to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares along with the presence of respiratory distress, suggests choanal atresia. The presence of ear and genital anomalies along with choanal atresia suggests the diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome. It consists of Coloboma of the eye Heart anomaly Choanal Atresia Retardation Genital anomalies Ear anomalies VATER syndrome: Vertebral defects, imperforate anus, tracheoesophageal fistula, as well as radial and renal dysplasia. Potter's sequence: Renal agenesis, oligohydramnios, and pulmonary hypoplasia Pierre–Robin syndrome: Micrognathia, retrognathia, and glossoptosis. Developmental Milestones
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following gross motor milestone would you expect to see in a 3-year-old child?
explanation: A three-year-old should normally be able to walk upstairs with alternate feet.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You notice a child pulling to the standing position and then shuffling around by holding onto furniture. At what age is this milestone typically attained?
explanation: Cruising is an activity in which a child pulls to the standing position and then shuffles around holding onto a piece of furniture. Cruising is attained by 10-11 months.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby, totally occupied with his little game and a mother trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
explanation: A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months. A child makes a tower of: 2 blocks by 15 months 3 blocks by 18 months 6 blocks by 2 years 9 blocks by 3 years
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
explanation: The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger. Developmental progression of the grasp: At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp). At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger. At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A final-year medical student is examining a baby in the ward. As the infant is pulled to sit, he notices a head lag. By what age should this infant ideally start to hold his head steady without any bobbing motion?
explanation: An infant can hold his head steady when pulled to sit, without head bobbing, by the age of 4 months. Regarding head steadiness: Up till 2 months of age, there is a significant head lag when the infant is pulled to sit. At 3 months, head lag is partially compensated but still present; the infant attains early head control with bobbing motion and sits with back rounded. At 4 months, there is no head lag when pulled to sit and the infant sits with full truncal support.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Your sister tells you that your nephew has now started using his crayons. He easily copies circles, but still has trouble with squares. Other than a minor ASD noted incidentally at birth, he is a perfectly healthy child. Which of the following would you expect him to be able to do at this stage?
explanation: Normally, a child is able to copy a circle at 3 years and a square at 4 years. This child is a 3-year-old, and he should be able to know his name and gender. A child is able to tell a story at 4 years. Asks meaning of words at 5 years. A child can skip at 5 years.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Match the following milestones with corresponding age.
explanation: Handedness is established during the 3rd year (24 to 36 months). Taste perception is present since birth. Monosyllabic babble is seen at 6 months. Response to faces and voices with a smile is seen at 1.5 months. The child creeps upstairs by 15 months.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are taking a detailed history from the parents of a child with a suspected autism spectrum disorder. Parents are worried that their child does not smile or maintain eye contact and is not interested in toys. At what ages should a typical child exhibit "social smile" and "stranger anxiety"?
explanation: Social smile is typically seen at 2 months and stranger anxiety at 6 months. Social smile: At 1 month of age, a child smiles involuntarily. At 2 months of age social smile develops; that is, the child smiles voluntarily and reciprocally, in response to someone else’s smile. Stranger anxiety: Before 6 months, the child is sociable and friendly even with strangers. At 6 months, there is an onset of stranger anxiety; infants look back and forth between an approaching stranger and parent and may cling or cry anxiously.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A pediatrician is evaluating a toddler for mental retardation. She hands a bright red ball to the baby and lets him play with it. She then takes the ball and hides it under a blanket in front of him. The child confusedly stares at the blanket and cries instead of searching for it. What is being tested here?
explanation: Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called object permanence. This is due to an ability to form a mental representation of the object. It is attained at the age of 8–9 months. Option A: Separation anxiety begins at about 9 months of age. Children wake up crying from their naps as they realize that their parents are not in the same room as them. This is different from stranger anxiety displayed by the child at the age of 6-7 months, wherein they react to approaching strangers by crying or clinging to their parent. Option B: A transitional object is an object, such as a blanket or a stuffed toy, that is used by many children as a symbol of the absent parent. It is seen at around 18 months. Option C: Symbolic transformations in play: At 12 months - make-believe (symbolic) play centres on the child’s own body, e.g., the child pretends to drink from an empty cup. At 18 month - symbolic transformations in play are not limited to the child's body, e.g., a do can be fed from a plate.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Parents of 9-month-old infant, with a history of preterm delivery and prolonged NICU stay, are concerned that child is lagging behind in his milestones. You would suspect a developmental delay in this child if his developmental quotient (DQ) is below %?
explanation: A developmental delay should be suspected if the development quotient (DQ) is below 70%. It is calculated as: DQ = Developmental age x 100Chronological age From the highest milestones achieved by the child, the developmental age in a particular domain is calculated. The chronological age is the actual age in term babies. However, in preterm infants, a corrected age rather than postnatal age is used till two years of age. This is used to account for the small gap in neurological development that premature children have yet to catch up. For example, a child born at 32 weeks gestation (gestational age) seen at 12 weeks of age (postnatal age), should be considered as a 4-week-old (corrected age) child. If there is a delay (DQ<70%) in more than 2 domains, then global developmental delay (GDD) is suspected.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following milestones is expected to be seen in a child at 5 years of age?
options: Riding a tricycle and making a tower of 9 blocks
Establishment of handedness and parallel play
explanation: Developmental milestones at the age of 5 years include: Motor - skips Adaptive - Draws a triangle Language - Asks meaning of words Social - Dresses and undresses Undressing is easier and hence learned before dressing. 2 years - Helps to undress 3 years - Helps in dressing (if helped with buttons) 5 years - Dress and undress fully (without any help)

question_text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear, that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved?
explanation: The earliest age of appearance of bidextrous reach is 4 months. Fine motor reflexes begin to appear only after the palmar grasp reflex disappears at 3-4 months. The development of unidextrous reach occurs by 6 months of age.

explanation: A 4-year-old child can count 4 pennies but cannot name 4 colours. A child can name 4 colours at 5 years of age. Note: An easy way to remember this: No. of objects counted = age No. of colours identified = age - 1

question_text: A term, 4-month-old infant, is developing normally. By what age do you expect her to walk without support and use polysyllabic jargon?
explanation: A 15-month-old child can walk without support and use polysyllabic jargon. Walking: A child begins to cruise at 10 months, walk with support at 12 months, and walk without support at 15 months. Jargon is seen around 15 months of age. It is a pre-linguistic vocalization in which the child babbles using strings of word-like sounds and produces words that do not make much sense to others.

explanation: The milestones at 5 years of age are: Motor - skips Adaptive - draws triangle Language - asks meaning of words, names 4 colors Social - dresses and undresses

question_text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay?
explanation: Feeding by spoon is a social milestone that typically appears by 18 months. If this is absent, then the child should be termed as having a developmental delay. Hopping on one leg, drawing a square, and passing a ball to someone appear by 48 months of age. Red flag signs in developmental screening and surveillance are indicators that suggest a serious disorder in a child's development, requiring referral to a pediatrician. These are given below: Positive indicators: Presence of any of the following Loss of developmental skills at any age Concerns about vision or confirmed visual impairment Hearing loss at any age Persistently low muscle tone Lack of speech by 18 months without other means of communication Asymmetry of movements or features suggestive of cerebral palsy Persistent toe walking Complex disabilities Unusual head circumference compared to norms Clinician uncertainty about the developmental disorder. Negative Indicators: Inability to sit unsupported by 12 months Inability to walk by 18 months in boys or 2 years in girls. Inability to walk normally Inability to run by 2.5 years Inability to hold objects in hand by 5 months or reach for them by 6 months. Inability to point at objects to share interest by 2 years

question_text:
After assessing a young child treated for unilateral retinoblastoma, you note significant delays in the cognitive and fine motor domains. The baby can stand without support and creep well.
Normally, the highest fine motor skill a baby of this age is expected to have is
explanation: A baby that stands without support is most likely to be 12 months. The highest fine motor skill she is expected to have is mature pincer grasp (12 months). Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months. Immature pincer grasp is seen at 9 months. Child begins to scribble after 15 months. Fine motor development is critically linked with hand-eye coordination. Children who have disease-related loss of vision in early infancy develop difficulties in visuomotor integration and lags behind in fine motor milestones.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are a pediatrics resident handling the well-child clinic for the week and you are teaching undergraduates how to do a simple developmental assessment. A preterm baby born at 32 weeks, is brought in for a follow-up visit at 6 months. What is the age you would ask the students to assume when undertaking developmental assessment in this child?
explanation: The corrected age (in weeks) to be assumed while undertaking developmental assessment is 16 weeks. Corrected age (in weeks) = (Gestational age + postnatal age) - 40 weeks In this case, since the baby is born 8 weeks preterm, the 8 weeks of intrauterine growth and development she missed, is accounted for post-natally. Thus, for assessing the correct developmental age, 8 weeks has to be subtracted from the chronological age. In babies born preterm, corrected age is used for their developmental assessment until 2 years of age.

A young infant is brought to you with a suspected developmental delay. The child is intently looking at his own hands. You would consider referring this child to a specialist if this milestone persists after .
12 weeks
explanation: Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently. This milestone is called hand regard and it should disappear by 20 weeks. Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered abnormal. In a blind child, however, it may persist beyond 20 weeks normally and is called apparent hand regard. Facets of Growth and Development

question_text: Which of the following fetal hormones does not play any role in fetal growth?
explanation: Growth hormone does not play any role in fetal growth, although it is present in high levels during the fetal period. However, it does have a role in the postnatal period. Insulin and thyroxine hormones are required for normal growth and development during late gestation. Glucocorticoid has a role in the prepartum maturation of organs such as liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child is brought to the pediatrician for vaccination. The child is able to speak in 2-3 word sentences and is able to make a tower of 6 cubes. What is the expected weight of the child, if his development is normal and birth weight was 3 Kgs?
explanation: The child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes and speaks in 2-3 word sentences which indicates the child is of 2 years of age. Birth weight quadruples by the age of 2 years. Hence the child's weight should be 3 kgs x 4= 12 Kgs. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life and regain it by their 2nd week.
