question_text: Which of the following statements is false?
options: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height
explanation: Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable. The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method. question_text: Which of the following statements regarding the eruption of teeth is false?
explanation: Primary teeth in the upper jaw erupt earlier than their counterpart in the lower jaw, except for lower central incisors and second molar. No primary teeth till the age of 13 months is called delayed eruption. As seen in the image below, the first primary tooth to erupt is the lower (mandibular) central incisor, at 5-7 months. All primary teeth erupt by 1.5–2.5 years of age. The first secondary tooth to erupt is the first molar (maxillary or mandibular), at 6-7 years, followed by the lower central incisor. Causes of delayed eruption: Idiopathic: Most common Hypothyroidism Hypoparathyroidism Familia Mechanical blockage of individual teeth
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 3-year-old boy presented to the clinic for a missed vaccination. His routine anthropometric measurements were noted. He was found to be 90 cm tall with a lower segment of 45 cm.
Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
explanation: The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options. The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height. The U/L ratio is 1.7 at birth 1.3 at 3 years 1 after 7 years 0.9 in adults High U/L ratio: Rickets Achondroplasia Untreated congenital hypothyroidism Low U/L ratio: Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia Vertebral anomalies Arm span: Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span. It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually<1 cm).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A team participating in an Under-14 national athletics sports tournament suspects foul play by, a rival team member. He claims to fit the criteria for the age requirements for the tournament, but the opposing team does not agree. Which of the following X-ray would be most useful to verify the claims of the player?
options: X-ray of the hands and wrist
X-ray of the elbow and hip
explanation: The X-ray of choice to determine the skeletal age of a 14-year-old boy is X-ray of the elbow and hip. The bone age of a child indicates his/her level of biological and structural maturity. Methods used for bone age estimation are Gruelisch–Pyle atlas (more common) and Tanner–Whitehouse method. Note: There is overlap in the age ranges for X-ray of choice. options: Head reaches 90% of adult size at 1 year
Lymphoid growth follows a sigmoid-shaped pattern
Perinatal period is between 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth
Growth of child is cephalocaudal and distal to proxima
explanation: Growth of child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal. During fetal life, the growth of the head occurs before that of the neck, and arms grow before legs. The distal parts of the body such as hands increase in size before the upper arms. Growth rate of different tissues: Growth Development Denotes a net increase in size /mass of tissues Denotes maturation of functi ons CephalocaudalHead  Neck  Trunk & upper limbs  L ower limbs DistalProximalHands incre ase in size before upper arms ProximalDistalHand use is learnt before the use of finger s Brain growth: At age of 1 month, the head size is about 36% of the expected head size in adults. It is rapid during the feta period and the first 3–4 years. It is steady in the following period, followed by a growth spurt during puberty. Later, it slows down considerably. question_text: A young boy is brought to the clinician by his parents with complaints of impulsive behavior and decreased levels of attention at school and everyday activities. The clinician is suspecting a case of ADHD. Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of ADHD?
options: Symptoms begin before 7 years of age

Should be reported by independent observers
Behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate in two or more settings
explanation: Attention-deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD) must begin before 12 years of age, according to DSM-5 criteria. It was 7 years as per the previous DSM-4 criteria. Treatment: Presynaptic dopaminergic agonists, commonly called psychostimulant medications, including methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, amphetamine, and various amphetamine and dextroamphetamine preparations are used. question_text: In the image given below, the weight and height of a child are plotted against his age in years. Identify the correct statement.
options: WHO growth charts used now are developed by National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS).
Short stature is defined as a height below 5th percentile.
Puberty in this child will be normal.
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age.
explanation: Bone age of this child is less than chronological age, as seen in cases of constitutional delay. As seen in the graph, the child was short initially, but the final height is within normal range. Hence, this child has constitutional delay. Other options: The WHO growth charts are based on Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS). Nationa Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) developed growth charts that were used in the past. Short stature is defined as a height below the third percentile or more than 2 standard deviations below the median height for age and gender (<-2 SD) according to the population standard. Puberty will be delayed in this child.

question_text: Identify the correct statement from the following.
options: Children with pica are at increased risk of megaloblastic anemia
Breath-holding spells are associated with hypertonia
Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension
Bedwetting after a period of 3 months of dryness at night is called secondary enuresis
explanation: Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension. It is a self-limiting habit disorder, usually seen between 6 months to 2 years. Option A: Pica is persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances for at least 1 month. It hampers the development of the child and requires clinical attention. Children with pica are at an increased risk of lead poisoning, iron-deficiency anemia, and parasitic infections. Option B: Breath-holding spells: It is preceded by a provocative event such as anger. Crying stops at full expiration. Child may have apnoea, cyanosis, pallor, hypotonia, or even loss of consciousness, and generalized tonic–clonic seizure (GTCS). Subtypes include cyanotic, pallid, and mixed episodes. Seizures and cardiac causes should be ruled out. Parents should be reassured that breath-holding spells are self-limiting. Option D: Enuresis: When the child has never been dry, it is called primary enuresis. When the bedwetting starts after a minimum period of six months of dryness at night, it is termed as secondary enuresis. Nocturnal enuresis is caused due to maturational delay. In a normal individual, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels usually peak between 4 am and 8 am. This circadian rhythm is impaired in nocturnal enuresis, leading to bedwetting. Treatment - Behavioural therapy with positive reinforcement, bladder alarms, and desmopressin reserved for cases resistant to behavioural therapy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As part of the annual school health check-up camp, the visual acuity of a 6-year-old girl is being tested by the optometrist. What is the expected visual acuity in this age?
explanation: According to Parson's diseases of the eye, visual acuity of 20/20 is attained by the age of 6 years. Nelson's Textbook of Paediatrics mentions that by the age of 5 or 6 years most children attain 20/20 vision. question_text: Identify the correct statement.
options: Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference greater than 3 SD above the mean for age and sex

Infants with benign familial megalencephaly have normal head circumference at birth

Familial short stature

explanation: Weight loss of >7-10% of birth weight is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in a neonate. question_text: A young working mother wants to add formula feeds to the diet of her 5-month-old child as she would be unable to breastfeed her baby frequently and satiate her. Which of the following fatty acid should the mother look for in the formula to ensure optimal brain development in the child?
explanation: Docosahexenoic acid (DHA) and arachidonic acid (ARA), both play an important role in the growth and CNS development in babies. DHA and ARA are essential poly unsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) present in breast milk. Both are essential for cognition functions, visual acuity, and immune responses. They have optimal effects on brain development when included together, in efficacious levels, in an infant's diet. Almost all infant formulae are now fortified with pre-formed DHA and ARA. It is advisable that all infants upto 6 months of age are to be exclusively breastfed and not formula fed. However, in unavoidable situations such as lactation failure or maternal infections where breastfeeding is contraindicated, the use of a formula feed that contains both DHA and ARA is recommended. Other options: Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and Linolenic acid are other essential fatty acids that are present in breast milk. These are required for the overall protection of the cardiovascular system as well as to reduce systemic inflammation.

question_text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow and urine appears pale straw, he is otherwise well. A provisional diagnosis of breastmilk jaundice is made. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: Some babies need treatment with phototherapy
It is common in the second week of life
explanation: Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals. Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2–4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain -glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding. Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ) It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

question_text: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with fever and pain in her left breast. She has had difficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals her left breast is warm, red, swollen, and painful to palpation. She was started on dicloxacillin. Continue feeding from only right breast
Continue feeding from only left breast

It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period of time. Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It requires frequent replacement. Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. question_text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child with a swollen belly, dull face with hypoproteinemia along with poor diet history suggests the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. In edematous malnutrition, the initial appearance of edema is commonly observed in the feet and lower legs, progressing into generalized edema affecting the hands, arms, and face. The skin over the swollen areas may show dark, crackled, peeling patches (flaky paint dermatosis) with pale skin underneath, making it susceptible to infections. There may be sparse and easily pluckable hair. Hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration is a common finding. Associated symptoms of misery, apathy, and loss of appetite are seen in children with edema. Other options: Option B: Marasmus is a severe form of wasting characterized by significant loss of fat and muscle tissue as the body utilizes these resources for energy. It is often triggered by acute starvation or illness in individuals with borderline nutritional status. Option C: Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a chronic liver disease that affects infants and young children. Common symptoms include jaundice, pruritus, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The disease progresses rapidly, leading to the development of cirrhosis. Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph node enlargement.

question_text: A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is receiving treatment in your clinic. Given below are five statements regarding the treatment. Pick out the incorrect statements.
explanation: Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14. The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases: Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment. Mnemonic: SHIELDED Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) Hypothermia Infection ELectrolyte imbalance DEhydration Deficiency of nutrients Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks. Steps: Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed) Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat. Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition. Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks. Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children. Correct micronutrient deficiencies: Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase. Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14. Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1) Zinc (2 mg/kg/day) Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day) Start cautious feeding: Give ù to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day. Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite. Beginning of feeding. After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development Transfer to home-based diet

question_text:
A 3 year old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of multiple episodes of loose stools and progressive weight loss. She was found to have a mid-upper arm circumference of
10.5 cm. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this child?
options: Administer 10 mL of 50% glucose IV, if unconscious
Continue aggressive hydration, even after dehydration resolves
Use ReSoMal for rehydration 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours
explanation: Progressive weight loss and mid-upper arm circumference of <11.5 cm denote severe acute protein-energy malnutrition (PEM). When accompanied by loose stools, management includes the use of low sodium ORS for rehydration of 5ml/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours. Management of fluid/electrolyte status in SAM: Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock. Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hr orally or NG tube. Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hour. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed every other alternate hour. Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy. Do not continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves. Treatment of hypoglycemia in malnutrition: If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL) orally or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue, whichever is the quickest. If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV. Note: 50% glucose is never used in children as it is extremely viscous and concentrated. This could lead to injection site pain, severe thrombophlebitis, and irritation. Also, this can cause osmotic overload in a three-year-old.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A young girl who was grossly emaciated and undernourished was started on partial parenteral nutrition together with enteral nutrition via a nasogastric tube. In the first week, which among the following would be the hallmark for the development of refeeding syndrome?
Hyperphosphatemia
explanation: The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia. Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce the following: Hypophosphatemia (hallmark) Hypokalemia Hypomagnesemia A controlled transition over 3 days from F-75 to F-100 is recommended by the WHO for treating malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome. Deficiency of Fat Soluble Vitamins

question_text: Which of the following is an 'Anti-infective' vitamin?
explanation: Vitamin A is required for the maintenance of epithelial functions, creating an effective barrier against pathogens; hence, it is called as an anti-infective vitamin. So, vitamin A deficiency can lead to changes in the epithelia of all mucosal surfaces, leading to increased chances of infections. Vitamin E (Tocopherol) helps is an anti-oxidant. Deficiency manifests as skin changes and hair loss. Vitamin D maintains calcium and phosphorus homeostasis. Deficiency can lead to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Vitamin C helps in the formation of connective tissues and collagen in the skin, bone, and blood vessels. Deficiency leads to their fragility and causes scurvy.
