question_text: A 2-year-old unvaccinated girl is brought to the OPD with high-grade fever and maculopapular rashes for 2 days. On examination, she has blue-white spots on her buccal mucosa as shown in the image attached below. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is associated with this condition?
explanation: The girl is suffering from measles. It is associated with vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency is associated with an increased risk of infection and increased mortality with a variety of infectious diseases particularly measles. Hence, vitamin A therapy is indicated in all patients with measles. The main functions of vitamin A are as follows: Maintenance of vision, especially night vision Maintenance of epithelial tissues Differentiation of various tissues, particularly during reproduction and gestation, by regulating gene expression. Features of vitamin A deficiency: Eyes: Defective dark adaptation is a characteristic early clinical feature, resulting in night blindness (earliest manifestation). This can further progress to xerophthalmia, Bitot's spots, conjunctivitis, or keratomalacia, leading to blindness. Poor overall growth, anaemia Diarrhoea, susceptibility to infections Increased intracranial pressure Keratinization of mucous membranes and skin (hyperkeratosis)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young girl of class 4 complains of a burning sensation in the eye. Clinical examination of eyes reveals the finding shown below. What could be the mechanism for the development of such lesions?
options: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva
explanation: The given clinical image is showing Bitot spots, which occur due to keratinization of the conjunctival epithelium. Bitot spots are triangular, frequently bilateral, and present on the bulbar conjunctiva. Normally, bulbar conjunctiva is a stratified, columnar, non-keratinized epithelium. In vitamin A deficiency, there is squamous metaplasia of the conjunctival epithelium and tangles of keratin admixed with gas-forming bacteria producing a dry, scaly patch with a foamy appearance called Bitot spots. Option A: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva is termed conjunctival concretions, which usually occurs over the palpebral conjunctiva, in chronic inflammatory conditions of the eye. Option B: Scarring of the conjunctiva is seen in chlamydial infection of the eye. Option C: Excessive growth of conjunctival tissue is seen in the pterygium of the eye.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old boy with complaints of dry, itchy eyes and night blindness had the following ophthalmic finding as given in the image. What is the stage of vitamin A deficiency as per WHO classification?
explanation: The image depicts a corneal ulcer occupying <1/3rd of the cornea under a slit lamp with a fluorescein stain. This corresponds to stage X3A of vitamin A deficiency.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of headache, desquamation of the skin, and bone pain. Pathological examination revealed lysosomal rupture within the cells, prompting a suspicion of hypervitaminosis A. Which of the following statement is false about the principle vitamin that is excess in the given condition?
explanation: Both hypervitaminosis A and deficiency of vitamin A cause raised intracranial pressure (ICP) (not just hypervitaminosis A). 11-cis retinal(not trans) is required for vision. Hypervitaminosis A causes headache, vomiting, desquamation of the skin, and hyperostosis of long bones. Rupture of lysosomes in the cells is the pathological feature of hypervitaminosis A. All-trans retinoic acid is the most bioactive form of vitamin A, and it is required for cell differentiation and the regulation of transcription. On the other hand, 11-cis retinal is required for vision. Protein-energy malnutrition can cause vitamin A deficiency because of the impaired synthesis of retinol-binding protein (RBP).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Your best friend is recently worried that she has a lot of hair fall. Which of the following vitamin capsules if added to her diet can help prevent free radical injury and thus be beneficial for her??
explanation: Vitamin E/ Tocopherol is a potent antioxidant and is helpful in preventing hair fall. It promotes hair growth and prevents hair roots from getting damaged by free radical injury. Alpha-tocopherol is the active component of vitamin E and it is mainly located within cell membranes, preventing lipid peroxidation and the formation of free radicals. Deficiency of this can also lead to neurological defects, hemolysis, and posterior column defect. Treatment includes vitamin E supplementation (25–50 units/day for a week). Note: The other vitamins having antioxidant properties are vitamins A, C, and E (vitamin E is the most important). The other vitamin beneficial in the treatment of hair fall is biotin.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An anxious mother brings her 6-month-old child with concerns about not gaining weight and height. On examination, stunted growth, craniotabes, frontal bossing, and craniosynostosis are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Craniotabes (soft skull), frontal bossing, stunted growth, and craniosynostosis are clinical features of rickets. General features include failure to thrive, listlessness, protruding abdomen, proximal muscle weakness, and fractures. Head to toe-examination would include the following features: Head examination would include craniotabes, frontal bossing, delayed fontanel closure, delayed dentition, and craniosynostosis. Chest examination would reveal rachitic rosary, Harrison's sulcus, and repeated respiratory infections and atelectasis. Spinal deformities could include kyphosis, scoliosis, lordosis. Limb examination and extremities may show windswept deformity, anterior bowing of tibia, coxa vara, and enlargement of wrists and ankles. Bowings of legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu valgum) may be noted. These changes can be seen only in children of the weight-bearing age group/ toddlers. The image shows frontal bossing: The image below shows the rachitic rosary: The image below shows craniotabes:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette with the above X-ray image shows fraying and cupping of the metaphysis, suggestive of rickets. Radiological features in rickets: Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate) Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis) Splaying at metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends) Generalized rarefaction
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this deformity?
explanation: Windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg) is seen in rickets. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but characteristically seen in rickets. Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets: Enlargement of wrists and ankles Valgus or varus deformities of limbs Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur Coxa vara
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Your school friend brings his 5-year-old son to your OPD with small swellings on the chest that he had felt while giving the child a bath. On examination, you note swellings at the costochondral junctions. Which of the following conditions would be your differentials to this clinical presentation?
explanation: Swelling of the costochondral junctions is seen in all the 3 conditions mentioned above. Rachitic rosary Scorbutic rosary Beaded (rounded) in appeara nce Angulated in appearance Non-tender Tenderness on palpation (sub periosteal haemorrhage) Due to metaphyseal widening Due to epiphyseal separation Note: Tietze syndrome is the benign inflammation of the costochondral junction. Image: Given below is a photo of the chest cage with pectus excavatum. Image: The above image shows a rachitic rosary type of appearance.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 22-month-old girl presents with failure to thrive and delayed achievement of motor milestones. On examination, she seems irritable and is noted to have bowed legs, thick wrists, and dental caries. Which of the following is not a radiographic sign of this condition?
options: Increase in the width of the growth plate
explanation: The child is suffering from rickets. Subperiosteal hemorrhage is not a radiographic sign of rickets. On the contrary, it is seen in scurvy. Radiographic features of rickets: Widening of the growth plate: Decreased calcification leads to reduced bone density Fraying: The edge of the metaphysis loses its sharp border. Cupping: The edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave surface. Splaying: Weight-bearing and stress on the uncalcified bone gives rise to the widening of the metaphyseal end. Enlargement of the wrists and ankles due to the widening of the distal end of the metaphysis. Coarse trabeculation of the diaphysis Generalized rarefaction
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-year-old child from an urban slum is diagnosed with nutritional rickets. Which of the following biochemical markers can be seen in this child?
explanation: In nutritional rickets serum, alkaline phosphatase levels are increased. Biochemical findings in nutritional rickets (nutritional vitamin D deficiency): Normal or low calcium (since due to low calcium and vitamin D deficiency, PTH increases which will try to normalize the low calcium) Parathyroid hormone levels are elevated (in order to increase the serum calcium) Hypophosphatemia (because of increased parathyroid hormone [PTH]) Metabolic acidosis (secondary to PTH induced renal bicarbonate wasting)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child in your unit is admitted with alopecia, oligodontia, and features of rickets with elevated serum levels of alkaline phosphatase activity and 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D. What could be the pathology?
explanation: Alopecia and oligodontia (reduced number of teeth) with features of rickets in a child is classically seen in vitamin D-dependant rickets type 2 where the pathology is end-organ resistance (receptor hyposensitivity) to vitamin D. Rickets causes Nutritional vitamin D deficiency Secondary vitamin D deficiency Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 1 (defect in 1-alpha hydroxylase) Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 2 (end organ resistance) Chronic kidney disease Hypophosphatemic rickets X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (PHEX gene mutation) Autosomal dominant (fibroblast growth factor [FGF] resistance to endopeptidases) Oncogenous rickets (increased FGF 23) Note: Vitamin D antibodies are found in most patients of systemic sclerosis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Stoss therapy is used in the treatment of which of the following micronutrient deficiencies?
explanation: Stoss therapy is used in the treatment of vitamin D deficiency. There are 2 strategies for the administration of vitamin D: Stoss therapy: Here, 300,000-600,000 IU of vitamin D are administered orally or intramuscularly as 2 or 4 doses over 1 day. The alternative strategy is daily vitamin D with a minimum dose of 2,000 IU/day for a minimum of 3 months. Both strategies should be followed by a daily vitamin D intake of 400 IU/day if the child is < 1-year-old or 600 IU/day if the child is >1-year-old. Children must also receive adequate dietary calcium and phosphorus.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child with rickets not responding to treatment is being evaluated. Investigations show serum calcium level of 9 mg/dL, low phosphate level of 2 mg/dL, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and normal parathyroid hormone levels with normal arterial blood gas levels. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario of a child with a history of treatment-resistant rickets, normal levels of calcium (9 to 11 mg/dL), parathyroid hormone, arterial blood gas (ABG), with decreased phosphate (normal, 2.5 to 4.3 mg/dL), and elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase (normal, 33 to 96 U/L) is suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets. Hypophosphatemic rickets: linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets while the most common, overall is nutritional vitamin D deficiency. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on x chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased. This is also associated with impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate leading to its excess excretion. The chart attached below summarizes the evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets. Treatment-resistant rickets : Patients respond well to a combination of oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). Frequent dosing helps prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus levels because there is a rapid decline after each dose. In addition, frequent dosing decreases diarrhea, which is a complication of high-dose oral phosphorus.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A concerned mother of an infant, known case of cystic fibrosis, presents to your OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, loose stools not settling with antibiotics, and other medications. She recently stopped breastfeeding and switched to formula feeds. On examination, you find petechial rashes. Which of the following below mentioned causes
would not prompt you to suspect a deficiency of Vitamin K in this child?
explanation: Vitamin K deficiency occurs mostly in breastfed infants not in artificial milk-fed babies, as the formula milk is fortified. The use of broad-spectrum antibiotics that eliminate the intestinal vitamin K2- producing bacteria can cause vitamin K deficiency. Biliary atresia causes malabsorption of vitamin K, due to defective fat absorption. There are 3 forms of vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB) of the newborn: Early VKBD of the newborn is prevented by the administration of a single intramuscular (IM) injection of vitamin K (1 mg) at birth. Secondary to maternal intake of medications Early VKDB(classic hemorrh agic disease of the newborn) Late VKDB Onse t At birth 1 to 14 days 2 to 12 weeks Caus e Drugs that cross the placenta and interferes with Vit K fun ction eg. phenobarbital, phen ytoin, warfarin Low stores of Vitamin K at bi rth, poor transfer of Vitamin K across the placenta, Inadeq uate intake during the first fe w days of life. In breastfed babies and in th ose with malabsorption of vit amin K (cystic fibrosis, biliar y atresia)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) of vitamin D in a 4-year-old child?
explanation: In a child of age 4 years, the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) of vitamin D is 600 IU. Note: Vitamin A: 1 IU = 1 IU retinol = 0.3 mcg of Retinol Equivalents (RE) Vitamin C: 1 IU = 50 mcg of ascorbic acid Vitamin D: 1 IU = 0.025 mcg cholecalcifero
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Rickets in an infant presents as all except
explanation: Bowing of legs is not a feature of rickets in infants, because it appears only after weight-bearing. Thus, bow legs are a feature of rickets in toddlers. Image: Rachitic rosary (widening of the costochondral junctions) Image: Wrist X-ray image
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Which of the following is false regarding phosphatonins?
It is a phosphate-regulating factor
options: It increases the renal reabsorption of phosphate
explanation: Phosphatonin is a group of phosphate-regulating factors produced by osteocytes, and FGF 23 is the most important phosphatonin. Phosphatonin increases renal excretion (not reabsorption) of phosphate. Mechanism of phosphatonin action: Vitamin D receptor activation by 1,25 dihydroxy D (active vit D)  FGF 23 release by osteocytes  Reduces expression of sodium-phosphate transporter in proximal convoluted tubules of the kidney  Increased urinary phosphate excretion Meanwhile, phosphatonin decreases the activity of 1 alpha hydroxylase and, therefore, the production of 1,25-D as well. So, the absorption of phosphate from the intestine is also reduced. Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins & Trace Elements
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Li Jing, a young tourist boy from the Keshan district of China visits India for a novel scientific exchange program. He presents to the ER with severe breathlessness. His previous medical records give the diagnosis of congestive cardiomyopathy. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely seen in this case?
explanation: Keshan disease is due to the deficiency of selenium. It is a congestive cardiomyopathy that is caused due to dietary deficiency of selenium. Keshan is a county of China where the symptoms were noted first. The disease is also endemic to that province. The patients will mostly present with acute breathlessness, paroxysms of exacerbated attacks. Selenium is an enzyme cofactor for glutathione peroxidase, which prevents oxidative damage. Note: Kashin Beck disease is a chronic, endemic osteochondropathy due to selenium deficiency.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Anika, a 6-year-old girl good at sprint events, has been avoiding her track practices over the recent few weeks. Her mother informs that she skips her classes owing to her knee pain. Her X-ray reveals subperiosteal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette is suggestive of pseudoparalysis which is a feature of scurvy - vitamin C deficiency The subperiosteal haemorrhages in the lower limb bones can cause acute swelling and pain; the condition might mimic acute osteomyelitis or arthritis. The child refuses to walk because of the pain; hence, it is called pseudoparalysis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A four-year-old boy presents with petechiae, perifollicular haemorrhages, and swollen, bleeding gums. On examination, you identify the child to be malnourished and suspect scurvy. Which of the following is/are part of biochemical functions of the vitamin deficient in this condition?
explanation: Scurvy is a deficiency of vitamin C. The correct answer is 1, 3, 5. Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin, which cannot be synthesized in the human body due to deficient L-gulonolactone oxidase enzyme. Breast milk contains adequate amounts of ascorbic acid, whereas the pasteurisation of animal milk at high temperature destroys vitamin C. Functions of Vitamin C / Ascorbic Acid : Synthesis of collagen (Hydroxylation of proline, which is vital for collagen; in the formation of the bone matrix). Neurotransmitter metabolism (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to serotonin) Cholesterol metabolism (conversion of cholesterol to steroid hormones and bile acids) Biosynthesis of carnitine Antioxidation (electron donor) For the cellular and immunologic functions of the hematopoietic system The image below shows peri-follicular haemorrhages.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child in your unit is receiving treatment for chronic diarrhea. His diet history is remarkable for a high phytate-rich diet. His labs reveal low serum zinc. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in this child?
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chronic zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency affects both cell-mediated and humoral immunity. The cell-mediated immunity is impaired predominantly, as zinc is essential for T-cell division, maturation, and differentiation. In a child with a phytate-rich diet, a chronic deficiency of zinc and iron usually co-exist. Isolated chronic zinc deficiency can be seen in the setting of a child suffering from chronic diarrhoea, repeated pneumonia or chest infections, and congenital malabsorption disorders. Chronic zinc deficiency manifests as: Dwarfism Hypogonadism Dermatitis of extremities and around orifices T-cell immunodeficiency Diarrhoea The features of acute zinc deficiency include: Decreased growth Poor wound healing Diarrhea
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The X-ray of a 7-year-old child diagnosed with scurvy showed the white line of Frankel. This would be best described as?
options: Opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centres of ossification
explanation: Calcified cartilage at metaphysis is known as the white line of Frankel and it is seen in scurvy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The eldest child of a ragpicker from the urban slums of Bandra presents with severe lower limb pain. Examination reveals swelling of costochondral junctions. The X-ray image obtained is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette involving a neglected child (eldest usually) from a poor socio-economic background with bone pains due to subperiosteal haemorrhages and scorbutic rosary (swelling of costochondral junctions) is suggestive of scurvy. Radiological features of scurvy: Early changes The white line of Frankel on the ends of the shafts of the tibia and fibula Wimberger ring sign: Sclerotic rings around the epiphyses of the femur and tibia. Late changes Trummerfeld zone: Zones of destruction in the femur and tibia Pelkan spur at the cortical end The image sums up the X-ray features noted in scurvy. The image attached below shows a child with the scorbutic rosary.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A farmer from Hoshiarpur, Punjab rushes his 10-year-old boy to the paediatric ER. The father complained of intractable nausea and diarrhoea in the child. On examination, the child has a garlicky odour and is severely dehydrated. You notice neurologic manifestations along with nail and hair changes in the child. Which of the following mineral toxicities would you suspect?
explanation: The clinical vignette is suggestive of acute selenium toxicity. Selenium toxicity is characterised by nausea, diarrhoea, neurologic manifestations, nail and hair changes, and garlicky odour. It is commonly seen in areas where drinking water and the collated soil is extremely rich in selenium. In India, selenium toxicity is endemic to agricultural sites located in the states of Punjab and Haryana. The presentations are usually acute in nature rather than chronic. Chromium toxicity (Option - B) is commonly seen only in adults with occupational exposure. Chromium is a pulmonary irritant and the symptoms are predominantly respiratory complaints similar to bronchitis. They also cause chronic allergic dermatitis and is carcinogenic too. Molybdenum toxicity (Option C) is very rarely seen in humans. It manifests usually as acute diarrhoea. Iodine toxicity (Option D) can range from mild GI illness to chronic thyroid dysfunction varying from hyperthyroidism to papillary thyroid carcinoma.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to your OPD. The mother complains that the child refuses to feed and is not gaining adequate weight. She has recently noticed changes in her hair. On examination, the hair seems to resemble steel to wood. Labs reveal low serum copper levels. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette is suggestive of Menkes disease or Tricholipodystrophy or Steely hair disease caused by copper deficiency. It is an X■linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase■ polypeptide, leading to the disruption of copper transport in the intestine. The clinical features include: Failure to thrive (First presenting complaint) Neurological degeneration (myeloneuropathy) Infections Hair abnormalities (kinky hair with pili troti seen on a Trichogram). These infants have a characteristic cherubic appearance with a depressed nasal bridge, pudgy cheeks, ‘cupids bow’ upper lip, and doughy skin. A therapeutic trial with copper-histidinase may be helpful. Option A: De Vivo disease is a metabolic disorder due to GLUT1 deficiency. Options C and D: Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-beck disease (endemic osteochondropathy) are caused by selenium deficiency. The image attached below shows the cherubic appearance of the child with kinky hair. The subsequent picture attached shows pili troti seen under the trichogram.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The anxious mother of a 5-month-old baby informs you that the baby incessantly cries on touching or lifting. The baby is comfortable when it is made to lie down. Diet history is significant for the child being fed exclusively on cow’s milk. What could be the probable cause?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of scurvy. A child who presents with a cry on touching or lifting is usually due to subperiosteal haemorrhages. Scurvy/Barlow’s Disease is caused due to the deficiency of vitamin c, especially in children fed predominantly on heat-treated cow’s milk. High temperature destroys vitamin C. JRA - Juvenile Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) rarely presents in infancy. Rickets (Option C) presents with growth retardation or other features such as craniotabes, craniosynostosis in infancy. It is generally associated with individuals who have a milk deficient diet. Caffey’s disease (Option D) is infantile cortical hyperostosis. It usually presents at 6 months of age with painful soft tissue swelling and bone thickening. The mandible is the most common bone involved.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child is born with the following abnormality. What advice do you give to the mother, with regards to the next pregnancy?
options: 400 mcg of folic acid after confirmation of pregnancy
explanation: The given image shows spina bifida, the most common neural tube defect (NTD). 4000 mcg of folic acid periconceptionally is given to prevent NTDs in subsequent pregnancies. The normal dose of folic acid in pregnancy is 400 mcg (0.4 mg). However, the history of a previous pregnancy with an NTD raises the risk of another NTD in subsequent pregnancies. An increased dose of folic acid is thus prophylactically given during the periconceptional period to prevent NTD in the next child.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-year-old girl presented with the triad of diarrhoea, dermatitis, and delayed mental development. The child had neutral aminoaciduria and a positive Obermeyer test. Which of the following statement is false regarding the vitamin deficient in this child?
options: Carcinoid syndrome can cause secondary deficiency of this vitamin
It decreases the levels of lipoprotein (a)
Most fatal complication with high dose of this vitamin is fulminant hepatitis
explanation: The clinical vignette is suggestive of Pellagra secondary to Hartnup's disease. The vitamin deficient in this condition is niacin. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan and not tyrosine. Niacin/vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD and NADP. Its deficiency occurs in a maize-based diet (maize is deficient in tryptophan), carcinoid syndrome (all the tryptophan is converted to serotonin), and hartnup disease (defective absorption from intestine and kidney). Niacin is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein(a) levels significantly. It also results in a decrease in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL cholesterol. Niacin deficiency causes pellagra (3Ds)- Diarrhoea Dermatitis (Cassal's necklace) Dementia Finally death. Niacin toxicity manifests as: Prostaglandin mediated cutaneous flushing Glucose intolerance Fulminant hepatitis (most fatal complication) Hartnup's disease is due to impaired renal and intestinal absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids. It is characterized by a varied clinical presentation including ataxia (lack of muscle control), delayed mental development, diarrhoea and dermatitis (pellagra-like symptoms as tryptophan is a precursor of niacin). Diagnosis of niacin deficiency secondary to hartnup's disease is based on neutral aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by the Obermeyer test. Image: Casal's necklace
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in the intestinal zinc-specific transporter gene. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management. It classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk. The symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, and alopecia. Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a U■shaped or horseshoe■shaped appearance. Investigations would reveal low serum zinc. Oral zinc therapy is the treatment of choice (3 mg/kg/24 hour) Option A: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is the classical triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent pyogenic infections. No history of bleeding rules out this option. Option C: Epidermolysis bullosa presents as bullous lesions in pressure handling areas. Option D: In atopic dermatitis usually the lesions will be itchy and distributed in extensor aspects (flexural in adults).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young school-going girl, a known case of seizure disorder controlled with valproic acid, complaints of constant bullying by her classmates for her patchy hair loss. Local scalp examination reveals scaly dermatitis and hair loss with intermittent constrictions. Which of the following deficiencies is associated with this condition?
explanation: Biotin (Vitamin H or Vitamin B7) deficiency can cause alopecia, dermatitis (periorificial), and thinning of hair. It is commonly seen in individuals who are on long term valproate therapy. Scarring alopecia with islands of dense hair referred to as intermittent constrictions is classically seen in biotin deficiency.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-day-old neonate is noted to have multifocal-clonic seizures. These seizures are unresponsive to pharmacologic therapy. Which vitamin dependency is responsible for such seizures?
explanation: Pyridoxine is one of the causes of refractory seizures in the neonatal period and infancy. Pyridoxine and pyridoxal dependency disorders can cause severe seizures. These seizures, which are often multifocal clonic, usually start during the first few hours of life. It involves a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene causing a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the degradation of alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies?
explanation: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are associated with the deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Early symptoms of thiamine deficiency include peripheral neuropathy, irritability, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and proprioception. As the disease progresses, increased intracranial pressure, meningismus, and coma develop. Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment. Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
During the routine ophthalmic examination of a 6-year- old child as a part of a school health survey, you notice the following finding as shown in the image. This is characteristically associated with deficiency of

Thiamine
explanation: The given image shows corneal vascularization, which is characteristic of Riboflavin deficiency. Other features include glossitis, cheilosis, and photophobia collectively called ariboflavinosis. The image below shows Cheilosis and glossitis Fluid and Electrolyte Disorders
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the OPD by his mother with a history of passing watery stools more than 4 times in the past day. On examination, the baby is alert and on pinching his skin, it goes back quickly. The infant weighs 5.7 Kg. What is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhoea in this infant?
explanation: In an infant with diarrhoea, the initial fluid of choice is oral rehydration solution (ORS). The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag. Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes reduction of stool output, decrease in vomiting and decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of hyponatremia. Other home available fluids that can be used are salted rice water/salted yoghurt drinks, vegetable/chicken soup with salt. ReSoMal is given to severely malnourished children. In this case, since the infant’s weight is appropriate for its age ORS is given.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The amount of total body water(TBW) in a term neonate weighing 3 Kg is approximately
explanation: The amount of total body water (TBW) in a term neonate is approximately 75% of the birth weight. So, in this case, 75% of 3kg is 2.25 litres. Note - TBW is 90% in early fetal life and becomes 60% by the end of the first year and stays the same till puberty.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the clinical procedure being performed?
options: Femoral IV access for fluid transfusion
explanation: The above image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia. The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation. So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route. Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia. Insertion sites for intraosseous infusion: In the proximal tibia, 1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity Distal tibia at the junction of the medial malleolus and the shaft of the tibia Distal one-third of the femur
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 9-year-old boy who has been operated on for craniopharyngioma presents with polyuria and polydipsia. On investigation, the serum osmolality is 305 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality is 250 mOsm/kg. The atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) level is normal. What could be the cause?
options: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
explanation: The given clinical scenario with serum osmolality and urinary osmolality, after a cranial surgery, suggests a diagnosis of post-surgical central diabetes insipidus (DI). Irreversible central DI follows most cases of complete resections of craniopharyngioma. Serum osmolality of >295 mOsm/L (normal: 280-295 mOsm/L) and the urine osmolality of <300 mOsm/L (normal: 500-850mOsm/L) are suggestive of DI. A water deprivation test is done to further classify the types of DI. Option A: In postoperative patients, because of IV fluids there is an acute expansion of ECF volume. This suppresses high ADH activity and causes diuresis with normal serum osmolality. Option B: In SIADH, serum osmolality is decreased. Option D: In cerebral salt-wasting syndrome there is hypersecretion ANP and their levels are usually elevated.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All the following statements are true regarding zinc supplementation in children with diarrhoea except:
options: It leads to reduced duration, severity, and recurrence of diarrhea
It reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials
Excessive zinc can cause copper deficiency syndrome
It is given at a dose of 20 mg/day for 4 weeks
explanation: Zinc supplementation is usually given for a duration of 10 to 14 days. Age <6 months: 10 mg/day Age >6 months: 20 mg/day Zinc administration for diarrhoea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhoea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials. Excessive zinc therapy can lead to copper deficiency syndrome, hence requires the regular monitoring of plasma zinc and copper concentrations.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 5-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?
options: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop
Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher center
explanation: The child in this scenario has some degree of dehydration, since the child is restless and irritable, drinks water readily, has sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (<2 seconds) with sunken eyes. Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy and zinc supplementation according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan B. WHO IMNCI PLANS:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Which of the following is not true about reduced(low)-osmolarity oral rehydration solution
(ORS)?
options: It contains 20 mmol of potassium per litre
Citrate is provided to prevent or correct base deficit acidosis
explanation: The total osmolarity of low-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is 245 mmol/L, and it is the most commonly used ORS. Potassium is provided to replace the large potassium losses, thus preventing serious hypokalemia. Citrate corrects base-deficit acidosis. Glucose promotes the absorption of sodium and water in the small intestine.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The amount of sodium present in ReSoMal is
explanation: Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal) contains 45 mmol/L of sodium. Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and reduced activity of the sodium–potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-year-old child weighing 7 Kg, presents to the emergency with a history of vomiting and diarrhea for the last 3 days. On examination, the skin pinch over the anterior abdominal wall goes quickly to its original position. What is the interpretation of the skin pinch test in this child?
options: Skin pinch cannot be evaluated in this chil
explanation: In the given scenario, the child is malnourished, so the skin pinch cannot be evaluated. The child is of age 2 years, and the expected weight is 12 Kg. But, the weight of the child here is 7 Kg, which suggests that the child is malnourished. The child may be having edematous malnutrition (kwashiorkor), where skin may go back to the original position even in the presence of dehydration. Hence, the skin pinch is not reliable for the assessment of dehydration in this child. Reliable indicators of dehydration in the malnourished child include Eagerness to drink Cool and moist extremities Weak radial pulse Reduced urine flow
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most dangerous type of dehydration?
explanation: Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration. Hypernatremia causes movement of water from brain cells into hypertonic extracellular fluid, causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within brain. This leads to central nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis. The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causes movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, seizures, brain herniation, and even death.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through a peripheral vascular line in a neonate?
explanation: Through a peripheral vascular line, a maximum of 12.5% dextrose can be infused. The dextrose concentration greater than 12.5% has an acidic pH and can cause irritation to the peripheral veins, which can lead to thrombophlebitis. Note: Central vein lines can be used for 25% D if needed.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he’s NPO?
explanation: The daily maintenance fluid required for a child weighing 30 Kg is 1700 ml. Bodyweight method for calculating the daily maintenance fluid volume (also known as Holliday-Segar method) is used. Calculation: In the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs. So, the formula for >20 Kg is used. 1500 mL + (20 mL x weight more than 20 Kgs) Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more. Therefore, fluid required is = 1500 mL + (20 mL x 10) = 1500 mL + 200 mL = 1700 mL. Bodywei ght Fluid required per day 0–10 Kg 100 mL/Kg 11–20 K g 1000 mL + 50 mL/Kg for eac h Kg >10 Kg >20 Kg 1500 mL + 20 mL/Kg for eac h Kg >20 kg
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common type of shock in children?
explanation: Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock in children. Cardiogenic shock: cardiac pump failure due to cardiomyopathies, myocarditis or congenital heart diseases. Hypovolemic shock: loss of body fluid due to diarrhea, vomiting or hemorrhage. Obstructive shock: mechanical barrier which obstructs the cardiac outflow like pericardial tamponade, tension pneumothorax, pulmonary embolism. Septic shock: It is the combination of hypovolemic (intravascular fluid loss because of capillary leak) and cardiogenic shock (because of myocardial depression by circulating inflammatory mediators) in association with infection.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old baby was brought by his parents to the ER. The parents complained that the child had been lethargic for a few hours and unresponsive for the past 30 mins. They give a history of 4-5 episodes of vomiting in the past one day. On examination, the baby had tachycardia, tachypnea, and very slow capillary refill time. The pediatrician asks you to initiate IV fluid therapy with a 24G IV cannula. Which colour IV cannula would you use?
explanation: The color of the 24 G cannula is yellow. 24 G cannula is usually used for paediatric age group.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All of the following are causes of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, except
options: Acidosis due to intestinal bacterial overgrowth
explanation: Acidosis due to intestinal bacterial overgrowth causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis because of excessive bacterial metabolism of glucose into lactic acid. Anion gap Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulphate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. Anion gap = [Na+] ([Cl-]+[HCO3-]) Metabolic acidosis Metabolic acidosis is of two types: Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption) Renal tubular acidosis Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel) High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy) Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation) Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Rani, a 6-year-old girl, who is known to have thalassemia, presented to the emergency with weakness, chest pain, and palpitations. There is a history of recent blood transfusion. The ECG of the child shows tall and peaked T-waves and flat P-waves as shown below. What could be the cause?

Acute pericarditis
explanation: The given electrocardiograph (ECG) characteristics show tall and peaked T-waves, flat P waves and since the girl has a recent history of massive blood transfusion, the most likely diagnosis is hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia may be due to blood transfusion (stored blood has increased potassium concentration, due to the failure of the Na+-K+ ATPase pump). Causes of Hyperkalemia: Spurious laboratory value Sampling error Thrombocytosis Leucocytosis Increased intake Oral or intravenous Blood transfusions Transcellular shifts Acidosis Tumor lysis syndrome Hemolysis Decreased excretion Renal failure Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism Drugs ACE inhibitors ARB (angiotensin receptor blockers) Potassium-sparing diuretics ECG Changes of Hyperkalemia Tall and peaked T waves Increased PR interval Flattening of the P wave ST-segment depression Widening of the QRS complex Note: Tall T waves are also seen in myocardial ischemia. Option A: There will be history of fever and ECG shows diffuse ST elevation. Option B: Patient presents with features of cardiac failure and ECG shows ventricular arrhythmias. Option C: Pulmonary hypertension is a known complication of hemolytic diseases (free Hb, angiotrophic factors causing vasoconstriction) and ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). Mendelian and Non-Mendelian Disorders
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A pregnant female arrives at your hospital for her antenatal check-up. As an intern, you were required to draw her family pedigree chart while taking history. She has previously delivered full-term healthy dizygotic twins 5 years back. Which of the following symbol will you use to denote dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart?
explanation: Pedigree charts are graphical representations of a person's family tree and are useful for identifying the pattern of inheritance of genetic disorders. Thus, they are vital in the history-taking of patients, especially in pregnancy. Option B is the symbol denoting dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart. Option A denotes monozygotic twins in the pedigree chart. Option C denotes offsprings. Option D denotes consanguineous marriage.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote?
explanation: The above pedigree chart denotes an autosomal recessive pattern. In the above pedigree chart, both males and females are carriers (equally affected) which indicates an autosomal pattern. Parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes), and no affected members in other generations. 25% of the children are normal, 50% are carriers, and only 25% are affected. This indicates a a recessive pattern. Pedigree charts in various modes of inheritance:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
While volunteering at the blood donation camp, Ananya came across a case of a thalassemic infant who has an AB-positive blood group. Her father is B-positive and her mother is
A-positive. In order to understand more about donor eligibility to explain the concerned parents, she wishes to understand the inheritance pattern of ABO blood grouping. Can you help her out by choosing the correct option?
explanation: The inheritance pattern of the ABO blood grouping system is codominance. Codominance: Gene expression and mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive; in some cases, both of the alleles of a gene pair contribute to the phenotype—a condition called codominance. Examples include histocompatibility and ABO blood group antigens. Classification of genetic disorders Mendelian disorders (Classic inheritance) Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive X-linked dominant X-linked recessive Non-mendelian disorders ( Non-classic inheritance) Trinucleotide repeat mutations Fragile X syndrome Friedreich ataxia Huntington’s disease Mutations in mitochondrial genes: MELAS, MERRF Genomic imprinting Angelman syndrome Prader–Willi syndrome Silver–Russell syndrome Gonadal mosaicism Chromosomal disorders: Microdeletions: Cri du chat syndrome Down’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An MBBS student, after attending a class on genetic disorders, noticed that a particular disorder appears in three consecutive generations of his family without any sex predilection. While drawing his pedigree chart, it also struck him that phenotypically normal family members were having healthy offspring. Based on this information, he concluded the pattern of inheritance of this disorder. What is the correct pattern?
explanation: The pattern of inheritance in this genetic disorder is autosomal dominant. Points in favour: Autosomal dominant disorders have a vertical mode of transmission (individuals of two generations are affected—parent and children affected). It appears in three consecutive generations of a family without any sex predilection. An affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the deleterious gene in each pregnancy. Males and females are equally affected. Unaffected individuals do not pass on the disorder to their children.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young boy presented with a history of a genetic disorder. On further enquiry, his father and grandmother had the same disease as well. Prior to his birth, the doctor had counseled the father that there is a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to his offspring irrespective of sex. Which of the following diseases is an example of this inheritance pattern?
explanation: Autosomal dominance is the inheritance pattern seen in his question due to three-generation of affected family members with a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to the next generation irrespective of sex. Tuberous sclerosis is an example of an autosomal dominant (AD) disorder. Note: All Ehlers–Danlos syndrome types are autosomal dominant, except types V, VI, and VII. All types of osteogenesis imperfecta are autosomal dominant, except types II, III, and VII.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Aryan is the first child born to parents suffering from achondroplasia. Although he is not suffering from this condition, the parents wish to know the chances of developing achondroplasia in the second child. What is the correct response?
explanation: The chances of having an affected baby when both parents have achondroplasia (autosomal-dominant disorder) is 75%. Autosomal dominant (AD) disorders are manifested in the heterozygous state. If both of the parents are affected, the chances of having an affected baby are 75% (50% - 'Aa', and 25% - 'AA'). Note: Here, we consider both parents as 'Aa' (heterozygous) because 'AA' (homozygous) is usually fatal in the first few months of life. The odds of having an affected baby does not change with subsequent pregnancies.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old boy presented with short stature and delayed motor milestones. An x-ray showed a trident hand as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The x-ray shows short stubby fingers, with a separation between middle and ring fingers. This is called a trident hand and is seen in achondroplasia. Achondroplasia It is an autosomal-dominant chondrodysplasia and the most common condition characterized by disproportionate short stature. It is caused by mutations in the gene coding for fibroblast growth factor receptor type 3 (FGFR3). Clinical features (see image below): Short stature, extreme joint laxity, bowing of legs, macrocephaly, frontal bossing, midfacial hypoplasia, small chest, redundant skin folds, recurrent infections, cor pulmonale, and restrictive pulmonary disease Radiological features Champagne glass pelvic inlet Trident hand Shortening of tubular bones with metaphyseal flaring. Chevron deformity
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 14-year-old child presented with multiple hyperpigmented lesions of around size 15-20 mm in the trunk and extremities. Similar lesions of size 2-3 mm were found in his axillary and inguinal regions. A photograph of his eye showing a characteristic lesion is shown below.
What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The features of cafe-au-lait macules, axillary and inguinal freckling along with Lisch nodules points toward a diagnosis of neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). The multiple hyperpigmented lesions of more than 15 in the trunk and extremities are known as cafe-au-lait macules (>5mm in prepubertal, >15mm in postpubertal) and are present in 100% of NF1 cases. The lesions of around 2-3mm in the axillary and inguinal regions are known as axillary/inguinal freckling and are pathognomonic of NF1. The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patients with NF-1. Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas. Neurofibromatosis: It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome with the following types- Axillary freckling is shown in the image below- NF1 (von Recklinghausen dis ease) NF2 (Central neurofibromato sis) Mutation on chromosome17 Mutation on chromosome22 NF1 (von Recklinghausen dis NF2 (Central neurofibromato ease) sis) NF1 (von Recklinghausen dis NF2 (Central neurofibromato ease) sis) 2 or more of the following sh ould be present:6 or more caf é-au-lait spots2 or more neur ofibromas or one plexiform n euromaFreckling in the axilla ry or inguinal region2 or mor e Lisch nodulesDysplasia of t he sphenoidal and tibial bone A first degree relative with N F1Optic gliomas Predisposes to multiple tumo urs of the nervous system.Mo st commonarebilateral vestib ular schwannomas; intracran ial and spinal meningiomas, gliomas, neurofibromas, and posterior subcapsular lenticul ar opacities.Vestibular schwa nnomas are benign tumours t hat arise from the intracanali cular segment of theinferior division of the vestibulocochl ear nerve.Extracanalicular ex tension into the cerebellopon tine angle can lead to an"ice c ream cone"appearance inMR I.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1?
options: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone
explanation: In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present: Six or more café-au-lait macules Axillary or inguinal freckling Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris) Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia Optic gliomas A 1st-degree relative with NF-1
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Consider the following statements about café- au- lait macules associated with neurofibromas:
options: Statements A, C and E true, B and D false
Statements B and C true, A, D and E false
Statements B, D and E true, A and C false
Statements A and B true, C, D and E false
explanation: Statement C: The spots are scattered over the body surface, with a predilection for the trunk and extremities; sparing the face. Statement D: For diagnosis, the macules should be >5 mm in prepubertal and >15 mm in postpubertal individuals. Statement E: 6 or more spots should be present for the clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosis Café-au-lait macules: Hallmark of neurofibromatosis, present in around 100% of the patients. 6 or more café-au-lait spots should be present for the clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosis along with other criteria. Present at birth, but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life. Note: Other diseases associated with multiple café-au-lait spots: Ataxia telangiectasia, Bloom syndrome, Fanconi's anaemia, McCune–Albright syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Maffucci syndrome, Hunter syndrome. Other neurocutaneous syndromes: Sturge–Weber syndrome: port-wine stain over the trigeminal distribution, contralateral hemiparesis, focal seizures contralateral to the side of facial capillary malformations, calcification of the cerebral cortex, mental retardation, and congenital glaucoma von Hippel–Lindau disease: retinal angiomas; cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas Ataxia telangiectasia Tuberous sclerosis Café-au-lait spots are shown in the image given below:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 9-month-old child presents with a history of a condition seen in the image below. On examination, a characteristic raised skin lesion of orange peel consistency known as shagreen patch is present in his lumbosacral region. Which one of the following is not seen in this autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome?
explanation: Optic glioma is not seen in tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis/Bourneville–Pringle Disease is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which may present during infancy with infantile spasms (as seen in the image), and has the characterisitic skin lesion known as shagreen patch. It is characterized by Vogt's triad (EPILOA), which includes Epilepsy Low intelligence (IQ) Adenoma sebaceum The most common manifestations are skin lesions such as ashleaf (hypomelanotic) macules, adenoma sebaceum, shagreen patch, confetti lesions, and periungual fibromas. Koenen's tumours (periungual fibromas) are small fleshy tumors that grow under the toe nails/finger nails. Cortical tubers and subependymal nodules are the characteristic brain lesions. Other lesions include bilateral renal angiomyolipomas, facial angiofibroma, cardiac rhabdomyoma, and retinal hamartomas. Vigabatrin is the first-line therapy for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis. Note: Drug of choice for infantile spasms: adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) Image below: Adenoma sebaceum Image below: Shagreen patch Image below: Periungual fibroma
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The first child of a normal healthy couple was diagnosed to have cystic fibrosis. The parents are anxious and wish to seek advice for future pregnancies. What is the percentage of chances for the second child to be affected?
explanation: Cystic fibrosis follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the disease has a 25% chance of affecting the offspring. If parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes): 25% chance of normal genotype 50% chance of carriers 25% chance of homozygous In autosomal recessive disorders, the disease manifests itself when the offspring has a homozygous state, which means each child has a 25% chance of being affected by the disease. Note: There are 2 alleles for this, say for example "A" = normal allele and "a" = abnormal allele. So, if each parent is phenotypically normal and their child is affected, then they are carriers, i.e., "Aa". So, each parent has a 0.5 (50%) probability of passing the affected allele to the next generation. Also, having each child is an independent event, and the chance that the child receives an abnormal allele from the father (0.5), as well as a mother (0.5), is equal to 0.5 x 0.5 = 0.25 i.e. 25%.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 29-year-old woman is homozygous for an autosomal-recessive gene and her husband is heterozygous for the same. They are planning to start a family and wish to know the outcome of their pregnancy. Which out of the following options correctly represent the percentages of the outcome?
options: No child affected, but all are carriers
explanation: If the husband is heterozygous and the wife is homozygous for an autosomal recessive gene, 50% of the children will be affected; the rest will be carriers. This is pseudo-dominant inheritance, which refers to the observation of apparent dominant (parent to child) transmission of a known autosomal-recessive disorder, or it can also mean the inheritance of a recessive trait mimics a dominant pattern. This occurs when a homozygous affected individual has a partner who is a heterozygous carrier, and their children have a 1 in 2 chance to get affected (50%).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the mode of inheritance of Menke's disease?
explanation: The mode of inheritance of Menke's disease is X-linked recessive. X-linked recessive disorders have the following features: Males are affected more commonly and more severely than females. Female carriers have a 25% risk for having an affected son, a 25% risk for a carrier daughter, and a 50% chance of having a child that does not inherit the mutated X-linked gene. The affected father will have all daughters (100%) to be carriers and unaffected sons because they pass their X chromosome to all of their daughters and their Y chromosome to all of their sons. X- linked recessive pattern of inheritance is shown in the image given below: Kinky hair disease (Menkes d isease) Wilson's disease X- linked recessive Autosomal recessive Mutation of copper-transport ing, P-type adenosine triphos phatase 7A leading tocopper deficiency Mutation of adenosine tripho sphatase 7B on chromosome 13q14 leading toexcessivecop per accumulation. Lowserum copper and cerulo plasmin levels Lowceruloplasmin levels;low serum-free copper levels andi ncreased urinary copper excr etion
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 41-year-old father of two has an X-linked genetic disorder. His daughter is a carrier for the same and his son is unaffected. His wife is healthy with no inherited disease. Which of the following is an example of this disorder?
explanation: The mode of inheritance is X- linked recessive and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an example of such a genetic disorder.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder?
explanation: Color blindness is primarily inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. The genes for color vision are located on the X chromosome. Males have a single X chromosome inherited from mothers. If the X chromosome inherited carries a mutation, males exhibit the disease. However, females become carriers of the color blindness gene and have a 50% chance of passing it on to their children. Female carriers usually are protected because of the random inactivation of one X chromosome. But there is a possibility that the mutant X chromosome remains active if the normal alleles are inactivated in some of the cells so the heterozygous female can express the disorder partially. The image shows the pattern of X-linked inheritance: In color blindness, the mechanism to appreciate one or more primary colors is either defective (anomalous) or absent (anopia). It may be congenital or acquired. Congenital color blindness can be dyschromatopsia (defective color vision of any one of the RGB colors) or achromatopsia (complete color blindness of all three RGB colors). RGB colors are red, green, and blue. Tests for color blindness include the Ishihara test, Hardy–Rand–Rittler test, and Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia?
options: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance
explanation: Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) or Louis–Bar syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. The defect in AT is in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11q22-23. The ATM gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to combined immunodeficiency (impaired immunoglobin isotype switching and association with thymic hypoplasia) and predisposition to an increased risk of lymphoreticular tumors such as lymphoma or leukemia. AT is characterized by progressive ataxia (beginning during infancy), telangiectasia (initially on bulbar conjunctiva), sinopulmonary infections, hypogonadism, sensitivity to ionizing radiation, insulin resistance, and raised alpha-fetoprotein levels.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 12-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness showing the following finding. It was found that the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. He was diagnosed with a hereditary muscular disorder. What is the mode of inheritance in this disorder?
explanation: This clinical vignette includes an image of a child with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles along with a history of inability to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is an X-linked recessive disorder. Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy: Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. X-linked recessive mutations of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21. Clinical features: Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to fibrofatty replacement of muscle Gower's sign: Patients use their arms and hands to walk up their own body from a squatting position due to the reduced strength in the proximal muscles(hip &thigh) of the lower limbs. Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle Inability to walk develops by the age of 10-14 years. Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia after anaesthesia. Death occurs by 3rd decade of life due to respiratory failure. Note: Becker's Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) vs. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) Mnemonic- BMD: Badly makes dystrophin (defective) DMD: Does not make dystrophin (absent)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Your second cousin, Prakriti, has been recently diagnosed with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Your relatives are worried and keep calling you to confirm the new information that they read on the internet. In an attempt to settle their doubts about the credibility of online resources, you inform them that all of the following are true except:
options: X- linked recessive mode of inheritance
Atopic dermatitis and eczema during infancy
explanation: IgM is decreased in Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome, not increased. It is a rare genetic immunodeficiency that keeps a child's immune system from functioning properly. It also makes it difficult for a child's bone marrow to produce platelets, making a child prone to bleeding. This syndrome is associated with decreased IgM, increased IgA, and increased IgE levels. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Mnemonic WAXTIE WA: Wiskott–Aldrich X: X-linked recessive T: Thrombocytopenia I: Infections E: Eczema
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 5-year-old girl has been diagnosed with a genetic disorder that follows a Mendelian pattern of inheritance illustrated by the pedigree chart below. Which of the following can be a likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given pedigree chart illustrates an inheritance pattern that is suggestive of an X-linked dominant disorder. Hence, hypophosphatemic rickets, which is an X-linked dominant disorder, is a likely diagnosis here. linked dominant disorders: Females are affected twice as often as males. An affected female has a 50% probability of transmitting the disorders to her son or daughter. An affected male transmits the disorder to all of his daughters and none of his sons. Some X-linked dominant conditions are lethal in a high percentage of males, e.g., incontinentia pigmenti. Other options: Lesh–Nyhan syndrome: X-linked recessive disorder affects young boys due to the deficiency o HGPRT enzyme in the purine pathway. It is marked by compulsive self-mutilation of the head and hands, together with learning difficulties and involuntary muscular movements. Fabry disease: X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease due to the deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A. Affected males have angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, acroparesthesias, and corneal-lenticular opacities. Note: Mnemonic to remember X-linked dominant disorders: Ribbons For All Children Ribbons - Rett’s syndrome/ Hypophosphatemic Rickets For - Fragile X tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) All - Alport syndrome Children - Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old girl presented with poor growth and social interaction as well as midline stereotypical movements of the hands as seen in the image below. All milestones were normal for the first 2 years. After that, the milestones delayed and her development slowed down. On examination, her gait was slightly clumsy, her speech had regressed to mere babbling and her anthropometry was below the 50th percentile. Following a battery of investigations, the diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. What is the affected gene for this condition?
explanation: The given features of poor growth & social interaction, gradual loss of speech, clumsy gait along with the characteristic hand movements point towards a likely diagnosis of Rett’s syndrome. The gene involved in Rett’s syndrome is the MeCP2 gene located on the X chromosome (Xq28 predominantly of paternal origin). Rett’s syndrome: Almost always affects girls (X- linked dominant) Development may proceed normally until 1 year of age slowing down to the extent of regression. After 1 year of age, rapid regression in language and hand skills, motor milestones, and acquired microcephaly become apparent. Clinical features can include repetitive hand wringing movements, ataxia, breathing dysfunction, bruxism, scoliosis, and profound mental retardation. Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients. Note: Rb: Retinoblastoma: 13 chromosome P53: Li–Fraumeni syndrome, Sarcomas: 17 NF1: Neurofibromatosis 1-17 NF2: Neurofibromatosis 2-22 WT1: Wilms's tumour: 11 FGFR3: Achondroplasia
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: While reviewing a junior's research manuscript on trinucleotide repeat sequences, you come across the following list of examples and spot an error. Which of the following diseases will you mark for omission?
explanation: Hereditary motor-sensory neuropathy, commonly known as Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy, is a type of X-linked dominant disorder. The rest of the options are associated with trinucleotide repeat sequences. Triple-repeat mutations (Allelic expansion disorders). Due to an increase in the number of nucleotide repeats above a certain threshold. Length of the nucleotide repeat often correlates with the severity of the disease. Anticipation: When repeat length increases from one generation to the next, disease manifestations may worsen or be observed at an earlier age. Disease Repe ats Clinical features Fragile X- syndrome CGG Mental retardation, large ear s, and jaws, macroorchidism in males Myotonic Dystrophy(chromo some 19) CTG Muscle loss, cardiac arrhyth mia,cataracts, frontal balding Huntington’s disease CAG Affective disorder Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1 CAG Progressive ataxia, dysarthria, dysmetria. Friedreich's ataxia GAA Progressive ataxia,dysarthria, hypertrophiccardiomyopathy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old child presents with previously diagnosed fragile X syndrome. As an intern posted in the department, you are asked to follow up on his cytogenetic analysis report. What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation seen in the report?
explanation: The trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with fragile X syndrome is CGG in the familial mental retardation -1 (FMR1) gene. Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions: GAA- Friedreich ataxia CAG- Huntington disease CTG- Myotonic dystrophy
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-year-old boy was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 45 and a previous report in his records show a trinucleotide repeat mutation of CGG. Which of the following is not seen in it?
explanation: In fragile-X syndrome, there would be a small nose, not large. Fragile X syndrome or Martin–Bell syndrome: Trinucleotide repeat mutation of CGG. Remember mnemonic Hello Mr. FRAGILE X Syndrome: Hello: Hyperextensible joint or high-arched palate Mr: Mitral valve prolapse F: FMR1 P deficiency (fragile X mental retardation 1 protein) - upregulates the metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR) 5 pathway and alters the expression of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) 9. R: Repeating the sequence of 3 nucleotides CGG, recurrent otitis media. A: Autism/Attention deficit–hyperactivity disorder/Anxiety G: Giant brain (macrocephaly) and giant testis (macroorchidism) I: Intellectual disability, i.e., mental retardation L: Long face with a large mandible E: Everted ear X: X-linked disorder (controversial as to whether it is X-linked dominant or recessive) The most common genetic cause of mental retardation is Down’s syndrome > Fragile X Syndrome. Sherman's paradox: Risk of expressing mental retardation in fragile X syndrome increases in later generations (anticipation). Fragile X-associated tremor or ataxia: Intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia, which may progress to parkinsonism. Note: Inhibitors of the mGluR (overexpressed in fragile X) are undergoing clinical trials. Minocycline (lowers MMP9) has resulted in short-term improvements in anxiety, mood, and the Clinical Global Impression Scale. Image: A child with affected fragile X- syndrome; note the everted ears, long face, and large mandible.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As a participant in the Indian Academy of Paediatrics quiz, you are asked to mark the type of inheritance in MELAS. The pedigree chart shown in the image below is provided to explain which family members may be affected (coloured in red). Which of the following will you choose?
explanation: The type of inheritance in MELAS is mitochondrial, which manifests as mitochondrial myopathy, encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes. Mitochondrial inheritance: Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperms contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization. Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease. 80% of mitochondrial DNA codes for mitochondrial RNA, and therefore most mitochondrial DNA mutations lead to functional problems, which may be manifested as muscle disorders. The following pedigree shows the mitochondrial inheritance pattern-
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In order to understand the topic 'Non-Mendelian disorders', you have prepared flashcards. But, while browsing through them before your viva, the order of cards have been jumbled up. Which of the following option will you choose to correctly match the phenomena with their definitions?
explanation: The phenomena are correctly matched with their definitions as follows- Genomic imprinting: Phenotypic expression of a gene depending on the parent of origin. Mosaicism: Single organism possessing more than one genetic line as the result of genetic mutation. Anticipation: Symptoms become more severe and/or appear at an earlier age as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next. Non-penetrance: A genetic trait that is present in the genome but does not manifest itself in the individual. Genomic imprinting: epigenetic process, that selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. These defects include: Beckwith- Wiedemann syndrome Silver Russell syndrome Angelman syndrome Prader Willi syndrome Note: Uniparental disomy: This refers to the situation in which two copies of a chromosome come from the same parent, instead of one from each parent. Eg., Angelman syndrome and Prader Willi syndrome. Prader–Willi syndrome AngelMan syndrome Deletions (70% cases) DeletionofPaternal genes afte r maternal gene silencing DeletionofMaternal genes aft er paternal gene silencing Uniparental disomy(UPD) (3 0%) UPD of maternal chromosom e 15 UPD of paternal chromosom e 15

question_text:
A 6-month-old presented with a genetic disorder attributed to multifactorial inheritance. This type of inheritance is most likely to play a significant role in which of the following disorder?
Achondroplasia
explanation: Multifactorial inheritance plays a significant role in the appearance of cleft lip. Multifactorial inheritance- It refers to traits that are caused by a combination of inherited, environmental, and stochastic factors. These include the following: Children (congenital malform ation) Adults Pyloric stenosisNeural tube d efectsCongenital heart defect sCongenital dislocation of the hipCleft lip and cleft palate Diabetes MellitusHypertensi onCoronary heart diseaseGou tSchizophrenia Chromosomal Disorders
