question_text: On watching the documentary 'The Secret of Our Lives: The Human Genome Project', a student reads up about the international consortium of scientists who fully deciphered the DNA of the most common chromosomal syndrome. What is this syndrome?
explanation: Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome) is the most common chromosomal syndrome. It is the second human chromosome whose DNA has been fully deciphered by the Human Genome Project. Chromosomal disorders: These may involve autosomal or sex chromosomes. Note: Most common trisomy leading to miscarriage/incompatibility with life: Trisomy 16. F body: Y chromosome (quinacrine, a fluorescence dye, binds strongly to the Y chromosome forming a bright fluorescent spot called an F body). Involving autosomes Involving sex chromosomes Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 2 1)Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18)Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)Cri du chat syndrome (5p deletion) Klinefelter’s syndrome (47, X XY)Turner syndrome (45, X0)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 39-year-old pregnant woman was found to have an abnormal nuchal translucency scan. An amniocentesis done revealed a chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21. This result most commonly occurs due to?
explanation: The chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21 is suggestive of Down’s syndrome which occurs due to nondisjunction in maternal meiosis. Non-disjunction points to the failure of the homologous chromosome to separate during the meiotic division. Down’s syndrome: Most common chromosomal disorder Incidence: 1/800 live births Mechanism: Trisomy 21 (meiotic maternal nondisjunction) (95%) Robertsonian translocation: 4% Mosaic pattern: 1% Note: Robertsonian translocations: involve 2 acrocentric chromosomes (chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22) that fuse near the centromeric region, with a subsequent loss of the short arms.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Your aunt has sent you an image of her 1-year-old son's palm using an instant messaging app. She read online that it is mostly present in genetic disorders and wishes to get your opinion. You identify it as a simian crease and prepare a list of differentials. All of the following diagnoses are correct except:
explanation: Simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is not seen in cystic fibrosis. Simian crease is seen in the following disorders: Down's syndrome Fetal alcohol syndrome Trisomy 13 Cri du chat syndrome
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A girl is born at term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery. On examination, she is noted to be hypotonic, has a protruding tongue, low set ears, an upward slant to the eyes with epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. On cardiac evaluation, what is the most common lesion expected in this syndrome?
explanation: The girl is suffering from Down’s syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion is an endocardial cushion defect. Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension. Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere) Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly Congenital heart disease Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum Protruding tongue Round face Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots Low (depressed) nasal bridge Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure) Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes Note: The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign). Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, includin acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). AML is more common during the first 3 years of life. The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia. The most common haematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM). Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people. Image: A child having features of Down’s syndrome Image: Brushfield's spots
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 41-year-old entrepreneur is excited to start her family. She has been getting a lot of unsolicited advice about the complications of pregnancy in advanced maternal age. On enquiring about such pregnancies, the doctor advised the mother to get prenatal testing done. All are findings associated with the prenatal diagnosis for Down’s syndrome except
options: Ventricular septal defect may be present
explanation: Increased umbilical flow is not seen during the prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome, instead, the flow is decreased. Reduced blood flow through the umbilical vessels and abnormal blood flow through ductus venosus (DV) in the first trimester are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down's syndrome. This decrease in blood flow causes IUGR in infants born with Down syndrome.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An elderly primigravida underwent a nuchal translucency scan at 14 weeks which was highly suggestive of Down’s syndrome. The doctor advised her to undergo a triple test and called her back at week 16. On receiving her receipt for the payment of the test, she realises that she has been billed wrongly for a component that is not included in the triple test. What is this component?
explanation: Inhibin A is not included in the triple test: Note: AFP: Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein HCG: Beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin PAPPA: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A UE3: Unconjugated estriol Test Components Triple test AFP + hCG + UE3 Quadruple test Triple test + Inhibin A Combined test(first-trimester screening) PAPPA + hCG + nuchal trans lucency Integrated test(most sensitive) Combined test + Quadruple t est

question_text: While writing your medical competitive exams, you come across the following image of karyotyping analysis in a question. You recognize this image as being highly suggestive of a particular syndrome. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The above karyotype is suggestive of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13). Clinical features of Trisomy 13/Patau syndrome (Mnemonic CMC DOCToR OPD) Cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect/atrial septal defect/patent ductus arteriosus) Microcephaly, Microphthalmia Cleft lip/palate Developmental delay Ocular hypotelorism Holoprosencephaly Thin posterior ribs (missing ribs) Renal abnormalities Polydactyly with flexed fingers Polycystic kidneys Scalp defects (aplasia cutis) Image: 37-week male with Patau syndrome demonstrating alobar holoprosencephaly with cyclopia. Facial features included a sloping forehead with a nose superior to a single central palpebral fissure.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-month-old boy presented with facial dysmorphism as well as two characteristic findings shown in the picture below. What is the condition affecting this newborn?
explanation: The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, and rocker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward’s syndrome (Trisomy 18). Clinical features of Edward’s syndrome: (Remember mnemonic: Hi Mr EDWARDS) Hypertonia Microcephaly/Micrognathia Eighteen trisomy/Elongated skull Digit overlapping with a closed fist Webbing of 2nd and 3rd toes Absent intellect (severe developmental delay)/Absent radii/ Arthrogryposis Rocker bottom feet Cardiac Disorders (ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) and kidney, death. Small lower jaw (Micrognathia), short sternum, small nipples Note: P, Patau syndrome: Trisomy 13 E, Edward's syndrome: Trisomy 18 D, Down syndrome: Trisomy 21 Alagille syndrome (AS) is an autosomal-dominant disorder associated with abnormalities of the liver (hypoplasia of hepatic duct), heart (tetralogy of Fallot), skeleton, eye, and kidneys and a characteristic facial appearance. William's syndrome is a developmental disorder that is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and cardiovascular problems.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young girl presents to you with learning disabilities. On examination, you notice a characteristic finding as shown in the picture below. Reports of her investigation scans mention horseshoe kidneys and streak gonads. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The child shows characteristic webbed neck, learning disabilities, horseshoe kidneys, and streak gonads and is diagnosed with Turner’s syndrome. Turner’s syndrome: Karyotype, 45; XO, phenotypically females Chromosomal abnormality XO is present in 60% of individuals, mosaic pattern in 40% Intelligence remains normal Important features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here) Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest Amenorrhea (primary), infertility Barr body absent Cardiac defects, Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema L: Learning disabilities Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosome material is present) Webbed neck Nipples widely spaced Horseshoe kidneys Note: The most common cardiac defect in Turner's is bicuspid aortic valve > coarctation of aorta.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Kaveri recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
explanation: Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome. Barr body Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus. Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated. The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes. Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body. Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body. Note: Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis. Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 15-year-old adolescent presents with an anti-mongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short stature, webbed neck, and undescended testis. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The adolescent presenting with antimongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short stature, webbed neck, and undescended testis is suggestive of Noonan syndrome. Although the webbed neck is a feature of Turner syndrome as well, the likely diagnosis would be Noonan syndrome since the patient is male (undescended testis). Noonan syndrome: Autosomal-dominant disorder (12q) Male or female with Turner phenotype; normal karyotype. Clinical features: Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant) Pectus carinatum Hypertelorism Cryptorchidism Low levels of clotting factor 11 and 12 Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia) Moderate mental retardation in 25% Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy Atrial Septal Defect Coarctation of aorta Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus: similarities with Turner syndrome Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty. Difference between Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome: Noonan syndrome Turner syndrome Normal karyotype(46XX/46X Y) 45, X0(60%) Most common heart disease: Valvular pulmonary stenosis Most common heart disease: Bicuspid aortic valve 25% have mental retardation Mental retardation rare Noonan syndrome Turner syndrome Noonan syndrome Turner syndrome Genitourinary:Female: Fertil e, delayed pubertyMale: Infer tile due to cryptorchidism Genitourinary:Female: Inferti le, streak ovariesNo males

question_text: A concerned pregnant woman underwent karyotyping which was highly suggestive of a particular syndrome. The image of her results is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is associated with patients with the given karyotype?
explanation: The above karyotype - 47, XXY, is suggestive of Klinefelter’s syndrome, in which gynecomastia and long thin limbs are seen. Klinefelter’s syndrome: Most common sex aneuploidy in males Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division) Clinical features: Disproportionately long arms and legs Mitral valve prolapse Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80 Minor developmental and learning disabilities Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production) Gynecomastia Higher risk of breast carcinoma Testicular dysgenesis Infertility/ azoospermia Note: A variant of Klinefelter’s syndrome—49, XXXXY—presents with short stature.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A newborn with previously diagnosed Cri-du-chat syndrome presented to the hospital. Which of the following is not observed in this condition?
explanation: Hypotonia is seen in cri-du-chat syndrome, not hypertonia. Cri-du-chat syndrome occurs due to the deletion of chromosome 5p. Main features: Hypotonia Characteristic shrill cry (cat-like cry) in the first few weeks of life Microcephaly Hypertelorism Bilateral epicanthic folds High-arched palate Wide and flat nasal bridge Intellectual disability Note: Cat-bite infection is caused by Pasteurella multocida. Tomcat urine odor is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiencies.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A senior asks you to read about an autosomal dominant condition known as Treacher- Collins syndrome. While browsing through numerous journals to learn about the topic, you come across a doubt about its features. Which of the following is not associated with this syndrome?
explanation: Intelligence is not affected in Treacher–Collins syndrome (like in Turners syndrome). Treacher–Collins syndrome/Franceschetti syndrome Autosomal dominant Facial appearance: downward sloping palpebral fissures, colobomas and drooping of the lower eyelids, sunken cheekbones, deformed pinnae, atypical hair growth extending towards cheeks Facial clefts, malformed ears, deafness Hypoplastic mandible Image: Treacher–Collins syndrome; note the sunken cheekbones, abnormality of ears, and hypoplastic mandible

question_text: All of the following are seen in a 5-month-old child with Pierre- Robin syndrome except?
explanation: Coloboma iris is not a feature of Pierre–Robin syndrome. Features of Pierre–Robin syndrome- Micrognathia accompanied by a high-arched or cleft palate Tongue normal size; the floor of the mouth is foreshortened Retrognathia: retracted mandible Glossoptosis/Retroglossoptosis: tongue appears to fall into the throat (retraction of the tongue) Of the children with Pierre–Robin syndrome, 30–50% have Stickler syndrome. Features include prominent joints, arthritis, hypotonia, hypermobile joints, mitral valve prolapse, hearing loss, and ocular problems (myopia, glaucoma, cataracts, retinal detachment). question_text: Shantanu, an avid reader, and a first-year resident, recently finished Joseph Heller's famous novel 'Catch-22'. While discussing the book with his friend, he realized that the title was an acronym of a chromosomal disorder they had studied. Which of the following is the least likely feature of this disorder?
explanation: DiGeorge syndrome, also known as Catch-22 syndrome, is associated with cardiac anomalies and not cranial anomalies. question_text: Riya was found to have a height of more than 95 percentile for her age and an arm-span to height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers. An image of her hands showing two characteristic signs is provided below. What other complications can be expected in this child?
explanation: The given features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the lens is a known complication. Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S) Mitral valve prolapse Myopia due to upward dislocation of the lens (bilateral ectopic lentis) Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation Retinal detachment Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved) Flat feet Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax) Nearsightedness Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea The image given below shows the Steinberg (thumb) sign:

question_text: Venkatesh decided to present a rare case report of maternal disomy of chromosome 15 at a scientific conference. He collected the following image representing the disorder's features. What is this disorder?
explanation: Maternal disomy of chromosome 15 is seen in Prader–Willi syndrome. The image shows the characteristic features of truncal obesity, short stature, and small hands and feet. Uniparental disomy: Offspring receives both copies of a chromosome from 1 parent and no copies from the other parent. question_text: Triangular facies is indicative of which of the following diagnosis?
explanation: Triangular facies is indicative of Russell–Silver syndrome. Russell–Silver syndrome: Clinical features: Short stature, triangular face (small jaw and pointed chin), microcephaly, limb and facial asymmetry, 5th finger clinodactyly. A few cases are due to genomic imprinting disorder involving chromosome 11. Note: Triangular facies is also seen in Alagille syndrome. The image given below shows a child with Russell–Silver syndrome.

question_text: During an intersectoral collaborative event, an award-winning geneticist from the National Human Genome Research Institute is invited for an endowment oration. He presents his lecture on an experimental form of treatment that uses the transfer of genetic material to cure diseases known as 'Gene Therapy'. Which of the following techniques does he mention for this therapy?
explanation: Electroporation is used in gene therapy. Gene therapy is a technique that uses genes to treat or prevent disease through the delivery of DNA into a patient's cell by using recombinant viruses/naked DNA/DNA complexes. The methods used include intranuclear injection, electroporation, gene-gun, sonoporation, and magnetofection. Gene therapy was first used for severe combined immunodeficiency disorder (SCID), which is due to adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The following is the finding noted in a 12-month-old baby who is growing well and developing normally since birth. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this finding?
options: Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy should be suspected
Chromosomal analysis should be done to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities
explanation: The picture depicts a Simian crease – a single transverse palmar crease. It is a normal finding in about 3% of the population. In a child with simian crease and normal growth and development, reassurance should be provided. A simian crease is one of the findings of Down's syndrome however presence of only this findin should not lead to a diagnosis of Down's syndrome. Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy does not lead to this finding. However, maternal alcohol intake can be associated with this condition. Chromosomal analysis in an otherwise well child is not indicated.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) is particularly useful in the modern era of diagnosis in clinical genetics. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this test?
Useful in screening for aneuploidies
options: Evaluates maternal blood for fetal abnormalities
Positive test need confirmation by invasive testin
explanation: Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) has a high negative predictive value. NIPS: Useful in screening high-risk pregnancies for aneuploidies. Done after 10 weeks of gestation. Evaluates maternal blood for screening. Positive tests need confirmation by invasive testing (like amniocentesis, chorionic villous sampling). Metabolic Disorders of Amino Acids
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother reports to the OPD with the complaint that her child smells funny. On examination, you notice that the child has a global developmental delay and smells mousy. What is your probable diagnosis?
explanation: Mousy odor is characteristically seen in phenylketonuria due to excess phenylacetate (phenyl ketone) formed in the body. In the absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase, phenylalanine enters into alternate metabolic pathways which result in the formation of phenyl lactate, phenylacetate, and phenylacetylglutamine.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A boy who attends school is sent to the principal's office as he often distracts others by rhythmically rocking back and forth on his seat. His mother worried about his behavior brings him to you. She also gives you a history of seizures. On examination, you notice he has blonde hair, fair skin, microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, and growth retardation. His urine changes its color transiently to blue-green on the addition of 1ml ferric chloride solution. What is the cause of CNS symptoms in this child?
explanation: The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue. High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barrier causing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine and tryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis. Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growth retardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density and osteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages. Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) that are excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNS damage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition. Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause is hyperphenylalaninemia. Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include: Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated Enzyme studie Genetic mutation studie Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant with severe vomiting who was misdiagnosed as a case of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is being screened for metabolic disorders. Screening reveals hyperphenylalaninemia. On ordering an enzyme study, you would include all of the following enzymes except:
explanation: Defects of either phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4) can cause hyperphenylalaninemias. PAH deficiency is diagnosed as phenylketonuria. Malignant hyperphenylalaninemias include three enzyme defects, dihydropteridine reductase,pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthase, and GTP cyclohydrolase which help in BH4 synthesis. The deficiency of BH4 impairs three hydroxylase(phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan), and severe neurological symptoms develop because of the lack of neurotransmitters. Dihydropteroate synthase is present only in bacteria and this makes it a useful target for sulfonamide antibiotics, which compete with the PABA precursor.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As a physician treating a 2-month-old baby with phenylketonuria what will be your mainstay of treatment?
explanation: A low-phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of treatment of PKU. The goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain. Because phenylalanine is not synthesized endogenously, small amounts of phenylalanine should be added to the diet to prevent phenylalanine deficiency. Dietary deficiency of this amino acid is manifested by lethargy, failure to thrive, anorexia, anemia, rashes, diarrhea, and even death; moreover, tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid in this disorder and its adequate intake must be ensured. Sapropterin dihydrochloride , a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients with residual PAH activity, is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to reduce phenylalanine levels in PKU.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant born out of a second-degree consanguineous marriage presents with jaundice, irritability, and vomiting. His mother gives a history of fever for the past 4 days. On examination, petechiae are present, he has hepatomegaly and extensor hypertonia of the neck and trunk. Labs reveal elevated serum transaminases, hypophosphatemia, and elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which of the following enzymes is deficient?
explanation: The clinical vignette describes a case of Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 is caused by the deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAAH). Elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine are diagnostic for tyrosinemia type I. Liver(jaundice, acute hepatic crisis, elevated serum transaminases), kidney(hypophosphatemia), and nerve damage(extensor hypertonia of neck and trunk) are caused by metabolites of tyrosine degradation, especially fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, and is usually precipitated by minor infections. A diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine can slow but does not halt the progression of the condition. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC), which inhibits 4-HPPD and reduces the flux of tyrosine metabolites to FAH, thus decreasing the production of the offending compounds, fumarylacetoacetate, and succinylacetone.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A father while changing his child's diaper observes a boiled cabbage odor emanating from it. Curious about the smell, he calls you. As a pediatrician, you investigate the child thoroughly and conclude that the child is suffering from Type 1 Tyrosinemia. As the child grows all of the following complications can occur except:
explanation: Corneal ulceration is not a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1. In fact, ocular manifestations are a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 which presumably occur due to tyrosine deposition. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Features of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (hepatorenal tyrosinemia): An acute hepatic crisis commonly heralds the onset of disease, which may progress to liver failure, hepatocellular carcinoma, and death. Episodes of acute peripheral neuropathy resembling porphyrias often triggered by a minor infection, such crisis can be associated with paralytic ileu Renal involvement, which is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and vitamin D–resistant ricket The treatment of choice for HT Type 1 is nitisinone, which blocks early steps in the tyrosine degradation pathway and limits the formation of toxic tyrosine metabolites. Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-year-old girl presented with photophobia and speech delay. On examination, she had bilateral herpetiform corneal ulcers and painful hyperkeratotic plaques on the palms and soles. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability are seen in hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (Richner–Hanhart syndrome/ oculocutaneous tyrosinemia) Treatment with a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine aiming to achieve plasma tyrosine levels <500 µmol/L improves skin and eye manifestations. The image below shows herpetiform corneal ulcer:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child who was being evaluated for hypertyrosinemia is diagnosed with Richner-Hanhart syndrome. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the likely cause of hypertyrosinemia in this patient?
explanation: Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase. It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability.Untreated patients have marked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal, as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 15-month-old baby who presented with seizures and self-injurious behavior has increased plasma tyrosine levels. Urine metabolic screening reveals the presence of
4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenyl acetic acids. Which of the following in-born errors of metabolism is the child suffering from?
explanation: Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditary tyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases in plasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 µmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine. Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening for hypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent. Note: Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasma tyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturity of 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding, and decreased motor activity. Hypertyrosinemia usually resolves spontaneously in the first 2 months of life. Treatment includes a low protein diet and vitamin C.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 4-month-old infant who was started on a high-protein diet after weaning from breastfeeding developed severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and an unusual swimming pool odor. A history of similar illness was noticed in his siblings and his father. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette and the characteristic swimming pool odor describe Hawkinsinuria. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD. In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal. Affected individuals excrete hawkinsin (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid), and its metabolites. Treatment consists of a low-protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged. A trial with large doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hour) is also recommended.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The following findings in an 18-year-old are characterized by a deficiency of
explanation: The following condition is characterized by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. The image represents ochronosis: Bluish-black pigmentation of the ear cartilage and/or sclera due to deposits of accumulated homogentisic acid. This is characteristically seen in alkaptonuria. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed, which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues. Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consist of ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening of the urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pigmentation of the face and severe backache and stiffness. The X-Ray image of the spine is as shown. Her urine color changes to brownish-black on standing. Which of the following drugs can be used in her treatment?
explanation: The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the face and urine turning brownish-black on standing are associated with alkaptonuria. X-ray shows calcification of intervertebral discs called ochronotic spondyloarthropathy also seen in alkaptonuria. Nitisinone can be used in the treatment of alkaptonuria. Nitisinone, formerly known as NTBC, inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD) (early step in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and efficiently reduces homogentisic acid production in alkaptonuria. Treatment of arthritis is symptomatic. In presymptomatic individuals, treatment using a combination of nitisinone with phenylalanine and a tyrosine restricted diet can be tried. The patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing as shown below in the image:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-year-old boy presented with right-sided weakness and deviation of angle of mouth to the left is diagnosed to have a metabolic disorder. Diffusion-weighted MRI reveals diffusion restriction along the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following defects can be responsible for the boy's condition?
explanation: The clinical vignette describes a thrombotic stroke in the left MCA territory. Elevated levels of serum homocysteine lead to a hypercoagulable state. Homocystinuria is caused by the following: Cystathionine -Synthase deficiency: This is classic homocystinuria. The most common inborn error of methionine metabolism. Defects in methylcobalamin formation: Methylcobalamin is the cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. Deficiency of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: This enzyme reduces 5,10 methylenetetrahydrofolate to form 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which provides the methyl group needed for remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. Pyridoxine deficiency: B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine -synthase Metabolic disorders which can cause stroke include: Homocystinuria MELAS (metabolic encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) Leigh syndrome Fabry's disease Propionic acidemia Glutaric aciduria Vitamin C deficiency increases the risk of hemorrhagic stroke.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-month-old boy presented with lethargy, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. On investigation, he had elevated levels of homocysteine in blood and homocystinuria. As the child grows, which of the following features is least likely to develop?
explanation: The above findings support a diagnosis of homocystinuria. Short stature is not a manifestation of homocystinuria. Manifestations of homocystinuria: Ectopia lentis - downward and inward subluxation (inferonasal). Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorder Thromboembolic episodes like stroke and MI Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin, (NOT short) with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 16-year-old boy with frequent episodes of photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and depression is diagnosed to have a metabolic disorder. Metabolism of which of the following amino acids is affected?
explanation: Pellagra-like symptoms- photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and episodic depression are seen in the deficiency of tryptophan. Niacin is not strictly a vitamin, since it can be synthesized in the body from the essential amino acid tryptophan; deficiency of tryptophan causes pellagra-like symptoms. Treatment with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide (50-300 mg/24 hr) and a high protein diet results in a favorable response in symptomatic patients with Hartnup disease. The image below shows Casal's necklace, a lesion seen around the neck which is caused due to the deficiency of niacin or nicotinic acid.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding Hartnup disease?
options: Defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic amino acids, including tryptophan, i een
Defect in the B0AT1 protein occurs in the intestine and renal tubule
Pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patient
Treatment is with supplementation of tryptophan
explanation: The treatment of Hartnup disease is not with the supplementation of tryptophan. Hartnup disease It is caused by a defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic (neutral) amino acids, including tryptophan, by the intestinal mucosa and renal tubules. There is a defect in B0AT1 protein in the intestine/ renal tubules or both, which is caused by a mutation in SLC6A19. Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor for nicotinic acid (niacin) and serotonin. Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss cause reduced availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis in affected individuals. A pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients, and some patients may have intermittent ataxia. Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by Obermeyer test. Treatment is with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant with poor feeding is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Further evaluation reveals hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In this case, hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. This is seen in organic aciduria. Organic acidemias most commonly present in infancy with poor feeding, vomiting, hypotonia, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, seizures. Organic acid accumulation inhibits gluconeogenesis and inhibits the urea cycle leading to hyperammonemia. Common organic acidurias: Methylmalonic aciduria Propionic aciduria Isovaleric aciduria Maple syrup urine disease Glutaric aciduria type I Multiple carboxylase deficiency
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-day-old male infant presented with poor feeding, and recurrent generalized convulsions. On examination, the pediatrician notices repetitive movements of the extremities –appears to be boxing and bicycling and a peculiar burnt sugar odor was present in urine. What is the deficient enzyme in this condition?
explanation: The diagnosis is maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) which is due to deficiency of branched-chain -ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH). Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino acids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate as a coenzyme. Leucine is metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to -ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to the disrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine, alanine, and aspartate). -Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation and result in cerebral lactic acidosis. Collectively, these processes are detrimental to the normal function of neurons and glia, clinically manifesting as encephalopathy and brain edema and referred to as leucinosis. Treatment options include hemodialysis, restricting dietary substances, thiamine for milder forms, and orthotopic liver transplant.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
While doing your morning rounds in the pediatrics department, you notice a peculiar rancid cheese odor emanating from a six-month-old girl who was admitted for respiratory distress. Second-degree consanguinity was documented between the parents. Urine organic acid analysis by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry showed marked excretion of
3-hydroxybutyric acid along with moderate excretion of 3- hydroxy-isovaleric acid. What is the most likely condition is she suffering from?
explanation: The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of isovaleric acidemia. Sweaty-feet odor or rancid cheese odor may be present. Isovaleric acidemia is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase, which affects the breakdown pathway of leucine leading to the accumulation of intermediates.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother brings her 3-year-old boy with the complaints that her child's urine smells like her tomcat's urine. She also gives a history of generalized seizures and perioral desquamating lesions. On examination, the child has global developmental delay and diffuse thinning of the scalp. Investigations reveal multiple carboxylase deficiency. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: Biotin is the treatment of choice for multiple carboxylase deficiency. Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism. Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency. Neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents in the first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting. Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow but progressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia, ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus. Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacological doses of biotin. It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans: Pyruvate carboxylase Acetyl CoA carboxylase Propionyl CoA carboxylase 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase Note: Acquired deficiency of biotin may occur in infants receiving total parenteral nutrition without added biotin, in patients with prolonged use of antiepileptic drugs (phenobarbital, phenytoin, primidone, carbamazepine), and in children with short bowel syndrome or chronic diarrhea who are receiving formulas low in biotin. Excessive ingestion of raw eggs may also cause biotin deficiency because the protein avidin in egg white binds biotin, decreasing its absorption. Infants with a biotin deficiency may develop dermatitis, alopecia, and candidal skin infections. This condition readily responds to treatment with oral biotin.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common acquired cause of increased plasma tyrosine levels?
explanation: Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasma tyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturity of 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding, and decreased motor activity. Treatment includes low protein diet and vitamin C. Options A and B, i.e., hepatorenal tyrosinemia and oculocutaneous tyrosinemia, are hereditary causes of increased tyrosine levels. Option C: Tyrosine levels are normal in alkaptonuria.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Richner-Hanhart syndrome is .
explanation: Richner–Hanhart syndrome is hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous tyrosinemia). It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase. It is characterized by ocular manifestations, skin lesions, and mild to moderate intellectual disability in ~50% of the patients. It is diagnosed by an assay of plasma tyrosine concentration. Treatment includes a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In phenylketonuria, which of the following phenyl ketones is excreted in urine?
explanation: In phenylketonuria, phenylpyruvate is excreted in the urine. In phenylketonuria (PKU), excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones, namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine, giving rise to the term phenylketonuria (PKU). Acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate are keto-acids but are not phenyl ketones. These are not excreted in phenylketonuria.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor.
Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette is in favor of tyrosinemia. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A neonate born out of a second-degree consanguineous marriage is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. He can present with all of the following except:
explanation: Irritability and incessant crying are not classical features of inborn errors of metabolism (IEM). Clinical clues suggesting IEM in a neonate are: Unexpected deterioration after a normal initial period. Nonspecific, unexplained features such as poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, hypotonia, failure to thrive, respiratory abnormalities, apnea, bradycardia, and hypothermia. Family history of similar illnesses, unexplained sibling deaths, or progressive neurological disease. Parental consanguinity: Most acutely presenting metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Oculocutaneous albinism
explanation: The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU). Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria: Mental retardation Failure to walk or talk Seizure Hyperactivity Tremor Microcephaly Failure to grow Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes) Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include: Strabismu Photophobia Nystagmu Impaired vision or blindne Astigmatism Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen. Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle, Complex Molecules, and Carbohydrates
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-day-old child is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Further evaluation reveals elevated blood ammonia in the presence of normal blood pH and bicarbonate levels. There are no ketone bodies in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In this case, hyperammonemia is +ve; acidosis is -ve; and ketosis is -ve: This is consistent with the urea cycle defect.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young infant started seizing in his cradle. He was immediately rushed to the casualty. On investigation, blood ammonia was markedly elevated. Which of the following is used to lower the ammonia levels?
explanation: All of the above agents are used in the treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant. Treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant: Provide adequate calories, fluid, and electrolytes intravenously. Minimal amounts of protein as a mixture of essential amino acids during the first 24 hours of therapy. Give priming doses of the following compounds: Sodium benzoate, Sodium phenylacetate, Arginine hydrochloride. Initiate peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis if the above treatment fails to produce an appreciable decrease in plasma ammonia levels. Benzoate forms hippurate with endogenous glycine in the liver. Each mole of benzoate removes 1 mole of ammonia as glycine. Phenylacetate conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is readily excreted in the urine. One mole of phenylacetate removes 2 moles of ammonia as glutamine from the body. Arginine administration supplies the urea cycle with ornithine. It is effective in all patients, except those with arginase deficiency. Note: Phenylbutyrate which is metabolized to phenylacetate in our body can also be used as it scavenges nitrogen.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant's mother is distressed that her baby refuses her feeds and starts vomiting immediately when fed and becomes lethargic. After thorough investigations, the baby is diagnosed with HHH syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be found?
explanation: Hyperuricemia is not a component of HHH syndrome HHH syndrome is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder caused by a defect in the transport system of ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria (deficiency of ornithine permease/translocase), resulting in the accumulation of ornithine in the cytosol leading to hyperornithinemia and a deficiency of this amino acid in mitochondria results in the disruption of the urea cycle and hyperammonemia. Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine, which can become a substrate for the OTC reaction when ornithine is deficient. Components of HHH syndrome: Hyperammonemia Hyperornithinemia Homocitrullinemia
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As a geneticist studying the familial inheritance of porphyrias, which of the following is likely to show the inheritance pattern given below?
explanation: The given pedigree chart shows X-linked dominant inheritance. X-linked protoporphyria is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. All porphyrias are autosomal dominant except the following : Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP) (autosomal recessive) -Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ADP) (autosomal recessive) Protoporphyria - X-linked protoporphyria (X-linked dominant) Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) (autosomal recessive)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common porphyria which manifests in childhood is
explanation: Erythropoietic protoporphyria (autosomal recessive) is the most common porphyria to manifest in childhood. Porphyria cutanea tarda (option A) manifests in adults. Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (option B) also known as Günther disease presents itself in utero or in infancy. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disease. Hereditary coproporphyria (option D) presents itself in the post-pubertal age.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is also known as plumboporphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning?
explanation: -Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is also called plumboporphyria/Doss porphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, although it is not related to lead exposure. ALAD catalyzes the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole porphobilinogen (PBG). The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-binding protein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it. Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs and symptoms. Symptoms resemble those of other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks of abdominal pain and neuropathy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 16-year-old girl was admitted for severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. She developed generalized seizures in the hospital for which she was given phenytoin. Her symptoms worsened, she developed muscle weakness which progressed to quadriparesis.
Urinary porphobilinogen was found to be high. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is acute intermittent porphyria which presents as a neurovisceral syndrome with no cutaneous manifestations and no phototoxicity. Acute Intermittent Porphyria: Autosomal dominant Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase Presents at post-pubertal age Present with hepatic and neurologic manifestations Exacerbated by P450 inducing drugs like phenytoin, progesterone and dietary restriction
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: çou are reading an article titled, ' Dark age vampires or our patients', which describes an 18-year-old man who has had an intolerance to sunshine since the age of 6. When playing cricket he suffered intense burning, redness, swelling, and crusting of knees unprotected by shorts, with similar changes on cheeks and bridge of the nose. His labs showed elevated concentrations of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies can explain this boy's condition?
explanation: Symptoms of cutaneous photosensitivity beginning in childhood and a substantially elevated concentration of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin supports a diagnosis of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic protoporphyria is ferrochelatase (FECH). Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposure and followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resemble angioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer. Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nail changes, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual. Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyte and plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormal liver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-month-old baby boy has coarse facial features, cloudy corneas, and gingival hypertrophy. He has no neck control and is unable to roll over. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly reduced activity of N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of I-cell disease or inclusion cell disease. It is also known as type II Mucolipidosis. It is an autosomal recessive inherited as a lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused due to a defect in N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase required for the Golgi to phosphorylate mannose residues on glycoproteins. This leads to defective mannose-6-phosphate, an important cell signaling molecule required for trafficking of the lysosomal enzyme from the site of its production in the endoplasmic reticulum to the lysosome. Due to this defect, the lysosomal enzymes are secreted out of the cell and there is an increased serum concentration of the same. Intracellularly, there are abnormal inclusion bodies and vacuolizations, thus earning the disease its name. Clinically, these patients present with symptoms either at birth or early in life with growth retardation, failure to thrive, delay of developmental milestones, coarse facial features with a cloudy cornea and gingival hypertrophy, and other non-specific findings such as hip dislocations, inguinal hernias, hepatomegaly, joint limitation, and skin changes. Investigations to establish a diagnosis may include measuring N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs or in cultured fibroblasts and estimating serum levels of lysosomal enzymes. Option B: Galactosemia is caused due to the complete absence of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate (galactose-1-P) to uridine diphosphate galactose. It is characterized by typical clinical features such as jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, poor feeding, lethargy, diarrhea, E.Coli sepsis. Infants may also have edema, ascites, full fontanelle, encephalopathy, and excessive bruising and bleeding. They tend to develop cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol. Option C: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of -oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death. Option D: Hurler syndrome is an important diagnosis in a patient presenting with clinical features given in this clinical vignette. But it is a mucopolysaccharidosis type 1-H caused due by the defect in the -L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate. It is characterized by skeletal abnormalities, hepatosplenomegaly, and severe intellectual disability. Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, a wide nasal bridge, and a flattened midface. Features such as hepatosplenomegaly, umbilical or inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex laos are also seen. They also have developmental delays and recurrent sinopulmonary diseases. Failure to thrive and growth restriction are also seen.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought with complaints of severe pain in his right thigh which has progressively worsened over the last few months. He is unable to walk because of the same. His mother also says he has had repeated nose bleeds in the last few months and the child has stopped playing with his friends as he gets easily tired for a month. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and anemia. An assay of peripheral blood leucocytes shows low levels of beta-glucosidase. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of bone pain, epistaxis, hepatosplenomegaly, and low levels of -glucosidase suggests a diagnosis of Gaucher's disease that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Gaucher's disease: It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (-glucosidase) that leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in the lysosomes of cells. It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues. There are 3 clinical subtypes, delineated by the absence or presence and progression of neurologic manifestations: type 1, or the adult, nonneuronopathic form; type 2, the infantile or acute neuronopathic form; and type 3, the juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form Typical clinical features include delayed puberty, painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, hypersplenism and pancytopenia, bleeding tendencies, bone pain due to avascular necrosis, osteoporosis, pathological fractures. Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3). Bone marrow examination usually reveals the presence of Gaucher cells (have a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance) Enzyme replacement therapy for Gaucher's disease: imiglucerase, velaglucerase alfa, taliglucerase alfa,eliglustat
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-month-old infant with progressive failure to thrive and milestone regression is being evaluated for an inborn error of metabolism. On examination, hypotonia, apathy, deafness, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy are present. Fundus examination is shown below. A liver biopsy shows foamy hepatocytes loaded with sphingomyelin. Electron microscopy reveals zebra bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical vignette along with the cherry-red spot on fundus examination suggests a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease type A- Lysosomal storage disorder due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement (hypotonia, milestone regression, apathy), marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin (hepatosplenomegaly, foamy hepatocytes, zebra bodies on EM), and progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life. In contrast, patients with Niemann-Pick disease type B have organomegaly but generally no CNS involvement.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious discharge from the nose is suggestive of Hurler's disease. It is the severe form of mucopolysaccharidoses type 1 (MPS 1), an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in -L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. The child usually presents between 6 and 24 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features (shown below), corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia. Most patients have recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Radiograph shows skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex - thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged and trabeculated diaphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphysis and epiphysis. Macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella, premature closure of lambdoid sagittal sutures, and shallow orbits are seen with disease progression. Obstructive airway disease, cardiac complications, and respiratory infections are the common causes of death. The image below shows the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges. Other options: Option B: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and renal anomalies. It is associated with an increased risk of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal cortical carcinoma. Option C: Proteus syndrome is a disturbance of cellular growth involving ectodermal and mesodermal tissues, caused by mutation in the AKT1 gene. They present with hemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous cutaneous lesions, thickening of the bone, and excessive growth of muscles. Option D: A child with untreated congenital hypothyroidism may have stunted growth, short extremities, narrow palpebral fissures, swollen eyelids, depressed nasal bridge, thick broad protruded tongue, and short and thick neck, dry and scaly skin.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A case series reviews children with lysosomal storage disorders who usually present with dysmorphic facies, organomegaly, milestones regression, and failure to thrive. Which of the following disorders does not have enzyme replacement therapy as a therapeutic option?
explanation: Enzyme replacement therapy is not available for Sanfilippo syndrome (MPS type III).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-month-old female child was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. On examination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. A muscle biopsy is performed and the findings are attached in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme that is involved in the suspected condition?
explanation: The muscle biopsy shows the presence of large vacuoles. This along with the clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Pompe's disease or type II glycogen storage disease. It is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. Clinically, the child presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure. Investigations include chest X-ray imaging which shows cardiomegaly. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 6-month-old is brought by his parents with a history of decreased weight gain. On examination, you find that the baby has hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness and atrophy, hypotonia, and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Blood tests reveal normal glucose levels.
Biopsy of the liver reveals initial stages of cirrhosis due to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with few branch points, whose structure resembles amylopectin. The clinical and laboratory results are indicative of which glycogen storage disease?
explanation: The clinical and laboratory features indicate Andersen's disease in the baby. Inability to gain weight, hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness, and accumulation of abnormal glycogen resembling amylopectin point towards the diagnosis. Andersen's disease is type IV glycogen storage disease. It is transmitted in an autosomal recessive pattern and occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme because of pathologic variants in the GBE1 gene. This leads to accumulation of of an abnormal structure of glycogen known as polyglucosan. It is characterized by Growth delay Hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points Myopathy There might be fasting intolerance and ketosis in the initial stages. Hypoglycemia usually appears late in the disease when it is associated with cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and ascites. Biopsy of the liver will show the presence of abnormal glycogen which resembles amylopectin. Amylopectin is found in plants and has very few branches. Since there is a defect in the branching of the glycogen, the abnormal glycogen appears like amylopectin. The diagnosis is confirmed by absent branching enzyme activity in skin fibroblasts, muscle, or liver and analysis of the DNA mutation. Von Gierke's disease (Option A) has features of lactic acidosis, hypoglycemia, hyperuricemia, impaired growth, and bone thinning. It occurs due to a defect in the glucose 6-phosphatase. McArdle disease (Option C) usually manifests as exercise intolerance, muscle cramping with exercise. It is usually a benign chronic condition. It occurs due to a defect in the muscle glycogen phosphorylase. Tarui disease (Option D) also presents similar to the McArdle disease. Patients may have developmental delay, and hemolytic anemia in addition to exercise-induced muscle cramps. It occurs due to a defect in the muscle phosphofructokinase.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old boy develops hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with moderate activity. On examination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed the accumulation of limit dextrins and increased glycogen deposits in the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Cori disease. Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease, Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis. Cori’s disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease in infancy and childhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common. Accumulation of limit dextrins is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 5-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency room with vomiting and poor feeding. Breastfeeding was initiated soon after birth. On examination, the child is lethargic and has hepatomegaly. Labs reveal increased plasma galactose and increased urine galactitol levels. Examination of the mother shows the presence of skin lesions on the breast with the histopathological appearance showing characteristic 'Cowdry Type A' inclusions as shown below. Choose the correct statements from those below:
explanation: The given clinical complex describes a case of classic galactosemia in the infant (increased plasma galactose and urine galactitol levels) and herpes simplex of the breast in the mother (histopathology shown in the image has large multinucleate virus-infected cells with typical eosinophilic Cowdry Type A inclusions). Galactosemia is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding and the child is at risk for E.coli sepsis. Herpes lesions on the breast are a relative contraindication to breastfeeding and she is at risk for recurrence. Deficiency of galactose-1-uridyltransferase leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol causes classic galactosemia. Infants show vomiting, diarrhea, and poor weight gain within 3-4 days of breastfeeding.Jaundice and liver dysfunction appear in the first or second week of life. Untreated children may show nuclear cataracts (oil-droplet cataract), vitreous hemorrhage, hepatic failure, cirrhosis, ascites, splenomegaly, or intellectual disability. The proximal renal tubular disease may also manifest as metabolic acidosis, galactosuria, glucosuria, and aminoaciduria. The most common cause of death is E.coli sepsis.Acute galactose toxicity is manifested by neurological symptoms Diagnosis is made by genetic or mutational analysis. There will the presence of reducing substances in the urine. Elimination of galactose from the diet along with adequate calcium supplementation reverses growth failure and renal and hepatic dysfunction.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A father has noticed that whenever his daughter drinks fruit juice she has multiple episodes of vomiting. He reports to you that his daughter is allergic to fruit juice. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is likely?
explanation: Aldolase B deficiency is likely in this child. In the given case scenario, the child becomes symptomatic after ingesting fruit juice that contains fructose; this indicates that she has hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by the deficiency of aldolase B. Deficiency of fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase (Aldolase B hereditary fructose intolerance): Fructose aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. Clinical features: Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It resembles galactosemia. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive and hepatic disease. The persistence of fructose intake can lead to liver failure, kidney failure, and death. Diagnosis: Reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test +). An assay of fructaldolase B activity in the liver gives a definitive diagnosis. Treatment: Complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet. With age, symptoms become milder even after fructose ingestion. The long-term prognosis is good. Note: The deficiency of fructokinase is not associated with any clinical manifestations. Fructosuria is an accidental finding usually made because the asymptomatic patient's urine contains a reducing substance. No treatment is necessary, and the prognosis is excellent.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: "Tomcat urine" is characteristically seen in
explanation: Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency. It is named so because of its peculiar odour.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The enzyme deficient in hereditary coproporphyria is
explanation: The enzyme deficient in hereditary coproporphyria is coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX). Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP): Autosomal-dominant hepatic porphyria is caused by the deficiency of CPOX. Acute attacks of HCP are treated as in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which includes intravenous hemin and identifying and avoiding precipitating factors. Cholestyramine may be of some value for photosensitivity occurring with liver dysfunction. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogs can be effective for the prevention of cyclic attacks.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes
explanation: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria. Other options: Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) Variegate porphyria: Deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX) X-Linked protoporphyria: Gain of function mutation of -aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS2)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A mother who is a hairstylist has noted that her baby's hair looks dull, breaks off easily, and is tufted. She brings the child to you and informs you about the past history of seizures.
Investigations reveal elevated plasma ammonia levels and argininosuccinate levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is argininosuccinic aciduria due to argininosuccinate lyase deficiency. It is accompanied by high levels of argininosuccinate levels in blood, CSF, and urine. It is also associated with friable, tufted hair known as trichorrhexis nodosa. Image showing Trichorrhexis nodosa:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Accumulation of takes place in Farber’s disease.
Lecithin
explanation: Accumulation of Ceramide is seen in Farber’s disease due to ceramidase deficiency. Clinical features of Farber’s disease : Painful joint swelling, nodules, progressive joint deformity Hoarse cry Breathing difficulty Failure to thrive Polio and AIDS
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child is found to have paralysis due to poliovirus infection. Which of the following is false regarding the paralysis seen?
options: It is an upper motor neuron type
Strenuous physical exercise during the onset exaggerates the paralysis
It can be caused by polio vaccination
explanation: Poliovirus mainly affects the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and medulla oblongata (cranial nerve nuclei), causing lower motor neuron (LMN) type of paralysis. It damages motor and autonomic nerves; sensory nerves are not involved. Poliovirus is a non-enveloped, positive-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Picornaviridae family. Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) are known. Ages 6 months to 5 years are most commonly affected. The virus is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and has an incubation period of 8-12 days. Humans are the only known reservoir for the polioviruses. The virus colonizes and replicates in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into the blood via regional lymph nodes. In blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. Most cases are subclinical. Some have minor illnesses like fever, sore throat, headache, and malaise. It can present as non-paralytic polio (aseptic meningitis) or paralytic polio (flaccid paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes). Most frequently, the completely affected muscle is the tibialis anterior. It is asymmetric paralysis which is more severe if strenuous physical exercise occurred during the onset of paralysis. Death usually occurs due to respiratory paralysis. Vaccination schedule for polio: Live attenuated: oral polio vaccine (OPV) (Sabin) at birth (day 0); then boosters at 6, 10, and 14 weeks and at 15-18 months; additional doses till 5 years Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) (Salk) given intradermally; two fractional doses at 6 and 14 weeks as well as 9 months of age.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An outbreak of paralytic polio has occurred in Nigeria. Which of the following is the most likely type to cause such outbreaks?
explanation: Most of the outbreaks of paralytic polio are caused by the type 1 virus. Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) of poliovirus are known. Poliovirus type 1 has historically been the predominant cause of poliomyelitis worldwide and continues to be transmitted in endemic areas. Most infections with poliovirus are asymptomatic. Rarely, patients can have the following presentations: Abortive poliomyelitis - a minor illness, manifested by fever, malaise, sore throat, or headache. Non-paralytic poliomyelitis - manifested by aseptic meningitis. Paralytic poliomyelitis - aseptic meningitis followed by severe back, neck, and muscle pain with rapid/gradual onset of motor weakness. It is the least common presentation of poliovirus infection. Wild poliovirus type 2 was eradicated in 1999. Until 2015, over 90% of cVDPV (circulating vaccine-derived polioviruses) cases were due to the type 2 component in OPV. Bivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) contains serotypes 1 and 3. Serotype 2 has been removed, as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of cVDPV and occasionally vaccine-associated paralytic poli (VAPP). Note: On 25 April 2016, India switched from trivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) to bivalent OPV; this day is called the National switch day.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following signs may be seen in a child with polio?
explanation: All of the above signs may be seen in a child suffering from polio. Tripod sign - When the child is asked to sit up unassisted, the child assumes the tripod posture. Kiss the knee sign - The child cannot kiss the knee due to spine stiffness. Head drop sign - A hand is placed under the patient's shoulder and the trunk is raised. Usually, the head will also raise, but in the case of poliomyelitis, the head drops backward.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You have been appointed as a member of the acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance team. What age groups would you target for surveillance?
explanation: Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance is done in children from 0-15 years. Every case of acute flaccid paralysis in any child under 15 years is to be reported promptly. Fecal samples of all these cases are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8 degree Celcius or frozen at -20 degree Celcius. This process is known as the reverse cold chain. The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis include the following: Non-polio enteroviruses West Nile virus Guillan–Barre syndrome Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: When was India declared polio-free by WHO?
explanation: India was certified polio-free on March 27, 2014. The last case of polio reported in India was in January 2011. Type 2 virus was declared eradicated in September 2015. Switch from trivalent to bivalent vaccine was done in India in April 2016.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not a component of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023 by WHO?
options: Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection
Separation of polio surveillance and vaccine preventable disease surveillance
Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)
