explanation: Integration, not separation, of polio surveillance with vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) surveillance, is a part of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023. Goals of the Polio Endgame Strategy 2019–2023 Goal One: Eradication Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV) Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection and eliminate the risk of emergence of future VDPVs Goal two: Integration Contribute to strengthening immunization and health systems to help achieve and sustain poli eradication Ensure sensitive poliovirus surveillance through integration with comprehensive vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) and communicable disease surveillance systems Prepare for and respond to future outbreaks and emergencies Goal Three: Certification & Containment Certify eradication of WPV Contain all polioviruses
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: At your vaccination center, you have noticed increased reporting of vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP). Which of the following statement is true regarding this adverse effect of the vaccine?
options: It occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine
It is more likely to occur if the first dose was parenteral inactivated polio vaccine
It Is most likely to occur if given on the same day as yellow fever vaccine
It is more likely to occur if multiple parenteral injections have been given at the same time
explanation: Vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine (OPV). VAPP is said to occur if: Acute flaccid paralysis occurred 4 to 40 days after receiving OPV, and residual weakness lasted for more than 60 days after the onset of paralysis. Isolation of vaccine-related poliovirus in any stool samples and no isolation of wild poliovirus from any stool samples. Note: VAPP: Vaccine-associated paralytic poli VDPV: Vaccine-derived polio virus. A very rare strain of polio virus, genetically changed from the original strain contained in OPV. cVDPV: circulating vaccine-derived polio virus. In areas of low vaccination coverage, a VDPV strain may revert to a form that can cause cases of paralytic polio, leading to an outbreak. This form is called a cVDPV.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
While volunteering in an orphanage that takes care of disabled kids, you notice the typical hand-knee gait of polio in a child. He walks by putting his right hand on his right lower thigh
while stepping forward. Which of the following muscle weakness is responsible for this finding?
explanation: Polio commonly affects the quadriceps, and weakness of the quadriceps leads to the buckling (bending) of the knee while walking or bearing weight on the leg. So, in order to walk, the person has to prevent the buckling of the knee by supporting with the hand, producing a hand-knee gait. Examination findings in paralytic polio: In the early stage Asymmetric motor paralysis - involvement of affected muscles is haphazard. No associated sensory loss. Commonly affects the lower limbs Most common muscle affected - Quadriceps, although it is most often partially paralyzed Most common muscle to undergo complete paralysis - Tibialis anterior The most affected muscle in the hand - Opponens pollicis Bulbar/bulbospinal polio - It is a rare but life-threatening disease affecting the motor neurons of the medulla and resulting in the involvement of the respiratory and cardiovascular centers, which may cause death. In the late-stage Weakness, wasting, and deformity of the limbs At the hip-flexion-abduction-external rotation At the knee, flexion deformity is common; in severe cases, there is triple deformity: flexion, posterior subluxation, and external rotation At the foot, the commonest deformity is equino-varus. Other deformities - equinovalgus, calcaneo-valgus, and calcaneo-varus In the upper limb: affects the shoulder and elbow, hand muscles are spared.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Serological testing of a neonate born to an HIV-infected mother turned out positive. Which of the following is the most likely route by which the newborn might have acquired the infection?
explanation: The most common cause of HIV infection in an infant is the intrapartum transmission. The mechanism of intrapartum transmission appears to be mucosal exposure to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal. The intrauterine contractions during active labor/delivery could also increase the risk of late microtransfusions. Routes of HIV transmission in an infant: Intrauterine Intrapartum - most common Breastfeeding - least common Risk factors for vertical transmission: High maternal viremia (most important) Preterm delivery (<34 weeks) Vitamin A deficiency Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours) Low birth weight Low maternal CD4 count
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are evaluating children infected with HIV in a village, where there is little awareness about HIV and its treatment. Which of the following will be the most common presenting feature in these children?
explanation: Failure to thrive is the universal finding in children with HIV. Important features in HIV-infected children include the following: Presenting features - failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea, or respiratory symptoms. Most common AIDS-defining illness (opportunistic infection) in children - Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia Most common fungal infection - oral candidiasis Recurrent and chronic bacterial infections (especially, Streptococcus pneumoniae) Most common GI disease - chronic/recurrent diarrhea with malabsorption Most common renal disease - nephrotic syndrome Most common hematological manifestation - anemia Most common neoplasms - non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma, and leiomyosarcomas
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Match the following HIV cases with their respective stages.
explanation: Correct match is: 1-a, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b. A 5-year old child with persistent diarrhea for 20 days - Stage 3 An asymptomatic 2-year-old with persistent generalized lymphadenopathy - Stage 1 A 7-year-old with recurrent oral ulcers and persistent parotid enlargement - Stage 2 A 4-year-old with HIV-associated cardiomyopathy - Stage 4
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 28-year-old woman in labor comes to the emergency department at 37 weeks gestation. She never had a prenatal checkup. The routine screening revealed she is HIV-positive. Which of the following method is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV?
options: Administration of ART prophylaxis to baby after birth
explanation: Vaginal cleansing before delivery is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV. Methods to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV include the following: Antiretroviral therapy (ART): Single-dose nevirapine at the onset of labor followed by a single dose to the newborn within 72 hours of birth. Zidovudine can also be used from the 2nd trimester onwards throughout pregnancy and for 6 weeks after birth to infancy. Breastfed infants should receive NVP for 6 weeks if the mother is receiving cART, or NVP for the duration of breastfeeding if the mother is not on therapy. Formula-fed infants in resource-limited countries should receive ZDV bid or NVP qd for 6 weeks. Elective cesarean section* Breastfeeding: Usually contraindicated, except in developing countries where breastfeeding may be continued for 6 months. *Note: Maternal cART is documented to decrease the rate of perinatal HIV-1 transmission to <2%, and <1% if the mother’s viral RNA level is <1,000 copies/mL at delivery. Thus, elective C-section at 38 weeks of gestation should be considered only for women whose viral load is >1,000 copies/ mL in late gestation, to further reduce the risk of vertical transmission. Guidelines for the use of antiretroviral drugs during C-section are as follows: For elective (planned) C-section, ART should be given prior to the operation. Women on lifelong ART should continue their standard ART regimen. In case of emergency C-section in pregnant women who are not on ART, the three-drug regimen should be started before the surgery and continued thereafter.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A patient is started on HAART treatment for HIV. Her CD4 count is 150 cells/l. She developed a fever and her symptoms worsened during her first week of treatment. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) is characterized by an increased inflammatory response to subclinical opportunistic infections after initiating retroviral therapy. Features seen are fever, worsening of opportunistic infections, new manifestations like lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates. It typically occurs within 1st few weeks of starting therapy. It commonly occurs in patients with progressive disease, or severe CD4 + T-lymphocyte depletion.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is an indication to start ART in children, as per the WHO guidelines?
options: <11 months infant of CD4 count < 1500 cells/mm3
explanation: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated in all children with HIV, regardless of clinical stage or CD4 cell count, as per the latest WHO recommendations 2016. Also, cotrimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended for infants, children, and adolescents with HIV, irrespective of their clinical and immune conditions.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother brings her 6-week old infant to your PHC for immunization. The baby was not administered the BCG vaccine as he is HIV positive. His recent CD4 counts were 13%. Which of the following vaccines should you not administer in this child?
explanation: The live attenuated oral polio vaccine (OPV) should be avoided in severely immunocompromised infants (CD4 cell percentage <15%) because of an increased risk of paralytic polio. Vaccine Recommendation Oral polio vaccine (OPV) Yes, if CD4% 15%No, if CD 4% <15% Varicella and MMR Yes, if CD4% 15%No, if CD 4% <15% Pentavalent (Hep B, DPT, Hi b) Yes Inactivated polio vaccine (IP V) Yes BCG No Live attenuated influenza vac cine (LAIV or nasal spray) No Injectable influenza vaccine ( flu shot) Yes
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the 2025 HIV targets of Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026?
options: 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health service needs met.
90% of people living with HIV recieve preventive treatment for TB
95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads.
75% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of breastfeeding
explanation: 95%(not 75%) of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of breastfeeding is part of the High level 2025 targets of Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026 High-level 2025 targets 95% of people at risk of HIV infection have access to and use appropriate, prioritized, person-centered, and effective combination prevention options. 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health service needs met. 95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads. 95% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of breastfeeding 75% of all children living with HIV have suppressed viral loads by 2023 (interim target) 95–95–95 testing and treatment targets are achieved within all subpopulations, age groups, and geographic settings, including children living with HIV. 90% of people living with HIV receive preventive treatment for TB. 90% of people living with HIV and people at risk are linked to people-centered and context-specific integrated services for other communicable diseases, noncommunicable diseases, sexual health and gender-based violence, mental health, drug and substance use, and other services they need for their overall health and wellbeing. The Strategy keeps people at the center and aims to unite countries, communities, and partners across and beyond the HIV response to take prioritized actions to accelerate progress towards the vision of zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination, and zero AIDS-related deaths. This Strategy lays out a framework for transformative action to reduce the inequalities by 2025 and to get every country and every community on track to end AIDS by 2030.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 26-year-old pregnant labourer who is HIV-positive delivers a healthy male baby. She was advised ART previously but has been non-compliant with her treatment. What is recommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
explanation: NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months. This is irrespective of the fact that the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARV prophylaxis for 6 weeks. Breast-feeding and replacement feed simultaneously (mixed feeds) in the first 6 months should not be done, as it leads to mucosal abrasions in the gut of the baby, thereby facilitating HIV entry. Breast-feeding should not be stopped abruptly. Only in situations where breastfeeding cannot be done (maternal death, severe maternal illness) or individual mother’s choice (at her own risk), then exclusive replacement feeding which is safe, sustainable, affordable and feasible can be started. In resource-rich settings/developed countries, exclusive alternative formulations are recommended.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are an intern posted in the postnatal ward of a hospital. You receive an HIV-positive patient on PND-1. Which of the following tests would you use to detect HIV in the baby?
explanation: HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR. NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18months Antibody assays (e.g., ELISA) that are commonly used for HIV testing in adults and older children are not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentally acquired maternal antibodies until 18 months after birth. For this reason, HIV virologic testing (PCR) must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA. Scheduled repeated testing is necessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure. Also, a very recent infection will not be detectable by PCR. Cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of the sample with maternal blood.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The image given below depicts the mode of infection with which of the following organisms?
explanation: The given image shows, infection through fecal oral route, colonization of the organism, and replication in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into blood via regional lymph nodes. In blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. The pathogenesis expalined above is that of polio infection. Option A: Infection with Campylobacter jejuni is implicated in the pathogenesis of Guillain–Barre syndrome, where the antibodies against C. jejuni cross-react with the gangliosides (GM1) in the peripheral nervous system. Option B: Hepatitis A infection occurs through the fecal-oral route, and the virus replicates in the GI mucosa and is then transported to the liver. Option D: Rotavirus causes diarrhea by causing malabsorption.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Kenny packs are used in the treatment of
Poliomyelitis
explanation: Kenny packs are used in the treatment of poliomyelitis. Treatment of poliomyelitis includes the following: Symptomatic and supportive treatment: Analgesics, bed rest, and physiotherapy Sister Kenny’s treatment: Hot moist packs applied to muscles to relieve pain and spasm Optimum positioning of limbs to prevent deformity Management of pure bulbar poliomyelitis consists of maintaining the airway and avoiding the risk of aspiration. Pediatric Bacterial and Parasitic Infections
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus?
explanation: Acute pharyngitis or sore throat is most commonly caused by group A Streptococcus (GAS) - not staphylococcus. Staphylococcus aureus causes localized infections like furuncle, carbuncle, bullous impetigo, pyomyositis, and folliculitis (skin and soft tissue infections). It may cause bloodstream infections if there is a breach in the skin.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Anu, a pre-school student presented with a fever and sore throat. She also had an acute onset generalized erythematous rash with pastia lines over the antecubital fossa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever. Scarlet fever is a delayed type of skin reaction to streptococcal exotoxin and occurs as a complication of streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis. There is a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash, which blanches on pressure. This gives a sandpaper quality to the skin. A characteristic physical finding in which red or pink petechial lines appear in skin creases is called Pastia's sign, Pastia lines, or Thompson's sign. The image below shows Pastia lines in the antecubital fossa.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young boy is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a rash, which appears as shown in the image, for the past 2 days. The rash started around the neck and then spread to the trunk and extremities. On examination, rash blanches on pressure. Tongue examination shows swollen papillae. Which of the following toxins is responsible for this child's condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever, which is caused by a pyrogenic exotoxin produced by Group A streptococcus (GAS). In scarlet fever, the rash appears within 24–48 hours of the onset of upper respiratory infections. It begins around the head and neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. It usually spares palms, and soles. It is a diffuse, papular, and erythematous eruption, which blanches on pressure. The cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth. The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance. The image below shows a strawberry tongue.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 7-year-old child abruptly developed symptoms suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder and Tourette syndrome. PANDAS, a pediatric neuropsychiatric disorder, is suspected. Which of the following organisms is associated with this condition?
explanation: PANDAS is associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection. PANDAS stands for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections. The symptoms usually occur abruptly and can include the following: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) Tic disorder Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (coprolalia and tics) Additionally, children may become moody or irritable, experience anxiety attacks, and/or show separation anxiety. These symptoms are the result of an autoimmune process that leads to inflammation of the basal ganglia and the resultant disruption of cortical-striatal-thalamic axis functioning. Features: Prepubertal onset Abrupt and episodic course Neurological symptoms Disorders associated: Tics, OCD Associated with a recent history of sore throat Note: Non-infectious manifestations of streptococcal infection: Rheumatic heart disease Glomerulonephritis PANDAS Guttate psoriasis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is a major criterion in the revised Jones criteria used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in high-risk populations?
explanation: Polyarthralgia is a major criterion in the revised Jones criteria used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in high-risk populations (ARF incidence >2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of >1 per 1000 population per year). Strict adherence to the Jones criteria in areas of higher prevalence may result in under-diagnosis. Therefore, the criteria are slightly modified for moderate to high-risk populations as follows: The major criterion of arthritis includes polyarthralgia or monoarthritis in addition to polyarthritis. Polyarthralgia should only be considered as a major manifestation after the exclusion of other causes. The minor criterion for joint involvement is monoarthralgia. A lower cutoff for fever is used (38°C [100.4°F] rather than 38.5°C [101.3°F]). A lower cutoff for erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is used (30 mm/hour rather than 60 mm/hour), although the C-reactive protein (CRP) cutoff is unchanged (3 mg/dL).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever and joint pain. Further questioning reveals that she had a sore throat 3 weeks back for which she did not seek medical help. Acute rheumatic fever is suspected. Which of the following is not a component of the criteria used for the diagnosis of this child's condition?
explanation: Erythema nodosum is not a component of Jones criteria which is used for acute rheumatic fever (ARF) diagnosis. Erythema marginatum is a major manifestation of the Jones criteria. It is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever. The image below shows erythema marginatum.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad?
options: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors
explanation: Hutchinson's triad refers to interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors. It is seen in late congenital syphilis. The image below shows Hutchinson incisors: Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose (depression of the nasal root) are some late findings. Other clinical features of congenital syphilis: Clutton joint - Due to synovitis, with sterile synovial fluid Juvenile tabes and paresis Rhagades - Linear scars radiating from mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, and genitalia Mulberry molars - Abnormal 1st lower molars with excessive cusps Sabre shin - Anterior bowing of the mid-portion of the tibia Olympian brow - Bony prominence of the forehead
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 1-year-old baby is brought to the paediatrician by his mother because of jaundice. On examination, the baby has hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. He has a saddle nose and persistent rhinitis as seen in the picture. The baby had been 2300g at birth. The delivery was complicated by preterm labour and a single, painless ulcer with a clean base on the mother's labia. Which of the following feature will not be seen in this baby?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital syphilis. Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia is a characteristic feature of congenital syphilis, not coombs-positive hemolytic anemia. Congenital syphilis results from transplacental transmission of Treponema pallidum or during birth by contact with infectious lesions of the mother. Clinical features of congenital syphilis: Hutchinson's triad - Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, sensorineural deafness Clutton joint - Due to synovitis, with sterile synovial fluid Juvenile tabes and paresis Rhagades - Linear scars radiating from mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, and genitalia Saddle nose - Depression of nasal bridge Mulberry molars - Abnormal 1st lower molars with excessive cusps Sabre shin - Anterior bowing of the mid-portion of the tibia Olympian brow - Bony prominence of the forehead Snuffles - Persistent rhinitis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A neonate was delivered via normal vaginal delivery. His mother was diagnosed with active tuberculosis infection during pregnancy but she refused treatment in fear of side effects to the baby. If the baby had been infected prenatally, which of the following organs is most likely to be involved?
explanation: The liver is the most commonly involved organ in congenital tuberculosis. Primary infection in a female just before or during pregnancy is more likely to cause congenital tuberculosis. Congenital transmission usually occurs from a lesion in the placenta through the umbilical vein. The tuberculous bacilli may pass through the umbilical vein and develop a hepatic focus. Tuberculosis in neonates generally presents with respiratory distress, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Note: The most common route of infection for a neonate is the postnatal airborne transmission from an adult with infectious pulmonary tuberculosis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 12-year-old boy presented with a persistent cough. There was a contact history with an active tuberculosis case in his neighborhood. His X-ray revealed prominent hilar lymphadenopathy as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is false regarding this patient's condition?
options: Puhl's lesion at the apex of lung is seen in primary infection
Most cases of pediatric TB are asymptomatic
Sputum smear-negative TB does not rule out pediatric pulmonary TB
The most common site of extrapulmonary TB is the lymph node
explanation: The patient had exposure to an active tuberculosis case and has hilar lymphadenopathy (image), suggestive of primary tuberculosis. Puhl’s lesion is chronic tuberculosis (TB) of the apex of the lung, not seen in the primary infection. The majority of children develop no signs or symptoms at any level. In primary pulmonary disease, the combination of the parenchymal pulmonary lesion and the corresponding lymph node is called Ghon’s complex or the primary complex. Asymptomatic pleural effusion is common and forms part of the primary complex. Erosion of a parenchymal focus of tuberculosis into the blood or lymphatic vessel can result in dissemination of the bacilli and a miliary pattern, with small nodules evenly distributed on the chest radiograph. Sputum smear-negative TB does not rule out pediatric pulmonary TB. Chronic pulmonary tuberculosis is common in children above 7 years of age. The commonest site is the apex of the lung—Puhl’s lesion. Regional lymph nodes are not involved. The most common site of extrapulmonary tuberculosis in children is the lymph node. NOTE: Ranke complex: Ghon's complex undergoes fibrosis and calcification. Simon focus: Hematogenous spread to the apex of the upper lobe, resulting in a post-primary infective lesion, which heals with scarring. Simmond's focus: Tuberculous focus in the liver. Weigert focus: Caseating metastatic tuberculous focus in the wall of a pulmonary vein. Rich focus: Tuberculous granuloma occurring in the cortex of the brain.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A woman with smear-positive tuberculosis is on anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). She delivered a healthy male baby at term. How is the newborn managed in this case?
options: Breastfeeding + INH for 2 months then BCG vaccine
Breastfeeding + INH for 6 months then BCG vaccine
BCG + INH for 6 months + withhold Breastfeeding
explanation: In a neonate born to a mother with smear-positive tuberculosis, breastfeeding along with INH prophylaxis for 3-6 months is recommended. BCG vaccine is recommended at birth or after completion of prophylaxis (3-6 months) in all neonates. When a child is born to a mother with active TB, the main aim is the TB-free survival of the newborn. It involves detecting active TB lesions (congenital TB) and treating them or prevention of transmission of tubercular infection to the neonate from the mother. Prophylaxis with isoniazid (3-6 months) is recommended in neonates born to mothers with TB who are infectious (smear-positive). Breastfeeding should be continued in these neonates and isolation is recommended only till the mother is infectious, has multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, or nonadherent to treatment. BCG vaccine is recommended at birth or after completion of prophylaxis (3-6 months) in all neonates. However, if the Mantoux test is positive and evidence of disease is found, ATT is started.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 25-year-old lady is detected to have active tuberculosis at 37 weeks of gestation. She delivers a baby girl 2 days later. As per NTEP guidelines, what advice is given immediately after delivery?
options: INH prophylaxis to be given to the neonate for 6 weeks
Mother is to be started on ATT
explanation: The mother with TB is advised to start ATT immediately irrespective of time of delivery. The management guidelines followed in a case of active TB in a mother immediately following delivery include: Mother has to be started on ATT. Do not separate the baby from the mother. Do not withhold breastfeeding. Screening of household contacts. Screen the neonate for congenital/active TB. In accordance with the NTEP 2020 guidelines, a newborn whose mother has active TB and is on ATT should be managed with prophylactic isoniazid (INH) for 6 months, BCG vaccination at birth, with the continuation of breastfeeding, after ruling out active TB. INH prophylaxis is given irrespective of the BCG or nutritional status. 10 mg/kg is administered daily for a minimum of six months. During monthly tablet collection, the child should be closely monitored for TB symptoms to rule out active TB and also assess for any INH-related adverse effects. BCG vaccination can be given at birth even if INH preventive therapy is planned. In case the newborn is found to have active TB, ATT is to be initiated along with the administration of BCG vaccine.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A worried couple brought their 4-day-old baby to the pediatrician due to difficulty in feeding and abnormal posture. The baby was delivered at home and the mother never had a prenatal checkup. On examination, the baby's body was rigid, with flexed upper limb and extended back. The umbilical cord was covered with cow dung. The mother says it's their tradition, and that the dirt helps with the falling off of the cord. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: The toxin responsible affects the excitatory neurons
Metronidazole is given as a treatment
It occurs in infants of unimmunized mothers
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal tetanus. It is caused by a neurotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani, which inhibits inhibitory neurons, not excitatory neurons. Clostridium tetani is a spore-forming obligate anaerobe commonly found in soil, dust, and gastrointestinal tracts of various animals. The baby's umbilical stump covered with cow dung serves as the source of infection. It also occurs in infants of unimmunized mothers. Tetanus typically manifests within 3-12 days of birth as progressive difficulty in feeding, rigidity, or spasms. Tetanus toxin binds at the neuromuscular junction and enters the motor nerve; it is then transported to the alpha-motoneuron via retrograde axonal transport. Subsequently, the toxin enters the adjacent spinal inhibitory interneurons, where it prevents the release of the neurotransmitters glycine and -aminobutyric acid. This leads to blockade of normal antagonistic muscle inhibition, while agonist muscles undergo sustained contraction without relaxing. Neonatal tetanus presents with progressive feeding difficulty (sucking and swallowing), irritability, and crying. Characteristic features include reduced movement or complete muscle paralysis, rigidity, and spasms. These features may or may not be associated with opisthotonos. Treatment includes supportive care in the form of muscle relaxants (diazepam), along with the administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and metronidazole, which is the antibiotic of choice. Parenteral penicillin G can serve as an alternate antibiotic. Excising the umbilical stump in a baby with neonatal tetanus is no longer recommended.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old unvaccinated child presents with complaints of sore throat and difficulty in swallowing. The patient also has fever and hoarseness of voice and her facial appearance is as shown below. A provisional diagnosis of Diptheria is made. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's condition?
options: It can be diagnosed by the demonstration of antibody by ELISA
Treatment of contacts is not indicated
Iron has a critical value in the production of toxins
explanation: The image shows a bull-neck appearance due to the soft tissue edema, seen in diphtheria. Iron is essential for the production of toxins in diphtheria. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Carriers are the most common causes of infection. Immunization does not prevent the carrier state. It spreads via droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites. The regulation of toxin production in the bacterium is partially controlled by iron, thus making it an important prerequisite for toxin production. Clinical features: Respiratory tract diphtheria (most common): Thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Dislodging of the membrane may cause bleeding. Underlying soft tissue edema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue edema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane. Cutaneous diphtheria is an indolent, non-progressive infection characterized by a superficial, ecthyma-like, non-healing ulcer with a gray-brown membrane. Occasionally, it causes mucocutaneous infections at other sites, such as otitis externa, purulent conjunctivitis, and vulvo-vaginitis. Diagnosis: The culture of the organism from the nose and throat swab specimens is the gold standard. Demonstration of the toxin is done by Elek's gel precipitation test. Gram stain and fluorescent antibody tests are unreliable. Complications include obstruction due to pseudomembrane, myocarditis, and polyneuropathy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A diphtheria screening camp is being held at a rural school to find carriers and to provide them adequate treatment. What is the investigation of choice in this scenario?
explanation: The investigation of choice for diphtheria carriers is throat swab culture. Specimens for culture should be obtained from the nose and throat and any other mucocutaneous lesion. A portion of the membrane should be removed and sent for culture along with the underlying exudate in those with overt disease. Direct smear using Gram stain or specific fluorescent antibody is unreliable.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Anuj has been■ diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay?
options: Nothing as the child is already exposed
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, a 3-year-old child is likely to have received the 4th dose (1st booster) of the diphtheria vaccine between 16–24 months of age according to National Immunization Schedule (i.e., 16 months ago). Since he has received a booster dose within 5 years, only erythromycin is indicated in case of close contact with the diphtheria patient. All household contacts with diphtheria patients should be closely monitored for 7 days. Culture should be taken from both the throat and nose. All contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin), regardless of immunization status. Children who have not received a booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid vaccine within 5 years should be given the vaccine in an age-appropriate form. Children who have not yet received their 4th dose should be vaccinated accordingly. If fewer than three doses of diphtheria toxoid have been given, or vaccination history is unknown, an immediate dose of diphtheria toxoid should be given and the primary series completed according to the current schedule. Asymptomatic carriers of diphtheria are treated with antimicrobial prophylaxis for a period of 10-14 days. If an individual has not received a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid within 1 year, an age-appropriate preparation of the vaccine should be administered promptly. Droplet precautions (respiratory colonization) or contact precautions (cutaneous colonization) of cases and carriers are maintained until two consecutive negative cultures (collected 24 hours apart) are obtained after cessation of therapy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and painful straining for 4 months. The symptoms were accompanied by rectal prolapse. Stool examination showed the following finding. Infection with which of the following helminths is most likely?
explanation: The image shows a barrel-shaped ovum, which along with rectal prolapse is characteristic of trichuris trichiura. Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon. They bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining causing edema, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles. This leads to loss of supports and rectal prolapse. Other clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects. Diagnosis is done by fecal smears showing the barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura. The image below shows the barrel-shaped ovum of Trichuris trichiura. Albendazole is the drug of choice (400 mg, orally, for 3 days; for all ages).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. The girl was passing loose, bulky stools for the past 4 days. This was often associated with pain in the abdomen. The pediatrician ordered stool examination, which showed the following organisms. Which vitamin deficiency is the child at the greatest risk for?
explanation: The stool examination (image) shows pear-shaped trophozoites having two nuclei and a flagellum, typical of Giardia lamblia. Giardiasis is associated with a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin A. Giardia lamblia is transmitted via contaminated drinking water. Clinical features include acute infectious diarrhea or chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and abdominal pain. Stools initially may be profuse and watery and later become greasy and foul-smelling. Stools do not contain blood, mucus, or leukocytes. It is associated with fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, iron deficiency, and growth stunting. Diagnosis is done by stool enzyme immunoassay (EIA) or direct fluorescent antibody tests for Giardia antigens; EIA is superior to microscopy. Treatment includes tinidazole and nitazoxanide.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In a child, the amoebic liver abscess can be diagnosed by demonstrating which of the following?
options: Cysts in the hepatic venous sample
explanation: The amoebic liver abscess can be diagnosed by demonstrating Trophozoites in the pus Amebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. Trophozoites are responsible for tissue invasion and destruction. Amoebic Colitis will present as colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements (6–8/day). Diarrhea is associated with tenesmus, heme-positive stool. Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa and produce flask-shaped ulcers. Amoebic liver abscess occurs in <1% infected individuals. Fever is the hallmark of amoebic liver abscess. It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention and enlargement, and tenderness of the liver. Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, can also occur. The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on USG, CT, or MRI. The image below shows a CT scan of a right lobe liver abscess. Invasive amebiasis is treated with nitroimidazoles such as metronidazole or tinidazole. This is followed by a luminal amebicide such as paromomycin.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the most common route of acquiring Ancylostoma duodenale infection?
explanation: Skin penetration is the most common route by which the larva of Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) enters the human body. Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) larvae enter the human host by skin penetration and undergo extraintestinal migration through the venous circulation to the lungs. They enter alveoli and climb up to the bronchial tree and pharynx, and are swallowed. Larvae reach the small intestine and become adult worms. Clinical manifestations include iron deficiency anemia, resulting from chronic occult intestinal blood loss. Dermatitis, sometimes referred to as ground itch, may occur when they penetrate human skin. Eosinophilic pneumonia can also be seen. Infection with a zoonotic hookworm, especially Ancylostoma braziliense, can result in the latera migration of the larvae causing cutaneous tracts of cutaneous larva migrans. The image below shows the lifecycle of the intestinal hookworm. The image given below shows cutaneous larva migrans. Treatment: Mebendazole 100 mg bid, orally, for 3 days or single dose of 500 mg Albendazole 400 mg, orally, once
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child from Bihar comes with a fever. Blood examination shows sheathed microfilaria as shown in the image. Identify the organism.
explanation: The incidence of Brugia malayi is more in children from Bihar and the image showing microfilaria with two nuclei at the tail. Hence the organism is Brugia malayi, which causes lymphatic filariasis. Brugia malayi (Malayan filariasis), Brugia timori, and Wuchereria bancrofti (bancroftian filariasis) are thread-like nematodes that cause a similar infection called Filariasis. Infective larvae are introduced into humans during sucking of blood by the mosquito vector (commonly, culex). Clinical manifestations include episodic fever, lymphangitis of an extremity, lymphadenitis (especially the inguinal and axillary areas), headaches, and myalgias. Hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy are often seen in children. These symptoms are caused by an acute inflammatory response triggered by the death of adult worms. Diagnosis is done by demonstration of microfilariae in the blood. Blood samples should be obtained between 10 pm and 2 am because microfilaremia is nocturnal. Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine 1 mg/kg PO as a single dose on day 1 1 mg/kg tid on day 2 1-2mg/kg tid on day 3 6 mg/kg/day divided tid on days 4-14 The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A boy is brought to the emergency with repeated episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. History is significant for a dietary intake of pork. MRI reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions as shown below. Which of the following organism is the likely cause for seizures in this patient?
explanation: The likely cause of seizures in a child who has multiple ring-enhancing lesions and dietary history of pork intake is an infection with Taenia solium. Children acquire the adult form of the parasite by ingestion of undercooked pork containing larvae cysts. In the intestines, the cyst converts into adult form. The adult form releases eggs in the stool. If the eggs are ingested (shed by tapeworm carriers or by unhygienic practices), the larvae are released from the eggs. The larva then invades through the intestines and migrate through the bloodstream to the muscles (and other organs), where they form tissue cysts called cysticercosis. When these larvae find their way to the brain, it is termed as neurocysticercosis. Neurocysticercosis typically presents with seizures (focal or generalized). It can be associated with basilar arachnoiditis that can present with signs of meningeal irritation. Cysticerci in the tissues may present with focal findings from the mass effect. Ocular neurocysticercosis causes decreased visual acuity because of cysticerci in the retina or vitreous, retinal detachment, or iridocyclitis. Treatment includes management of seizures. albendazole therapy (treatment of choice). Praziquantel can also be used.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding congenital toxoplasmosis?
options: It occurs through hematogenous dissemination to the placenta
Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation
It can manifests as hydrops fetalis
explanation: IgG is not diagnostic for congenital toxoplasmosis. The presence of IgG antibodies in a newborn can be due to an old infection in the mother, as IgG can cross the placenta. IgM cannot cross the placenta, hence the presence of IgM in newborns confirms the diagnosis of congenital toxoplasmosis. IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay (ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests. Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondi. Toxoplasma can be transmitted to humans by three principal routes: Ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat Ingestion of oocysts through exposure to cat litter or soi Newly infected pregnant woman passing the infection to her unborn fetus It can be acquired orally, transplacentally or rarely, parenterally or by transfusion. Congenital toxoplasmosis: When a mother acquires the infection during gestation, organisms may disseminate hematogenously to the placenta. Infection may be transmitted to the fetus transplacentally or during vaginal delivery. The characteristic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications may be present. Other clinical features include small size for gestational age, prematurity, persistent jaundice, mild thrombocytopenia, hydrops fetalis, and perinatal death.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is
explanation: Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis. The characteristic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Clinical manifestations apart from the triad include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia. Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman acquires the infection during gestation. The organism may cross to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of the disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy. The causative agent is Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan. The diagnosis is made by the detection of IgM anti-toxoplasma antibodies. IgG can cross the placenta is hence, cannot confirm infection in the infant. IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay (ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests. Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce vertical transmission. It does not cross the placenta and therefore cannot be used to treat an infected fetus. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) is used when a fetal infection is confirmed or in maternal infections after 18 weeks.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Maternal antibodies that do not provide significant immunity in a neonate:
explanation: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity to polio infection in a neonate. Administering an oral polio vaccine (OPV) dose at birth can provide early mucosal protection, safeguarding against enteric pathogens before they can hinder the intestinal mucosal immune response. Furthermore, administering OPV during the period when infants are protected by maternal antibodies may help prevent vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP). All pregnant women should receive a tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine during each pregnancy, as early in the 27–36-week-of-gestation window as possible. The maternal antibodies formed from Tdap will provide immunity against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis in the newborn. Administering the Tdap vaccine earlier, between the 27th and 36th week of gestation, maximizes the transfer of passive antibodies to the infant (options A and C). Infants less than 6 months are generally protected from measles by maternal antibodies (option D).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the daily dosage of ethambutol for an adolescent of age 14 years?
explanation: The daily dosage of ethambutol is 20 mg/kg body weight. First-line antitubercular drugs: Note: All first-line antitubercular drugs are hepatotoxic except ethambutol. All first-line antitubercular drugs are bactericidal except ethambutol, which is bacteriostatic. Drug Daily dosage(mg/k g) Adverse effects Isoniazid 10-15 Peripheral neuritis, hepatic e nzyme elevation Rifampin 15-20 Orange discoloration of secre tions andurine Ethambut ol 20 Optic neuritis,decreased red- green color discrimination Drug Daily dosage(mg/k g) Adverse effects Pyrazinam ide 30-40 Hepatotoxicity, hyperuricemi a
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Which of the following is not a component of Hutchinson's triad in congenital syphilis?
Peg-shaped upper incisor
explanation: Saber shin is not a component of Hutchinson’s triad. Saber shin is the anterior bowing of the midportion of the tibia. Note: Peg-shaped upper central incisor is called as Hutchinson's teeth (erupts during the 6th year of life). Hutchinson’s triad: It is a triad of stigmata seen characteristically in congenital syphilis. The components are as follows: Hutchinson's teeth Interstitial keratitis Sensorineural deafness Image: Hutchinson teeth (peg-shaped upper incisors) Measles, Mumps, Rubella and Other Viral Infections
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother brought her 7-year-old child to the OPD because of fever and facial swelling for the past 2 days. She says that he has been refusing to eat because of the pain near the jaw. He has not been vaccinated since birth because of his parent's fear of side effects. On examination, a tender swelling is noted on the jaw as shown in the picture. Which of the following statement is true regarding this patient's diagnosis?
options: Salivary gland involvement is limited to the parotids
Patient is not infectious prior to clinical parotid enlargement
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mumps. Meningoencephalitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. Mumps is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. It is spread from person to person via droplets from clinical and subclinical cases. The incubation period is 12-21 days. The virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling. The patient presents with prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, and vomiting. After the prodrome, unilateral or bilateral parotitis develops, which is tender. It may be associated with ipsilateral ear pain. Ingestion of sour or acidic foods may enhance pain. It can be prevented by administering live attenuated, MMR vaccine at 9 months, 15 months and 4-6 years. Option B: Mumps can affect all the salivary glands, but most commonly affects parotid glands. Option C: The patient is infectious from 7 days before to 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling. Option D: Orchitis or oophoritis is a common finding in mumps, along with parotitis. But, mumps leading to infertility is very rare.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An outbreak of mumps infection was reported from a local school a few days ago. A boy studying in the 2nd standard of that school presented with painful bilateral swelling near his jaw and cheek for 3 days. His mother is anxious about the possible complications of the disease. Which of the following is the most common complication that can occur in this patient?
explanation: Meningoencephalitis is the most common complication that can occur in mumps in children. Most common complications in mumps: Children - Meningoencephalitis Adolescents and adult males - Orchitis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: On your pediatrics rotation, you notice a 2-day-old baby with the rash shown in the image below. Which among the following is the most likely cause for this baby's rash?
explanation: The image shows purple papulonodular lesions, which are suggestive of blueberry muffin rash. It is seen in congenital rubella. Blueberry muffin rash represents dermal erythropoiesis. In addition to congenital rubella, it can be seen in: Congenital viral infections such as cytomegalovirus and parvovirus Neoplasms such as neuroblastoma and acute myeloid leukemia Rh hemolytic disease
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A woman who came with complaints of fever, myalgia, and rash at 12 weeks of gestation is found to have positive IgM titers for rubella. She is advised MTP. If the pregnancy is taken to full term, which of the following triad of complications would you expect to see in the child?
options: Sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly
Cataracts, cicatricial skin lesions, limb defects
Sensorineural hearing loss, cataract, congenital heart defects
explanation: The patient has an increased risk of congenital rubella if the pregnancy is taken full term. The triad of complications that would be expected in the child include: Sensorineural hearing loss: Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome Congenital cataract Congenital heart disease: The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus Option A: Chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications - congenital toxoplasmosis. Option B: Sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly - congenital CMV infection. Option C: Cataracts, cicatricial skin lesions, limb defects - congenital varicella syndrome.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Palak, a neonate is being evaluated for the finding shown in the image. The mother's prenatal history is significant for viral exanthem in early pregnancy. On examination, a grade 3 murmur is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's murmur?
explanation: The image shows a bilateral cataract, which along with the antenatal history of viral exanthem is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). Frequency of heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are evaluating a baby in NICU with diffuse petechiae. On examination, mild hepatosplenomegaly, bilateral cataract, and a continuous murmur suggestive of patent ductus arteriosus are noted. Which of the following investigations would you do to diagnose this baby's condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. IgM antibody detection in infant blood are done to diagnose congenital rubella syndrome in a newborn. Congenital rubella syndrome is diagnosed by: Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth (since IgM does not cross the placenta), or Persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months (maternally derived antibody would have disappeared)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. The child's parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?
options: The period of infectivity is 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common complication is pneumonia
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. The most common cause of death is pneumonia (Hecht's giant cell pneumonia). Measles (rubeola) is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. The infection is spread via droplets, with a secondary attack rate of 90%. The patients are infectious from 4 days before upto 5 days after the appearance of the rash. The rash appears on the 4th day of fever. It starts from the retro auricular region. Koplik spots are pathognomonic. The most common cause of death is pneumonia. Measles can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) as a late complication. Measles can be prevented by administering live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young child presented with fever and cough in the OPD. He is observed to have the finding shown in the image below on the inner aspect of cheeks. Which of the following statement is false regarding this clinical finding?
options: It appears 1 to 4 days before the rash
It appears as tiny-rose colored lesions
It is seen at the level of molars
It may also occur in conjunctiva
explanation: The image shows discrete red lesions with white spots in the center on the inner aspect of the cheeks, suggestive of Koplik spots. They do not appear as tiny rose-colored lesions. Koplik spots are pathognomonic of measles. These are the spots present at the level of molars. They appear 1-4 days prior to the rash. They may also occur in conjunctival folds and vaginal mucosa. Forchheimer spots: Tiny red-colored lesions in the oropharynx or petechial hemorrhages on the soft palate, seen in rubella (German measles).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of myoclonic jerks, seizures, and rapid decline in cognitive function. The mother gives a history of fever with a rash at 1.5 years of age. The rash had started behind the ears, progressed to involve the whole body, and resolved on its own.
What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario with a classic history of exanthematous fever suggestive of measles, seizures, myoclonic jerks, and cognitive dysfunction is suggestive of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE). SSPE is a chronic, progressive demyelinating disease that develops years after measles infection, most often in patients between 5-15 years of age. Patients have a history of measles infection at <2 years of age. CSF shows elevated measles antibody levels and MRI shows increased T2 intensity in white matter. No definitive treatment is available. Other complications of measles: Meningoencephalitis Giant-cell pneumonitis Pneumonia Croup Secondary infections - otitis media Protracted diarrhea
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Akshay developed a fever, headache, and a diffuse rash as shown below. The rash is most prominent on the face and chest. He says the rash is very itchy bothering his everyday life. He is a football player and has an upcoming tournament in the next few days. He wants to know if he'll be able to play by then. Considering the rash infectivity, until when would you advise him to stay isolated?
options: 4 days after the appearance of lesions
7 days after the appearance of lesions
14 days after the appearance of lesions
After crust formation has occurred over lesions
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of chickenpox. You would advise the boy to stay isolated until after crust formation has occurred over lesions. People with chickenpox are contagious 24-48 hours before the rash is evident and until the vesicles have crusted, which is usually 3-7 days after the onset of rash.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: There is an outbreak of chickenpox among the children at a daycare center. What is the most common extracutaneous site of involvement of this disease?
explanation: The most common extracutaneous site of involvement by the varicella-zoster virus in children is the central nervous system. It is a benign complication of VZV infection in children and generally does not require hospitalization. The most common infectious complication of varicella is secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus. The most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Seema is brought to the OPD due to the development of a very itchy rash. Her father says he's worried because she has been constantly scratching her body leading to scratch marks. Before the development of the rash, she had a fever and headache for 2 days. On examination, you note a vesicular rash, which is in different stages of evolution. Which of the following is not a possible complication of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chickenpox caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of Varicella-zoster infection. It occurs due to measles. The characteristic rash of chickenpox is present in different stages of evolution. Complications of VZV occur with disseminated varicella or with reactivation of infection. This more commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. Complications include: Bacterial infections of the skin and soft tissues Pneumonia Hepatitis Acute cerebellar ataxia Encephalitis Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy Sepsis Shingles/Herpes Zoster: vesicular lesions are confined to the unilateral segment of the sensory nerve (dermatome). In children, the rash is mild, with complete resolution within 1-2 week. Unlike in adults, postherpetic neuralgia is unusual in children.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child presents with fever, headache, and a diffuse rash as shown below. The rash resolves by crusting and the child recovers in 10 days. Which spinal segments are most commonly involved in a latent reactivation of this infection?
options: It involves all spinal segments equally
explanation: The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of chickenpox. Latent reactivation of the infection or shingles most commonly occurs in the T3 to L3 spinal segments. Herpes zoster/shingles are characterized by a unilateral vesicular dermatomal eruption associated with severe pain. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus affects the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve. It is shown below: Ramsay–Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) affects the facial nerve with an eruption on the tympanic membrane, the external auditory canal, and facial palsy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are a pediatrics resident posted in the labor room. You are examining a baby which was delivered via C-section a few minutes ago. You notice that the baby has zig-zag hypertrophic cutaneous scarring in a dermatomal distribution on the left side of the limbs and face. He also has a small head and small limbs. Antenatal history of the mother will be significant for which of the following infection?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. Hence, antenatal history of varicella infection would be significant in the mother of this baby. Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy. Clinical features include: Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution Microphthalmia Cataracts Optic atrophy Chorioretinitis Microcephaly Limb hypoplasia Motor and sensory deficits.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected.
Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR?
explanation: Among the following options, urine is the best sample to be sent for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. In congenital CMV infections, the investigation of choice is PCR or viral culture. It should be done within the first three weeks of life (after this period, it is difficult to distinguish between a congenital and an acquired infection). Since not all affected infants are viremic at birth, urine is a more reliable sample than blood. Most CMV transmission occurs in the first trimester. The risk of transmission is high in the third trimester. 90% of the infected babies are asymptomatic and have lesser chances of having late sequelae. The clinical manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss. There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness. The image below shows periventricular calcifications:
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child is brought to the OPD with complaints of a rash and fever. The worried parents say the rash appeared on his cheeks yesterday. However, this morning, they observed it has spread to the trunk as well. The image of the child is given below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
options: It is also known as sixth disease
It is caused by an RNA virus
It is associated with a transient arrest of erythropoiesis
It is associated with immune fetal hydrops
explanation: The image shows a characteristic slapped cheek appearance of a rash, which is classically present in parvovirus B-19 infection or erythema infectiosum. This is associated with transient aplastic crisis and erythropoiesis is mainly affected. Erythema infectiosum is also known as the fifth disease. The rash appears first on the cheeks called the slapped cheek appearance then spreads to the trunk. It is caused by parvovirus B-19, which a single-stranded DNA virus. Clinical features: Febrile, non-toxic child with a nonspecific prodrome Transient aplastic anemia, pure red cell aplasia Petechial/ purpuric skin eruptions: Papular purpuric “gloves and socks” syndrome (PPGSS) Myocarditis Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise Arthritis and arthralgia (adults)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Niki, a 9-month-old baby is brought to the OPD for a rash. The mother says the baby had a high fever of 103 F for 3 days for which she was given paracetamol. This morning, the baby had no fever but the mother noticed a rash on the trunk. On oral examination, ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction are present. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?
options: It is also called as erythema subitum
It is caused by human herpes virus-6
It is a non-pruritic, morbilliform rash on the trunk
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of roseola infantum. It is also called exanthema subitum, not erythema subitum. Roseola infantum is also called as sixth disease or exanthema subitum (exanthema=breaking out, subitum=sudden rash). It is caused by a human herpesvirus (HHV) -6A, 6B, and 7. Clinical features: Prodrome of high-grade fever Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down. Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction Image: Exanthem subitum
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 14-year-old boy came to the OPD with the complaint of fever and sore throat. On examination, you noted generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following picture. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
explanation: The image of the peripheral blood film shows atypical lymphocytes, also known as Downey cells. The given clinical scenario along with characteristic atypical lymphocytes is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. Infectious mononucleosis, also called, glandular fever is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). It is transmitted person-to-person through salivary secretions and blood transfusion. The incubation period is 4 to 5 weeks. It presents with a classic triad of Fever Pharyngitis Lymphadenopathy Other clinical features include fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. The patients are advised to avoid contact sports for 3-4 weeks due to the risk of splenic rupture. The screening test of choice is the monospot test. This is a heterophile antibody test. Atypical lymphocytosis of >10% is a characteristic laboratory finding. These are CD8 T lymphocytes that develop in response to the infected B lymphocytes. Other diseases caused by EBV include: Hodgkin's lymphoma Non-Hodgkin lymphoma Burkitt's lymphoma Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease Nasopharyngeal carcinoma Option B: Kimura disease is s a chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy. Option C: Scrofuloderma is the result of cutaneous infection adjacent to a tuberculous focus, which may correspond to peripheral ganglionar tuberculosis (the most common form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis in HIV-positive patients and in children).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infantile diarrhea worldwide?
explanation: The most common cause of infantile diarrhea worldwide is rotavirus. Rotavirus causes diarrhea in children of 3-5 years of age, via the fecal-oral route. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. This is presumably because of the protection by maternal antibodies in breast milk. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens Lactose intolerance is actually not very common in infants and typically only starts showing up after age 3. All babies are born with lactase in their intestines. As they grow older, the lactase enzyme decreases.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of hepatitis B from the infected mother to the baby?
explanation: Breastfeeding is not a mode of transmission of hepatitis B from an infected mother to the baby. Mother-to-child transmission of HBV can occur via the following three routes: Intrauterine transmission Transmission during delivery (most frequent method) Postpartum transmission Postpartum transmission: A proportion of babies may acquire the infection after birth due to close contact with the mother. However, breastfeeding is not a risk factor for HBV infection. Transmission following amniocentesis has been described, but the risk appears low. Newborns born to seropositive Hepatitis B mothers are given Hep B immunoglobulin as well as Hep B vaccination at birth.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which fungal infection spreads in neonates through the care giver's hand?
explanation: Candida parapsilosis is increasingly responsible for hospital outbreaks, and the hands of healthcare workers may be predominant environment sources.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 16-year-old boy presented with rigidity and difficulty in movement. He has a history of involuntary movements in a single group of muscles of legs suggestive of myoclonic jerks. On examination, choreoathetosis movements and lead pipe rigidity is noted in the limbs. EEG shows suppression-burst episodes which are characteristic for subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. This clinical presentation is a complication of which of the following infection?
explanation: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles. Hence, prior infection with measles is most likely. SSPE occurs 3-8 years after a primary measles infection. It is the least common complication of measles but is almost always fatal. The clinical manifestations occur in 4 stages: Stage I: Maybe missed due to mild symptoms like irritability and reduced attention span. Stage II: Hallmark is massive Myoclonus. Involuntary muscle movements and myoclonic jerks start from one group of muscles but gives way to massive spams and jerks. Stage III: Involuntary movements disappear and are replaced by choreoathetosis, immobility, dystonia, and lead-pipe rigidity due to destruction of deeper parts of basal ganglia. Stage IV: Loss of critical centers that lead to coma and then death. Diagnosis of SSPE is by: Detection of measles antibody in CSF Characteristic findings on EEG Typical histological findings or/and isolation of virus or virus antigen from brain tissue obtained by biopsy or after postmortem.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is:
explanation: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). Cardiac anomalies have been observed in 50% of children infected during the first 8 weeks of gestation. The incidence of heart disease in congenital rubella syndrome is: PDA > PS (right >left) > ventricular septal defect > atrial septal defect.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows small red lesions with bluish-white spots in the center on the inner aspects of the cheek opposite to the lower premolar, indicating the presence of Koplik spots. The appearance of these spots, along with a rash appearing three days later, strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. The measles virus is a single-stranded RNA virus. Measles infection has 4 phases: the incubation period, prodromal illness, exanthematous phase (characterized by the rash), and recovery phase. After an incubation period of 8-12 days, the prodromal phase of measles starts with mild fever and is followed by conjunctivitis, photophobia, coryza, cough, and increasing fever. Koplik spots, appearing 1-4 days prior to the rash, are a characteristic sign of measles. Symptoms gradually intensify over a period of 2-4 days until the first day of the rash. The rash typically begins on the forehead (around the hairline), behind the ears, and on the upper neck as a red maculopapular eruption. It then spreads downward to the torso and extremities, often becoming confluent on the face and upper trunk. Complications include acute otitis media (most common), pneumonia (the most common cause of death), croup, bronchiolitis, reactivation of tuberculosis, diarrhea, appendicitis, febrile seizures, and encephalitis. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare chronic complication of measles. Other options: Option B: Leukoplakia appears as a white patch in the oral cavity that cannot be wiped off. Option C: Scarlet fever is Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis and is characterized by a distinctive sandpaper rash. The rash appears as a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption that turns the skin bright red and blanches on pressure. It starts around the neck and spreads to the trunk and extremities. Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash (maculopapular, erythema multiforme urticarial, or micropustular), conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph node enlargement.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
What is the secondary attack rate of chickenpox?
60%
explanation: The secondary attack rate of chicken pox is 85% (range 61–100%) Chicken pox: Causative agent: Varicella–zoster virus Incubation period: 2 to 3 weeks Rash: On 1st day, centripetal, pleomorphic, vesiculopapular lesions with erythematous base (dew drops on rose petal) Treatment: Acyclovir 20 mg/kg/dose; four doses per day; for 5 days Complications: Cutaneous: Secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin Systemic: Acute cerebella ataxia, Guillain–Barre syndrome, transverse myelitis, optic neuritis, facial nerve palsy, pneumonia, Reye's syndrome Aspirin is contraindicated due to risk of Reye’s syndrome. Vaccine: Oka strain (live attenuated) All adults who have never had chickenpox should receive 2 doses 0.5 mL in the deltoid area subcutaneously. For <13 years of age, the first dose is administered at 12–15 months and the second dose at age 4–6 years. For people older than 13 years, the two doses are administered 4–8 weeks apart. For those already immunized, booster doses are not needed if titers are adequate. Surgical GI Disorders
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young boy came to visit his mother admitted to the antenatal ward for her delivery. You are the paediatrician on rounds in the adjacent post-natal cubical. His speech was very different from a normal child. Out of curiosity, you examine his oral cavity and the following finding is seen. What would be the most likely cause of this condition?
explanation: The given image shows an abnormally short lingual frenulum called Ankyloglossia. Ankyloglossia is also called “tongue-tie” due to an abnormally short lingual frenulum that can hinder tongue movement. It can interfere with speech or feeding. In such cases, surgical correction is indicated. The image below shows tongue tie and the classic W-shaped appearance of the tongue on protrusion: Fissured tongue (Option C) (scrotal tongue or lingua plicata) is a benign malformation in which numerous small furrows or deep grooves are present on the dorsal surface of the tongue. Food particles and debris may become trapped in the fissures, resulting in irritation, inflammation, and halitosis. Macroglossia (Option D), or an abnormally large tongue, may be seen in disorders like Down's syndrome, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome, Hurler's syndrome, and cretinism.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Sirish, a young talented singer failed to make it through the Music Idol audition. Deeply affected by this, he drank a full bottle of a drain unclogger. He was rushed to the ER with froth in the mouth. Which of the following could be done as the first step in treatment?
options: Gag the child to induce emesis
explanation: The recommended first step in the case of alkali ingestion (most commonly seen with drain uncloggers/ house hold cleaning agents) is dilution through the administration of milk or water. Contraindications in a case of caustic (strong acid or alkali) ingestion: Neutralization Induced emesis Gastric lavage
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Mala, a young student of class 9 accidentally pipettes sulphuric acid while performing volumetric analysis in her chemistry lab. Which type of mucosal damage would you expect in her?
explanation: Acid ingestion produces coagulative necrosis. Acid ingestion produces coagulative necrosis and a somewhat protective thick eschar. The amount of acidic agents usually ingested is low as they are generally bitter. Alkali ingestion: Most cases (70%) of caustic ingestions are accidental. Drain uncloggers are most common as they are tasteless so more is ingested. Alkali ingestion produces liquefactive necrosis.
subject: Pediatrics
