question_text:
You are doing a quick pre-op evaluation of a 2-day-old baby shifted for emergency pediatric surgery. Parents had brought him with a history of sudden, noisy breathing. He appeared cyanotic with decreased breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray taken in the casualty is given below. Which of the following is not true about the underlying condition?

Not associated with dextrocardia
options: Most commonly seen on the left side
Mortality is usually associated with pulmonary hypoplasia
Pulmonary dilators markedly improve the survival
explanation: The given clinical picture of neonatal respiratory distress, absent breath sounds in the left side of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). Though less commonly documented, dextrocardia is seen in association with CDH. A diaphragmatic hernia is defined as a communication between the abdominal and thoracic cavities with or without abdominal contents in the thorax. It is mostly congenital, with a defective formation of the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Females are affected twice as often as males. Bochdalek hernia accounts for up to 90% of the hernias seen in the newborn period, with 80-90% occurring on the left side. So, the heart will be pushed to the right side (dextroposition). Predictors of a poor prognosis include an associated major anomaly, symptoms before completion of 24 hours since birth, severe pulmonary hypoplasia, herniation to the contralateral lung, and the need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). Nitric oxide is a selective pulmonary vasodilator. It reduces ductal shunting and pulmonary pressures, resulting in improved oxygenation. Childhood Respiratory Disorders
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother brought a healthy-looking, 3-month-old infant for routine immunization. As you were giving the shot, you noticed some noisy breathing in the baby, which became worse once he started crying. However, it decreased, as you held him in a prone position. There were no clear signs of distress. According to his mother, he had been feeding well at home and has not had any episodes of apnea or cyanosis. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: A clinical picture of inspiratory stridor that worsens on crying and relieves in a prone position in a newborn without respiratory distress is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and the most common cause of stridor in infants and children. Stridor is exacerbated by any exertion: crying, agitation, or feeding. In the prone position, the stridor disappears. On laryngoscopy, an omega-shaped epiglottis is visualized. In most children, only expectant observation is required as the condition resolves secondary to nervous system maturation, within 18 to 24 months of birth. However, neonates with severe laryngomalacia may develop marked upper airway obstruction resulting in cor pulmonale, life-threatening apneic episodes, feeding difficulties, obstructive sleep apnea, and failure to thrive. In such cases, surgical resection of supraglottic tissues and supraglottoplasty has been the favoured approach.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A senior casualty nurse informs you that a 5-year-old girl with severe respiratory distress might require intubation. You just finished stabilising and placing an ET tube in Mohan, a 57-year-old man with head trauma and a GCS of 7. Which of the following is not a feature of child's airway?
options: The larynx being located higher in the neck at the level of C3-C4
The narrowest part being the subglottic region
explanation: The pediatric airway is funnel shaped. In comparison, the adult airway is cylindrical. In newborns, the larynx is situated at the level of C3-C4, where it facilitates simultaneous respiration and swallowing during feeding.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During a night shift, you get a call from the ER to come and see a toddler, who presented with complaints of fever, drooling, and a muffled voice since evening. On examination, the child has a stridor and you pick up a "thumb sign" on the lateral x-ray of his neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Thumb sign on lateral x-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis (AE). It is seen due to epiglottic enlargement. AE is an inflammation of the epiglottis. The arytenoids, false cords, and posterior tongue may also be involved. In children, Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is the most common cause. This has decreased dramatically since the widespread availability of immunization (pentavalent). Streptococcus pyogenes, S. pneumoniae, and S. aureus have also been implicated. Non-infectious causes can be foreign body ingestion and trauma from thermal or caustic agents. It has a progressive and potentially fulminating course, characterised by high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction. AE is a clinical diagnosis and a true emergency, X-ray soft tissue neck is not necessary to confirm it. It may be used to rule out differentials such as laryngotracheobronchitis, foreign body obstruction, retropharyngeal abscess or congenital anomalies. The time taken for X-rays should be avoided in a critically ill child due to the risk of sudden complete airway obstruction. The definitive diagnosis of AE is made during direct laryngoscopy. However, since manipulation can induce a laryngospasm, it is generally avoided. The image below shows thumb sign:

question_text: Which of the following is the most common etiological agent associated with epiglottitis in children, overall in the world?
explanation: The most common etiological agent, overall in the world, of acute epiglottitis in the pediatric age group, now is Streptococcus. In the past, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) used to be the most commonly identified cause of acute epiglottitis. But, since the widespread use of the H. influenzae type b vaccine, invasive disease caused by H. influenzae type b in pediatric patients has been reduced by 99%. Therefore, other organisms, such as Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS), Streptococcus penumoniae, non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus, have become the common causes of acute epiglottitis in pediatric age group, overall in the world. Lateral X-ray of the neck shows the thumb sign in acute epiglottitis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?
explanation: Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing. The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever. Management: Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema. Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup. Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %) Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: 2-year-old Neha has been having fever since yesterday and is refusing food. Parents became alarmed when she developed an abnormal barking cough today morning and have brought her to the casualty. On examination, the child looked exhausted and had visible chest retractions and stridor. The temperature was 39.6° and SpO2 was 93% on room air. Chest X-ray reveals a 'steeple' sign. What is the treatment of choice in this child?
options: Send a throat swab and start IV antibiotics
explanation: Fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor and a steeple sign on chest radiograph are suggestive of acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The treatment of choice in this child is nebulization with racemic epinephrine. Epinephrine acts rapidly and provides immediate relief. It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure. This increases fluid resorption and reduces airway edema. question_text: A child in your unit is admitted with acute bronchiolitis. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent responsible for this condition during infancy?
explanation: Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease in children younger than 2 years. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most likely etiological agent and is responsible for more than 50% of cases. Acute bronchiolitis refers to airway inflammation and obstruction of the lower respiratory tract. Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratory wheezes, and breathing difficulty. Cyanosis may be seen in severe cases. Radiographs may be normal in some patients. In the majority of them, there will be interstitial infiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening. Management is mainly conservative. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
10-month-old Ishaan was presented to the OPD with a 3-day history of lower respiratory tract symptoms and an expiratory wheeze. Chest X-ray showed mild peribronchial thickening.
Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition described?
options: The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.
It is more common in children who have not been breastfed.
The mainstay of treatment is antibiotics.
There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchiolitis. The treatment is mainly supportive. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation. It is more common in boys, in those who have not been breastfed, and in those who live in crowded conditions. The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy. Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and antibiotics are not indicated. There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
The pediatric intensivist is contemplating whether to start aerosolized ribavirin in a young boy with a severe respiratory infection. There would be a clear indication to start the drug if
.
options: The child has not received any immunization
There is a history of severe atopy
There is a history of recurrent infection
explanation: Ribavirin is the only specific antiviral therapy available for the treatment of severe bronchiolitis caused by RSV infections. It is reserved as a last-line agent for life-threatening bronchiolitis in patients who are immunocompromised or who have hemodynamically significant cardiopulmonary disease. In otherwise healthy children, the management of acute RSV bronchiolitis is typically supportive. Ribavirin is a prodrug, which when metabolized resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this form, it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral replication. MNEMONIC: (for indications of ribavirin) C-RIBAvirin: Hepatitis C RSV Influenza B Arenaviruses (Lassa, Bolivian, etc.) Note - Ribavirin is also used in the treatment of hepatitis C and some viral hemorrhagic fevers.

question_text: 3-year-old Sravya was referred with a one-week history of being unable to look upwards, constant neck flexion, and deviation to the right side. Parents also complained of feeding difficulty. On examination, the child was noted to have poor oral hygiene and the neck was tender on palpation. The X-ray is given below. Which of the following statements are false about the given condition?
options: It occurs mostly in children younger than 3-4 years
It is more common in boys
Examination shows unilateral bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall
Trauma to the posterior pharynx is the most common cause
explanation: The history of progressive torticollis, neck pain and dysphagia in a young child along with a neck X-ray demonstrating a prevertebral soft-tissue swelling are all indicative of a retropharyngeal abscess. In young children, an antecedent upper respiratory tract infection is the most common cause of an RP abscess and not trauma. It involves the suppuration of lymph nodes present in the RP space and is more common in children younger than 3-4 years since these lymph node chains involute after 5 years of age. Boys are affected more often than girls. In older children and adults, the cause is usually trauma to the posterior pharynx, which leads to inoculation of the retropharyngeal space. Risk factors include poor oral hygiene, diabetes, an immunocompromised state, and low socioeconomic status. Clinical manifestations are nonspecific and include fever, decreased oral intake, and drooling. Neck stiffness and torticollis may also be present. As the abscess grows in size, it can also lead to upper airway obstruction and asphyxiation. The physical examination can reveal unilateral bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall. Although lateral radiograph is used for initial imaging, CT of the neck with intravenous contrast is the best imaging study to evaluate patients with a retropharyngeal abscess. Treatment ranges from prolonged courses of intravenous antibiotics to surgical incision and drainage.
subject: Pediatrics

The most common cause of bacterial pneumonia in children 3 weeks to 4 years of age is
.
explanation: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is the most common bacterial pathogen in children 3 weeks to 4 years of age. question_text: A 9-year-old boy presented with a 4-day history of high-grade fever and a productive cough with yellow sputum. Chest x-ray showed a consolidation in the right middle zone. According to WHO guidelines, which of the following is not an indication for hospital admission?
explanation: As per the revised 2014 WHO guidelines, it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home. However, a child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing will need to be referred for inpatient treatment. Only those children who have general danger signs are classified as having “severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission). explanation: Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia manifests as confluent bronchopneumonia, which is often unilateral and characterized by the presence of hemorrhagic necrosis and irregular areas of cavitation of the lung parenchyma, resulting in pneumatoceles, empyema, or at times, bronchopulmonary fistulas. question_text: A one-and-half-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold. On examination, respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?
options: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute respiratory illness. According to the IMNCI guidelines 2020, this child can be classified as having 'Pneumonia'. The treatment is oral amoxicillin, vitamin A and home care advice. question_text: An adolescent boy with a family history of asthma presented with intermittent wheeze and cough for 2 months. The onset of wheeze is triggered during exercise and while playing at school. Which of the following is preferred as regular therapy for the prevention of his symptoms?
explanation: Inhaled corticosteroids are recommended as regular therapy for the prevention of his symptoms of exercise-induced asthma. According to GINA 2021 guidelines, exercise-induced bronchoconstriction can be prevented with daily treatment (regular therapy) with inhaled corticosteroids. SABA, LABA, or chromones may be used prior to exercise, along with warm-up before exercise. Those who have mild exercise-induced asthma can use their regular inhaled corticosteroid before exercise and need not take SABA pre-exercise.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy presented to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has a history of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetic testing in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to be decreased in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most likely to be decreased. Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to failure of development of Wolffian duct structures leading to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens. There is defective sperm transport resulting in obstructive azoospermia. The sexual function is generally unimpaired. Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR protein leading to defective chloride transport. Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis. Option D: Patients with cystic fibrosis have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following has similar inheritance pattern as cystic fibrosis?
options: Accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome
Trinucleotide repeat expansion of CAG on chromosome 4
explanation: Cystic fibrosis (CF), is an autosomal-recessive disorder. Accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome is seen in Pompe's disease which is another autosomal-recessive disorder. Option B: Trinucleotide repeat expansion of CAG on chromosome 4 is seen in Huntington's disease, which is autosomal dominant. Options C and D: Adult-onset polycystic kidney disease and retinoblastoma (RB gene mutation) are autosomal-dominant diseases.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following statements about cystic fibrosis is not true?
options: Abnormality in CFTR gene leads to defective calcium transport.
Mutation in cystic fibrosis transport regulator is seen.
Males have infertility in adult life
explanation: In cystic fibrosis, abnormalities in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride channels and not calcium channels. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder of children and adults. Dysfunction of the CFTR, the primary defect, leads to a wide and variable array of presenting manifestations and complications. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion. More than 95% of males are azoospermic because of failure of development of Wolffian duct structures, but the sexual function is generally unimpaired.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among the pediatric age group is .
explanation: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among the given options. The most common organisms causing pneumonia in CF patients: The pediatric age group- S. aureus The adult population- P. aeruginosa (mucoid) Pseudomonas aeruginosa-mucoid may also cause pneumonia in pediatric CF patients. In cystic fibrosis, P. aeruginosa shows a special feature of developing a mucoid capsule. This complex polysaccharide generates a biofilm that provides a hypoxic environment and thereby protects Pseudomonas against antimicrobial agents. Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia is associated with higher mortality, but it is not the most common. These patients are found to have severe pulmonary hypertension, possibly due to pulmonary inflammatory vascular response.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 5-year-old boy was evaluated for cystic fibrosis. Sweat chloride shows value of 38 and 44 mEq/L (normal<40). Which is the next best test to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis?
explanation: DNA analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in patients with equivocal (one normal and one abnormal value) or frankly normal sweat chloride values. The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met: Presence of Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or Positive newborn screening or A sibling with cystic fibrosis Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference Options A and B: 72-hour fecal fat and chest CT are not used in the diagnosis of CF. Option D: This testing is primarily used in research applications and has never undergone extensive validation as a clinical tool.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A couple planning for pregnancy visits you for genetic counseling. They are both known to be heterozygous carriers of CFTR mutations. Which of the following is the most likely complication in an affected child at birth?
explanation: CFTR mutations are associated with cystic fibrosis (CF). Meconium ileus is a common complication associated with CF patients at birth. Meconium found in the intestine of a neonate consists of succus entericus (bile salts, bile acids, and debris from the intestinal mucosa) and is normally evacuated within 6 hours of birth (or earlier). Meconium ileus occurs in the first 24-48 hours of life when meconium becomes inspissated and obstructs the distal ileum causing abdominal distension and emesis. Abdominal radiographs show dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels and, frequently, a collection of granular, “ground-glass” material in the lower central abdomen. Meconium ileus may also be seen with pancreatic atresia or pancreatic duct stenosis. Radiological image shows contrast enema in a newborn infant with abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium. Several air–fluid levels in the small bowel are visible on the upright lateral view.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 9-year-old boy, diagnosed with cystic fibrosis shortly after birth has been having around 2-3 exacerbations per year, requiring hospital admissions. Infection by which of the following
organisms has increased mortality in such patients?
explanation: Cystic fibrosis patients with Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia are found to have severe pulmonary hypertension, possibly due to pulmonary inflammatory vascular response, and have higher mortality. Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (mucoid) are the most common pathogens causing pneumonia in CF patients. However, they have lower mortality compared to B. cepacia.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent pneumonia and chronic diarrhea. His mother states that he has 6-8 foul-smelling stools per day. Physical examination reveals a
low-grade fever and scattered rhonchi over both lung fields. Sweat chloride testing is elevated on 2 separate occasions. Which of the following drugs is used as a treatment option for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). Ivacaftor is used in the treatment of cystic fibrosis. Ivacaftor is a potentiator of the chloride channel and overcomes its defect. It activates the CFTR-G551D mutant protein. Remember: IvaCaFToR (CFTR mutation in CF)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 4-year-old girl presented with cough and difficulty breathing following accidental inhalation of a peanut. On examination, there was localised wheezing and decreased breath sounds on the right side. What is the next best step in management?
explanation: In a child with a suspected foreign body in the lung, the next best step would be to do a rigid bronchoscopy as it is both diagnostic and therapeutic. The rigid bronchoscope has a ventilation mechanism and a suction port making it easy for visualization and handling of the foreign body. However, it is pertinent to note that the initial investigation is usually a chest X-ray.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All the following are true about Macleod syndrome except that .
options: It is also called Swyer-James syndrome.
It is not a true emphysema.
It is mostly linked to adenovirus.
Affected lung is larger in size compared to unaffected lung.
explanation: Macleod syndrome refers to the inability of the lungs to grow after a severe obstructive bronchiolitis. Children with this condition often have chronic cough, recurrent pneumonia, and wheezing. On CT scan, the affected lung shows small size and decreased vascularity, hyperexpansion, and hyperlucency (false emphysema). It is also called Swyer–James syndrome. It is mostly linked to adenovirus. Patients respond well to bronchodilators.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 15-year-old child has been recurrently hospitalized for infections, since 2 years of age. After a detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was suspected. All of the following are components of the Kartagener triad except .
explanation: Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad. Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesiacharacterized by the classical triad of: Situs inversus Chronic sinusitis Bronchiectasis Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis. As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. Its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality. Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All the following are components of Young's syndrome except:
explanation: Asthma is not usually seen in Young's syndrome. Young's syndrome is characterized by: Bronchiectasis Sinusitis Obstructive azoospermia In contrast, Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by Bronchiectasis Sinusitis Situs inversus
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A term male neonate develops respiratory distress at birth, unresponsive to surfactant. Echocardiography is normal and chest X-ray shows a ground-glass appearance. Parents say that their first child died at 10 days of birth due to similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The history and chest X-ray findings are suggestive of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). PAP is a rare, diffuse lung disease that is characterized by alveolar and interstitial accumulation of a periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain-positive phospholipoprotein (derived from surfactant). Infants and children with PAP present with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Boys are affected 3 times as often as girls. Chest X-ray shows ground-glass opacity and HRCT shows crazy-paving pattern (as shown below). Treatment options include total lung lavage, inhaled or subcutaneous granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-month old previously healthy baby was brought to the casualty when the parents found that the baby was not breathing while asleep. Following resuscitative measures, the baby was still apnoeic, pulseless and asystolic. Which of the following is not a risk factor for sudden infant death syndrome?
options: Infants born to women aged >35 years
Infants of mother who smoked during pregnancy
explanation: Higher maternal age is not a risk factor for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Risk factors for SIDS include Low socioeconomic status 3-4 months of age have the highest incidence Higher birth order irrespective of maternal age and low birth weight Cigarette smoking, alcohol, and drug abuse during pregnancy Sleeping prone, even side sleeping increases the risk
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-month-old infant was admitted because of increasing stridor since birth, cough, pulmonary infections, and episodes of acute respiratory distress. On detailed evaluation using bronchoscopy and MRI imaging, a bronchial cyst was found to be the cause. The following are features of the lesion except that .
options: It is usually confined to 1 lobe.
It is never associated with malignancy.
explanation: Bronchial cysts are associated with malignancy (pleuropulmonary blastoma). Bronchial cysts are congenital malformations of the bronchial tree. It mainly presents as a mediastinal mass that may enlarge and cause local compression. It is usually confined to a single lobe and is mostly multiloculated.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In a child with yellow nail syndrome, you would expect to find all the following clinical features except .
explanation: Yellow nail syndrome is not associated with clubbing. Yellow nail syndrome is characterized by respiratory manifestation (pleural effusion, bronchiectasis), lymphedema, and discoloured nails. Yellow nail syndrome almost always occurs after 50 years of age, but a juvenile or familial form has also been observed.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
What is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a 2-year-old child?
Neurogenic tumors
explanation: The most common mediastinal masses in young children are neurogenic tumours (50%-60%). In most cases (< 4 years of age), they are invariably malignant (neuroblastomas). Anterior mediastinal masses: Thymoma - most common Malignant lymphoma (Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's) Teratoma Thyroid (retro- or sub-sternal extension) Thymic cyst Angioma Middle mediastinal masses: Foregut duplication cyst (bronchogenic, enteric, and neurenteric) - most common Lymphadenopathy Vascular malformations Posterior mediastinal masses: Neurogenic tumour - most common overall Foregut duplication cyst Vascular malformations Extramedullary hematopoiesis Fetal Circulation
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence that he would follow is:
options: Umbilical artery  inferior vena cava  ductus venosus  right atrium  left atrium
Umbilical artery  superior vena cava  right atrium  ductus arteriosus  left atrium
Umbilical vein  ductus venosus  inferior vena cava  right atrium  left atrium
Umbilical vein  ductus arteriosus  superior vena cava  right atrium  left atrium
explanation: The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein  ductus venosus  inferior venacava  right atrium  left atrium.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by .
explanation: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by the umbilical vein. The umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus into the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in the fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygenation. Note: In the umbilical cord, there are a pair of umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein. Mnemonic: AVA- artery –vein- artery(2 arteries and a single vein).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A final year student is asked to give a seminar on 'fetal circulation.' Which among the following statement told by him in the seminar is likely to be false?
options: Heart receives blood with high oxygen saturation
Pressure in right and left ventricles are equal
Liver receives blood with low oxygen saturation compared to the brain
Blood in inferior venacava has lower oxygen concentration compared to superior venacava
explanation: Blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava. The superior vena cava carries the deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium. The highly oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus from the placenta via the umbilical vein with 50% of the umbilical venous blood entering the hepatic circulation and the rest bypassing the liver and joining the inferior vena cava (IVC) via the ductus venosus. Hence, the blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava. Also, relatively a larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain. Pressures in both the right and left ventricles are equal in a developing fetus. The upper part of the body is perfused exclusively by the left ventricle while the lower extremities are perfused by the right ventricle.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The total fetal cardiac output at term is estimated to be per minute.
explanation: The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min. Approximately 65% of descending aortic blood flow returns to the placenta, and hence, only the remaining 35% perfuses the fetal organs and tissues. The clinical relevance of this 65% blood flow being directed to the placenta comes in the context of delayed cord clamping vs early cord clamping after delivery. Delayed cord clamping entails the umbilical cord is clamped more than one minute after the birth or when cord pulsation has ceased. This delayed clamping allows the blood flow between the placenta and neonate to continue and helps improve the iron status in the infant.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During the evaluation of a newborn, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. Where would the structure responsible for the murmur ideally be located?
options: Just proximal to the left common caroti
Just distal to the left subclavian
Just distal to the left common caroti
Just proximal to the left subclavian
explanation: Continuous machinery murmur in a newborn is characteristic of Patent ductus arteriosus. Most commonly, the ductus arteriosus is just distal to the left subclavian artery and the ductus enters the pulmonary artery at its bifurcation. The image attached below shows the relations of ductus arteriosus.

options: Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosus
Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus venosus
Ductus venosus --> Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale
Ductus arteriosus --> Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale

question_text: During the examination of a neonate with documented hearing defects and bilateral zonular cataracts, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. By when should the underlying defective channel that is responsible for the murmur anatomically close?
explanation: The given vignette is suggestive of Patent ductus arteriosus in a child with congenital rubella syndrome. The anatomical closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs at 10-21 days. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery murmur. Triad of congenital rubella syndrome Sensorineural deafness Congenital heart defects – MC is PDA Cataracts Classical rubella syndrome consists of: Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis Ear defects: Sensorineural hearing loss due to destruction of organ of Corti Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects Fetal circulatory adjustment Functional closure Anatomical closu re Ductus venosus After removal of the placenta from fetal circulatory unit 7 days Foramen ovale At birth - after breathing is in itiated Months to years Ductus arteriosus 10–15 hours 10–21 days

question_text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?
options: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)
explanation: Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure. Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants. The fetal circulatory adjustments after birth are given below: The patency of ductus arteriosus may either provide an alternative route for blood to bypass congenital defects such as pulmonary atresia or coarctation of the aorta. Therapeutic medications can be used to either maintain the patency (prostaglandin E1) or promote closure (indomethacin). Drugs like indomethacin are not recommended during the third trimester of pregnancy. Functional closure Anatomical closu re Ductus venosus After removal of the placenta 7 days Foramen ovale At birth - after breathing is in itiated Months to years Ductus arterios us 10–15 hours 10–21 days

question_text: A newborn infant develops respiratory distress 2 days after birth. On examination, she is mottled and has weak upper extremity pulses and absent femoral pulses. Investigations reveal the coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following drugs can you use to keep the ductus open medically before surgical repair?
explanation: Alprostadil, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, can be used to keep the ductus open medically in the coarctation of the aorta. The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth. Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of PDA in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia and cyanosis. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle. PGE1 analogues like alprostadil, misoprost and rioprostil can be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply. In patent ductus arteriosus, the ductus is closed medically by NSAIDS (which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis) like ibuprofen trometamol/ ibuprofen lysine and indomethacin. Morphine can be used to manage respiratory distress but rarely preferred in a neonate.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 23-year-old woman with G2P1 and an ‘h-negative pregnancy gave birth to a baby with an ‘h-positive blood group. The direct Coomb's test is positive. Cord blood bilirubin level is more than 4 mg/dL. The team plans for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up exchange transfusion. But the preferred vessel seems obliterated. This obliterated fibrotic vessel would now be called as?
Medial umbilical ligaments
explanation: The umbilical vein is the preferred vessel for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up exchange transfusion. The obliterated remnant of the umbilical vein is the Ligamentum teres. The vessels that are occluded soon after birth are in due course replaced by fibrous tissue and forms the following ligaments: The median umbilical ligament or Xander's ligament represents the remnant of the embryonic urachus. The lateral umbilical ligaments are folds of the peritoneum over the inferior epigastric arteries. Note: Cord blood bilirubin level more than 4 mg/dL is an indication for change transfusion in a neonate. Fetal structure Adult structure Foramen ovale Fossa ovalis Umbilical vein Ligamentum teres Ductus venosus Ligamentum venosum Umbilical arterie s Medial umbilical ligament s Ductus arteriosu s Ligamentum arteriosum Acyanotic Congenital Heart Diseases
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common mode of inheritance of congenital heart disease is .
explanation: The most common mode of inheritance of congenital heart disease is multifactorial. Multifactorial inheritance refers to traits that are caused by a combination of inherited, environmental, and stochastic factors.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As a medical officer working under the RBSK scheme, the commonest congenital heart disease you would encounter is .
explanation: Ventricular septal defect(VSD) is the most common congenital heart disease. The prevalence of congenital heart disease is estimated at 6-8 per 1000 live births. The relative frequency of major CHD: VSD > ASD = PDA > CoA = ToF NOTE: Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic heart disease.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As an intern posted in the pediatrics department, you notice a neonate with jaundice and a characteristic blueberry muffin rash. The mother gives an antenatal history of fever with a rash in her first trimester. On examination, he has bilateral cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, and a murmur on auscultation. BERA reveals sensorineural deafness. On cardiac evaluation, which of the following is least likely to be found?
explanation: The classical triad of cataract, sensorineural deafness, and congenital heart disease point towards congenital rubella syndrome. Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not found in congenital rubella infection. Prenatal exposure to rubella increases the risk of congenital heart defects like: Patent ductus arteriosus (Most common) Peripheral pulmonic stenosis Ventricular septal defect (VSD) Myocarditis Nonspecific signs of TORCH infections are hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, jaundice, and growth restriction.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother reports to you that her baby is irritable and cries all the time. She has also noticed that her infant sweats excessively while feeding. Which of the following findings noted during the examination would you not include under NADA's major criteria?
options: Grade 2 mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area
Grade 3 pansystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border
explanation: Wide and variable S2 (Abnormal S2) is not included under Nada's major criteria. Features of congestive cardiac failure, a grade 3 pansystolic murmur with wide and variable S2, and an MDM at the mitral area suggest a diagnosis of large VSD in this baby. NADA's criteria for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease: The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease. Pansystolic murmurs are always pathological no matter their intensity. Short, soft systolic murmurs of intensity <3 are often detected during febrile illnesses, after which they disappear. Such murmurs are called innocent murmurs. Before labeling any murmur as innocent, it should be reassessed after an interval. Major criteria Minor criteria Systolic murmur grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3 Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2) Cyanosis Abnormal ECG Congestive cardiac failure Abnormal chest X-ray finding s Major criteria Minor criteria Major criteria Minor criteria Abnormal BP
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common type of ventricular septal defect is .
options: A and B have equal prevalence
explanation: Membranous is the most common type of ventricular septal defect (VSD) to occur. VSD is the most common congenital cardiac malformation. Types of VSD include membranous (most common), muscular, inlet/atrioventricular canal defects, and supracristal defects. Swiss Cheese septum: a special type of muscular VSD with defects in the mid-portion or apical region of the ventricular septum. Restrictive VSD -A small VSD where the size of the lesion is usually <5 mm. It is associated with normal right ventricular pressure. Non-restrictive VSD -A large VSD where the size of the lesion is usually >10 mm leading to equalization of pressures in the right and left ventricle.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant born to a diabetic mother was diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. On examination of the baby, all of the following features can be found except:
options: Ejection systolic murmur at the pulmonary area
Holosystolic murmur at the left 4th intercostal space
Reverse splitting of second heart sound (S2)
A mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area.
explanation: Wide, variable splitting of S2 is a feature of VSD and not reverse splitting. The basic defect in VSD is a left-to-right shunt which occurs at the ventricular level. During systole, the left ventricle empties into the aorta and the right ventricle via the VSD, because of which the total amount of blood in the right side of the heart increases, and that on the left decreases. Due to this increase, the right ventricle takes a longer time to empty causing a delayed P2 and on the other hand, the left ventricle empties sooner causing an early A2. This explains the wide S2. Variations due to respiration still happen and hence, the second heart sound is widely and variably split. Auscultatory findings of VSD include a pansystolic murmur also known as Roger's murmur/shunt murmur can be best heard in the fourth left intercostal space. Flow murmurs that can be heard include, an MDM at the mitral area and an ejection systolic murmur at the pulmonary area. A hyperdynamic precordium, a palpable P2, parasternal heave, a laterally displaced apical impulse, and a systolic thrill can be detected on palpation.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother is worried about her 4-month-old infant's growth. She says that her infant feeds slowly and often requires periods of rest during feeding. On examination:
explanation: The above findings are suggestive of a large VSD with congestive cardiac failure. On a chest X-Ray of such a patient pulmonary oligemia is not seen. “Suck- rest-suck cycle “, failure to thrive, high respiratory rate are features suggestive of congestive cardiac failure. Acyanosis, hyperdynamic precordium, palpable P2,pansystolic murmur, and MDM in the mitral area suggest a large VSD. I ventricular septal defect (VSD), there is left to right shunting of blood, and this large volume of shunted blood passes through the lungs, which is recognized in the chest X-ray as pulmonary plethora (increased pulmonary vasculature). Other findings seen on a chest X-ray include cardiomegaly with left ventricular apex. If the defect is large, frank pleural effusion can be seen. Significant cardiomegaly, prominence of the pulmonary arterial trunk, pulmonary plethora (increased vascular markings seen in the lung fields) can be seen on the X-ray image.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for immunization. She has a loud and harsh holosystolic murmur best heard over the lower left sternal border and is accompanied by a thrill. The chest radiographs and EKG are normal. Echocardiography reveals a small muscular VSD. What is the appropriate management?
options: Wait and watch till 5 years and then operate
Restrict physical activity and operate at 2 years
explanation: I patients with small VSDs, parents should be reassured of the relatively benign nature of the lesion, and the child should be encouraged to live a normal life, with no restrictions on physical activity. Surgical repair is not recommended. Guidelines from the Council on Cardiovascular Disease in the Young of the American Heart Association (AHA) state that an isolated, small, hemodynamically insignificant VSD is not an indication for surgery. VSDs may get smaller or close completely without treatment, but they won't get any bigger. Echocardiography is used to estimate pulmonary artery pressure, screen for the development of Left ventricular outflow tract pathology (subaortic membrane or aortic regurgitation), and confirm spontaneous closure.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A good surgeon knows when not to operate. As a pediatric surgeon, on which of the following cases of VSD would you operate?
explanation: Severe pulmonary vascular disease unresponsive to pulmonary vasodilators is a contraindication to the closure of a VSD - due to permanent remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature. I dications for surgical closure of a VSD include: Patients at any age with large defects in whom clinical symptoms and failure to thrive cannot be controlled medically; Infants between 6 and 12 mo of age with moderate to large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension, even if the symptoms are controlled by medication; and patients older than 24 mo with a Qp: Qs ratio greater than 2: 1. Patients with a supracristal VSD of any size are usually referred for surgery because of their higher risk for developing aortic valve regurgitatio A child with large VSD showing transient improvement in symptoms with better exercise tolerance may be the first sign of developing pulmonary hypertension and indicates an urgent need for evaluation and immediate surgery - the increased pulmonary pressure reduces the amount of blood pushed into the lungs and thereby, congestion transiently. The presence of a mid-diastolic, low-pitched rumble at the apex is caused by increased blood flow across the mitral valve and usually indicates a Qp: Qs ratio of 2: 1. This murmur is best appreciated with the bell of the stethoscope. Surgical risks are somewhat higher for defects in the muscular septum, particularly apical defects and multiple (Swiss cheese–type) VSDs. These patients may require pulmonary arterial banding if symptomatic, with subsequent de-banding and repair of multiple VSDs at an older age.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Rahel, a 3-year-old girl who is a known case of congenital heart disease is admitted to your pediatric ward because of low-grade fever with afternoon elevations. On examination, she is febrile and has painless small erythematous lesions on her palms. Her echocardiography showed oscillating intracardiac vegetation. Which one of the following congenital defects is most likely associated with the above findings?
explanation: The above findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of infective endocarditis according to Modified Duke’s criteria. Patients with high-velocity blood flow lesions such as ventricular septal defect (VSD) and aortic stenosis are at high risk for infective endocarditis. To make a diagnosis of IE,she has evidence of endocardial involvement (1 major) and fever, predisposing heart condition, Janeway lesions(a painless small erythematous lesion on palms)- 3 minor criteria. I VSD, a high-pressure gradient across the defect  turbulent blood flow  traumatizes the vascular endothelium  predisposition for infective endocarditis. Important complications of VSD include infective endocarditis and Eisenmengerisation, High-risk cardiac lesions for which endocarditis prophylaxis is advised before dental procedures and invasive procedures like tonsillectomy/adenoidectomy are prosthetic heart valves, prior endocarditis, post-cardiac transplant, congenital heart disease(6 months post repair and unrepaired).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother brings her 4-year-old child to the OPD. She says that the child has recurrent chest infections, easy fatiguability, and poor growth. You notice a limb abnormality as shown in the image below and find the given X-ray of the child's arm in his medical history. Based on all the findings, you suspect a congenital heart disease. Which of the following conditions are you most likely to find on screening echocardiography?
explanation: The X-ray of the upper limb shows radial ray defects (absent radius and thumb) and the family history of heart disease suggest a diagnosis of Holt-Oram syndrome (aka hand-heart syndrome). Out of all the syndromes associated with cardiac defects, HOLT- ORAM has the strongest familial tendency - it is inherited in an Autosomal dominant manner. Holt–Oram syndrome/cardiac limb syndrome is most commonly associated with atrial septal defect (ASD). Features of Holt-Oram syndrome include: Hypoplastic or absent thumbs, radii Triphalangism Phocomelia 1st-degree heart block ASD
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child born to a 35-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, and a protruding tongue. Karyotyping of the child is as shown below. Which of the following is commonly associated with this disorder?
explanation: The given clinical findings and the karyotyping suggest a diagnosis of Trisomy 21 or Down syndrome. The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is an endocardial cushion defect. Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension. Other congenital defects are seen in some syndromes: Syndrome Congenital defect Trisomy 21 (Down syndro me) Endocardial cushion defect, VSD, ASD XO (Turner syndrome) Bicuspid aortic valve, coarcta tion of aorta William's syndrome Supravalvular aortic stenosis, peripheral pulmonic stenosis Noonan syndrome Pulmonic stenosis, ASD Holt–Oram syndrome ASD, 1st-degree heart block Marfan's Syndrome Mitral or Aortic Regurgitatio
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
explanation: Ostium secundum ASD (labelled as 3) is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at the mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis. ASD is characterized by an abnormal opening in the atrial septum allowing communication between the right and left atria. There are four types based on their location within the septum: Secundum ASD - most common, usually an isolated abnormality Primum ASD - associated with abnormal mitral valve leaflet (partial AV septal defect) Sinus venous - is located at the junction of the superior vena cava and right atrium. Associated with anomalous right pulmonary venous return to the SVC or RA Coronary sinus type ASD - also called unroofed coronary sinus Ostium primum ASD: is located at lower atrial septum Endocardial cushion defect/An AV septal defect/ AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome. Congenital conditions associated with ASD include: Down's syndrome - usually an ostium primum defect Holt-Oram syndrome - autosomal dominant disorder with upper limb bony defects and cardiac septal defects, commonly secundum ASD Ellis-van Creveld syndrome - chondroectodermal dysplasia associated with postaxial polydactyly and ASD Lutembacher syndrome - combined ASD and mitral stenosis due to rheumatic valvulitis Mitral valve prolapse
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The age of the patient, normal physical findings except for a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed splitting of S2 are all in favor of a diagnosis of Atrial septal defect. Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. The soft ejection systolic murmur is a flow murmur heard due to increased blood flow through the normal pulmonary valve. A delayed diastolic murmur can also be heard in the tricuspid area. As the right ventricle now receives more blood, the time required for its emptying is increased resulting in prolonged P2. Since the two atria are linked, inspiration does not produce any net pressure changes between them abolishing respiration-related changes in venous return hence causing fixed S2. Causes of Wide and fixed splitting of S2 include, Atrial septal defect RBBB TAPVC Other options: TAPVC - patients usually present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure around 4-10 weeks of age - this is when the fetal pulmonary vasculature regresses and there is increased pulmonary blood flow which results in early-onset cardiac failure. The physical findings are identical to ASD. VSD - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include a pansystolic murmur best heard in the left 4th parasternal area and a wide and variable split S2 which is usually masked by the pansystolic murmur. PS - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include an ejection systolic murmur and a thrill in the left second interface and a wide and variable split S2 because of delayed closure of P2.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child who used to play for hours together now comes back home and says he gets tired too easily, his concerned mother brings him to you. On auscultation, you find that there is a wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, ECG shows left axis deviation and features of left ventricular hypertrophy. What is your probable diagnosis?
explanation: Wide splitting of the 2nd heart sound with left axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) points to the diagnosis of ostium primum atrial septal defect (ASD). Wide-fixed splitting of the 2nd heart sound is characteristic of ASD. I ostium primum ASD, the basic abnormality is the combination of left-to-right shunt across the atrial defect and mitral insufficiency due to mitral valve clefts. Mitral valvular insufficiency increases the volume load on the left ventricle (seen as LAD & LVH on ECG). When mitral insufficiency is severe enough to cause clinical symptoms like fatigue on exertion, the left atrium enlarges as a result of the regurgitant flow, and the left ventricle becomes hypertrophied and dilated.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An ECG finding of right ventricular enlargement in a 2-year-old child is most consistent with which of the following disorders?
explanation: I atrial septal defect (ASD), there is a left-to-right shunt, resulting in increased blood flow through the right side of the heart, which leads to enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle and dilation of the pulmonary artery, the left atrium may also be enlarged, but the left ventricle and aorta are normal in size. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): There is shunting of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary trunk, which goes into the lungs and then again to the LA and LV. If the ductus is large, left ventricular or biventricular hypertrophy is present. I ventricular septal defect (VSD), there is shunting of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, but most of the blood is shunted directly to the inflow tract of the pulmonary trunk, so, there is no significant right ventricular hypertrophy. In VSD, the pulmonary artery left atrium, and left ventricle are enlarged. I Tricuspid atresia, there is right to left shunting of blood through an ASD as the tricuspid valve is dysfunctional due to which the entire systemic venous return enters the left side of the heart using the foramen ovale or through an ASD, and hence, there is left ventricular hypertrophy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During an outreach program, you incidentally discover a child with an asymptomatic ASD. His parents are anxious as they had read on the web about transcatheter device closure and want to know if their child needs one. Your advice is he does not require it, for now, but needs regular follow-up. During the course of follow-up, you would take up the child for transcatheter device closure immediately in all of the following instances except:
options: If the size of the defect is <5mm at 2 years of age.
If the Qp: Qs ratio is > 2:1
explanation: An ASD defect of size <5mm at 2 years of age does not need immediate transcatheter device closure. Small ASDs (3 to <6mm in diameter) may grow smaller or close spontaneously. They do not cause symptoms and usually only need observation. Transcatheter device or surgical closure is advised for: All symptomatic patients Asymptomatic patients with a Qp: Qs ratio of at least 2: 1 Those with RV enlargement. ASD size >8mm Closure (if indicated) is recommended before school entry. Repair is preferred during early childhood because surgical mortality and morbidity are significantly greater in adulthood.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As an obstetrician, you discover an atrial septal defect incidentally in a 20-year-old primigravida. You will be watchful about all of the following complications, except:
explanation: I fective endocarditis is extremely rare in isolated atrial septal defect (ASD) and antibiotic prophylaxis for isolated ASDs is not recommended. ASD is a low-pressure gradient defect whereas a high-pressure gradient across a defect is required to create a turbulent flow, which traumatizes the vascular endothelium, making the patient susceptible to endocarditis. Patients with a small or moderate ASD are asymptomatic unless a complication occurs. Pulmonary hypertension, atrial dysrhythmias, tricuspid or mitral insufficiency, and heart failure may initially appear during the increased volume load of pregnancy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: I a NICU you examine a preterm baby, who has a loud, harsh, continuous, machinery murmur in the Gibson area. All of the following can be found, except:
explanation: A preterm baby with the classical continuous machinery murmur in the Gibson’s area is in favor of patent ductus arteriosus as the diagnosis. Preterm babies with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) have wide pulse pressure, hyperdynamic precordium, and bounding peripheral pulses with a continuous murmur. If the PDA is large, it can cause overloading of the left ventricle leading to cardiomegaly and congestive heart failure. Retrograde aortic flow, decreased systemic blood flow, and moderate hypotension is common in premature infants with a PDA predisposing them to necrotizing enterocolitis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
You are posted as an intern in the pediatrics OPD and your professor asks you to examine a interesting case of cyanosis. On examination, you notice the bluish discoloration of the lower limbs but the upper limb and head are pink and on examination of the chest you see a
parasternal heave and a thrill is palpable. These findings can occur in which of the following?
explanation: Differential cyanosis can be seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) when there is a reversal of shunt. Differential cyanosis is manifested as cyanosis of only the lower extremities while upper extremities are unaffected. It is a result of reduced arterial oxygen saturation in the distal aorta compared to that in the aorta proximal to the left subclavian artery. It is seen with: right-to-left shunting across a ductus arteriosus in the presence of coarctation or an interrupted aortic arch patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with severe pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) The rest of the options cause cyanosis of all extremities. Among the options, PDA is the only condition that can manifest with differential cyanosis when there is a reversal of shunt. Image: Right to left shunting of blood flow through a PDA between the aortic arch and pulmonary artery.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago?
explanation: The right upper limb is the best area to check pre-ductal oxygen saturation in a newborn infant as it receives blood supply primarily from the right brachial artery, which arises from the aorta before the ductus arteriosus. I routine neonatal screening for critical congenital heart diseases (CCHD), saturation probes are placed on the right upper limb (pre-ductal) and the right lower limb (post-ductal) respectively. If the difference between pre-ductal and post-ductal saturation is more than five percent, it confirms the presence of hypoxemia. Any reading showing an SpO2 <90% or greater than a three percent difference between the right hand and right foot for three successive readings separated by an hour each would suggest the presence of a congenital cardiac disease. Screening is done to identify critical conditions before they present symptomatically, and before the neonate leaves the hospital post-delivery. This would allow for early and effective treatment of an underlying disease. Critical congenital heart diseases include coarctation of the aorta, double outlet right ventricle, Ebstein anomaly, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, interrupted aortic arch, pulmonary atresia, single ventricle, tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC), d-transposition of the great arteries (TGA), tricuspid atresia, and truncus arteriosus.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During neonatal resuscitation of a baby delivered via Cesarean section, you hear a continuous murmur. Which of the following would you not include in your differential diagnosis?
explanation: Small ventricular septal defect (VSD) characteristically produces a loud, harsh, or blowing holosystolic murmur (not continuous murmur) and is heard best over the lower left sternal border; it is frequently accompanied by a thrill. Pansystolic or holosystolic murmurs begin almost simultaneously with the 1st heart sound and continue throughout systole (do not spill into diastole like a continuous murmur). Continuous murmur is a systolic murmur that continues or “spills” into diastole and indicates continuous flow, such as in the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus or other aortopulmonary communication. Other options: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): The classic continuous murmur is described as being like machinery in quality. Aortopulmonary window: The findings can mimic those of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) (wide pulse pressure and a continuous murmur). Pulmonary arteriovenous malformations: Large fistulas are associated with dyspnea, cyanosis, clubbing, a continuous murmur, and polycythemia, commonly associated with Osler Weber Rendu disease.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-year-old boy starts seizing while playing catch with his father. He is immediately brought to the casualty. On examination, blood pressure in the upper extremity measured as 200/140 mm Hg and femoral pulses were not palpable. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Here, the diagnosis is coarctation of the aorta because the classic sign of coarctation of the aorta is a disparity in pulsation and blood pressure in the arms and legs (as seen in this patient). The femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak (or absent in up to 40% of patients), in contrast to the bounding pulses of the arms and carotid vessels. Seizure is a complication secondary to systemic hypertension since untreated coarctation can increase the risk for intracranial hemorrhage and hypertensive encephalopathy. The most common site of coarctation of the aorta is distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery near the insertion of ligamentum arteriosum (juxtaductal coarctation). DDx: Takayasu arteritis is a chronic vasculitis of unknown etiology, predominantly affecting women with an age of onset that is usually between 10 and 40 years. The disease primarily affects the aorta and its primary branches.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A chest X-ray of a patient shows inferior rib notching. Which of the following diseases would you include in your differential diagnosis?
explanation: Notching of the inferior border of the ribs (four to eighth ribs) from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is a characteristic finding in the coarctation of the aorta by late childhood. What’s your diagnosis and which is the most common anomaly associated with reference to the X-ray given below?

Transposition of great vessels , renal dysplasia

Coarctation of aorta, renal dysplasia
options: Transposition of great vessels, bicuspid aortic valve
explanation: The given X-ray demonstrates the “3” sign, which is pathognomic of coarctation of aorta. question_text: You are called to see a cyanotic neonate in the NICU. You note that the neonate has an oxygen saturation of 60%. Which of the following would not be in your differential diagnosis
options: Ventricular septal defect with pulmonic stenosis
explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of cyanotic congenital heart disease. Isolated infundibular stenosis would not be in the differential diagnosis because it is an acyanotic congenital heart disease. question_text: Which of the following is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease?
explanation: The most common cyanotic congenital heart disease is tetralogy of Fallot (ToF). Infants are often asymptomatic until later in life (beyond 1yr of life). TOF has 4 components: Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis) Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD) Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), an Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Below is an X-ray of an infant with cyanotic heart diease. Which is not a finding seen here?
explanation: Cyanosis and boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French) points towards tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and the atrial septal defect is not a finding seen in TOF. Clinical findings in TOF: Right ventricular hypertrophy causing left anterior hemithorax bulge. Single S2 or soft P2 because of the stenotic pulmonary valve Systolic thrill in the left sternal border in 3rd and 4th parasternal spaces. The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle. There is a loud and harsh systolic murmur due to the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction. It becomes louder, longer, and harsher as obstruction increases in severity from mil to moderate. However in severe obstruction, especially during tet spell, the murmur becomes less prominent as the blood is shunted towards the aortic valve and not through RVOT. Ray in TOF showing boot shaped heart: Acyanotic/pink tetralogy of Fallot: This occurs when obstruction to the right ventricular outflow is mild to moderate. The blood would flow more through the mildly obstructed RVOT and less through the VSD. Hence, there is less cyanosis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time. Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked like that of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?
options: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse
explanation: The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation. In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle. Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure. Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart. Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A primary school teacher notices a peculiar behavior in one of her pupils. Whenever he plays with his friends, she notices that her fingers and lips turn blue. The child then squats for sometime after which he feels better. Which of the following does not occur during squatting?
options: It increases the systemic vascular resistance
It increases the magnitude of right-to-left shunt
Leads to trapping of deoxygenated blood in lower limbs
explanation: Squatting decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt in a child with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) . The child feels comfortable while squatting due to two compensatory mechanisms: Increasing systemic vascular resistance and, thus, decreasing the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Therefore, more blood goes to the lungs for oxygenation. Trapping deoxygenated venous blood in the lower limbs.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: While waiting for corrective open-heart surgery, you decide to manage a case of tet spells medically. Which of the following drugs would worsen the cyanosis?
explanation: Isoprenaline/isoproterenol should be avoided in tet or hypercyanotic spells. It will cause a decrease in total peripheral resistance (TPR) or systemic vascular resistance (SVR). So, more blood leaves the left ventricle leading to the increased right to left shunt. This results in the worsening of right ventricular outflow and causes worsening of cyanosis and the symptoms. Treatment of hypercyanotic spell involves placing child in knee–chest position (or squatting), and use of: oxygen morphine - sedates the patient sodium bicarbonate - to counteract metabolic acidosis that develops when arterial Po2 <40 mmHg alpha-agonists (phenylephrine)- vasopressor used in severe cases beta-blockers (propranolol)- improves resting saturation and decreases the frequency of spells. Drugs that increase SVR, such as IV phenylephrine (alpha-1 agonist) or propranolol (non-selective beta-antagonist/beta-2 block), can improve right ventricular outflow, decrease the right-to-left shunt, and improve the symptoms. This is same principle as squatting.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Blalock-Taussig shunt is done between .
explanation: Blalock–Taussig shunt is done between subclavian artery to pulmonary artery Blalock–Taussig shunt is currently the most common aortopulmonary shunt procedure and consists of a Gore-Tex conduit. Sometimes, the shunt is brought directly from the ascending aorta to the main pulmonary artery; in this case, it is called the central shunt. Corrective open-heart surgery performed in critically ill newborns and early infancy is the preferred surgical treatment now.
