question_text: Which of the following is a component of the pentalogy of Fallot?
explanation: Pentalogy of Fallot consists of Tetralogy of Fallot: Ventricular septal defect + Pulmonic stenosis + Overriding of the aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy Atrial septal defect
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
An adolescent who is a known case of VSD is brought by his parents with complaints of breathlessness on exertion which is gradually progressive, bluish discoloration, and swelling of toes and fingers. Investigations showed features suggestive of pulmonary hypertension.
Which of the following is not a part of the condition?
explanation: Given clinical scenario along with the development of pulmonary hypertension is seen in Eisenmenger’s syndrome and predominant right to left shunt (not left to right shunt) is seen here. Gradual onset of cyanosis, dyspnoea, fatigue, and in later stages, heart failure, chest pain, headaches, syncope, and hemoptysis in a setting of congenital acyanotic heart disease, are signs and symptoms of Eisenmenger’s syndrome. Reversal of the shunt at the level of atria/ventricles/patent ductus arteriosus due to irreversible pulmonary vascular obstructive changes is defined as Eisenmenger’s syndrome. Features of pulmonary hypertension in Eisenmenger physiology: Right ventricular heave, narrow split S 2 with a loud pulmonic component. Chest X-ray showing prominent pulmonary artery and right ventricle, peripheral pruning of pulmonary vessels. ECG shows features of right ventricular hypertrophy, with spiked P waves. Treatment: Calcium channel blockers, prostacyclin, and it's analog treprostinil and lung transplantation.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection is .
explanation: The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) is supracardiac. In TAPVC, pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly. Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior venacava or left innominate vein. Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus. Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A neonate was noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Chest x-ray revealed a snowman appearance of the cardiac silhouette. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Snowman's appearance on the chest X-ray image is classically seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC). The supracardiac variant can classically depict a snowman appearance/figure of 8/cottage loaf heart on the frontal chest radiograph. The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. The image given above shows a snowman or figure-8 configuration. Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
You are examining a week-old male infant who was severely cyanotic at birth in the
post-operative ward. He has undergone balloon atrial septostomy following prostaglandin E1 administration. Post-surgery there was a marked improvement in cyanosis. The most likely diagnosis is .
explanation: Cyanosis at birth, prostagladin E1 administration, and septostomy to improve oxygenation are typical features of transposition of great vessels (TGA). TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur: At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD) At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD) At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic “egg-on-string appearance”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels. Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 24-year-old woman with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy expresses intent to conceive. She must be advised to stop the drug due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
explanation: She must be asked to stop the intake of lithium as it can cause an Ebstein anomaly in the newborn. Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets. Lithium can also cause macrocephaly as a teratogenic effect.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Akshay, a high schooler presents to you with swelling of fingers and toes. He said he gets palpitations while he is exercising and even when he hangs out with friends. An X-Ray of the patient is given below. ECG showed the presence of delta waves. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The diagnosis is Ebstein's anomaly. The presence of clubbing and a box-shaped heart on chest X-Ray in the given case is suggestive of Ebstein’s anomaly. Clubbing develops secondary to cyanosis as ebstein's anomaly is a right to left shunt. Delta wave is observed in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. WPW and supraventricular tachycardia causing palpitations can be seen in association with Ebstein’s anomaly.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In a 13-year-old child with Ebstein's anomaly, echocardiography would likely reveal:
explanation: Tricuspid regurgitation would be seen in a child with an Ebstein anomaly. Mild cases develop cyanosis during adolescence or early adulthood. In severe cases, cyanosis manifests at birth. Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets. In Ebstein's, tricuspid valve tissue is dysplastic and results in tricuspid regurgitation. The right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow and there will be functional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septal defect (ASD) results in cyanosis at birth. Himalayan P wave (amplitude > 5 mm) is associated with tricuspid atresia, Ebstein anomaly, and combined tricuspid and pulmonary stenosis, where they indicate a dilated right atrium. Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome (WPW) and supraventricular tachycardia may be present in Ebstein anomaly. Note: In Ebstein anomaly, the malformed tricuspid valve is usually regurgitant, but may rarely be stenotic.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A cyanotic newborn is suspected of having congenital heart disease. He has an increased left ventricular impulse and a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border. ECG shows left axis deviation and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Clinical cyanosis in combination with left-axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) noted on the electrocardiogram distinguishes tricuspid atresia from most other cyanotic heart lesions. Other points in favor: Increased left ventricular impulse (in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, in which an increased right ventricular impulse). Holosystolic murmurs audible along the left sternal border (due to associated ventricular septal efect). Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of the tricuspid valve. So, blood cannot flow directly from the right atrium to the right ventricle, and the following associated defects are necessary for survival: Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle There is a hypoplastic right ventricle. Option B and D: Truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot and - The ECG demonstrates right axis deviation (RAD) and evidence of RVH. Option A: Transposition of great arteries- ECG is usually normal, showing the neonatal right-sided dominant pattern.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are examining a case of cyanosis in NICU as a resident. Which of the following cardiac features would make the diagnosis of tricuspid atresia unlikely?
explanation: Left ventricular hypoplasia would make the diagnosis unlikely as right ventricular hypoplasia is seen in tricuspid atresia. Other features of tricuspid atresia: An increased left ventricular impulse is noted in contrast to an increased right ventricular impulse seen in most other cyanotic diseases. A VSD holosystolic murmur is audible along the left sternal border. The second heart sound (S2) is usually single. Left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation on ECG. Tall, peaked P waves on lead II known as Himalayan P waves which are suggestive of an enlarged right atrium.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following cases could develop recurrent infections due to pulmonary congestion?
explanation: Patients with atrial and ventricular septal defects have increased pulmonary blood flow. This results in recurrent pulmonary infection due to congestion in the lungs. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and tricuspid atresia (TA) are associated with reduced pulmonary blood flow (oligemic lung fields). They do not cause pulmonary congestion and do not predispose to infections. Reduced pulmonary blood flow is due to Right ventricular outflow obstruction in tetralogy of Fallot Right ventricular inflow obstruction in tricuspid atresia Cyanotic congenital heart diseases (CCHD) with decreased and increased pulmonary blood flow: Decreased pulmonary blood f low Increased pulmonary blood fl ow Tetrology of FallotPulmonary atresiaEbstein's anomalyTric uspid atresia with an intact v entricular septumTranspositi on of the great vessels with V SD and pulmonary stenosis Transposition of the great ve ssels with VSD or PDATotal a nomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC)Truncus arter iosusHypoplastic left heart sy ndrome (HLHS)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A cyanotic baby at the 8th hour of life is being evaluated in NICU. Pulse oximetry shows 80 % not improving with 100 % O2. Records show that continuous machinery murmur was heard at birth but not anymore. Which of the following can be done?
explanation: This baby has a cyanotic congenital heart disease that is dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus. Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents the closure of PDA in term neonates with duct-dependent congenital heart disease (CHD). Cyanosis failing to improve with 100% oxygen suggests an underlying cyanotic CHD. Functional closure of the PDA occurs soon after birth, usually within first week of life. The open PDA acted as a conduit between systemic and pulmonary circulations, thereby preventing the onset of cyanosis. Upon its closure, cyanosis manifested in the baby as the blood could not be pumped into the lungs for oxygenation. Deoxygenated blood is being shunted into the systemic circulation after the closure of PDA. Hence, you should maintain the patency of the duct with PGE1 infusion until surgery can be done. Duct-dependent lesions: Anomalies, in a newborn with CHD, which are dependent on the patency of ductus arteriosus for survival. Right-sided lesions (Tetralogy of Fallot, PA/PS) cannot pump blood to the lungs. These patients are dependent on an open PDA for pulmonary circulation. Left-sided lesions (Hypoplastic left heart syndrome, Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of aorta) cannot pump blood into the systemic circulation. These patients are dependent on open PDA for systemic circulation.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of:
explanation: The given chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette which is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped (coeur en sabot) cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields appear relatively clear due to reduced pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries, or both. In Ebsteins's anomaly (Option D) box-shaped heart is seen.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which among the following options describes the chest x-ray image?
explanation: The given chest x-ray shows 'coeur-en-sabot' or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The characteristic silhouette is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries and the aorta is usually enlarged. The image below describes the likeness of the cardiac silhouette to a boot: TOF is cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components: Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis) Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD) Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta) Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild°, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe°, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period. Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterised by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initially awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis. Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child is able to resume the activity.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest x-ray except:
explanation: The given chest x-ray shows an egg-on-string appearance seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). Enlargement of the left atrium is seen in TGA, not the right atrium. The reason for left atrial enlargement is due to increased pulmonary blood flow. TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This abnormal configuration leads to a narrow vascular pedicle. As pulmonary vascular resistance drops during the first few days of life, blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature is increased. There is also elevated pulmonary venous pressure seen in TGA, especially in infants with an intact interventricular septum. The globular (egg) appearance of the heart due to abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and the narrow superior mediastinum (string) result in the classical egg-on-string appearance. TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers. Early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductus arteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy is a palliative catheter-based intervention that can be done to improve the hypoxic state before definitive surgery. The procedure creates an opening in the atrial septum which allows better inter-circulatory mixing of the blood. Jatene arterial switch procedure is the definitive surgery. Most infants with TGA do not survive till adulthood without corrective surgery.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Below is the chest X-ray image obtained for a neonate on day 7 of life who developed heart failure later■. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Tetralogy of Fallot
explanation: The classic "egg on end" appearance on this chest X-ray image is seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). In the chest X-ray image, cardiomegaly with narrow mediastinum gives rise to the classic “egg-shaped heart.” The superior mediastinum appears narrow due to the anteroposterior relationship of the transposed great vessels and the radiologic absence of the thymus. Pediatric Nephrology
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Hematuria in children is defined as the presence of at least RBCs per high power field in uncentrifuged urine.
explanation: Hematuria in children is defined as the presence of at least 5 RBCs/HPF (high power field) in uncentrifuged urine. When using commercially available dipsticks (capable of detecting 3-5 RBCs / HPF of urine), the presence of 10-50 RBCs/L suggests an underlying pathology. False-negative results can occur in the presence of Formali High urinary concentrations of ascorbic acid False-positive results, on the other hand, may be see With alkaline urine (pH > 8) Contamination with oxidizing agents such as hydrogen peroxide (used to clean the perineum before obtaining a specimen)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 11-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of multiple episodes of passing blood in the urine. Which of the following condition is not associated with this symptom?
explanation: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) presents with acute-onset microscopic hematuria not recurrent gross hematuria. Causes of recurrent gross hematuria: Alport’s syndrome: hereditary nephritis Thin glomerular basement membrane disease IgA nephropathy: Berger’s disease Idiopathic hypercalciuria/hyperuricosuria Sickle cell nephropathy (papillary necrosis)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old girl with urinary complaints was brought to the hospital by her parents. On further enquiry, they mention a history of skin lesions 5 weeks back. Low C3 levels are found during her investigations. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals a “lumpy-bumpy” pattern of immunoglobulin and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is not typically associated with this condition?
explanation: Urinary complaints with a history of skin lesions (pyoderma) point towards a likely diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Results of complement study and immunofluorescence microscopy also correlate with this diagnosis. Frothy urine is due to proteinuria, which is a feature of nephrotic syndrome. Classic features of nephritic syndrome/glomerulonephritis: Cola coloured urine (hematuria) Oliguria Hypertensio Facial or body edema
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Akshay, accompanied by his father, presents to the OPD with complaints of cola-coloured urine and facial puffiness for 3 days. He has a history of fever with a sore throat that resolved 2 weeks back. Which of the following findings is consistent with the diagnosis of
post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
options: C3 level increases and ASO level increases
C3 level decreases and ASO level increases
C3 level decreases and ASO level decreases
C3 level increases and ASO level decreases
explanation: C3 level decreases and ASO level increases in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Acute PSGN is a classic example of an acute nephritic syndrome characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, oedema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It follows infection of the throat or skin by certain nephritogenic strains of group A -hemolytic streptococci- 1 to 2 weeks after an antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis?
explanation: Hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis is typically painless. Hematuria from within the glomerulus is often associated with brown-, cola-, or tea-colored urine. Urine analysis reveals RBC casts and deformed urinary RBCs (particularly acanthocytes).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 7-year-old boy presents with decreased urine output for 3 days. He has a history of sore throat 2 weeks back. On examination, he is hypertensive with pitting pedal oedema. The diagnosis is concluded as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is true about this condition?
options: Renal biopsy is indicated in severe impairment of renal function.
explanation: The given clinical vignette of oliguria, pedal edema and hypertension point towards glomerulonephritis. Severe impairment of renal functions in a background of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is an indication for renal biopsy. Indications for renal biopsy in glomerulonephritis: Presence of acute renal failure or nephrotic syndrome Absence of evidence of streptococcal infectio Presence of normal complement levels Persistence of hematuria and proteinuria, diminished renal function, and/or a low C3 level for more than 2 months after the disease onset Serum triglycerides (Option A) are elevated in nephrotic syndrome, not in nephritic syndrome. The acute phase generally resolves within 6 to 8 weeks. Although urinary protein excretion and hypertension usually normalize by 4-6 wk after onset, microscopic hematuria (Option B) can persist for 1 to 2 years after the initial presentation. The serum C3 level (Option C) is significantly reduced in >90% of patients in the acute phase, and returns to normal 6-8 weeks after onset.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old boy with a previously diagnosed renal disorder is brought to your OPD with the following reports for a second opinion. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The findings mentioned are characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Findings in PSGN: Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix. Polymorphoneutrophil (PMN) infiltration in the early stages. Immunofluorescence: “Lumpy-bumpy” deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM. The image given below depicts the microscopic picture of PSGN. It shows glomerular hypercellularity due to intracapillary leukocytes. Neutrophilic infiltration is present and is marked with purple hematoxylin stain (black arrows). Other options: Idiopathic rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis: Light microscopy: Crescents develop in several forms of glomerulonephritis (are a characteristic response to the deposition of fibrin in Bowman’s space) Electron microscopy: No deposits Focal segmental glomerulonephritis: Light microscopy: Focal sclerotic lesions Electron microscopy: Foot process fusio Minimal change disease: Light microscopy: Normal Electron microscopy Effacement of foot process
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-year-old boy presented with cola-coloured urine, decreased urine output, and facial puffiness for 3 days. He had a history of skin infection 4 weeks back. On examination, he is found to be hypertensive. His serum C3 levels are low and ASO levels are increased. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?
explanation: The features of hematuria, oliguria, facial oedema present with a history of skin infection points towards the diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Results of complement study and ASO levels also support this diagnosis. Supportive conservative therapy is the best step in the management of PSGN. Management of PSGN is directed at treating the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium restriction and prescribing diuretics - usually with intravenous furosemide) and hypertension. Although a 10-day course of systemic antibiotic therapy with penicillin is recommended to limit the spread of the nephritogenic organisms, antibiotic therapy does not a■ect the natural history of acute PSGN. Note: Steroids and cyclosporine are not used in the management of PSGN.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Sarthak, a 7-year-old boy, was brought to the emergency department by his parents with complaints of blurred vision and severe headache since today morning. They mentioned an episode of fits 2 hours back following which they rushed him to the hospital. On further enquiry, it was elicited that the child had decreased urine output for 5 days with cola coloured urine. He was hypertensive with bilateral pitting pedal oedema. The doctor remembered that Sarthak has a glomerular disorder warranting him multiple prior ward admissions and his existing condition could be a possible complication of the same. All of the following are commonly seen as a complication of this disorder except-
explanation: The given features of oliguria, hematuria, pedal edema and hypertension are likely of glomerulonephritis. The complication of hypertensive encephalopathy is seen in this case due to symptoms of seizure, blurred vision and severe headache. Hyperkalemia and left ventricular failure are also common complications of glomerulonephritis while bleeding diasthesis is not a complication of glomerulonephritis. Acute complications of glomerulonephritis result from hypertension and acute renal dysfunction- Hypertension is seen in 60% of patients and is sometimes associated with hypertensive encephalopathy and intracranial bleeding. Acute renal failure can occur, which may require treatment with dialysis. Other potential complications include the following: Heart failure Hyperkalemia Hyperphosphatemia Hypocalcemia Hyponatremia Acidosis Seizures Uremia
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 9-year-old boy presents with gross hematuria 2 days after an episode of diarrhoea. The serum C3 levels are normal. Light microscopy demonstrates focal and segmental mesangial proliferation and increased mesangial matrix in the glomerulus. What is the probable
diagnosis?
explanation: Gross hematuria following a gastrointestinal infection, associated with normal C3 levels, in a male patient is suggestive of immunoglobulin A nephropathy (Berger nephropathy). IgA nephropathy is the most common chronic glomerular disease in children. Focal and segmental mesangial proliferation and increased mesangial matrix are seen in the glomerulus. It is characterized by a predominance of IgA within mesangial glomerular deposits in the absence of systemic disease. It is seen more often in males. Gross hematuria occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection (in contrast to the long latency period observed in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis). It can be associated with loin pain. Normal serum levels of C3 in IgA nephropathy (help to distinguish this disorder from PSGN). Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic value because they are elevated in only a few paediatric patients.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tract infection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury in this condition?
explanation: The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial cell. Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseases characterized by the deposition of immune complexes. Mesangial cell diseases: IgA nephropathy IgM nephropathy Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis Class II lupus nephritis Diabetic nephropathy Note: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks is observed in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: ANCA-positive , pauci-immune glomerulonephritis include-
explanation: Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinct forms: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis) Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly called Churg–Strauss syndrome (CSS) Kidney biopsies typically demonstrate crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no immune complex deposition. ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) comprises a group of multi-systemic diseases affecting small-to-medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by the presence of ANCA with specificity for either proteinase-3 (PR3) or myeloperoxidase (MPO). Absence or paucity of immune complex deposits in vessel walls is very characteristic, hence the name “pauci-immune vasculitis.”
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-year-old girl presented with complaints of cough, hemoptysis and swelling of both legs. Urinalysis was notable for hematuria and proteinuria. Serum anti-GBM antibodies were positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The diagnosis is Goodpasture disease (anti-GBM antibody disease). Anti–glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies are diagnostic. "Goodpasture syndrome" is characterized by pulmonary haemorrhage and glomerulonephritis and "Goodpasture disease" is used for those patients with glomerulonephritis, pulmonary hemorrhage, and anti-GBM antibodies. It is caused due to autoantibodies directed against type IV collagen, which is present in the alveoli and glomerular basement membrane. Currently, the preferred term for both conditions is “anti-GBM antibody disease”. Other options along with the pathogenesis of glomerular diseases: IgA nephropathy- mesangial cell disease due to immune complex depositio Minimal change disease- epithelial cell disease due to flattening of podocytes
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Microscopic analysis of his renal biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following finding?
explanation: The boy in this clinical scenario has characteristic features of Henoch–Schonlein purpura (HSP). The renal biopsy in this patient will show mesangial proliferation with mesangial deposition of IgA HSP is a common small-vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. About half the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis. The nephritis associated with HSP usually follows the onset of the rash The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All are features of Alport syndrome except-
explanation: Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive hearing loss) is a feature of Alport syndrome (AS). AS or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease (most have X-linked inheritance) caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membranes. Clinical features of Alport syndrome: Hematuria: All patients have asymptomatic microscopic hematuria. Recurrent episodes of gross hematuria may be seen 1-2 days after an upper respiratory infection. Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive) Ocular abnormalities: anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, corneal erosions Proteinuria: Progressive proteinuria, often exceeding 1 g/ 24 hrs, is common by the 2nd decade of life.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 16-year-old boy presented with dark coloured urine. Urinalysis was notable for macroscopic hematuria and heavy proteinuria. His father is a known case of Alport syndrome. What defect is responsible for this condition?
explanation: A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible for Alport syndrome. Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All of the following syndromes are associated with renal disease except .
explanation: Sinding–Larsen–Johansson syndrome is an insertional periostitis at the inferior pole of the patella (not associated with Renal disease). Lowe syndrome Oculocerebrorenal syndrome: Hypotonia, renal disease Denys–Drash Syndrome Associated withWilm's tumor: Early-onset renal failure with renal mesangial sclerosis, m ale pseudohermaphroditism Alport syndrome Bilateral sensorineuralhearin g loss, renal disease Sinding–Larsen–Johansson s yndrome Periostitisat the inferior pole of the patella
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Microalbuminuria is defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of .
explanation: Microalbuminuria is defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of 30–300 mg/24 hrs. Here, the presence of albumin in the urine is above the normal level but below the detectable range for the urine-dipstick methods. It is commonly associated with glomerular hyperfiltration and blood pressure elevation. In adults, persistent microalbuminuria indicates diabetic nephropathy and is also a predictor of cardiovascular and renal disease. In children, microalbuminuria is associated with obesity and predicts the development of diabetic nephropathy in type 1 diabetes mellitus.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 5-year-old boy presents with facial puffiness and frothy urine. Upon investigating, his urine was positive for proteins with no hematuria and no RBC casts. To conclude the diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome, the range of proteinuria is defined as > mg/m2/hr and urine protein:creatinine ratio of > .
explanation: The currently accepted definitions of “nephrotic range proteinuria” include: Urine protein: creatinine ratio > 2 Urine protein > 40 mg/m2/hr Urine protein 3+ or 4+ in dipstick test As a consequence of the large urinary loss of protein, the patient develops hypoalbuminemia (< 2.5 g/dL) and gross edema.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: It is expected to see all of the following clinical features in a 5-year-old boy with nephrotic syndrome except-
explanation: Hematuria is not a usual feature of nephrotic syndrome. It is a feature of nephritic syndrome. However, occasionally it is seen in the FSGS variant of nephrotic syndrome as well. Classic features of nephrotic syndrome: Nephrotic range proteinuria ( >40mg/m2/hr urine protein: creatinine ratio >2) Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL) Edema Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL) Hypercoagulability
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children?
explanation: The commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease. (85% of cases). The glomeruli appear almost normal on microscopy, hence the name. Immunofluorescence microscopy are negative, and electron microscopy shows effacement of the epithelial cell foot processes. Treatment: Steroids; 95% of patients respond. Other options: Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly; it is a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis: All patients have asymptomatic hematuria; progressive proteinuria is common only by the 2nd decade of life and can be severe enough to cause nephrotic syndrome. This nephrotic syndrome is not common in children. IgA nephropathy presents more commonly as an acute nephritic syndrome or with asymptomatic hematuria. It presents with nephrotic syndrome quite rarely.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 5-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling around the eyes, abdomen and feet for 2 weeks. On investigating, his urine was positive for 4+ proteinuria with absent hematuria. A spot urine protein: creatinine ratio was reported to be
2.5. His serum albumin was 2.3 g/dL and serum creatinine was 0.5 mg/dL. Serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels were also elevated. A diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome was concluded. Which of the following correctly mentions the aetiology of its most common variant in children?
explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is concluded as the diagnosis here because of the symptoms of anasarca and proteinuria. A spot urine protein:creatinine ratio >2, low serum albumin levels, and hyperlipidemia marked by high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, further add to this diagnosis. Minimal change disease is the commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and constitutes 85% of all paediatric cases. The etiology is due to the flattening of foot processes (podocytes) of epithelial cells (seen on electron microscopy). This finding is marked in the image given below. Here, the glomeruli appear normal or show a minimal increase in mesangial cells and matrix. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Epithelial cells, in conjunction with the basement membrane, allow the filtration of plasma solutes but block the passage of cells and plasma proteins. Hence, this epithelial cell disease, disrupts the filtration barrier, resulting in proteinuria. More than 95% of children with minimal change disease respond to corticosteroid therapy. Causes of epithelial cell injury: Minimal change disease Membranous nephropathy Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis Class V lupus nephritis Diabetic nephropathy
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is not a cause of hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome?
options: Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletio
Increase in hepatic production of fibrinoge
Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S
explanation: Increased (and not decreased) platelet number and aggregability cause hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome. Hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome is due to all of the following factors: Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletio Increase in hepatic production of fibrinoge Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S Increased platelet number and aggregability
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 4-year-old boy presents with facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and serum cholesterol was also elevated. What is the initial treatment of choice?
explanation: The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone. Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral oedema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome. They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended. Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows: Cyclophosphamide Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus Mycophenolate Levamisole Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after
weeks of corticosteroid therapy.
explanation: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks of corticosteroid therapy. According to the latest Indian Society of Pediatric nephrology(ISPN) guidelines, it is defined as the absence of remission despite 6-weeks therapy with prednisolone at daily dose of 60mg/m2
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?
options: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be give
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child’s sibling
explanation: In a child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines can be given. Option A: Live virus vaccines are administered with caution in children receiving corticosteroid therapy. They can be given to patients in whom the prednisone dose is below 1mg/kg daily or 2mg/kg on alternate days. If the patient is receiving corticosteroid-sparing agents (cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine), live virus vaccines are contraindicated. Option C: Only live vaccines are contraindicated in this child. Full pneumococcal vaccination (with the 13-valent conjugate vaccine and 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine) and influenza vaccination can be given annually to the child and their household contacts. Option D: Immunization of siblings/healthy household contacts with live vaccines is necessary to reduce the risk of infection transmission to the immunosuppressed child. Direct exposure to the gastrointestinal/respiratory secretions of the household contacts is avoided for about 3-6 weeks after vaccination. Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is characterized by heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. The diagnosis is confirmed by performing a urinalysis and urine protein: creatinine ratio. Nephrotic range proteinuria is proteinuria greater than 3.5 g per 24 hours (3+ or 4+) or a urine protein : creatinine ratio exceeding 2. The recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome is a daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) of prednisolone for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks. Definitions regarding the course of nephrotic syndrome: Frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome: 2 relapses in 6 months or 3 or more relapses in 12 months. Steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome: Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks of discontinuation. Steroid resistance: Failure to achieve remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone for 6 weeks Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are cyclophosphamide, calcineurin inhibitors: cyclosporine and Tacrolimus, mycophenolate, levamisole, and rituximab (a chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Congenital nephrotic syndrome is defined as nephrotic syndrome manifesting .
options: At birth or within 3 months of life
At birth or within 6 months of life
At birth or within 1 year of life
explanation: Congenital nephrotic syndrome is defined as nephrotic syndrome manifesting at birth or within 3 months of life. It may be Primary: Due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2. Secondary: Due to in utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis, HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 11-year-old boy with a chronic hepatitis B infection develops nephrotic syndrome. What would be the most likely pathology encountered in renal biopsy of this child?
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests that the pathology would be membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy can be secondarily caused by Hepatitis B infection. Membranous nephropathy: Membranous nephropathy is a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is classified as the primary, idiopathic form, where there is an isolated renal disease, or secondary, where nephropathy is associated with other identifiable systemic diseases or medications In children, secondary form is far more common. The most common etiologies of secondary form are systemic lupus erythematosus or chronic infections. Among the latter, chronic hepatitis B infection and congenital syphilis are the best characterized and recognized causes.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Finnish-type congenital nephrotic syndrome is caused by a mutation in the gene.
explanation: Finnish type congenital nephrotic syndrome is a steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome caused by a mutation in the nephrin gene (NPHS 1). Affected infants usually present at birth with edema caused by massive proteinuria. They are delivered with a large placenta (>25% of the infant’s weight). There is severe hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypogammaglobulinemia. Prenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated maternal and amniotic -fetoprotein levels. Gene Name Inheritan ce Renal disease NPH S1 Nephrin Recessive Finnish-type congenital neph rotic syndrome NPH S2 Podocin Recessive Focal segmental glomeruloscl erosis (FSGS) WT1 Wilms tumor-suppressor g ene Dominan t Denys–Drash syndrome with diffuse mesangial sclerosis Fr asier syndrome with FSGS Gene Name Inheritan ce Renal disease LMX 1B LIM-homeodomain protein Dominan t Nail–patella syndrome
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
FSGS is caused by mutations in the gene.
NPHS 1 (nephrin)
explanation: focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is caused by mutation in NPHS2 (podocin) gene. Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome is usually caused by FSGS (in 80% of cases). In FSGS, glomeruli show lesions of mesangial cell proliferation and segmental scarring that are both focal (present only in a proportion of glomeruli) and segmental (localized to 1 intraglomerular tufts). FSGS is associated with a 50% risk for end-stage kidney disease. Gene Name Inheritan ce Renal disease NPH S1 Nephrin Recessive Finnish-type congenital neph rotic syndrome NPH S2 Podocin Recessive Focal segmental glomeruloscl erosis (FSGS) WT1 Wilms tumor-suppressor g ene Dominan t Denys–Drash syndrome with diffuse mesangial sclerosis Fr asier syndrome with FSGS LMX 1B LIM-homeodomain protein Dominan t Nail–patella syndrome Pediatric Urology
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During her antenatal ward rounds, an intern noticed a USG report indicating the presence of just one kidney in the fetus. Which of the following association would be expected to be seen in the baby?
explanation: The presence of a single umbilical artery can be expected to be seen in the case of a baby with unilateral renal agenesis. Renal agenesis occurs secondary to a defect of the Wolffian duct, ureteric bud, or metanephric blastema. It is often discovered during the course of an evaluation for other congenital anomalies (VACTERL syndrome). Its incidence is increased in newborns with a single umbilical artery. The contralateral kidney undergoes compensatory hypertrophy. Some children also have contralateral vesicoureteral re■ux. Most males have an ipsilateral absent vas deferens. NOTE: VACTERL syndrome - Vertebral defects, imperforate Anus, Congenital heart disease, Tracheo-Esophageal fistula, Renal and Limb defects
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-month-old female is brought to the clinic with a 102° F fever for 2 days. The mother says that she also cries during urination. The history is significant for similar episodes in the past which were treated with antibiotics. Urine analysis shows nitrite-positivity and gram-negative bacteria are seen on urine microscopy. Which of the following anomaly is most commonly associated with this child's condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent urinary tract infection. The most common anomaly associated with this condition in children is vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). VUR usually is congenital and often familial. It is more common in females. It occurs when the submucosal tunnel between the mucosa and detrusor muscle is short or absent. The image below shows VUR grading
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A pediatrician suspects vesicoureteric reflux in a girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the investigation of choice to confirm this condition?
explanation: Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux. Recurrent febrile urinary tract infections in a child should raise the suspicion of an anatomical defect like vesicoureteric reflux as the cause. Compared to other investigations, a VCUG provides more anatomic information. It can demonstrate: Vesicoureteral reflux Duplex collecting system Ectopic ureter Paraureteral (bladder) diverticulum Bladder outlet obstruction Signs of voiding dysfunction, such as a spinning top urethr

question_text: Which of the following is the first-line imaging investigation done in a child presenting with an episode of UTI?
explanation: In a child presenting with an episode of urinary tract infection (UTI), initial imaging should be ultrasonography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. A voiding cystourethrogram is indicated only if the ultrasound study is abnormal, the patient has atypical features or after a recurrent febrile UTI. question_text: A mother is concerned that her 1-year-old daughter has been having repeated episodes of UTI since birth. The pediatrician ordered a voiding cystourethrogram, which revealed reflux of urine into the upper collecting systems without any dilation. Under which grade of vesicoureteral reflux will this presentation be classified?
explanation: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract on contrast voiding cystourethrogram. It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V): Grading of vesicoureteral re■ux: Grade I- VUR into a non-dilated ureter Grade II- VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation Grade III- VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices. question_text: Ashi, a 12-year-old girl presented with features of hematuria, headache, and blurring of vision. Her past history is significant for recurrent UTI. On examination, she was found to have a BP of 150/110 mmHg. Investigations revealed mild renal scarring and urine analysis showed broad casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Posterior urethral valve with chronic renal failure
Reflux uropathy with chronic renal failure
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of reflux uropathy with chronic renal failure. The pathogenesis of vesicoureteral reflux is as follows: Loss of renal parenchyma and renal scarring reduces renal function significantly. This renal insufficiency leads to renin-mediated hypertension and further progresses to end-stage renal disease. Re■ux nephropathy remains a common cause of hypertension in children. Broad casts or renal failure casts are associated with end-stage renal disease.

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal mass in neonates?
explanation: Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) is the most common cause of an abdominal mass in the newborn but is mostly non-palpable at birth. In most cases, it is discovered incidentally during prenatal sonography. In some patients, the cysts are identified prenatally, but the cysts regress in utero, and no kidney is identified on imaging at birth. MCDK is usually unilateral and generally not inherited, unlike polycystic kidney disease (PKD). Contralateral hydronephrosis is present in 5-10% of patients.

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with the lesion seen in the image?
explanation: The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is not associated with the posterior urethral valve. Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lie in front of L3 vertebra due to arrest of ascent. question_text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical presentation of a young girl with continuous dribbling of urine, despite normal voiding, strongly suggests the diagnosis of an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter refers to a condition where the ureter drains outside the bladder. It is more common in females and opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina. Hence, they present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly (paradoxical incontinence). The terminal part of the ureter is frequently narrowed, leading to hydroureteronephrosis. Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common due to urinary stasis. In males, ectopic ureters usually enter the posterior urethra above the external sphincter, hence they are usually continent and most patients present with UTI or epididymitis. Investigations include renal ultrasound (USG), voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), and renal scan to assess function. USG shows a hydronephrotic kidney or dilated upper pole and ureter. If there is a satisfactory function, the recommended treatment options are ureteral reimplantation into the bladder or ureteroureterostomy. The poor function may require partial or total nephrectomy. Other options: Option B: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, typically obstructive due to a small ureteral opening. In childhood, they commonly present with infections. Larger ureteroceles can cause obstruction at the bladder neck. Option C: Congenital megaureter (dilated ureter) presents UTI, urinary stones, hematuria, and flank pain because of urinary stasis. Option D: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the ureter and kidney. They usually present with recurrent attacks of UTI.

question_text: A newborn is being evaluated for anuria. Imaging reveals renal agenesis and pulmonary hypoplasia. The delivery was complicated due to oligohydramnios. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history of oligohydramnios, is suggestive of Potter's sequence Potter's sequence is characterized by the triad of: Renal agenesis Oligohydramnios Pulmonary hypoplasi Option B: Pierre–Robin syndrome: micrognathia, retrognathia, glossoptosis. Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: It can present with pulmonary hypoplasia but other features like renal agenesis, anuria will not be seen. question_text: A 20-year-old primigravida was rushed to the OT for an emergency caesarean section. Her pregnancy was unplanned and she did not take folic acid supplementation prior to conception. Moreover, owing to the pandemic led lockdown and her remote residence, she could not adhere to regular antenatal care. The newborn was born with a neural tube defect and immediately shifted to the NICU. What is the least likely diagnosis?
explanation: Holoprosencephaly is not a neural tube defect (NTD) and hence, it is the least likely diagnosis. Folic acid deficiency, especially in a young primigravida, is a risk factor for the development of NTDs in children, as seen in the given clinical vignette. NTDs result from the failure of the neural tube to close spontaneously between the 3rd and 4th week of in utero development. These can be detected in antenatal ultrasound scans and subsequently managed for a better prognosis. The major NTDs include the following: Spina bifida occulta Meningocele Myelomeningocele Encephalocele Anencephaly Syringomyelia Diastematomyelia (split spinal cord) Iniencephaly In holoprosencephaly, the forebrain fails to develop into two hemispheres due to mutations in the sonic hedgehog gene at the long arm of chromosome 7. It is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and the inadequate induction of the forebrain structures. The three types include, alobar, semilobar, and lobar, apart from the middle interhemispheric fusion variant or syntelencephaly. The image given below shows alobar holoprosencephaly-

question_text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn is suggestive of occult spinal dysraphism or neural tube defect. It comprises a range of conditions, including spina bifida occulta, intradural lipoma, and dorsal dermal sinus. Spinal dysraphism is due to the defective fusion of the midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures. Associated clinical features are high-arched feet, muscle size and strength differences between legs, and abnormal walking patterns. In newborns and young infants, the neurological examination is usually normal, but older children may experience a lack of sensation in the perineal area and back pain. Most of the patients will have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, including a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma. The image shows a tuft of hair in a case of spinal dysraphism: Spinal dysraphism also includes meningocele, myelomeningocele, lipomeningocele, diastematomyelia (split spinal cord), thickened filum terminale, and cauda equina tumour. The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI. Spina bifida is the most common type of spinal dysraphism, in which the spinal column does not close completely, leaving the spinal cord and its protective covering exposed. Myelomeningocele is the most severe form of spina bifida, where the spinal cord and nerve roots are exposed and may be damaged. A sac-like protrusion, containing spinal cord tissue, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid, is visible outside the body, often leading to significant neurological impairments and disabilities.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman underwent second-trimester screening and had an abnormal presence of a biochemical marker. Following this, she went to a tertiary care referral centre for further investigations. An anomaly scan revealed cranial lemon and cerebellar banana signs. What is the abnormal marker present in this condition?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the presence of abnormal sonographic markers, like the lemon and banana sign, is highly suggestive of neural tube defects (NTDs). Acetylcholinesterase is used as a biochemical marker of neural tube defects during the screening tests. NTDs account for the largest proportion of congenital anomalies of the CNS. The failure of closure of neural tube allows excretion of fetal substances such as -fetoprotein (AFP) and acetylcholinesterase into the amniotic fluid thereby serving as biochemical markers for NTDs. The lemon and banana sign, noted on antenatal imaging, are one of the many notable fruits' inspired signs. The banana sign refers to the shape of the cerebellum owing to caudal displacement while the lemon sign refers to the lemon-shaped head resulting from scalloping of the frontal bones. It is seen in fetuses with open neural tube defects. The image below shows the characteristic lemon sign on ultrasound- The image below shows the characteristic banana sign on ultrasound- Note: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPPA), inhibin A, and human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) are the biochemical markers of trisomy 21 (Down's syndrome).

explanation: Until the time of surgery, the sac of myelomeningocele has to be covered with a sterile gauze soaked in normal saline. This is to prevent drying and trauma to the sac. As the normal saline is less irritant to the sac, it is preferred. Note: Surgery is done as early as possible (within a day of birth).

question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was rushed to the casualty of a maternity hospital due to imminent delivery. It resulted in a stillborn baby as shown in the picture below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows an occipital bone defect with retroflexion of the neck and trunk, which is typical of iniencephaly. Inion is the tip of the external occipital protuberance and this defect comes under the spectrum of neural tube defects. Diastematomyelia (Option A) is a congenital disorder in which a part of the spinal cord is split, usually at the level of the upper lumbar vertebra. Craniorachischisis (Option B) is the anencephaly associated with a continuous bony defect of the spine and exposure of neural tissue. Holoprosencephaly (Option D) occurs when the procencephalon fails to develop into two hemispheres.

question_text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns?
explanation: Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly and hydrocephalus in newborns. Ventriculomegaly is the dilation of the ventricles. When ventriculomegaly occurs in association with raised cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, it is called hydrocephalus. Pathologic etiologies can be congenital or acquired. Congenital causes include structural abnormalities such as aqueductal stenosis, agenesis of the corpus callosum, Dandy-Walker malformations, Chiari malformations, and neural tube defects. Acquired causes are intracranial infections(cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis), intracranial hemorrhage, ischemic injury, and brain parenchymal tumors. Aqueductal stenosis is the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a narrow channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. As a result, the fluid accumulates within the ventricles, causing them to enlarge. Treatment for aqueductal stenosis includes ventriculostomy, diuretics, serial lumbar punctures in specific cases, and CSF diversion. In severe cases, CSF diversion procedures (shunting), may be necessary to redirect the flow of CSF and relieve pressure on the brain.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant is brought to the OPD with complaints of multiple episodes of vomiting that is more in the morning and relieved when sitting. She has an unusually large head with bulging fontanelles. The image of the child showing a characteristic sign is given below. Which of the following is not a cause of the communicating variant of this condition?
explanation: The clinical features of frequent vomiting, large head, bulging fontanelles, and a positive sunset sign (as seen in the image) point to a likely diagnosis of hydrocephalus. A vein of Galen malformation can expand to become large and, because of its midline position, obstruct the flow of CSF, thereby causing an obstructive or non-communicating hydrocephalus. Vomiting is more in the morning and becomes better when sitting due to poor absorption of CSF in a lying down position. Hydrocephalus is not a specific disease; it represents a diverse group of conditions that result from impaired circulation or absorption of CSF. question_text: Shreya, a 2-year-old girl, presented with irritability for 2 days. On examination, macrocephaly, hypotonia and spasticity were present with a positive head transillumination test. She started walking independently at 18 months and became dry by day a month before her 2nd birthday. An MRI-brain revealed cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis explaining her obstructive hydrocephalus?
explanation: The features of hydrocephalus like irritability along with macrocephaly, hypotonia and spasticity indicate a likely diagnosis of Dandy-Walker syndrome. A positive transillumination test is present in this syndrome. The child has developmental delay especially in motor and cognitive milestones because normally children walk independently at 12-13 months and become dry by day around 18 months. The Dandy-Walker malformation consists of a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. It results from a developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle during embryogenesis. Most of the affected patients have hydrocephalus, agenesis of the posterior cerebellar vermis, and corpus callosum. Brisk tendon reflexes, spasticity, clonus, Babinski sign, cerebellar ataxia, and delayed motor and cognitive milestones are seen in this. Management is by shunting if hydrocephalus is present. question_text: A 6-month-old baby presented with fever, poor feeding, and frequent vomiting. On examination, the head circumference was 46.5cm with a positive sunset and Macewen sign. Which of the following infections is associated with the most common cause of the underlying neurological disease in this child?
explanation: Symptoms of poor feeding and frequent vomiting with signs of enlarged head circumference and a positive sunset and Macewen sign(crack-pot resonance) points toward a diagnosis of hydrocephalus. Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of hydrocephalus. Out of the above options, mumps infection can cause stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct. Mumps is associated in a child with aqueductal stenosis because- Mumps virus is neurotropic and is thought to enter the CNS via the choroid plexus and infect the choroidal epithelium and ependymal cells. CNS complications of mumps include meningitis, meningoencephalitis (most commonly manifests 5 days after the parotitis), transverse myelitis, aqueductal stenosis, and facial palsy.

question_text: A 9-month-old baby presented with seizures, developmental delay and failure to thrive. Following an MRI, a diagnosis of a neuronal migration disorder was made. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: Among the given options, schizencephaly is a neuronal migration defect. MRI is the study of choice for elucidating schizencephaly and associated malformations. Neuronal migration is the process during brain development, where the neuronal cells migrate to their proper designated site by various mechanisms, to form the 6-layered cerebral cortex. Any abnormality in the above process leads to neuronal migration defects. Neuronal migration defect includes the following: Schizencephaly: (schiz = split or cleavage) It is the presence of unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres. The patient can be severely intellectually challenged, with microcephaly, seizures, and spastic quadriparesis. The image below shows schizencephaly: Lissencephaly (agyria): It is the absence of cerebral convolutions. Rather than the normal 6 ayers of the cortex, there may be fewer layers. The child will have developmental delay, microcephaly, and seizures. The image below shows lissencephaly: Myelomeningocele (Option B) is a neural tube defect that occurs due to defective closure of the neural tube. Lhermitte–Duclos disease (Option C) is the cerebellar dysplasia leading to focal enlargement of cerebellum and macrocephaly, cerebellar signs, and seizures. Plagiocephaly (Option D) is the asymmetry and flattening of the skull of the child, due to extrinsic moulding forces (consistent sleeping on the same side of the head).

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?
options: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome
explanation: The given image shows discrete tan-colored nodules over the iris called Lisch nodules (pigmented melanocytic hamartomas). They are seen in neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis (TS) and not neurofibromatosis. The image below shows facial angiofibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease). Lisch nodules are specifically associated with NF-1 and are usually multiple and bilateral. They are best visualized with a slit lamp examination and don’t cause any visual disturbances. Other important ocular manifestations in NF-1 include eyelid plexiform neurofibroma, which causes S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture, optic nerve glioma, and spheno-orbital encephalocele due to dysplasia of greater wing of the sphenoid. NF-1 (von Recklinghausen's disease) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation of the NF-1 gene located on chromosome 17q11.2. NF-1 produces neurofibromin, which acts as a tumor suppressor and a negative regulator of RAS-MAP kinase signaling. Clinical features of NF-1 include café-au-lait macules, axillary freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. NF-1 is more common than NF2 and typically diagnosed in childhood. NF-2 is rarer but often presents with bilateral acoustic neuroma, juvenile cataract and schwannoma. question_text: During a telemedicine consultation, you come across a case of a 9-year-old child with a previously diagnosed autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome known as tuberous sclerosis. Which one of the following is not seen in it?
explanation: Ependymomas are not seen in tuberous sclerosis. Neurocutaneous syndromes like tuberous sclerosis are a group of disorders with abnormalities in both the integumentary system and the CNS (defect of primitive ectoderm). They include the following: Neurofibromatosis Tuberous sclerosis Sturge–Weber syndrome von Hippel–Lindau disease Ataxia telangiectasia Tuberous sclerosis is caused due to mutation of genes coding for hamartin (chromosome 9) and tuberin (chromosome 16), which leads to the formation of hamartomas. Clinical features: CNS CNS involvement is the hallmark of tuberous sclerosis. Glioneuronal hamartomas (cortical tubers). Subependymal nodules are lesions found along the wall of the lateral ventricles, where they undergo calcification. Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs) are the characteristic brain tumours. These benign, slow-growing tumours arise in the periventricular area. White matter lesions are common and include nodules, cysts, and areas of gliosis and hypomyelination. question_text: During rounds in the neurology ward, an 11-year-old child is observed with the following lesion on his back. Which of the following characteristic skin manifestation of tuberous sclerosis is depicted in this picture?
explanation: The lesion seen in the picture depicts a shagreen patch. This is a characteristic skin lesion found in patients with tuberous sclerosis. It consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the image of the question. Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis: The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp. Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance. Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients. Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis. question_text: A 3-year-old child is rushed to the emergency department because of an episode of fits associated with uprolling of eyes and high fever. Kernig’s sign is negative and there are no post-ictal neurological deficits. There is a history of a similar episode when the child had a fever due to gastroenteritis. Which of the following is false regarding this type of seizures?
options: Likelihood of developing epilepsy is low
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions
Absence of having a developmental delay
explanation: This is a probable case of febrile seizures due to the presence of high fever, no post-ictal deficits and a negative Kernig's sign ruling out meningitis. Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure, as the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly. Febrile seizures are seizures that- Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit. Types of febrile seizures: Investigations: Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis). EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures. Treatment: Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present. Prophylaxis: Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode. Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails or in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used. question_text: Your neighbour, Sheila, frantically knocks on your door to seek help as her toddler had suddenly started convulsing with uprolling of eyes. The child had a high fever and this was his third episode of seizures in 6 months. Post-recovery, Sheila is still anxious and wishes to know the risk factors for such recurrences of febrile seizures. You would explain all of the following except-
explanation: Early age of onset (age <1 year) is a risk factor for recurrence of febrile seizures. The other risk factors for such recurrences are as follows: Major: Age <1 yr Duration of fever <24 hr Fever 38-39°C Minor: Family history of febrile seizures Family history of epilepsy Complex febrile seizure Male gender Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation

question_text: A child presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled by an array of drugs. Electroencephalogram (EEG) shows 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves with polyspike bursts in sleep. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: A child with features of developmental delay, intractable seizures and an electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep has a likely diagnosis of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome. Lennox–Gastaut syndrome- Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. Consists of a triad of: Developmental delay Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures) EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies. The drug of choice for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is valproate. Other drugs used for this condition are clobazam, lamotrigine, rufinamide and topiramate. question_text: A 15-year-old girl presented with episodes of brief involuntary muscular twitching that causes her to drop her toothbrush or teacup in the morning. Following investigations including an EEG, a diagnosis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy was made. Which of the following is not a feature of it?
explanation: In juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, EEG characteristically shows 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome): It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults ( 12-18 years). They are benign generalized myoclonic seizures with a good prognosis. They commonly affect the upper limbs more than the lower limbs and sometimes cause the dropping of objects. Typically, it starts in early adolescence (12-18 years), with 1 or more of the following manifestations: Myoclonic jerks in the morning (“shock-like” contraction of a muscle, that is often repeated), generalized tonic-clonic or clonic seizures upon awakening; and juvenile absences. Sleep deprivation, alcohol (in older patients), and photic stimulation provoke seizures. The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges. The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate. Lamotrigine is also useful. question_text: An adolescent girl complaints of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario describes an adolescent girl with myoclonic jerks (a history of dropping objects) with preserved consciousness. This, along with abnormal EEG findings strongly suggests juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults. It starts in early adolescence with one or more of the following features: bilateral myoclonic jerks in the morning, causing patients to drop things, generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening, and juvenile absence seizure. Consciousness is usually preserved. Precipitating factors include sleep deprivation, alcohol, and photic stimulation. EEG shows 4 to 5Hz polyspike and slow wave discharges. A family history of epilepsy is often present. The treatment options for JME include sodium valproate, levetiracetam, and topiramate. Benzodiazepine, lamotrigine, perampanel, phenobarbital, primidone, and zonisamide can be considered as add-on drugs. Complete remission is uncommon and has a high risk of seizure recurrence, hence antiepileptics are continued lifelong in a majority of the patients. Other options: Option B: Atypical absence seizures have been associated with myoclonic components and head drop. They are precipitated by drowsiness and EEG shows 1 to 2 Hz spike and slow wave discharges. Option D: In benign childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes, the child typically wakes at night due to a focal seizure with preserved awareness. Buccal and throat tingling and tonic or clonic contractions on one side of the face are seen, with drooling and preserved consciousness. EEG shows typical wide-based centrotemporal spikes.

explanation: The drug of choice for infantile spasms is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). The EEG shows a specific type of abnormal chaotic brainwave pattern called hypsarrhythmia. It is characterized by continuous, high-amplitude, asynchronous delta activities with interspersed independent, multiple spikes. Hypsarrhythmia on EEG can occur even between attacks.Excessive corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) production is hypothesized to cause infantile spasms. ACTH administration suppresses CRH secretion and hence controls the seizures. Causes include hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, neurocutaneous syndromes, and idiopathic. Drug of choice: Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), Vigabatrin. question_text: An 8-month old male child presented with delayed motor milestones. He was born at 28 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1200 grams.
