question_text: A newborn with abnormal neonatal screening tests was diagnosed with Pendred syndrome. Which of the following is not a feature of this syndrome?
explanation: Sensorineural hearing loss is present in Pendred syndrome; not conductive hearing loss. Pendred syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder, caused by a mutation in the gene SLC26A4 on chromosome 7, which codes for pendrin, a chloride–iodide transport protein common to the thyroid gland and the cochlea. Clinical features include sensorineural hearing loss and goitre with hypothyroidism. It is the most common cause of syndromic deafness. The biochemical reason for hypothyroidism in patients with Pendred syndrome is impaired iodide organification (resulting from a mutation in the Pendrin gene).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 9-day-old infant has elevated TSH level and low T4 level on newborn screening. If this condition is left untreated, which of the following is most likely to be seen in this infant in the first few months of life?
explanation: Elevated TSH levels and low T4 levels in a 9-day-old infant are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia is an early sign of congenital hypothyroidism. It is due to delayed maturation of the hepatic glucuronide conjugation system. Hyperreflexia, hyperirritability and diarrhoea are seen in hyperthyroidism; not hypothyroidism. Note: Kocher–Debré–Sémélaigne syndrome: The muscles are usually hypotonic in congenital hypothyroidism. Rarely, hypothyroidism in infancy can be characterized by generalized muscular pseudohypertrophy, myxoedema, short stature and cretinism. Affected older children can have an athletic appearance. Boys are more prone to the development of the syndrome.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: During a rural health camp, a father brings a dull-looking baby with macroglossia and an umbilical hernia. On enquiry, you find out that the parents were told about a thyroid problem in the child at birth, for which they did not pursue any treatment. Which of the following is least likely to be found in children with the given condition?
explanation: A dull-looking face with macroglossia, and umbilical hernia in a child with a thyroid disorder are all indicative of congenital hypothyroidism. Craniosynostosis is not seen in neonatal hypothyroidism. It is seen in hyperthyroidism. Craniosynostosis refers to the premature fusion of sutures and closure of fontanelles and often results in abnormal, triangular facies. In congenital hypothyroidism, there is delayed closure of the fontanelles. Palpable goitre, though not common, can be seen in cases of untreated thyroid dyshormonogenesis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As part of a quality improvement project undertaken by the maternal and child health services, you are evaluating the current practice of newborn screening and detection rates of hypothyroidism in various community health centres. Which of the following statements is false?
options: Simultaneous measurement of T4 and TSH levels is the ideal method.
The sample is obtained by heel-prick between 1-5 days of life using dried blood spot.
Newborn screening always detects the affected twin in same-sex twins.
Primary TSH, with back up T4 is the most common strategy used.
explanation: Newborn screening can fail to detect the affected twin with hypothyroidism. Discordance for thyroid dysgenesis is the rule in monozygotic twins. The transfusion of euthyroid blood from the unaffected twin normalizes the serum levels of T4 and TSH in the affected twin, resulting in delayed or missed diagnoses. Therefore, a second sample for congenital hypothyroidism screening at 14 days of age should be considered in monozygotic twins. Neonatal thyroid screening strategies: Primarily TSH, backup T4; T4 is measured if TSH level is >20 mU/L Primarily T4, backup TSH: TSH is measured only if T4 level is low Concomitant T4 and TSH; it is the most sensitive method Note: the sample is obtained after 24-48 hours, to minimize the false elevation of TSH values due to normal post-delivery neonatal TSH surge.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As an intern posted in paediatrics, you are asked to interpret the results of a heel prick test that you performed on a newborn. Which of the following results is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism?
options: Low T4 level and low TSH leve
Low T4 level and high TSH leve
High T4 level and low TSH leve
High T4 level and high TSH leve
explanation: Low T4 and high TSH levels indicate primary hypothyroidism. B ood specimen for neonatal thyroid screening is obtained by heel prick between 1 and 5 days of life. Levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis, at 10 to 15 µg/kg per day. Condition Goitr e T4 TSH Thyroid dysgenesis Abse nt Low Elevate d Thyroid dyshormonogenesis Pres ent Low Elevate d Thyroid receptor blocking an tibodies Abse nt Low Elevate d Central hypothyroidism Abse nt Low Normal/ Low Hyperthyroidism Pres ent High Low
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The image given below depicts an x-ray of the knee in a term baby. Which among the following conditions is associated with it?
explanation: The deformity shown in the X-ray image is the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, which is a typical radiological feature of congenital hypothyroidism. ray findings in hypothyroidism Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses at birth. Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis (multiple foci of ossification) Deformity or beaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebra X-ray image of the skull shows large fontanels and wide sutures; wormian (intrasutural) bones; and, often, an enlarged and round sella turcica. Image below: The infant on the left with congenital hypothyroidism demonstrates the absence of the distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses, while in the normal infant on the right the distal femoral epiphysis is present: The image below shows small upper femoral epiphyses: The image below shows enlarged sella turcica and wormian bones (intrasutural):
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
Ayesha is a 9th standard girl who presented with a neck swelling, which began more than a year ago. Her mother says she is embarrassed about it and always covers her neck with a
shawl when she goes to school. Her menstrual cycles have also become irregular as of late. B ood tests reveal slightly elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPO-Abs) and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level in a child with a goitre is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis. Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. Clinical presentation can include goitre, growth retardation, and other features of hypothyroidism. The thyroid is diffusely enlarged, firm, and non-tender. TSH is moderately elevated and TPO-Abs and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-Tg Abs) can be detected. The image given below shows goitre due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A lady, with a history of a thyroid disorder and three prior abortions, delivered a female neonate prematurely at 34 weeks of gestation. In the newborn infant, tachycardia, irritability, and prominent eyes were noted and neonatal hyperthyroidism was suspected. Which of the following statements is false about the condition?
options: Maternal Graves' disease is the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism
It results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibody
Microcephaly and frontal bossing with triangular facies are common clinical findings
Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in most infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’ disease
explanation: Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in only about 2% of infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’ disease. But maternal Graves' disease is by far the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism. Neonatal hyperthyroidism (due to Grave's) results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory thyrotropin/TSH receptor antibody (TSHR-Ab). Clinical features are as follows: Low birth weight (IUGR) Premature birth Microcephaly Frontal bossing and triangular facies Warm, moist skin Irritability, hyperactivity, restlessness, poor sleep Tachycardia Note: TSHR-Ab (TSH-R-stimulating antibodies) is another name for TSH-R-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A pregnant woman with a past history of Grave's disease has currently completed 36 weeks of gestation. She underwent partial thyroidectomy 10 years back and has remained euthyroid since then. The previous child had craniosynostosis. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be detected, if a cord blood sampling is done at delivery?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of Graves' disease in the mother and craniosynostosis (neonatal Graves') in the previous child suggests that the fetus is at increased risk of neonatal Grave's disease. Thus, the antibody likely to be found at birth in the cord blood sampling is the TSH receptor stimulating antibody (TRSAb). Neonatal Graves is caused by the transplacental passage of TRSAbs from a mother with a history of Graves' disease. The mothers can have Active Graves' disease Graves' in remission Prior history of Graves' treated with radioactive ablation or thyroidectomy TSRAbs bind to the receptor for TSH and stimulate cyclic AMP, leading to thyroid hyperplasia and unregulated overproduction of thyroid hormone.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinic with a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have
Graves’ disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of the following except .
explanation: Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease. Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases): Diabetes mellitus type 1 Pernicious anaemia Celiac disease Vitiligo Addison disease Alopecia areata Myasthenia gravis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 11-year-old girl was brought by her parents with complaints of weight loss, increased appetite, and a decline in scholastic performance. Following investigations, a diagnosis of Grave’s disease is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for initial therapy?
explanation: Methimazole is the initial drug of choice for treating Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) in children. Option A: Propylthiouracil is not recommended in children because it is associated with fatal hepatotoxicity. Option C: Radioactive iodine is not preferred as the first-line treatment in hyperthyroidism for children. Option D: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Your unit chief has asked you to present the case of a teenager, who was admitted for evaluation of mental retardation, deaf-mutism and a gait disturbance. He also has a significant patellar clonus. On general exam, you note a goitre but according to lab reports, he is apparently euthyroid. His pubertal development has also been normal. The most likely diagnosis is .
explanation: The clinical presentation of a euthyroid patient with goitre as well as mental retardation, deaf-mutism, and normal pubertal development points towards neurological endemic cretinism. Endemic cretinism includes 2 different, but overlapping, syndromes: neurologic type and myxedematous type. It is essentially the same disorder, phenotypically modified by the length and severity of postnatal hypothyroidism. Neurological manifestations are interpreted as reflecting the effects of maternal and fetal hypothyroxinemia, secondary to severe iodine deficiency, on the developing nervous system. Both neurologic and myxedematous type can manifest neurologic symptoms. Although neurological cretins are euthyroid, linear growth arrest lines in the long bones are often demonstrated radiologically, suggesting previous hypothyroidism. Option B: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goitre, ophthalmopathy, and dermopathy (no mental retardation, deafness, or pyramidal signs). Option C: Pendred Syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride–iodide transporter in thyroid and cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goitre and sensorineural hearing loss (pyramidal signs like clonus are not seen).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
During a health outreach program in Sikkim, you come across 3 children from the same family, with goiter. Endemic cretinism was suspected. Which of the following can be a manifestation of this condition?
Facial nerve involvement
explanation: Strabismus and spastic diplegias are among the manifestations of the neurological type of endemic cretinism. Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual development. Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. It is associated with severe, irreversible mental retardation. Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia and Related Disorders
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The parents of a neonate diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia come with queries about the disease. They have been told that it's an inherited condition and ask you how is it possible for the baby to be affected when neither of the parents are. What is the mode of inheritance of the disease?
explanation: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia / adrenogenital syndrome follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Depending on the enzyme that is deficient, patients will have : Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia) or excess (hypernatremia, hypokalemia) Incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in male Virilization or sexual infantilism in female
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A baby delivered at home was born with ambiguous genitalia. The parents could not identify the sex of the child. The baby was diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is this child most likely to have?
explanation: This child is most likely to have a 21-hydroxylase deficiency as it is the most common enzyme deficiency implicated in congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The second most common is 11 beta-hydroxylase deficiency. 21-hydroxylase enzyme hydroxylates progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to yield 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol, respectively. They help in the synthesis of aldosterone and cortisol. Therefore, the deficiency of this enzyme leads to the deficiencies of aldosterone and cortisol. Also, the accumulated steroid precursors are diverted into the pathway for androgen (testosterone) production. Clinical profile in 21-hydroxylase deficiency: Aldosterone deficiency: Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis) Cortisol deficiency: Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock Androgens excess: Virilization of females and precocious puberty in male
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia is not due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency?
explanation: Under virilizing type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is not caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Depending on the extent of enzyme deficiency, CAH caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency is broadly classified into classic and non-classic forms: Classic forms can be of two types - salt-wasting and simple virilizing types. Salt-wasting type is the severe form in which both cortisol and aldosterone are deficient, with excess androgen production. In the simple virilizing type, there is an impaired synthesis of cortisol and adequate amounts of aldosterone. Here, clinical features are due to the overproduction of androgens. The non-classic form is characterized by partial 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Cortisol and aldosterone are produced normally, but at the expense of producing excess androgens.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A concerned mother brings her 15-day old baby to you with complaints of decreased activity and vomiting. On examination, the baby is hypotensive, has depressed fontanelles and reduced skin turgor. The image of the external genitalia of the baby is shown below. Which electrolyte abnormality can you expect to see in this baby?
explanation: The image shows ambiguous genitalia. This along with signs of dehydration and hypotension suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) can be seen in this condition. These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension. Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Investigation of choice to diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency is estimation of levels.
explanation: 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels estimation is the investigation of choice to diagnose CAH due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency. It will be markedly elevated. Other findings include: Elevated androstenedione and testosterone (in females). Low cortisol and aldosterone. Elevated ACTH levels.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You see Sanjay who is a known case of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, on steroid therapy in the ER with vomiting and fever. You administer double the regular dose of steroids. Which drug is being referred to here?
explanation: Hydrocortisone, which is the mainstay treatment for commonest type of CAH, is the drug referred to in the given clinical scenario. Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as infection or surgery. Glucocorticoid replacement therapy with hydrocortisone, 15-20 mg/m²/24 h, orally, in 3 divided doses is continued lifelong. Mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone is used for patients with the salt-wasting disease. The daily dose of fludrocortisone in infants is higher than that in older children.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The autopsy image of a baby who died during the neonatal period is shown below. Parents of the child undergo genetic counseling regarding future pregnancies. When should the mother be started on steroids in a future pregnancy?
options: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
After karyotyping and determination of sex of the baby
explanation: The autopsy image shows a bilaterally enlarged adrenal gland (white arrows) with a history of death during the neonatal period (probably due to shock, cardiac arrhythmias) which is suggestive of CAH in the baby. Mothers with a previously affected child of CAH should be started with steroid therapy as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed. Since it is an autosomal recessive disorder, there is a risk of the subsequent children being affected. Dexamethasone at 20 g/kg is started to suppress the secretion of steroids by the fetal adrenals (including adrenal androgens) and prevent the virilization of the external genitals in affected females. Then, chorionic villus biopsy is performed to determine the sex and genotype of the fetus, and therapy is continued only if the fetus is an affected female.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
You see Sathya, an adolescent in the endocrinology clinic referred by his family physician. He was told by his parents that he was a boy, but he felt differently. As he grew up, he felt increasingly uncomfortable with his identity and this caused him a great deal of sadness and
isolation. On examination, he is hypertensive and has genitalia resembling a female phenotype. After karyotyping, you diagnose him with 46XY DSD. Which of the following enzyme deficiency would be in your differential?
explanation: 46XY DSD - a genotypical male with female phenotype- along with hypertension makes the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency more likely. Clinical profile in 17-hydroxylase deficiency: Aldosterone excess: Salt retention, hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hypertension. Sex steroid deficiency: In contrast to 11-hydroxylase deficiency, patients with 17-hydroxylase deficiency are unable to synthesize sex hormones. Affected males are incompletely virilized (male pseudo-hermaphroditism/ ambiguous genitalia 46XY) and there is a failure of sexual development in affected females. Cortisol deficiency is not manifested, as elevated corticosterone is an active glucocorticoid. Intersex or DSD means a condition in which development of chromosomal, gonadal, or anatomical sex is atypical. There is a greater incidence of gender dissatisfaction, gender non-conformity, gender fluidity in such individuals.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant with hypospadias, bifid scrotum presents with signs and symptoms of salt wasting. Lab reports reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxy pregnenolone and dehydroepiandrosterone. Which of the following deficiency would you suspect in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of incomplete virilization (hypospadias with or without bifid scrotum and cryptorchidism), salt wasting due to cortisol and aldosterone deficiency, and elevated dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and 17 hydroxy pregnenolone levels are suggestive of 3 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. Clinical profile in 3-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (3-HSD): Aldosterone deficiency- Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and acidosis) Cortisol deficiency- Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), and hock Androgen deficiency- Males are incompletely virilized (male pseudo-hermaphroditism/ambiguous genitalia 46XY/hypogonadism, cryptorchidism) Excess DHEA (weak androgen)- Females are mildly virilized (acne, hirsutism).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension among the following is .
explanation: The most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension is 11-hydroxylase deficiency causing congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Hypertension in CAH is due to 11-hydroxylase deficiency followed by 17-hydroxylase deficiency. Cortisol and aldosterone deficiency cannot be manifested because some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone, and hence, there are no signs of adrenal insufficiency. 21- hydroxylase deficiency causes salt-wasting resulting in hypotension.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A boy presents with precocious puberty and hypertension to your OPD. The estimation of
will help in the diagnosis of CAH.
explanation: Precocious puberty in a male with hypertension is suggestive of CAH due to 11-hydroxylase deficiency. An increase in 11-deoxycortisol levels is diagnostic of the enzyme deficiency. 11-hydroxlase catalyzes the convertion of deoxycortisol to cortisol. Therefore, 11-hydroxlase deficiency causes an increase in 11 deoxycortisol levels.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: On a vacation trip to Hawaii, a father was helping his 7-year-old son change into swimming trunks. He noticed the presence of pubic and axillary hair. He knew it was abnormal and brought the child to the pediatrician. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of pubic and axillary hair in a seven-year-old boy is suggestive of precocious puberty and 17-Hydroxylase deficiency is least likely to cause it. In 17-hydroxylase deficiency, patients are unable to synthesize sex hormones, and hence the affected males are incompletely virilized and present as phenotypic females (but gonads are usually palpable in the inguinal region or the labia). In both 21-hydroxylase and 11-hydroxylase deficiencies, the respective precursors to the hormones are shunted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in all the signs and symptoms of androgen excess, including virilization of female and precocious puberty in males.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as .
explanation: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism as the most common enzyme deficiency is 21-hydroxylase deficiency. A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia resembles a male's. The image below shows ambiguous genitalia in a female with CAH: The mechanism underlying the endocrine defects in 21-hydroxylase deficiency is depicted in the image below: Babies with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present around 10-14 days of age with the subset of symptoms due to aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency and androgen excess. Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises marked by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis. Cortisol deficiency causes manifestations like hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock. Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency results in virilization of females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males. Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks. Other options: Option A: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency resulting in incomplete virilization. 17-hydroxylase deficiency is 2nd most common enzyme affected in CAH. Option C: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development(DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH. Option D: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, 17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A postgraduate examines a female baby in late infancy with failure to thrive. The genitalia appears normal. Reports reveal serum sodium of 125 MEq/L and serum K+ of 6.5 MEq/L. Estimation of which of the following hormones will be helpful in the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of failure to thrive in late infancy, normal genitalia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia suggests aldosterone synthase deficiency. Estimation of aldosterone levels will help in the diagnosis. Normal genitalia in female children rules out congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) caused by 21-hydroxylase and 3-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia rule out CAH due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency and 11-hydroxylase deficiency. Infants with aldosterone synthase deficiency may have severe electrolyte abnormalities with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Since cortisol synthesis is unaffected, infants rarely become as ill as untreated infants with salt-losing forms of CAH. So some infants escape diagnosis at birth because of normal cortisol levels. Later in infancy or in early childhood, they may exhibit failure to thrive and poor growth. Adults often are asymptomatic, although they may develop electrolyte abnormalities when depleted of sodium through procedures such as bowel preparation for a barium enema.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 12-year-old boy presents with obesity and short stature, with signs of abnormal masculinization as shown below. Which statement regarding this condition is false?
options: Most common cause is adrenocortical tumor
Hypertension seen here can occasionally lead to heart failure
Generalized obesity is a common finding in younger children.
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing round face (moon facies), obesity, abnormal masculinization, and purple skin striae are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. The most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids, not an adrenocortical tumor. Cushing's syndrome is characterized excess glucocorticoids that can be due to: Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoid Excess endogenous cortisol secretion: In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor In children >7 years: Most often by an ACTH–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing' disease) Important clinical features in children: Obesity or weight gain (most common) Moon facie Purple skin striae Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls) Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girl Proximal muscle weakne Osteoporosi Hypertension Hyperpigmentation Hypokalemic alkalosi Hyperglycemia Sepsi
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A high school girl Meenu presents to you with anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness for the past few months. On examination, she had the finding shown in the image. Which of the following will not be seen in this condition?
explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Addison's disease and hypertension is not seen here. Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency due to acquired lesions of the adrenal cortex, which prevent the production of cortisol and, often, aldosterone. Hence, due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, there will be hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. The deficiency of cortisol stimulates the production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Increased ACTH leads to diffuse hyperpigmentation, including areas not exposed to the sun, such as buccal mucosa and gums. Addison’s disease is characterized by the following: Hyponatremia Hyperkalemia Hypotension Hypoglycemia Increased ACTH level Metabolic acidosi Hyperpigmentation ACTH stimulation test (cosyntropin) - Low cortisol levels before and after administration of ACTH are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency, Addison's disease.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You have been called to see a 10-year-old child in the emergency room with complaints of fever and vomiting for the past three days. On examination the child had tachycardia and there was significant postural hypotension. Upon investigation, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia were present. You suspect adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following is the most likely organism grown in blood culture?
explanation: The most common infectious etiology for adrenal insufficiency in children is meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis. Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome: Adrenal apoplexy due to fulminant bacterial infection (most common Meningococcus). Clinical features: Non-specific like fever, rigors, vomiting, headache, disseminated intravascular coagulation (large petechial rashes in the skin and mucous membrane), hypotension, and septic shock Petechial rashes in meningococcal infection: Most commons in adrenal insufficiency: The most common infectious cause of Addison's disease in India is tuberculosis. The most common cause of adrenal insufficiency is the sudden withdrawal of steroids in a patient on long-term steroid therapy. The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in children is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The most common antigen against which antibodies are found in Addison's disease is CYP 21 (21-hydroxylase).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In the pediatric ward, a resident is evaluating a case of primary adrenal insufficiency who has failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification is noted radiologically. The most likely diagnosis is .
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wolman's disease. It is a rare lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) that leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs. Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are evaluating a case of hyperpigmentation. The patient reports having undergone bilateral adrenalectomy a few years back for Cushing's disease. MRI shows an enlargement of the pituitary adenoma. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario of hyperpigmentation, history of bilateral adrenalectomy and MRI showing enlarged pituitary adenoma points to the diagnosis of Nelson's syndrome. Nelson's syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible. The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or formation of a new one. Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of: Hyperpigmentation Excessive ACTH secretion Corticotroph adenoma Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol. The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days. Option B: Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease. It affects the brainstem and basal ganglia. Option C: Hamman-Rich syndrome also known as acute interstitial pneumonia, is a rare and severe form of idiopathic interstitial lung disease. Option D: Job syndrome, also known as hyper-IgE syndrome is an autosomal dominant immunodeficiency disorder. It occurs as a result of STAT3 mutation leading to deficiency in the IL-17 producing T cells. This results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils to sites of infection.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Using novel chemiluminescence immunoassay techniques, you measure the hormonal profile of the adrenal gland of a normal fetus. Which of the following would be present in higher concentrations?
explanation: The fetal adrenal gland produces a maximum amount of DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone). DHEA and DHEA-S serve as estrogen precursors. The maternal adrenal gland does not produce a sufficient amount of DHEA-S. The fetal adrenal glands are quantitatively the most important source of placental estrogen precursors in pregnancy. During most of gestation, the fetal adrenal gland is almost solely dedicated to the production of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate DHEAS.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A woman has a previous child with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. In the present pregnancy, steroid therapy should be started
options: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
After karyotyping and determination of sex of the baby
explanation: Mothers with pregnancies at risk (previously affected child) of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) should be started with steroid therapy as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed. Dexamethasone 20 g/kg is started to suppress the secretion of steroids by the fetal adrenals (including adrenal androgens) and prevent the virilization of the external genitals in affected females. Then, chorionic villus biopsy is performed to determine the sex and genotype of the fetus and therapy is continued only if the fetus is an affected female.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
You see a newborn with an enlarged clitoris and partially fused labia. You also note features such as frontal bossing, brachycephaly, midface hypoplasia, slender fingers, medial bowing of ulna, and heart abnormalities. Investigation reveals a deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase.
What is your diagnosis?
Antley Bixler syndrome
explanation: Deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase (POR) along with the given findings are suggestive of Antley-Bixler syndrome. Features of Antley–Bixler syndrome: These include deficiencies of 17-hydroxylase and 21-hydroxylase along with other congenital anomalies. It leads to under virilization of males and virilisation of females via an alternate pathway. Virilization of mother is seen because of decreased placental aromatase activity leading to exce androgens in fetus and mother. Congenital anomalies seen are as follows: Head and face: Craniosynostosis, brachycephaly, frontal bossing, severe midface hypoplasia, with proptosis and choanal atresia. Limbs: Humeroradial synostosis; medial bowing of the ulnas; long, slender fingers, with camptodactyly and anterior bowing of the femurs. Malformations of the heart and kidneys. Disorders of the Pituitary Gland
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common tumor associated with growth hormone deficiency in children?
explanation: The most common tumor associated with growth hormone (GH) deficiency in children is craniopharyngioma. Growth hormone deficiency can be caused by congenital CNS malformations, genetic defects or acquired neurological insults. Note: Most common cause of GH deficiency: Idiopathic Most common infection causing GH deficiency in India: Tuberculosis > Histoplasmosis Most common infiltration causing GH deficiency in India: Histiocytosis > Sarcoidosis. Trophic hormone failure with pituitary compression or destruction: GH> FSH> LH> TSH> ACTH. Most common tumors associated with central diabetes insipidus: Pinealomas, Germinomas
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Asha was being bullied about her height in school. The concerned parents bring her to the pediatrician who plots the growth chart as shown below. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among the following could be a cause?
explanation: The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point towards Laron syndrome/dwarfism. It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to the GH receptor mutation. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features as those seen in pituitary dwarfism. Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low. In Turner's syndrome (Option A), loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and decreased utilization. Pituitary dwarfism (Option B) is a condition with GH deficiency. Maternal deprivation dwarfism (Option D) is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules this out.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormone deficiency?
explanation: The most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormone deficiencies (MPHD)/panhypopituitarism is the mutation of the PROP1 gene. LHX3 and GLI2 are other genes involved in MPHD. GNAS1 mutations cause McCune Albright Syndrome. c-MYC gene is mutated in Burkitt's lymphoma WT-1 gene is mutated in Wilms tumors.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You come across a child with growth hormone deficiency during your ward rounds. Which of the following features would you not expect in this child?
options: History of short stature at birth
explanation: Children with growth hormone deficiency usually have normal growth at birth. Growth retardation (decline in growth velocity) becomes apparent around 1 year of age. Growth in-utero is dependant on genetic, environmental, nutrition and growth factors. GH levels peak at mid-gestation, increase at birth, and then reduce by 2 weeks of life. At around 6 months of age, GH levels reach pre-pubertal levels and from there on have a major influence on growth. Thus the deficiency becomes apparent after a significant period of GH-dependent growth has occurred. Characteristic features of growth hormone deficiency (Pituitary Dwarfism): Normal growth at birth with growth retardation becoming apparent around 1 year of age Proportionate short stature Hypoglycemic seizures in newborn Small larynx with a high-pitched voice Small genitalia (micropenis) Delayed skeletal maturation Delayed dentition Delayed puberty (sexual infantilism) Doll-like facial appearance: small, round facies, frontal prominence, depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose), eyes may bulge, underdeveloped mandible and chin, normal head circumference but craniofacial disproportion due to small facies Short neck Normal intelligence.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are evaluating children with short stature on whether they are eligible to receive growth hormone therapy as per FDA guidelines. In which of the following children would you prescribe it?
options: An 8 year old with Laron dwarfism
A neonate diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism
A 7 year old with Chronic kidney disease
A 6 year old diagnosed with Maternal deprivation dwarfism
explanation: Chronic kidney disease is an FDA-approved indication for growth hormone (GH) therapy. Renal failure is a state of GH resistance. Moderate-to-severe growth retardation in chronic kidney disease is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. GH therapy with recombinant growth hormone has been shown to improve catch-up growth and to allow the child to achieve normal adult height; the final adult height is still significantly below the genetic target. FDA-approved indications for growth hormone (GH) treatment- GH deficiency Turner's Syndrome Chronic Renal Failure before Transplantation Small for Gestational Age / Short Stature Idiopathic Short Stature Noonan Syndrome Prader-Willi Syndrome AIDS-related wasting Malabsorption associated with the short-bowel syndrome
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Chotu, a 5-year-old boy is on regular outpatient follow-up for growth hormone deficiency diagnosed 2 weeks back. He is planned for recombinant growth hormone therapy. All of the following are possible side effects except-
explanation: The use of recombinant growth hormone is associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (not type 1 diabetes mellitus). Other adverse effects: Pseudotumor cerebri Slipped capital femoral epiphysis Gynecomastia Worsening of scoliosis Children who have been treated with rhGH have a higher risk of developing hemorrhagic strokes in adulthood. Some studies show an increased risk of new neoplasms in cancer survivors.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common pituitary adenoma diagnosed in childhood is .
explanation: The most commonly diagnosed adenomas during childhood are prolactinoma > corticotropinoma > somatotropinoma. Note: Hypothalamic hamartomas that secrete excess gonadotropin-releasing hormone can cause precocious puberty.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Akash is the tallest kid in his 5th-grade class. While at a routine visit for a booster immunization, his pediatrician plots his height on a growth chart and finds him to be above 3-SD for his age. Which of the following can be an endocrine cause for his height?
explanation: McCune–Albright syndrome (endocrine dysfunction affecting multiple glands) is an endocrine cause of tall stature in childhood. The triad of McCune–Albright syndrome is precocious puberty, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and cafe au lait macules Causes of childhood tall stature: Non-endocrine causes Endocrine causes Familial (constitutional) tall s tature Excess GH secretion(pituitar y gigantism) Cerebral gigantism (Sotos sy ndrome) McCune–Albright syndrome Marfan syndrome Precocious puberty Fragile X syndrome Hyperthyroidism Homocystinuria Klinefelter syndrome(XXY) XYY syndrome Beckwith–Wiedemann syndr ome
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: "Weak giants" are produced by .
explanation: "Weak giants" are due to hyperpituitarism that is most commonly produced by pituitary adenomas. Hyperpituitarism causes growth hormone (GH) excess, leading to tall stature (giants) with weak muscles. Overproduction of GH results in gigantism in children (before fusion of bone growth plate) and acromegaly in adults. Clinical features include: Gigantism, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones Proximal myopathy (though there is muscle hypertrophy, it is weakened due to atrophy of type II muscle fibers) Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues) Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver, spleen, kidney, and prostate Local effects of the adenoma: Headache, visual field defects, raised ICT Note: Although hypothalamic hamartomas can also produce gigantism, the most common cause of gigantism is pituitary adenomas.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young boy is diagnosed to have central diabetes insipidus. A lesion in which of the following nuclei is likely to cause this condition?
explanation: Lesions in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus can cause central diabetes insipidus. These nuclei synthesize vasopressin, a 9-amino-acid peptide with antidiuretic and vascular pressor activity. It is transported to the posterior pituitary via axonal projections, where it is stored for release into the systemic circulation. Diabetes insipidus (DI) is characterized by pathologic polyuria and polydipsia (>2 L/m²/24 hr or 5 mL/kg/hr). It can result from either: Vasopressin deficiency (decreased anti-diuretic hormone production) causes central DI. Vasopressin insensitivity at the level of the kidney causes nephrogenic DI.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his mother with new-onset nocturnal bedwetting. She also reported, he has been drinking more water for the last 3-4 months. 24-hour urine volume was 4 liters and the urine osmolality was low. ADH assays recorded a value was 0.7 pg/mL. T1 weighted MRI brain indicated an absence of a pituitary bright spot. What is the treatment of choice for his condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The treatment of choice is desmopressin. It is a vasopressin analog (V2 receptor agonist). It can be administered intranasally, or subcutaneously. Option A: Leuprolide is a GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) analog used in the treatment of prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis. Option B: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drug of choice. They are generally used in nephrogenic DI. Option D: Terlipressin is a long-acting analog on vasopressin that acts on V1 receptors of vascular smooth muscle. It is used as a vasopressor in shock and acute variceal bleeding.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old boy diagnosed with Wolfram syndrome is admitted to the pediatric ward of your hospital. Which of the following features would you expect to find in this child?
explanation: Optic Atrophy is seen in Wolfram syndrome. The components of the syndrome are represented by the acronym DIDMOAD: Diabetes Insipidus Diabetes Mellitus (type 1) Optic Atrophy Neural Deafness It is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
While working in a tertiary care center, a 5-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturnal enuresis for the past 1 year. A water deprivation test is done and shows low urine osmolality on stopping the intake of water. On desmopressin administration, there is a 7% rise in urine osmolality. The treatment of this condition uses all of the following except?
Thiazide diuretics
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The treatment includes pharmacological treatment combined with salt restriction and not increased salt intake. Treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: Adequate water intake along with a low sodium diet Thiazide diuretics: Acts by Volume contraction and increases the responsiveness of other parts of the tubule Increase the AQP2 channels independent of vasopressin Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice for ithium-induced DI Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin) Disorders of Puberty
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are suspecting a case of delayed puberty in a 15-year-old boy. To assess puberty in this patient, what is the first sign you would look for?
explanation: The first sign of puberty in males is the increase in testicular volume. In males at 11 to 12 years, the growth of the testis (>4 mL in volume) and thinning of the scrotum occurs, which are the first signs of puberty. This is followed by the pigmentation of the scrotum, growth of the penis, and pubarche. Growth of testis > pubarche > adrenarche > growth spurt (TPAG). In females at 10 to 11 years, the breast bud (thelarche) appears, which is the first sign of puberty followed by the appearance of pubic hair (pubarche), growth spurt, and menarche. Thelarche > pubarche > growth spurt > menarche (TPGM).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: As an intern, you are currently posted in the Paediatric endocrinology OPD where you see multiple cases of girls having precocious puberty. The condition is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of .
explanation: Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys. Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified in the following manner: Note: Central Precocious Puberty(more common) >> Peripheral Precocious Puberty Central Precocious Puberty(G onadotropin-dependent pube rty) Peripheral Precocious Pubert y(Gonadotropin independent) Due to the excess secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from pituitary Due to excess secretion of tes tosterone or estrogen from th e gonads/adrenals. Always isosexual (appearance of phenotypically appropriat e secondary sexual characteri stics before age 8 years in gir ls and before 9 years in boys) . Can be isosexual or heterosex ual (appearance of secondary sex characters of the opposit e sex). GirlsIdiopathic (most commo n)BoysCNS pathology (most c ommon) GirlsEstrogenic ovarian cysts (isosexual)Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (testoster one increases; heterosexual)B oysCAH (isosexual; most com mon)
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother who is concerned about her significant increase in height compared to her classmates in the last 2 years. On examination, the girl shows breast development corresponding to B2 Tanner stage. What is the most common brain lesion causing this condition?
explanation: Hypothalamic hamartoma, a neuronal migration defect, is the most common cause of organic central precocious puberty. The onset of breast development before the age of 8 years in females and onset of testicular development (>4 mL) before the age of 9 years in males is suggestive of central precocious puberty. It is a congenital malformation that consists of ectopically located neural tissue characterised by- Early-onset of puberty Seizures associated with unnatural crying or laughing episodes are known as gelastic seizures. Tuberculous meningitis, tuberous sclerosis, and astrocytomas can also cause central precocious puberty.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young girl was referred to the paediatrician with stage IV breast development and growth acceleration seen at the age of 5 years. Her estradiol concentrations were elevated. The sagittal MRI of the brain is as shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
explanation: A pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle as shown in the MRI, with elevated levels of estrogen is suggestive of a Hypothalamic Hamartoma, which is the most common brain lesion causing central precocious puberty and is treated with GnRH agonists. Treatment of Hypothalamic Hamartoma- GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implant) are the treatment of choice of tumour-induced Central precocious puberty In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (Gamma Knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention. Long-acting formulations of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are the preparations of choice for the treatment of central precocious puberty as they maintain fairly constant serum concentrations of the drug for weeks or months.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A primary school teacher notices bloodstains on the skirt of her second-grade student. She immediately informs her parents and accompanies the child to the doctor on campus. On examination, the 7-year-old girl had blood-stained vaginal discharge, enlarged breasts and areola. Which of the following is not a cause for this condition?
explanation: Vaginal bleeding with well-developed breasts before the age of 8 years is suggestive of precocious puberty. Prader–Willi syndrome is one of the causes of delayed puberty in girls (not precocious puberty), where there is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypothalamic hamartoma, McCune–Albright syndrome and hypothyroidism are causes of precocious puberty. Note: In prolonged hypothyroidism, adolescents typically have delayed puberty. Younger children might present with pseudo-precocious puberty, characterized by breast development and vaginal bleeding in girls and macroorchidism in boys. Elevated levels of TSH appear to interact with the FSH receptor (specificity spillover), thus inducing FSH-like effects in the absence of LH effects on the gonads. The FSH-like effect suffices to induce estradiol secretion by the ovaries, whereas in males, testicular enlargement occurs without substantial testosterone secretion.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An incessantly crying 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her father. You observe that she needs support to walk and her trunk is not symmetrically aligned. There is a history of recurrent fractures in her limbs. She also has blood-stained vaginal discharge from a few days. On examination, the girl appears as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: Precocious puberty(vaginal discharge), bony lesions (polyostotic fibrous dysplasia), and cafe au lait spots, as shown in the picture, are features of McCune–Albright syndrome. There is pain due to the multiple bony lesions and repeated fractures may result in incessant crying in the children and may require regular visits to the orthopaedics department. McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues. Fibrous dysplasia of multiple bones (polyostotic) represents a major cause of morbidity in this syndrome. The base of the skull and the proximal femurs are most commonly involved, but any bone can be affected. A CT scan is usually recommended even in absence of deformities. The prognosis is favourable for longevity, but deformities, repeated fractures, pain, and occasional cranial nerve compression may result from the bony lesions. Cardinal features: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia Cafe au lait macules Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty Predominantly affects girls
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 15-year-old boy on examination is found to have genital development corresponding to Tanner stage 1 and his height is below the 3rd Percentile on growth charting. What is the most common cause for this condition?
explanation: Failure of development of pubertal features by the age of 14 years in male is suggestive of Delayed Puberty. The most common cause of delayed puberty in males and females is a constitutional delay in growth and puberty. Lack of pubertal changes in boys by the age of 14 years is suggestive of delayed puberty. Delayed puberty is more common in boys than in girls.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Breast and papillae appear as a small mound on examination of a young girl. If you are suspecting a case of delayed puberty, it is defined as a lack of development of secondary sexual characters beyond the age of .
explanation: Delayed puberty in girls is defined as lack of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 13 years or absence of menarche by the age of 16 years or within 3 years of pubertal onset.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child presents with features of delayed puberty. On investigating, he has decreased levels of LH, FSH, and testosterone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and testosterone pointing towards hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and Kallman's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Causes of delayed puberty: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central) Hypogonadism is due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production Malnutrition, systemic diseases Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure) Hypogonadism is due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body) Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome) Androgen insensitivity syndrome Ovotesticular dysgenesis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All of the following are features of Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome except .
explanation: Hypertension is seen in Laurence–Moon–Biedl syndrome. Laurence–Moon–Bardet–Biedl is an autosomal-recessive disorder of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Characteristic features: Polydactyly Obesity Retinitis pigmentosa Male hypogonadism Hypertension Mental retardation
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A female child presents with bilateral inguinal masses, which were thought to be hernias but were found to be testes in the inguinal canals. Which karyotype would you expect to find in the child?
explanation: Here, this baby girl with bilateral inguinal masses (testis) probably has androgen-insensitivity syndrome, where karyotype is 46,XY. Androgen-insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the androgen receptor gene that makes XY fetuses insensitive to androgens. The patients phenotypically resemble females because a part of the testosterone is converted to estrogen, which leads to the development of female external genitalia, normal development of breast, and female habitus. Patients with Klienfelter's syndrome have a karyotype of 47, XXY and can have undescended testis, but they have male external genitalia where the phallus tends to be smaller than average. Characteristic features: Most common forms of male disorders of sexual differentiation (DSD). 46 XY male child with female phenotype, present with primary amenorrhoea. Normal male gonads, mostly undescended ones, can present as inguinal masses or hernia. Here, as testosterone receptors are defective, they do not act on tissues, leading to the absence of secondary sexual characters (absence of pubic hair and axillary hair).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An infant was found to have elevated levels of LH. The baby has a 46, XY chromosome pattern on karyotyping and the vagina is short and ends blindly in a pouch. Which of the following is false in the condition suffered by the infant?
explanation: An infant with a 46, XY chromosome pattern and female external genitalia are suggestive of Androgen-insensitivity syndrome(AIS) where there is absent internal female genitalia. These patients have absent internal female genitalia with normal female external genitalia with the vagina ending blindly, in a pouch and normal male gonads in the form of undescended testis (mostly) which can present as inguinal masses. In a male child (46, XY), testicular hormones are resistant to receptors, and a part of the testosterone is converted to estrogen leading to the development of female external genitalia and eventually normal development of breast, and female habitus. Features of Androgen insensitivity syndrome at different age groups- In infants, elevated LH levels should suggest the diagnosis of AIS Prepubertal females with this disorder are often detected when inguinal masses which prove to be testes In older children and adults, amenorrhea is the usual presenting symptom. Note: Reifen-Stein syndrome: Males with various forms of ambiguous genitalia and undervirilization (hypogonadism, severe hypospadias, and gynecomastia). They are phenotypically normal-appearing males with infertility.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 31-year-old female delivers a term baby. On examination, it has a micropenis and unpalpable testis. She gives a history of acne from 16 weeks of gestation which worsened throughout pregnancy and was treated after delivery. The baby was diagnosed to have female pseudohermaphroditism. Which of the following statements are right about the given condition?
options: Female external genitalia and male internal genitalia
explanation: Female pseudohermaphrodites are genectic females (XX genotype) with male external genitalia. Causes: Enzyme deficiencies: 21 hydroxylase, 11 hydroxylase, and 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (HSD) deficiencies Maternal androgen excess Male pseudohermaphrodites are genetic males (XY genotype) with female external genitalia. Causes: Enzyme deficiencies: 17 hydroxylase and 3-beta HSD deficiencies Defect in androgen action True hermaphroditism/ovotesticular dysgenesis: An intersex condition in which an individual is born with ovarian and testicular tissue.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development?
options: Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased.
explanation: Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual. An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 of affected individuals. Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in female sexual development. In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XX karyotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the X chromosome or another chromosome. There is a defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by the RSPO1 gene, described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD. An abnormal vagina and an underdeveloped uterus are usually present. The testes are usually undescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias. Upon reaching puberty, breast development, feminization, and menstruation may occur. Most affected individuals are infertile, but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible. The response of testosterone to hCG is normal or reduced.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
21 hydroxylase deficiency
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a girl (46XX) with an enlarged clitoris is highly suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex. The majority of cases of CAH are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This deficiency leads to a lack of synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone, resulting in the salt-wasting form of the disease, which is the most severe form. Severe 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with symptoms including weight loss, dehydration, weakness, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances. Accumulated steroid precursors like 17-hydroxyprogesterone, are shunted into the pathway of androgen synthesis leading to elevated levels of androstenedione and testosterone. This can result in abnormal genital development in affected female fetuses during early gestation. Females may have masculinized external genitalia. This can include enlargement of the clitoris, partial or complete labial fusion, and a shared opening of the vagina and urethra (urogenital sinus). Untreated individuals develop signs of androgen excess after birth. These signs include accelerated skeletal maturation, premature epiphyseal closure leading to stunted adult stature, excessive muscular development, the appearance of pubic and axillary hair, acne, and deepening of the voice. In males, enlargement of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. In females, the clitoris may become further enlarged. Diagnosis of confirmed by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Glucocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone is done. In a salt-wasting crisis, fludrocortisone supplementation is given. Vaginoplasty and clitoral recession are done for females with ambiguous genitalia. Paediatric Hemato-oncology
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Cancer-'The emperor of all maladies spares no one'. Which of the following is the most common childhood malignancy?
explanation: Leukemias are the most common childhood malignancies. Among these, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common, accounting for about 77% of childhood leukemias. Most commons in childhood malignancies: Second most common malignancy in childhood: Brain tumor Third most common malignancy in children: Lymphoma Most common solid tumor in children: Brain tumor
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are asked to review an article titled, 'Childhood cancers- a menace'. Which of the following statements is wrong and needs to be edited out?
options: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children with Down syndrome.
The most common intra-abdominal malignancy is Wilm’s tumor.
The most common extracranial solid malignancy is neuroblastoma.
The most common brain tumors in children are infratentorial.
explanation: The most common intraabdominal malignancy in children is neuroblastoma. The most common leukemias seen in Down’s syndrome: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) > acute myeloid leukemia (AML) The most common site of a brain tumor in children: Infratentorium The most common extra-cranial solid neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma The most common intra-abdominal neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma The most common primary neoplasm of renal tissue in children: Wilm’s tumor
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the most common leukemia you would encounter in a child with the following findings?
explanation: The image shows a typical Down's facies (flattened nose, flat occiput, low set ears, protruding tongue). The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life. Note: Most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (overall) The most common leukemia in children <3years of age with Down syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Most common AML in Down's syndrome: M7/megakaryoblastic
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Jeevit, a 7-year-old boy brought to you by his mother, complains of bone pain so severe that he cannot sleep. Investigations reveal:
explanation: B-lymphoblastic leukemia(pre-B-ALL) is the most common immunophenotype with TdT+,HLA DR+, CD10+, CD19+, CD20+, CD24+, Cy Ig + , with onset at 1-10 years of age. The most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is B-lymphoblastic leukemia (previously termed pre-B-ALL) Based on current WHO classification: The most common subtype of ALL is B lymphoblastic leukemia > T lymphoblastic leukemia > Mature B-cell Leukemia (Burkitt leukemia) The production of symptoms and signs of ALL is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure. On physical examination, findings of pallor, listlessness, purpuric/petechial skin lesions, or mucous membrane hemorrhage can reflect bone marrow failure. The proliferative nature of the disease may be manifested as lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or, less often, hepatomegaly. At presentation 75% of patients have leukocyte counts of <20,000/µL; thrombocytopenia is seen in 75% of patients and hepatosplenomegaly in 30–40% of patients. Patients with joint pain may have evidence of joint swelling and effusion. Deep bone pain may be present with marrow involvement, but tenderness will not be elicited.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are posted in the pediatric hematology department as a first-year postgraduate. All of the following cases you encounter are at an increased risk of developing leukemias except:
explanation: Fanconi’s anemia (not syndrome) predisposes to the development of childhood leukemias eg: B-ALL due to defective DNA repair. Fanconi syndrome is a syndrome of inadequate reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules. Congenital pernicious anemia does not predispose to leukemias. Factors predisposing to childhood leukemias Genetic conditions: Fanconi’s anemia Bloom syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Li-Fraumeni syndrome Down syndrome Severe combined immunodeficiency Neurofibromatosis 1 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Diamond-Blackfan anemia Schwachman diamond syndrome Kostmann syndrome Environmental factors: Ionizing radiation Alkylating agents Nitrosoureas Epipodophyllotoxin Benzene exposure Advanced maternal age.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: To diagnose a 5-year-old child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a pathologist has to see at least percentage of blast cells in a bone marrow biopsy.
explanation: The lower cut-off percentage for diagnosing acute lymphoblastic leukemia on bone marrow biopsy is 25%. Unlike with myeloid leukemias, there is no agreed-upon lower limit for the proportion of blasts required to establish a diagnosis of lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). In general, the diagnosis should be avoided when there are < 20% blasts. The image below shows numerous lymphoblasts seen on a peripheral smear. Work-up of ALL: It is important that all studies necessary to confirm a diagnosis and adequately classify the type of leukemia be performed, including bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, flow cytometry, cytogenetics, and molecular studies. The initial evaluation should also include a CSF examination. If lymphoblasts are found and the CSF leukocyte count is elevated, overt CNS or meningeal leukemia is present. This finding reflects a poorer stage and indicates the need for additional CNS and systemic therapies.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 4-year-old child who was being evaluated for pancytopenia is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following findings would indicate a poor prognosis?
options: Minimal residual disease>0.01% at the end of induction therapy
explanation: MRD(Minimal residual disease) is a quantitative estimate of the burden of leukemic cells present in marrow. MRD>0.01%at the end of induction suggests a poorer prognosis. Initial WBC count of <50,000cells/mm3, B-cell immunophenotype and t(12,21) indicate a standard risk(Favourable prognosis) Risk-directed therapy is the standard of current ALL treatment and accounts for: Age at diagnosis Initial WBC count Immunophenotypic and cytogenetic characteristics of blast populations The rapidity of early treatment response (i.e., how quickly the leukemic cells can be cleared fro the marrow or peripheral blood) Assessment of MRD at the end of induction therapy.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 14-year-old boy is rushed to the casualty due to difficulty in breathing and swelling of the face and neck. Clinically, he has features suggestive of superior vena cava obstruction. Chest X-ray image shows superior mediastinal widening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is the most likely diagnosis since the chest X-ray shows superior mediastinal widening- indicating an involvement of the thymus gland. T-ALL accounts for about 15% of childhood ALL cases; it is more common in adolescents - this is the time when the thymus reaches maximum size. 60% of patients with T-ALL present with a mediastinal mass. The mediastinal mass may be asymptomatic and detected only on chest x-ray or may cause cough and dyspnea, particularly on lying flat or with facial swelling and plethora due to vascular compression (superior vena cava syndrome). B-ALL presents usually between 1-10 years of age perhaps because the number of normal bone marrow pre-B-cells (the cell of origin) is greatest very early in life.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 2-month-old infant with seizures and failure to thrive has cutaneous nodules and hepatosplenomegaly. On investigations, CBC reveals hyperleukocytosis with a leukocyte count of 1,10,000cells/mm3. Peripheral smear and immunophenotyping studies reveal large,
irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker. On a cytogenetic study which of the following is most likely to be seen?
explanation: The above findings are diagnostic of Infantile acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Translocation (4;11) involving the MLL gene is most commonly associated with Infantile leukemia accounts for the very high relapse rate. 2% of cases of leukemia during childhood occur before the age of 1 year and are referred to as infantile leukemia. Patients often present with hyperleukocytosis and extensive tissue infiltration producing organomegaly. Subcutaneous nodules, known as leukemia cutis, caused by infiltration by leukemic cells are observed more often in infants than in older children. The leukemic cell morphology is usually that of large, irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker (pro-B), unlike most older children with B-ALL, who are CD10 +. Has a very poor prognosis. Note: Infants with AML present with CNS and skin involvement and most commonly have a subtype known as acute myelomonocytic leukemia.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A mother has noticed recently that her child refuses to be touched, seems to be in distress, and cries inconsolably. She brings her child to you who was investigated thoroughly and was diagnosed to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat her?
explanation: L-asparaginase is used in the treatment of acute lymphoid leukaemia (ALL). ALL can present with hepatosplenomegaly, severe joint and bone pains that the kid refuses to be handled. It is observed that some lymphoid malignancies are unable to synthesize asparagine on their own and must derive it from the bloodstream. L-asparaginase catalyses circulating L-asparagine, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis in the cancer cells. Treatment of ALL Induction: 4 weeks L-asparaginase: single dose (side effects: pancreatitis, thrombosis) Vincristine: weekly (side effects: neuropathy, SIADH) Prednisolone Anthracycline CNS prophylaxis- intrathecal methotrexate Consolidation: Methotrexate Epipodophyllotoxin Cyclophosphamide Cytosine-Arabinoside Maintenance: 24-36 months 6-Mercaptopurine Methotrexate Other options: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia and acute lymphoblastic leukemia with t(9;22) BCR-ABL fusion gene. Tretinoin is used in acute promyelocytic leukaemia with t(15;17) PML-RARA fusion gene. Cladribine is used in hairy cell leukaemia.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are posted in the hematology department as a pathologist. You are asked to report the bone marrow biopsy slide given below, which belongs to a 3-year-old child who is being evaluated for pancytopenia. To make a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia, what percentage of such cells should you visualize at the least?
explanation: Diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is confirmed by the presence of more than 20% myeloblast cells (as shown in the image) in the bone marrow. Flow cytometry and special stains can be used to identify myeloperoxidase-containing cells, which confirms the myelogenous origin of leukemia. Note: The diagnosis of acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) requires the presence of more than 25% blasts in the bone marrow.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent fever for the past 1 week. His CBC is given below:
explanation: Monosomy 7 is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The production of symptoms and signs of AML is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure-pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance, bruising, oral mucosal bleeding, or epistaxis, as well as fever, which may be caused by infection or the disease. In addition, patients with AML present with signs and symptoms that are uncommon in Acute lymphoblastic leukemia, including subcutaneous nodules or“blueberry muffin” lesions (especially in infants), infiltration of the gingiva (especially in monocytic subtypes), signs and laboratory findings of disseminated intravascular coagulation (especially indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia), and discrete masses, known as chloromas or granulocytic sarcomas.
