question_text: A child with a violaceous, raised nodular skin lesion which on biopsy is found to be infiltrated by myeloblasts is likely suffering from which type of Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)?
explanation: Nodular, violaceous skin lesion infiltrated with myeloblasts is descriptive of Chloroma otherwise known as extramedullary myeloblastoma or granulocytic(myeloid) sarcoma. Myeloid sarcomas are seen in AML subtypes M2, M4, M5a, and M5b. “Chloroma” was coined due to the peculiar green color of the tumor caused by myeloperoxidase present in tumor cells. These masses can occur in the absence of apparent bone marrow involvement and typically are associated with t(8;21) translocation. Chloromas also may be seen in the orbit and epidural space.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Erythemic myelosis is .
explanation: Erythemic myelosis is AML M6. Constitute about 1% of AML cases Two subtypes of AML M6: Erythroid or myeloid leukemia: M6a (more common) Pure erythroid leukemia: M6b, also called erythemic myelosis (Di Guglielmo disease).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A neonate with trisomy 21 has anemia, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, and no
life-threatening complications on examination.CBC reveals high leucocyte count and peripheral smear shows numerous myeloblasts. The genetic makeup of blast cells when studied reveals GATA-1 mutations. At 3 months of age, his CBC counts come back to normal and there are no blast cells in his peripheral smear. As his treating physician, what would you recommend?
explanation: This infant has a transient myeloproliferative disease, which usually resolves spontaneously in the first 3 months of life, and they require close-follow up because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life. Approximately 10% of neonates with Down syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder characterized by high leukocyte counts, blast cells in the peripheral blood, and associated anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. Although these neonates can require temporary transfusion support, they do not require chemotherapy unless there is evidence of life-threatening complications. As only 20-30% of such children develop acute megakaryocytic leukemia a bone marrow transplant would be a drastic step in our case.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 18-month-old child presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of fever and rashes for the past 1 week after extensive workup gets diagnosed as Juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia. Which of the following findings is not consistent with this baby’s diagnosis?
options: The genetic study may reveal NF-1 mutation
The presence of Philadelphia chromosome on FISH
The bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern with <20% blasts.
The peripheral smear reveals nucleated RBCs
explanation: Patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia do not have the Philadelphia chromosome. Formerly termed juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), it is a clonal proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells that typically affects children younger than 2 years of age. Patients with JMML present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. Patients with this disease do not have the Philadelphia chromosome (the Philadelphia chromosome is characteristic of CML). The peripheral blood smear shows an elevated leukocyte count with increased monocytes, thrombocytopenia, and anemia with the presence of erythroblasts. Bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern, with blasts accounting for <20% of cells. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and Noonan syndrome have a predilection for this type of leukemia. JMML in the setting of Noonan syndrome is unique, with most patients having a spontaneous resolution.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children is .
explanation: Burkitt lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children under the age of 15 years. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in adults and adolescents (15-19) years, worldwide. B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy and the most common leukemia in children. (It is not a non-Hodgkin's lymphoma).
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following statements best describe the behavior of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in a 10-year-old child?
options: Is of high grade and aggressive
explanation: In contrast to adult non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), which is typically indolent, pediatric NHL is usually high-grade and aggressive. NHL in the pediatric age group has distinct clinical and behavior properties when compared to adults. These include the following: NHL in adults NHL in children Low/intermediate grade High grade Dominantly nodal Extra-nodal Variable growth fractio n High growth fractio n Poor long-term outcom e Good outcome

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal distension, fatigue, and night sweats for the past 4 months. He also has a 2-month history of postprandial fullness and recurrent non-bilious vomiting. On examination, he is pale, has hepatosplenomegaly and shifting dullness. A CT scan shows mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement. A biopsy specimen of the mesenteric lymph node reveals tumor cells with high mitotic index and starry sky pattern. The cytogenetic study revealed t(8;14).To stage the disease, which of the following systems would you use?
explanation: Retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and short duration of disease, point towards a diagnosis of lymphoid neoplasms.The classic translocation of t(8;14) and starry sky appearance with a high mitotic index on HPE point toward a diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt’s lymphoma is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma worldwide. St Jude system of staging is used for staging childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The current revised staging system used for NHL is the International Pediatric Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Staging System (IPNHLSS) which reflects our increasing ability to diagnose lower levels of organ involvement with disease. For instance, the older staging system (St. Jude/Murphy classification) did not account for molecular or flow cytometry involvement of bone marrow, which is now reflected in the new system. question_text: A lymph node biopsy of a 9-year-old child with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is .
explanation: In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is a pathognomonic feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). Reed–Sternberg cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli. The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function. Hodgkin lymphoma encompasses a group of lymphoid neoplasms that typically arise in a signal node or chain of nodes and spread first to anatomically contiguous sites. WHO classification of Hodgkin lymphoma includes 5 subtypes namely; Nodular sclerosis Mixed cellularity Lymphocyte-rich Lymphocyte depletion Nodular lymphocyte predominance

CT scan of the chest and abdomen reveals the presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, mediastinum, and liver, and an FDG-PET/CT scan shows multiple scattered consolidation lesions involving also the bones. The diagnosis of classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma, nodular sclerosis subtype, is made on cervical lymph node biopsy. According to Ann-Arbor's staging system, how will you stage her disease?
explanation: The clinical vignette describes Hodgkin’s lymphoma with the involvement of liver and bone marrow, which is classified as Stage 4 according to Ann-Arbor staging. question_text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis .
explanation: Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL. Leukocyte count <50,000/mm3, hyperdiploidy, and trisomy of chromosomes 4,10,17 indicate a good prognosis.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Sanctuary sites of acute lymphoblastic leukemia are .
explanation: Both CNS and testis are considered as sanctuary sites of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). A sanctuary site is an area of the body that is poorly penetrated by pharmacological agents and, therefore, serves as a place in which tumor cells or infectious organisms can escape the effects of drug therapy. Early institution of CNS prophylaxis (intrathecal methotrexate) is essential to eradicate these escaped leukemic cells. Testicular involvement is rarely evident at diagnosis, testicular involvement can present as painless testicular enlargement.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 4-year-old boy presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly. Bony tenderness is also present. He is most likely suffering from the following type of ALL .
B cell
explanation: B-cell lymphoblastic leukemia (L1) This is the most common immunophenotype of acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) in a child between the ages of 1-10 years. They present with features of bone marrow failure and organ infiltration such as pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly, respectively, so B-cell ALL is the most likely diagnosis. Bony tenderness may be present due to sub-periosteal infiltration of lymphoblastic cells. T-cell ALL (L2) typically presents in adolescent boys with a large anterior mediastinal mass (thymus or mediastinal lymph nodes), causing respiratory distress or superior vena cava obstruction. Solid Neoplasms of Childhood

question_text: Which of the following is the second most common malignancy in childhood?
explanation: The second most common malignancy in childhood is a brain tumor. The most common malignancy in childhood is Leukemias. Brain tumors in childhood: Most common solid tumor in children- Brain tumor Most common site of a brain tumor in children- Infratentorium Most common brain tumor in childhood- Pilocytic astrocytoma

question_text: The MRI scan of an 11-year-old girl revealed a brain tumor. In which of the following conditions would you do a lumbar puncture for cytological analysis?
explanation: Germ-cell tumor is an indication for lumbar puncture for cytological analysis of CSF. Usually, lumbar punctures are contraindicated in intracranial space-occupying lesions with high intracranial pressure as it can lead to brain herniation and death. They are thus delayed until surgery or shunt placement. However, in tumors with a risk of leptomeningeal metastases, lumbar puncture is indicated for cytology. question_text: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to the hospital with sudden onset vomiting. She has also been noticing an alarming increase in the head size of the baby. On examination, significant macrocephaly is seen. MRI reveals a supratentorial tumor. Which of the following tumors is the most likely cause of this child's presentation?
explanation: Choroid plexus carcinoma is a pediatric supratentorial tumor presenting with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits. Choroid plexus tumors are the most common CNS tumors in children aged less than 1 year. These tumors are intraventricular epithelial neoplasms arising from the choroid plexus. Children present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), whereas infants may present with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits. Medulloblastoma, pilocytic astrocytoma, and ependymoma, are all predominantly infratentorial tumors. The age-related differences in the primary location of the tumor are given below: Age Predominant S ite Examples < 1 year Supratentorial Choroid plexus tumor and te ratoma 1 - 10 year s Infratentorial Juvenile pilocytic astrocytom a and medulloblastoma > 10 years Supratentorial Diffuse astrocytoma

question_text: Sanam, a 7-year-old kid is suspected to have an ependymoma. Which of the following features on histopathology would favor this diagnosis?
explanation: Perivascular rosettes will be seen on histopathological examination of ependymoma. Other features include ependymal rosettes and monomorphic nuclear morphology. Ependymomas are tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system occurring predominantly in childhood. They are usually non-invasive, extending into the ventricular lumen and/or displacing normal structures, sometimes leading to significant obstructive hydrocephalus.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A young child was evaluated for increased ICP. A brain tumor was found on an MRI scan. It was resected and sent for histopathological examination. The slide is shown below. This tumor is found most commonly in the .
explanation: The slide shows perivascular pseudorosettes and ependymal rosettes, characteristic of ependymoma. The most common site of ependymoma in children is the floor of the 4th ventricle. Monomorphic nuclear morphology can also be noted. Ependymomas are tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system, occurring predominantly in childhood. These tumors are usually non-invasive, extending into the ventricular lumen and/or displacing normal structures, sometimes leading to significant obstructive hydrocephalus.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A concerned mother brought her daughter to the clinic for evaluation of symptoms that have worsened in the last few weeks. The daughter frequently wakes up at night with severe headaches and vomiting. She has also been having some difficulty walking. On examination, ataxia and multiple cranial nerve palsies are noted. Imaging is suggestive of a brainstem
tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The MRI given shows a diffuse, infiltrating pontine lesion. Multiple cranial nerve dysfunctions, cerebellar signs, motor weakness, and features of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are all strongly suggestive of a pontine glioma. These are not amenable for surgical resection. The standard approach is radiation therapy. The prognosis is very poor.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: On your neurology rotation, you come across Ashu, a 5-year-old child who presented with a 6-month history of ataxia, headaches, and vomiting. He was admitted to the ward for further evaluation. MRI scan showed a brain tumor with a combination of solid and cystic components. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given slide shows condensed masses of glial filaments occurring in compact areas suggestive of Rosenthal fibers. The clinical features, MRI findings, and histopathology point towards a diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma. Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade astrocytoma tumor. It is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. These are classically found in the cerebellum (infratentorial) and the optic pathway regions. There is usually a 3-6 month history of limb ataxia, secondary headaches, and vomiting. Mural nodule, a contrast medium enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass is seen on MRI. The tumor has a low metastatic potential and is rarely invasive.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: What is the WHO grading for Pilomyxoid astrocytoma?
explanation: Pilomyxiod astrocytoma falls under WHO Grade II. Pilomyxoid astrocytoma: Occurs most commonly in the hypothalamic/optic chiasmic region and carries a high risk of local as well as cerebrospinal spread. This astrocytoma affects young children and infants. It is classified as a WHO grade II tumor. question_text: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally. Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy. Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene. Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are: Medulloblastoma Neuroblastoma Retinoblastoma Ewing’s sarcoma Rhabdomyosarcoma
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A child is brought to the emergency department by his teacher when he started having abnormal jerking movements during math class. The parents give a history of the child having similar episodes in the past. On the way to the CT room, the child had an episode of seizure and was stabilized with lorazepam. The imaging done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Calcified cortical mass with a seizure is suggestive of oligodendroglioma. Oligodendrogliomas are uncommon tumors of childhood. These infiltrating tumors occur predominantly in the cerebral cortex and originate in white matter. Treatment involves surgical resection followed by involved field radiation therapy. The image below shows histology of oligodendroglioma showing characteristic fried egg appearance and chicken wire capillaries. Craniopharyngioma is associated with suprasellar calcification. Also, the child may often present with a history of endocrinological and visual complaints.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An erythropoietin-secreting brain tumor is detected in a child. His father passed away one year back from end-stage renal cell carcinoma. Family history is significant for VHL mutation. On examination, a fiery red retina is seen. Which of the following is the most likely tumor present in this child?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cerebellar hemangioblastoma. Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. The major neurological features of VHL include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas. Cerebellar hemangioblastomas are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead to polycythemia. It typically appears as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CT or MRI scan. Retinal angiomas are small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheral retina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascular mass. It can lead to retinal detachment and visual loss. Associations of VHL syndrome include: Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymis Renal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death) Pheochromocytoma Cerebellar hemangioblastoma Retinal angioma
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Akhil, a 15-year-old boy with sun-setting eyes, has a tumor in the pineal region as seen in the MRI. Parinaud syndrome is suspected. Which of the following findings will not be seen in this boy?
options: Convergence retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze
explanation: Parinaud’s syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder. Parinaud’s syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis. Causes: Pineal region or midbrain tumors (Most common cause) Neurocysticercosis Stroke Multiple sclerosis Features include the following: Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved) Convergence–retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign Lid retraction- Collier's sign Pseudo-Argyll–Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilated and show light-near dissociation Bilateral papilledema Skew deviation Pseudoabducens palsy
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the casualty after a minor accident that occurred when he failed to see a bike coming from sideways. His mother says he is a clumsy child, who sometimes knocks things over accidentally even at home. Visual field examination findings are given below. On imaging, an intracranial mass is seen. The resected specimen shows cholesterol-rich machinery-oil-like fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Patients with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma present with bitemporal hemianopia (image), and the cystic component of this tumor contains a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil." Craniopharyngiomas develop from remnants of the Rathke pouch. Adamantinomatous variant of craniopharyngioma predominates in childhood. These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with headache and visual field abnormalities. These children also have endocrinological abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to hypopituitarism (GH deficiency). These tumors are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures. CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic components.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common extracranial solid tumor in the pediatric age group?
explanation: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children and the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in infants. It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral nervous system. The signs and symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and the extent of the disease. Neuroblastomas originating from the superior cervical ganglion can present with Horner syndrome. Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following Fever Irritability Failure to thrive Bone pain Cytopenia Bluish subcutaneous nodules Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus), and ataxia are characteristic of the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastomas. Some neuroblastomas may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course. question_text: A 5-year-old child presents with rapid dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking of limbs and poor coordination. You suspect a paraneoplastic syndrome. Which of the following conditions should you look for in this child?
explanation: Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus) and ataxia is characteristic of opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastoma. All children with OMA should undergo investigations for neuroblastoma such as ultrasound followed by CT or MRI of chest and abdomen, bone scans and marrow biopsies. The definitive diagnosis of neuroblastoma is through biopsy which shows small round blue cells. Other small round blue cell tumours are medulloblastoma, retinoblastoma, Ewing’s sarcoma and rhabdomyosarcoma.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: In the ophthalmology OPD, you see a 3-year-old child with the following finding. There is no history of trauma. There is no significant family history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This image shows periorbital ecchymoses and proptosis suggestive of metastases of neuroblastoma (a sign of orbital bone involvement). Neuroblastomas may develop at any site in the sympathetic nervous system. Metastatic spread is common in children who are diagnosed after 1 year of age. It occurs via local invasion, hematogenous, or lymphatic routes. Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following: Fever Irritability Failure to thrive Bone pain Cytopenia Bluish subcutaneous nodules Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 10-month-old infant is diagnosed with neuroblastoma. Which of the following factors is associated with a good prognosis?
explanation: Hyperdiploidy is associated with a good prognosis in neuroblastoma if the child is younger than 1 year of age at diagnosis. Bad prognosis in neuroblastoma is seen in cases of: Amplification of N-MYC Loss of Heterozygosiy of 1p, 11 q ,14q Gain of 17q TrkB expression
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of an enlarging scalp lesion. There is no history of trauma to the head or scalp. The child is otherwise healthy and investigations are normal. X-ray of the head is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the x-ray image showing a punched-out lytic lesion is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). LCH is a rare histiocytic disorder characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions that can infiltrate nearly every organ, most notably the skin (of the scalp), lungs, thymus, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. LCH is so named because of its resemblance to the Langerhan’s cells, which are specialized dendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 12-year-old child is brought with 4 small, purplish, rubbery lesions on his back and arms. On examination, you note inguinal freckling and nodules on the iris as shown below. Which
chromosome is involved in the syndrome described in this child?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1. The NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11 is involved. It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome. It is diagnosed when at least 2 of the following 7 criteria are met: 6 or more cafe-au-lait macules >5mm prepuberty >15mm post-puberty Skin-fold freckling- axillary and inguina 2 or more iris lisch nodules (image) 2 or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma (purplish, rubbery lesions) Osseous lesions Osseous dysplasia Cortical thinning of long bones without a pseudoarthrosis Low-grade astrocytomas like optic gliomas 1st degree relative with diagnosed NF-1

explanation: Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNS manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 2 It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12. von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3p25-26. The CNS manifestation is usually a hemangioblastoma. Turcot syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5q21. The CNS manifestation is a medulloblastoma.

explanation: Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular tumor of the pediatric age group. It is an embryonal malignancy of the retina.

question_text: James was brought by his mother for evaluation of a squint she noticed. On examination, the given finding was observed. Investigations revealed retinoblastoma with a germline RB1 gene mutation. The secondary malignancy most likely to develop in him is:
explanation: Children with germline RB1 mutations are at significant risk for the development of secondary malignancies, especially Osteosarcoma (Most common) Soft tissue sarcomas Malignant melanoma The risk of secondary malignancies is further increased by the use of radiation therapy. question_text: A 5-year-old boy presented with an abdominal mass. On examination, the mass is firm, smooth, non-tender, and does not cross the mid-line. The boy is also found to have moderate hypertension. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria. Wilms tumor is suspected. This condition can be associated with all of the following except .
explanation: Polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilm's tumor. Wilms tumor (WT), also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. Polycystic kidney disease can also present with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. However, there will be multiple irregular cysts on ultrasound and is not associated with Wilms tumor.

question_text: You are assisting on a left partial nephrectomy in a child with Wilms tumor. Intraoperatively, a small mass is noted on the right kidney as well. Frozen section reveals it to be a Wilms tumor. What is the stage of Wilm's tumor in this child?

question_text: While posted in the pediatric oncology ward, you come across a case of metastatic triphasic nephroblastoma in a 4-year-old. What is the most common site for metastasis of this tumor?
explanation: The most common sites for metastases of nephroblastoma or Wilms tumor are the following: Lungs (Most common) Regional lymph nodes Liver The triphasic components visualized on histopathology are- Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component). Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component). Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

question_text: What is the most important determinant of prognosis in a child diagnosed with Wilm's tumor?
options: Loss of heterozygosity of chromosome 1 p
explanation: Histology is the most important determinant of prognosis in Wilm's Tumor. The absence of anaplasia is considered a favorable histological finding. Other prognostic factors for risk-adapted therapy include Age Stage Tumor weight Loss of heterozygosity at chromosomes 1p and 16q.

question_text: A 5-year-old child comes with abdominal distension, a palpable mass, and gross hematuria. A biopsy of the mass shows the following picture. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes in not associated with this tumor?
explanation: The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components of Wilm's tumor. Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy is not a paraneoplastic syndrome of Wilm's tumor. Several distinct paraneoplastic syndromes have been reported in Wilm's tumor. They are as follows: Hypertension Erythrocytosis/Polycythemia Hypercalcemia Cushing syndrome Acquired von Willebrand disease Bleeding may occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome in Wilm's tumor. It is due to acquired deficiency of von Willebrand factor or factor VII deficiency. Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

question_text: The most common soft tissue sarcoma in the pediatric age group is .
explanation: Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma. The most common sites are- head and neck (25%) > genitourinary tract (24%) > extremities (19%) > orbit (9%).

question_text: A 4-year-old girl presents with the lesion shown in this picture. The diagnosis is .
explanation: The lesion seen in the picture is sarcoma botryoides Vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma may manifest as a grape-like mass of tumor tissue bulging through the vaginal orifice, known as sarcoma botryoides.

question_text: The precursor lesion of Wilm's tumor is .
explanation: Wilms tumor is derived from foci of incompletely differentiated/undifferentiated rena mesenchyme called nephrogenic rests. Nephrogenic rests usually regress or differentiate, but those that persist can become malignant. Nephrogenic rests that persist abnormally in the kidneys into postnatal life are seen in 1% of children in the general population, but are seen in up to 90% of children who develop or have a family history of Wilms tumor.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The term “trilateral retinoblastoma” refers to bilateral retinoblastoma + .
explanation: A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called “trilateral retinoblastoma.” In hereditary retinoblastoma (having spontaneous germline RB1 mutation), second malignancies are a major concern. The most common second malignancy is osteosarcoma; other second neoplasms include rhabdomyosarcoma and melanoma.

question_text: Tumor which may undergo spontaneous regression is .
explanation: Neuroblastoma is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system with heterogeneous presentation and prognosis; some tumors may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course.

question_text:
Which of the following pediatric tumors is called a “triphasic" blastoma?
Hepatoblastoma
explanation: The classic nephroblastoma, aka Wilms tumor, is a mixed tumor (more than one neoplastic ce type) derived from one germ-cell layer (examples: Wilms tumor and pleomorphic adenoma of salivary gland). Histologically, it is made up of the classic "triphasic" combination (recapitulating stages of normal renal development) of Stroma Epithelial, and Blast cells Musculoskeletal Disorders

question_text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. His mother says he has always walked on his toes and walks by tilting side-to-side. He also has progressive muscle weakness. There is no history of trauma, fever, or rash. On examination, calf hypertrophy with atrophied thigh muscles is noted as shown below. There is no tenderness on palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle weakness and waddling gait are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles which occurs due to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is paradoxically weak, unlike the muscle that enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature. Clinical features: Progressive weakness with developmental delay Pseudohypertrophy of calves Wasting of thigh muscles Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle. Gower’s sign Dilated cardiomyopathy Diagnosis: Elevated serum creatine kinase levels Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for dystrophin gene If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done. Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration. Note- The FDA has approved Vamorolone, a novel corticosteroid for the treatment of DMD. The rug offers enhanced anti-inflammatory properties and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonism as well. It is potentially a safer and more effective alternative to glucocorticoids. Other options: Option B: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle involvement is very late. Option C: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. Death occurs early. Option D: Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of scapular and humeral muscles. The given question describes the involvement of lower limb muscles. Hence, Emery–Dreifuss dystrophy, in this case, is less likely.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: The image below shows the model of a skeletal muscle fiber. Which of the following structures is affected in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
explanation: The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. This gene is located on the short arm of chromosome X near the p21 locus (Xp21). Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Abhi, a young boy is being evaluated in the ward for proximal muscle weakness. Waddling gait and Gowers sign are observed in this child. Genetic analysis confirms the diagnosis as Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the following is false regarding this patient's condition?
options: It is less severe than Becker's dystrophy
Tendon reflexes are lost after age 6
Gene affected is the largest gene in humans
explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is more severe than Becker’s dystrophy. In DMD, tendon reflexes are lost after age 6. Becker’s dystrophy is similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a genetic defect at the same locus (Xp21) but clinically less severe. Gene affected in both is dystrophin, which is the largest gene in humans. Important differences between Duchenne and Becker’s muscular dystrophy: Duchenne's dystrophy Becker's dystrophy Onset Age: 2–3 years Age: 5–15 years Weakness Progressive Variable Intellectual impairmen t Common Uncommon Prognosis Wheelchair dependant by ad olescence Ambulatory till early adult lif e Death By the age of 18–20 years By 40s or 50s
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You observe a six-year-old child in the ward and notice the following. Which of the following are true regarding this sign?
explanation: The image shows the Gowers sign. Patients use their hands to “climb up” their legs when asked to rise from a prone position to compensate for proximal lower-extremity weakness. An early Gowers sign is often evident by age of 3 years and is fully expressed by age of 5 or 6 years. This maneuver can be seen in patients with: Duchenne muscular dystrophy Becker's muscular dystrophy Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy Polymyositis Dermatomyositis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A concerned mother brought her son to the clinic because of difficulty writing in school. She also says that his eyes remain partially open when he sleeps. There is no history of trauma or surgery. On examination, he has asymmetric wrist and finger weakness. The mouth appears puckered and rounded, deltoid muscles are flattened and the following finding is observed.
What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows winging of the scapula, which when combined with this patient's features are suggestive of facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy. Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant condition that generally presents with asymmetric weakness in facial and shoulder girdle muscles. Occasionally, finger and wrist weakness is the first symptom. The mouth is rounded and appears puckered because of the protruding lips. Upper facial weakness will manifest as an inability to close the eyes completely in sleep. Scapular winging is prominent, even in infants. Flattening or even concavity of the deltoid contour is seen, and the biceps and triceps brachii muscles are wasted and weak. Eventually, proximal muscles get involved and undergo atrophy, and Gowers sign & Trendelenburg gait appear. Lumbar lordosis, foot drop, and kyphoscoliosis are common complications. Treatment includes orthopedic measures for scoliosis and foot drop, surgical intervention for scapular deformity. Physiotherapy has no value. Other options: Long thoracic nerve palsy: No history of trauma or surgery rules out this diagnosis. Klippel-Feil syndrome: Classic triad of Klippel–Feil syndrome (congenital musculoskeletal condition) low posterior hairline short neck ecreased cervical range of motion Myotonic dystrophy patients have a characteristic V-shaped upper lip, a history of myotonia, and progressive weakness.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical picture showing pain in the calves occuring within a week of an upper respiratory tract infection (URI), with elevated creatine kinase levels suggests the diagnosis of viral myositis. The specific history of URI suggests influenza myositis. Infectious myositis has a male predominance and is typically seen in young adults. Childhood form presents with fever, malaise, and rhinorrhea and is usually followed by severe pain, especially in the calves. The muscle pain is usually worse with movement and the symptoms last for about a week. In children, toe walking and wide-based gait may be seen because of the involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles. Other viral causes of myositis include HIV-1 (one of the most common causes of myositis), group B coxsackievirus (epidemic myalgia), HTLV-1 (Human T-lymphotropic virus), and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Lab features of influenza myositis include elevated CK which may be as high as 500 times normal the value. Urine myoglobin is usually positive. Detection of the virus with PCR testing of nasopharyngeal specimens can be carried out but is not of much clinical significance. The histopathological examination would reveal muscle fiber necrosis without much inflammatory change. Treatment includes bed rest, IV fluids, and symptomatic management with analgesics and antipyretics. Amantadine and other antiviral agents may be considered in adults. Complications include myocarditis and respiratory dysfunction. Rhabdomyolysis is an uncommon complication.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Rekha brought her 5-day-old infant to the clinic because of feeding difficulties. She says he does not latch properly. Her antenatal history is significant for polyhydramnios and decreased fetal movements. On examination, hypotonia and hyporeflexia are noted in the baby. which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Among the given options, only Spinal muscular atrophy presents in infancy. The rest present in late childhood. Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a degenerative disease of motor neurons, that is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It usually starts in infancy with hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and thin muscle mass (atrophy). Polyhydramnios may be present prenatally due to weakness in swallowing. Diagnosis is done by genetic testing for SMN gene mutation. Muscle biopsy is done for cases with negative genetic testing and strong clinical suspicion. The muscle biopsy in infancy shows a characteristic pattern of perinatal denervation that is unlike that of a mature muscle. Groups of giant type I fibers are mixed with fascicles of severely atrophic fibers. Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Recent updates: Nusinersen is an antisense oligonucleotide approved by the FDA for treating SMA. It is administered intrathecally. Risdiplam (first oral drug) has been approved by FDA to treat infants >2 months of age with SMA. It is an oral splicing modifier that corrects the splicing defect of SMN2, which leads to increased levels of full-length SMN protein.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Pinky, a high school girl, has difficulty in combing her hair and climbing up stairs since 6 months. On examination, Gower sign is positive and maculopapular rash present over MCP joints. What is the next appropriate investigation to be done?
explanation: A maculopapular rash over the metacarpophalangeal joints is indicative of Gottron papules in a child with proximal muscle weakness is suggestive of juvenile dermatomyositis. As it is an inflammatory myopathy, the next investigation is serum creatine kinase. Though the gold standard investigation is a muscle biopsy, it is indicated only when the diagnosis is in doubt or when grading of the disease severity is required. Nerve conduction studies are usually normal unless associated with severe muscle necrosis and atrophy. Electromyography would show the characteristic signs of myopathy and muscle fiber necrosis but is preferably performed in a specialized center.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 1-day-old girl is being evaluated for decreased muscle tone. On examination, thin cheeks, high arched palate, inverted V-shaped upper lip, and a narrow head are observed. Facial muscle wasting is prominent. She has a club foot deformity. Her mother has a history of delayed relaxation of hand muscles after opening doors. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The patient's clinical features along with the history of myotonia in the mother are suggestive of Myotonic dystrophy. Facial weakness, inverted V-shaped upper lip, and loss of muscle mass in the temporal fossae are characteristic of myotonic muscular dystrophy. A severe congenital form of myotonic dystrophy appears in infants born to mothers with symptomatic myotonic dystrophy. It is inherited as an autosomal-dominant trait. Clinical features include: Skeletal deformities (clubfoot deformities alone or congenital contractures involving many joints and can even include the cervical spine). Generalized hypotonia and weakness at birth Facial wasting and weakness Inverted V-shaped upper lip Loss of muscle mass in the temporal fossa Infants can require gavage feeding or ventilator support for respiratory muscle weakness or apnea. Other Options: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy with hypotonia but has no facial features that are present in this child. In Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the baby appears normal at birth and the facial features present in this child are not seen. Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of scapular and humeral muscles. The given scenario makes this diagnosis less likely.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A small baby who was being evaluated for multiple bone fractures with minor trauma is found to have brittle bone disease. Which of the following is false regarding this disease?
options: It is caused by defects in type 2 collagen.
Blue sclerae and deafness may be associated.
Biphosphonates are useful in the treatment.
explanation: Brittle bone disease is another name for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It is due to defects in type 1 collagen, not type 2 collagen. There are 12 types of OI, with type 1 being the most common. Triad of fragile bones, blue sclera, and deafness is known as van der Hoeve syndrome. Treatment includes bisphosphonate therapy and orthopedic rehabilitation.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: All of the following are radiological signs of scurvy except .
explanation: White line of Frankel, ground-glass appearance, and zone of rarefaction are the radiological signs seen in scurvy. Radiological signs in scurvy includes: White line of Frankel: calcified cartilage at metaphyses Trummerfeld zone: lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line Pelkan spur: lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends Wimberger ring sign: circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A 6-month-old infant presents with anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. X-ray imaging done as a part of the skeletal survey showed the following image. What is the diagnosis?

Achondroplasia
explanation: Anemia and hepatosplenomegaly in an infant with the X-ray image showing dense bones, and bone within the bone appearance is suggestive of osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 in osteoclasts. Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, anemia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels are observed. Radiological features include diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen (image). Treatment is symptomatic. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done in severe cases. Achondroplasia usually presents with pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, obstructive sleep apnea, and recurrent infections. In both scurvy and osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), the child cries on touching. On radiography, certain typical features are seen in scurvy, while multiple fractures are seen in OI. Paediatric Rheumatology
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Most common rheumatic disease in children is .
explanation: The most common rheumatic disease in children is juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). Juvenile idiopathic arthritis represents a heterogeneous group of chronic disorders characterized by Arthritis* in 1 joint Age at onset: <16 years Duration of disease: 6 weeks *Arthritis clinically defined as swelling or effusion, or the presence of 2 or more of the following signs: limitation of range of motion tenderness or pain on motion increased heat

question_text: You are evaluating JIA patients in a pediatric rheumatology clinic. As per the ILAR criteria, which of the following patients would you not include under JIA?
options: A 18-year-old with RF negative Polyarthritis first diagnosed 3 years back
explanation: Reactive arthritis is not a subtype of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis(JIA) so you would not include this subset of patients under your evaluation. ILAR (International League of Associations for Rheumatology) defines JIA as arthritis of one or more joints with onset below 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks. The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):- Oligoarthritis (4 or lesser joints) (Most common type) Polyarthritis (5 or more joints) RF Positive RF Negative Systemic JIA Psoriatic arthritis Enthesitis-related arthritis Undifferentiated
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Mohit is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of red-eye. He complains of blurring of vision and on examination, the pupil appears as shown in the picture. Which of the following subtype of JIA is associated with the highest risk for the ophthalmic complication noted in this patient?
explanation: The patient has red-eye and the blurring of vision along with the finding of the irregular pupil, which is suggestive of uveitis. ANA-positive oligoarthritis is associated with the highest risk for uveitis in patients with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis. The presence of a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination every 3 months.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A worried mother brings her 4-year-old girl who has been complaining about pain in the joints of arms and legs for 2 months. On examination, multiple nodules over the bony prominences suggestive of rheumatoid nodules are noted. On investigation, RA-factor was found positive pointing to the diagnosis of RF-positive polyarthritis. Which of the following complication is not likely to occur in this patient?
explanation: Ankylosis is not seen in patients with RF-positive Polyarthritis. Polyarthritis is characterized by inflammation of 5 joints in both upper and lower extremities. Rheumatoid factor (RF)–positive polyarthritis resembles the characteristic symmetric presentation of adult rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid nodules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, spine, and over the Achilles tendons are associated with a more severe course and almost exclusively occur in RF-positive individuals. Complications may include: Micrognathia (due to chronic temporomandibular joint disease) Cervical spine involvement, manifesting as decreased neck extension, occurs with a risk of atlantoaxial subluxation and neurologic sequelae. Hip disease may be subtle, with findings of erosion.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis?
explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) factor is negative in systemic JIA. It is positive in a subtype of polyarthritic type of JIA. Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of Evanescent erythematous ras Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly Generalized lymphadenopathy Serositis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Anuj, a school-going kid has been brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother with complaints of fever for 3 weeks. She says her son has been skipping school because of the fever but in the evening he gets better and plays with his siblings. She also noticed a rash that appears along with fever and disappears spontaneously. He has a history of joint pain on and off since pre-school. On examination, generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are noted along with an evanescent erythematous rash on the trunk. Which of the following characteristically defines the fever associated with this child's condition?
explanation: The patient has clinical features of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA), which is associated with quotidian fever. Quotidian fever - fever that rises to 39°C (102.2°F) once a day and returns to 37°C (98.6°F) between fever peaks Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of Evanescent erythematous rash that is non-pruritic and migratory with lesions lasting<1 hr. Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly Generalized lymphadenopathy Serositis
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Aarav is a known case of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). He is referred to a Rheumatology specialist center from a local hospital, when his condition started deteriorating on steroid treatment. On examination, the patient has lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and purpura along with the acute onset of high spiking fevers. Vitals show persistent hypotension (85/45 mmHg), tachycardia (160/min), and oliguria. He was urgently admitted into the PICU. The resident physician is confused between macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) and JIA flare-up. Which of the following is best suited to distinguish these two?
explanation: Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) is characterized by all of the listed features. However, the diagnosis is confirmed by bone marrow biopsy demonstrating hemophagocytosis and is the best test to distinguish MAS from a flare-up of JIA. MAS is a rare but potentially fatal complication of systemic JIA. It is characterized by an uncontrolled activation and proliferation of T lymphocytes and macrophages. It is the result of a cytokine storm that leads to a dysregulated inflammatory activation of the immune system, with rapid progression to multiorgan failure if not promptly diagnosed and properly treated. It is characterized by the following: Macrophage hemophagocytosis in the bone marrow Hypofibrinogenemia (paradoxical fall in erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR]) Hypertriglyceridemia Extreme hyperferritinemia Fever >38.5°C Splenomegaly Cytopenia affecting at least two of three cell lineages Treatment usually includes high-dose corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents in refractory cases.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text:
A mother brought her 12-day old baby to the OPD due to the rash shown in the picture for the last 5 days. The mother says the rash gets worse in the sun. The infant was born at home and she never had a prenatal check-up. She herself has a history of joint pains and a facial rash which she says is "no big deal". On examination, Vitals are normal for the baby. A subsequent ECG shows P wave rate 120/min and R wave rate at 70/min with no relation between the two.
Which of the following antibodies will be used to diagnose this baby's condition?
explanation: The baby has raccoon eyes (periorbital rash) with complete heart block (P-R dissociation) suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE). Anti-Ro antibodies are used to diagnose neonatal lupus. Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus(NLE): NLE is not an autoimmune condition. It occurs when maternal autoantibodies enter the fetal circulation (passive transfer). The antibodies responsible for this condition are anti-Ro antibody (anti-SSA) and anti-La antibody (anti-SSB). The periorbital rash typically appears within 6 weeks of life and lasts 3-4 months. However, it can be present at birth. Infants may also have cytopenias and hepatitis, but the most feared complication is congenital heart block. Cardiomyopathy is seen in the most severe cases. The noncardiac manifestations of neonatal lupus are usually reversible, whereas congenital heart block is permanent. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age. Fluorinated corticosteroids seem to improve cases of hydrops. Significant conduction system abnormalities after birth are treated with cardiac pacing and occasionally intravenous immunoglobulin and steroids, while severe cardiomyopathy may require cardiac transplantation. Transient, noncardiac manifestations are conservatively managed, with topical steroids used occasionally to treat the rash. Other options: Anti-Jo antibodies are a type of myositis-specific antibodies. These are not related to neonatal lupus. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for SLE (Systemic Lupus erythematosus). Anti-histone antibodies are present in Drug-induced SLE. Note: SS in SSA and SSB stands for Sjögren's syndrome-related. Anti-SSA and anti SSB are antinuclear antibodies and are mainly found in patients with SLE and Sjögren's syndrome.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Vikas, a high school student is observed to have an indented 'en coup de sabre' lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: En coup de sabre lesion is seen in juvenile localized scleroderma (morphea). It appears as an indented, vertical, colourless, line of skin on the forehead. The indentation looks as though the person may have been struck (coup) by a sword (sabre). This lesion involves the scalp and/or face and often extend into the central nervous system, resulting in neurologic sequelae such as seizures and headaches.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP). HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases. The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affected blood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy. Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, which characteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows the appearance of the rash. Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, along with the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may show nonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies and biopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic information Treatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition. Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement. Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severe disease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinal problems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP is favorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and manage potential complications.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Pinky, a small child with Kawasaki disease is admitted to the ward for treatment. Which of the following feature would you not expect to see in her?
explanation: Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival infection with limbal sparing is characteristically seen in Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome and is commonly seen in children between 3 months to 5 years of age.

question_text: A worried father brought her 5-year-old son to the pediatrician with a history of fever, rash, irritability, and poor feeding. A few days back, he developed perianal desquamation and non-purulent conjunctivitis with edema of the hands and feet. He has been up to date with his immunization. Tongue findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is not likely to occur in the child?
explanation: The above clinical features are suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Thrombocytosis is a characteristic finding in Kawasaki disease and commonly occurs in the second week. Important laboratory findings of Kawasaki disease are anemia, elevated ESR, and CRP. Major complications of Kawasaki disease are arteritis and aneurysms of coronary vessels, myocarditis, myocardial infarction, and pericarditis.

question_text: Nisha presents to the clinic with clinical features suggestive of Kawasaki disease. She was admitted to the ward for treatment. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this disease?
explanation: Treatment of choice in Kawaski disease is IV immunoglobulins. IV immunoglobulins along with aspirin have proven beneficial in preventing coronary artery abnormalities.

question_text: Who among the following children with Kawasaki’s disease is at greatest risk for coronary aneurysms?
options: 8 year-old girl with 6 days of high fever and strawberry tongue
5-year-old boy with 8 days of fever and CSF pleocytosis
2-year-old girl with IVIG treatment at 7th day of fever
11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV
explanation: An 11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV is at the greatest risk for coronary aneurysms. Risk factors for coronary aneurysms in Kawasaki's disease: Age younger than 1 year or older than 9 years Male sex Fever 14 days Hematocrit(PCV) <35 percent Serum sodium concentration <135 mEq/L White blood cell count >12,000/mm3 Elevated ESR and CRP Administration of IVIG during the first 10 days of illness reduces the prevalence of coronary aneurysms fivefold.

question_text:
A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic complaining about recurrent painful oral ulcers as shown in the picture. He also experiences repeated episodes of eye redness and pain which subsides with medication. On examination, similar ulcers are seen on his genitals. Behçet disease is suspected. Which of the following feature would you not expect to see in this patient?

Dural sinus thrombosis
options: Tender red nodules on the legs
explanation: Behcet disease is not associated with nail fold capillary abnormalities which is typically seen in systemic sclerosis. Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test (Pustular reaction, 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection). There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. Dural sinus thrombosis is the most common CNS manifestation in children. Pulmonary aneurysms are the most severe feature of pediatric BD. It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17(Th17) cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall. Pediatric Hematology - Introduction, Bleeding, and Clotting Disorders

question_text: Which of the following is the predominant site of hematopoiesis in a 20-weeks old fetus?
explanation: The liver is the predominant site of hematopoiesis in the fetus during mid-pregnancy. question_text:
Hemoglobin fractions were analyzed in a neonate with a family history of sickle cell disease. The test shows elevated levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). Which of the following is true about
HbF?
options: HbF accounts for 100% of the total hemoglobin at term.
HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.
HbF has lower affinity for oxygen than HbA.
HbF has higher affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate than HbA.
explanation: HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation. Elevated levels of HbF are seen in sickle cell disease and -thalassemia, where there is a mutation of the  globin gene. Increased HbF levels persist in childhood and later. Properties of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation. This property forms the basis of the alkali denaturation test (or Apt test) to detect the presence of fetal blood in maternal circulation in suspected feto-maternal hemorrhage. The Kleihauer–Betke test (or acid elution test) is used to quantitate the amount of feto-materna hemorrhage to calculate the dosage of anti-D required in Rh-negative mothers. HBF accounts for ™0% of the hemoglobin at term. Increased HbF can be seen in hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, sickle cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, HbC disease, and HbE disease HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen. This allows for gas exchange from maternal circulation by binding to oxygen at a relatively low oxygen tension in the maternal blood supplying the chorion. HbF has lower affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) than HbA. Lack of interaction between HbF and 2,3 BPG increases the affinity of HbF to oxygen.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: You are measuring the life span of RBCs in a normal neonate using chromium-labeled erythrocyte studies as a part of a research project under the clinical hematology department. What would be the result?
explanation: The lifespan of neonatal RBCs is 60-90 days. The short lifespan of neonatal RBCs is the cause for rapid fall in hematocrit immediately after birth. The highest hematocrit during a person’s lifetime occurs at birth, and the lowest occurs about 10 weeks later. The lifespan of RBCs in preterm infants is 35-50 days. The average lifespan of RBCs in adults is 120 days.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A concerned mother brings her preschool child to you. She states that her child was fine until yesterday night and now is covered with bruises and purple dots, which she had noticed while changing his clothes in the morning. She informs you that one month back, her child had a cough and cold. Findings on physical examination are normal, other than petechiae and purpura. Which of the following is most likely to be seen while investigating this child?
explanation: An otherwise well-baby with acute onset of petechiae and purpura with a preceding history of viral infection 1 to 4 weeks prior to the onset of thrombocytopenia is a classical presentation of (autoimmune) idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Prolonged bleeding time is a feature of ITP. The most common cause of acute onset of thrombocytopenia in an otherwise well-child is (autoimmune) idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). ITP is a bleeding disorder and has prolonged bleeding time, low platelet count, and normal coagulation profile (prothrombin time [PT] and activated partial thromboplastin time [aPTT]). ITP has an acute presentation with a self-limited course in children. Features of ITP: Commonly affects children between 1-4 years Preceded by a viral infection Mucocutaneous bleeding Ecchymoses and petechiae Wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) Retinal hemorrhages Bleeding into the CNS, which may be life-threatening Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy, fever, jaundice are absent Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks. Laboratory features of ITP: Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000/L) Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow Prolonged bleeding time Normal tests for coagulation (PT/aPTT/INR) Eosinophilia and lymphocytosis common Peripheral smear is norma Bone marrow biopsy shows megakaryocytes
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A pediatrician sees a child in the OPD. He has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis, which has very little interference with his daily activities. Based on further workup, he diagnoses the child as a case of mild ITP. How will he manage this child?
options: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin
explanation: Other than education, counseling, and watchful expectancy, no therapy is needed for patients with mild ITP. Classification system for ITP: No symptoms. Mild symptoms- bruising and petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis which has very little interference with daily living. Moderate symptoms- more severe skin and mucosal lesions, more troublesome epistaxis, and menorrhagia. Severe symptoms- bleeding episodes - menorrhagia, epistaxis, and melena - requiring transfusions or hospitalization, symptoms interfering seriously with quality of life. Treatment of ITP: Mild to moderate bleeding symptoms- watchful expectancy, education, and counseling. Platelet count < 30,000 + risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders)- oral glucocorticoids/ intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or IV anti-D Severe bleeding symptoms- IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG or IV anti-D Life-threatening bleeding (eg. intracranial hemorrhage)- platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG or IV anti-D Note: The role of splenectomy in ITP should be reserved for 2 circumstances: The older child (4 yr) with severe ITP that has lasted >1 year (chronic ITP) and whose symptoms are not easily controlled with therapy When life-threatening hemorrhage (ICH) complicates acute ITP and the platelet count cannot be corrected rapidly with transfusion of platelets and administration of IVIG and corticosteroids.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Veena, an adolescent girl has had recurrent episodes of bleeding from her nose and gums. She also gives a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and repeated blood transfusions. Her bleeding time is deranged and flow cytometry reveals markedly decreased CD41 and CD61 expression. A defect in which of the following is most likely seen in her?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia which is characterized by defective platelet aggregation. Decreased CD41 (GPIIb) and CD61 (GPIIIa) expression are diagnostic of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Bleeding in Glanzmann thrombasthenia is quite severe and is typically mucocutaneous, including epistaxis, gingival, and GI bleeding. Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann thrombasthenia are severe congenital disorders of platelet function. Patients usually present with petechiae and purpura at birth. The diagnosis is confirmed by flow cytometric analysis of the patient’s platelet glycoproteins.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Which of the following is the most common congenital bleeding disorder?
explanation: Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common congenital bleeding disorder. VWD is thought to affect approximately 0.1- 1% of the population. It is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF). VWF is an adhesive protein that acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and platelets. It also binds and protects the circulating factor VIII from rapid clearance in circulation. Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosoma recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (partial = type 1 or absolute = type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2 = dysproteinemia). The majority (~ 80%) have type 1 disease. Hemophilia A (factor 8 deficiency) occurs in 1 in 5,000 males. Hemophilia B (factor 9 deficiency) occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 males.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: Shortly after birth through normal vaginal delivery, a neonate develops petechiae and purpura. You suspect bleeding disorder and send samples for further workup. A prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT is seen along with large platelets in the peripheral smear. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Bernard–Soulier syndrome is the likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario. The presence of petechiae and purpura at birth, especially after vaginal delivery, along with prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT are seen in qualitative platelet defect disorders like Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. The presence of large platelets rules out Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Evans syndrome is an autoimmune hemolytic disorder with thrombocytopenia. Von Willebrand's disease doesn't usually manifest at birth. Bernard–Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive functional/qualitative platelet disorder. It is characterized by the deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor causing defective platelet adhesion. It is due to genetic mutations in the genes forming the GPIb complex of glycoproteins Ib, Ib, V, and IX. Laboratory parameters: Normal platelet count (or mild thrombocytopenia) Large platelets (megathrombocytes) with dense granules Bleeding time abnormally prolonged Platelet aggregation tests are normal (with collagen, adenosine diphosphate [ADP], epinephrine) Ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal/no response von Willebrand factor (vWF) levels are normal.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A panicked father brings his adopted daughter to your OPD with complaints of bleeding gums. Hematological investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding time. The ristocetin-aggregation test was abnormal. Which of the following would you include in your differential diagnosis?
explanation: The ristocetin-aggregation test is abnormal in both von Willebrand disease and Bernard–Soulier syndrome. All of the above diseases are inherited bleeding disorders affecting platelet function. Hence, there is prolonged bleeding time but platelet levels are not significantly affected. Platelet aggregation tests use a panel of platelet agonists (adenosine diphosphate [ADP], epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin) to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. Ristocetin induces the binding of VWF to platelets and agglutinates platelets. Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a severe congenital platelet function disorder, is caused by an absence or severe deficiency of the VWF receptor on the platelet membrane. Hence, in Bernard–Soulier syndrome, no response (or no aggregation) is seen with ristocetin. The ristocetin-aggregation test is also abnormal in von Willebrand disease. However, it normalizes after the addition of normal plasma (which contains vWF) since there is no defect in binding receptors.
subject: Pediatrics

question_text: A pediatric resident administers 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione intramuscularly to all newborn infants in the ward. Deficiency of which of the following factors is prevented by this medication?
explanation: Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants because it prevents the deficiency of factor VII that occurs transiently after birth. Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X. Causes include: Lack of free vitamin K from the mother Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K. It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

question_text: The most common bleeding manifestation seen in severe hemophilia is .
explanation: Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation of severe hemophilia. Hemophilia is said to be severe when the residual activity of factor VIII is <1%. Clinical features of hemophilia: Clinically, hemophilia A and B are indistinguishable. It presents early in life- bleeding after circumcision or when beginning to walk or crawl. Most common bleeding manifestation in severe hemophilia is recurrent hemarthrosis and the most common joint affected is the knee. Acute hemarthrosis- local pain, swelling, and erythema; muscle contractures due to fixed positioning. Chronic hemarthrosis- synovial thickening and synovitis in response to intraarticular blood. Muscle hematomas can lead to compartment syndromes. Hematuria is common but self-limited. Life-threatening bleeding- bleeding to oropharyngeal spaces, CNS, and retroperitoneum.

explanation: The treatment of choice for hemophilia A is factor replacement therapy with factor VIII concentrate. Cryoprecipitate is used when factor concentrates are not available. question_text:
A grandmother has noticed that her granddaughter's umbilical stump hasn't fallen off even after 4 weeks. On examination, the pediatrician notices mild bruising. Which of the following
clotting factor deficiencies should he suspect?
Factor VII deficiency
explanation: Delayed separation of the umbilical stump beyond 4 weeks is a characteristic finding seen in factor XIII deficiency. However, these findings can also be seen in septicemia or loca infections. Factor XIII is responsible for the crosslinking of fibrin to stabilize the fibrin clot, symptoms of delayed hemorrhage are secondary to the instability of the clot. Typically, patients have trauma one day and then have a bruise or hematoma the next day. Results of the usual screening tests for hemostasis are normal in patients with factor XIII deficiency. Screening tests for factor XIII deficiency are based on the observation that there is increased solubility of the clot because of the failure of cross-linking. Pediatric Anemias

question_text: As a part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, you screen preschool children for anemia. What Hb values would prompt you to diagnose anemia in this age group?
explanation: Anaemia in a preschool child is defined as a hemoglobin level of <11 g/dL. Preschool age is defined as 2 to 5 years.
